Text: 1. Two answers required. A military unit from one of these two countries has preserved the wooden hand of a captain killed fighting the other at the Battle of Camarón. An artist from one of these two countries painted the shooting of the other's ruler at the Hill of the Bells. One of these two countries invaded the other after its president placed a two-year moratorium on foreign debt repayment shortly after the Reform War. The (*) Pastry War was fought between these two countries, one of which supported Maximilian I as emperor of the other. Charles de Lorencez's ("LORE-uhn-says") defeat at the Battle of Puebla between these two countries is commemorated on Cinco de Mayo. For 10 points, name these countries led by Benito Juárez and Napoleon III. ANSWER: France AND Mexico [or Kingdom of France or Second French Empire in place of "France"; or Second Federal Republic of Mexico, Second Mexican Empire, or Centralist Republic of Mexico or in place of "Mexico"] <Cooper Roh, History - World - Miscellaneous> ~29818~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

2. This operation yields a value proportional to the negative-first coefficient of a Laurent series in a theorem named for that coefficient. Édouard Goursat ("gore-SAH") showed that a form of this operation vanishes for a holomorphic function over a simply connected domain while improving upon a proof by Cauchy ("KOH-shee"). The residue theorem is used to perform this operation, which is applied in both two and three (*) dimensions in Stokes's theorem. A "fundamental theorem" reduces this operation to a difference between two values of the function capital-F. A "curtain" visualizes the "line" form of this operation that can be calculated "by parts" or with u-substitution. For 10 points, name this operation that yields a function's antiderivative. ANSWER: integral [or integration or line integral or closed line integral or surface integral or contour integral] <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~29618~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Mississippi River (The excerpt from Life on the Mississippi is from an unpublished draft of Huckleberry Finn.)
Text: 3. Seven articles in the Atlantic together titled for "Old Times" in this place were adapted into a memoir including a book excerpt where Dick Allbright fears a haunted barrel here. That memoir begins by calling this place "well worth reading about." In that memoir titled for this place, X falls asleep here, and Horace Bixby teaches the author to memorize its shape. A term used in this place for a distance of two (*) fathoms allegedly inspired the pen-name of an author who wrote a memoir about "Life on" it. A novel's protagonists meet two con artists, the Duke and the Dauphin ("DOH-fan"), on a raft in this place. For 10 points, Mark Twain's time as a boatman on what river inspired The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn? ANSWER: Mississippi River [accept Old Times on the Mississippi or Life on the Mississippi; prompt on the American Southeast] (The excerpt from Life on the Mississippi is from an unpublished draft of Huckleberry Finn.) <Joseph Krol, Literature - American - Misc> ~28204~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

4. Miles Davis' album Bags' Groove features three early compositions by a player of this non-vibraphone instrument, including "Doxy" and "Oleo." An album titled "[this instrument] Madness" features two players of it, one of whom practiced on the Williamsburg Bridge for 15 hours a day. A Bahamian ("buh-HAY-me-in") folk song inspired a player of this instrument to write "St. Thomas," which begins his album "[this instrument] (*) Colossus." A chord progression developed by a player of this instrument cycles through keys a major third apart. Sonny Rollins played this instrument, as did a musician who used the "sheets of sound" style of improvisation on albums like Giant Steps. For 10 points, name this instrument played by John Coltrane. ANSWER: tenor saxophone [accept tenor; accept Saxophone Colossus; accept Tenor Madness] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~29573~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

5. The patient known as S.M. has a lesion on this structure resulting from Urbach–Wiethe ("UR-bock VEE-tuh") disease. James McGaugh's research suggests that this structure's basolateral region plays a large role in memory consolidation. This structure coordinates more strongly with the nuclear accumbens after classical conditioning. The olfactory bulb directly connects to this structure, which sits atop the hippocampus. This part of the (*) temporal lobe is a key component of the limbic system. This structure signals the hypothalamus to trigger the fight-or-flight response, and stimulation of this structure may increase aggression. For 10 points, name this almond-shaped brain structure known for regulating emotions like fear. ANSWER: amygdala [prompt on temporal lobe until read] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Psychology> ~30304~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

6. This artist depicted a lord's party leaving a castle at sunrise and then hanging their heads in defeat at sunset in the paired paintings The Departure and The Return. A volcano erupts behind a glimmering mountain in this artist's Expulsion from the Garden of Eden. A fierce tempest provides the background of a painting by this artist that shows a bridge collapsing under the weight of a crowd and a headless statue posed with its arm raised like the (*) Borghese Gladiator. A series by this artist contains a rocky outcrop in the background of all five of its paintings that depict the rise and fall of a civilization. For 10 points, name this painter of the Course of Empire series who founded the Hudson River School. ANSWER: Thomas Cole <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - U.S. to 1945> ~29544~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

7. The freelance journalist Jeff Atman travels to this city to conduct an interview at a festival in a novel by Geoff Dyer. Another book's protagonist ultimately travels to this city after standing outside another city's Byzantine mortuary chapel, where he notices a mysterious man wearing a straw hat. The protagonist of a book mainly set in this city, who perceives a "summoner" before collapsing in a chair, wrote the (*) novels Maia and The Abject. While on holiday in this city, that novella's protagonist eats overripe strawberries and develops cholera before watching Tadzio ("TAD-zhoh") play on the beach. For 10 points, name this Italian city where Gustav von Aschenbach ("ASH-un-back") dies in a novella by Thomas Mann. ANSWER: Venice [or Venezia or Venedig; accept Death in Venice or Der Tod in Venedig; prompt on Jeff in Venice, Death in Varanasi] <Will Grossman, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~17302~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

8. A Harriet Hosmer monument commemorating this document failed to be funded by the Western Sanitary Commission. A more radical version of this document by Robert Dale Owen was published in the New York Evening Post. News about this document was spread by a man who read it from a balcony, Gordon Granger. Accepting this document's provisions was a requirement for the author's later statement on (*) Amnesty, dubbed the "ten percent plan." This document's Preliminary version was issued following a victory for George McClellan. This document only covered areas in rebellion prior to the Thirteenth Amendment. For 10 points, name this text authored by Abraham Lincoln that freed some of the nation's enslaved people. ANSWER: Emancipation Proclamation [or Proclamation 95; accept Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation or Final Emancipation Proclamation] <Michael Bentley, History - American - Pre-1865> ~28772~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

9. One type of this technique uses dyes like Fast Sulphon Black or Murexide. This technique is paired with calorimetry to measure the binding of small molecules to proteins at constant temperature. This technique is performed after Kjeldahl ("KELL-dal") digestion to measure a sample's nitrogen content. A form of this technique reacts thiosulfate with a mixture of manganese and iodide to determine oxygen concentration in the (*) Winkler test. The "complexometric" type of this technique uses EDTA to chelate ("KEE-late") metal ions out of solution. This technique may use an indicator such as phenolphthalein ("FEE-nawl-THAL-een") to detect a change in pH at the equivalence point. For 10 points, name this technique in which a buret ("byur-ET") is used to add a solution drop by drop. ANSWER: titration [or titrating; accept complexometric titration or colorimetric titration or Winkler titration or isothermal titration calorimetry] <June Yin, Science - Chemistry> ~29748~ <Editor: June Yin>

10. Variants of this system were likened to overlapping three-letter strings in a 1995 essay that described a self-styled "super-" holder of it, Julius Evola. This system names a personality test measuring receptiveness to it developed by Theodor Adorno. The section "Fundamental Ideas" of "The Doctrine of [this ideology]" was ghostwritten by Giovanni Gentile. Fourteen principles characterizing this ideology, such as action for action's sake, were formulated in an (*) Umberto Eco essay titled for its "ur-" form. This ideology was named for a Roman symbol of a bundle of sticks by a leader who was often defended for supposedly making the trains run on time. For 10 points, name this far-right ideology of Benito Mussolini. ANSWER: fascism [or fascismo; accept word forms like fascist; accept "Ur-Fascism"; accept "The Doctrine of Fascism" or "La dottrina del fascismo"; accept superfascist; prompt on F-scale by asking "what does the ‘F’ stand for?"; prompt on authoritarianism or totalitarianism] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~30137~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

Answer: quantum tunneling (The system in the lead-in is the rectangular potential barrier.)
Text: 11. In one model system, this phenomenon's probability equals the reciprocal of one plus a term proportional to sinh ("sinch") squared of k-sub-one a. The log-probability of this phenomenon (read slowly) equals negative two times the integral of the square root of two-m-over-h-bar-squared times V minus E over the interval between two turning points in the WKB approximation. Stellar nucleosynthesis is possible because this phenomenon overcomes the (*) Coulomb barrier, which also determines the rate of this process in George Gamow's ("GAM-off's") model of alpha decay. This phenomenon allows low-energy particles to escape a finite square well. For 10 points, a particle passes through a potential barrier in what quantum mechanical phenomenon? ANSWER: quantum tunneling [or tunnel effect] (The system in the lead-in is the rectangular potential barrier.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~29572~ <Editor: David Bass>

12. Description acceptable. To prevent spreading news of deaths among these people, the bard Phemius plays wedding music. For providing these people weapons, Melanthius is dismembered and executed. Zeus and Athena intervene in a skirmish at a Cephallenian ("KEFF-uh-LEN-ian") king's farm led by Eupeithes ("you-PAY-thees"), the father of one of these people. The maid Melantho falls in love with one of these people, (*) Eurymachus, who disrespects the practice of xenia ("ZEE-nee-ah") alongside Antinous ("aan-TIN-oh-us"). After consulting Nestor in Sparta, Telemachus manages to evade an ambush by these people. A hero in disguise who shoots an arrow through twelve ax handles kills these people after reuniting with his wife. For 10 points, identify these men who try to take the hand of Odysseus's wife in the Odyssey. ANSWER: Penelope's suitors [accept answers describing the men who try to court Penelope; accept proci; accept mnesteres; prompt on answers describing suitors without mentioning Penelope by asking "of whom?"] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~29597~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

13. Oothoon ("oo-thoon") represents the "soft soul of America" in a book by this author, who represented America’s rebellious spirit with the fallen angel Orc in another book. This non-Polish author wrote "Drive your plow over the bones of the dead" in his "Proverbs of Hell." The frontispiece to a book by this author shows a compass being pointed downward by the bearded Urizen ("YUR-ee-zen"), who is one of the Four Zoas created by the fall of Albion. The preface to this author's "prophetic book" (*) Milton includes the poem "and did those feet in ancient time." This author illustrated his own works based on an imagined mythology prefigured by The Marriage of Heaven and Hell. For 10 points, name this poet who described an animal "burning bright, in the forests of the night" in "The Tyger." ANSWER: William Blake <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - British - Poetry> ~30042~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: Toccata and Fugue in D minor
Text: 14. Peter Williams claimed this piece was originally written for violin since it imitates bariolage ("bar-ee-oh-LAZH") with repeated 16th note As displaced by a 32nd note. This piece shares a title with one nicknamed "Dorian" for its lack of key signature. In this piece's second bar, a C-sharp diminished seventh chord is slowly built up over a held low D. Evidence that this piece is misattributed includes its opening parallel octaves that outline a lower (*) mordent on A, then the fast notes [read slowly] "G, F, E, D, C-sharp, D." Disney's Fantasia opens with a silhouetted orchestra playing a transcription of this D minor piece, popularizing its association with horror. For 10 points, name this organ piece by J.S. Bach titled for two musical forms. ANSWER: Toccata and Fugue in D minor [or BWV 565] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~29514~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

15. An 1896 campaign pledge to abolish this group lost steam following a high-profile struggle against Almighty Voice. In 1960, this organization warned Davie Fulton about the former German prostitute at the center of the Munsinger Affair. This organization formed the Special Emergency Response Team in response to the bombing of Air India Flight 182. The McDonald Commission investigated illegal intelligence activities this organization pursued before the 1976 (*) Summer Olympics in response to criticism of their handling of the October Crisis. This law enforcement organization's traditional Red Serge uniform includes a wide-brimmed felt hat and riding boots. For 10 points, name this Canadian police force. ANSWER: Royal Canadian Mounted Police [accept Mounties or RCMP or North-West Mounted Police or NWMP or Dominion Police; accept Gendarmerie royale du Canada] <Lalit Maharjan, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~29526~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. A giant one of these buildings with a "Dome of Harmony" recently opened in Abu Dhabi with funding by BAPS. In 2012, an estimated trillion dollars in gold was found in one of these buildings in a former princely state. So-called "volunteers" received as little as $1 per hour working on the largest one of these buildings in the US in Robbinsville, New Jersey. In 2024, a politician fasted on coconut water for 9 days before (*) consecrating one of these buildings that was built on a complex torn down by RSS members in 1992. A building of this type constructed atop the former Babri Masjid mosque was a political accomplishment for the BJP. For 10 points, name these buildings that include one in Ayodhya dedicated to Ram. ANSWER: Hindu temples [or Mandir; or Devasthanam; or Pura; or Kovil; accept temple to Ram; prompt on temples or religious buildings] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~30242~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: South African apartheid (The first three plays are Ubu and the Truth Commission, Woza Albert!, and Sizwe Banzi is Dead.)
Text: 17. Jane Taylor based a play set after the end of this time period on Alfred Jarry's ("all-FRAY zhah-REE's") Ubu Roi. In a two-man play set during this time period, Jesus comes to Earth as Lord Morena before the government nukes him. Two of the Serpent Players co-wrote a work set in this period where the title character tells his wife he is dead while at Styles' photography studio. Two characters debate whether Darwin and Tolstoy are (*) men of magnitude in a play set during this time period. Morris and Zachariah never meet their pen pal Ethel Lange in Blood Knot, a play set during this period which is also the setting of Master Harold and the Boys. For 10 points, what time period is the setting of plays by Athol Fugard set in his native South Africa? ANSWER: South African apartheid [prompt on descriptions in the right time period (1948-1994) that don’t mention apartheid] (The first three plays are Ubu and the Truth Commission, Woza Albert!, and Sizwe Banzi is Dead.) <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~29789~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

18. It's not the skin or kidneys, but a condition of this organ characterizes Reed's syndrome. The mnemonic "PALM COEIN" ("PALM COIN") lists causes of issues in this organ, like one with "intramural" and "subserosal" types. This organ, whose "appendages" are called "adnexa," is anchored by its namesake broad ligament. Myomectomies operate on this organ, which is the largest structure that develops from the (*) para·meso·nephric duct. Leio·myoma is characterized by growths of smooth muscle and connective tissue in this organ, which are its namesake "fibroids." Implantation into this organ follows travel through the fallopian tubes. For 10 points, hysterectomies remove what organ whose endometrium sheds to cause menstruation? ANSWER: uterus [prompt on womb by asking "what is the scientific name?"] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30583~ <Editor: David Bass>

19. A noble family whose surname derives from the name of this region included Karl Marx's wife, Jenny. A short-lived kingdom named for this region, which in 1807 adopted its country's first written constitution, was led by Napoleon's spendthrift brother Jérôme. This region names the modern form of nation-state sovereignty in reference to an agreement that was deemed "reprobate," "inane," and "devoid of meaning" by Pope (*) Innocent X. Two treaties named for its cities of Osnabrück and Münster made up an agreement named for this region, which in 1648 confirmed the division of the Holy Roman Empire into Protestant and Catholic areas. For 10 points, what region names the "Peace" that ended the Thirty Years' War? ANSWER: Westphalia [or Kingdom of Westphalia; accept Westfalen or von Westphalen; accept Westphalian sovereignty] <Joseph Krol, History - European - 1500-1900> ~29668~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

20. D. Michael Quinn compared this person's "magic world view" and description of three "degrees of glory" to Emmanuel Swedenborg's cosmology. Masonic oaths resemble penalties that this person outlined for a ceremony that reenacts the fall of Adam and Eve. This author of the "Word of Wisdom" denied the inheritance of original sin in the second of 13 articles of faith he listed. This person's translation of the Gospel of Matthew is included in the (*) Pearl of Great Price. This person created the endowment ceremony and the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles. The Three Witnesses saw this person receive a holy text on golden plates from the angel Moroni. For 10 points, name this founder of the Mormon Church. ANSWER: Joseph Smith Jr. <Sean Farrell, RMP - Other Religion> ~29716~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: Poland (the unnamed composer is Maria Szymanowska.)
Text: 21. The trio section of a dance from this country typically uses drone fifths to accompany lydian-mode melodies. A woman wrote 24 of this country's "National Dances" based on the rhythm "dotted eighth, sixteenth, accented quarter, quarter." The 3/4 rhythm "eighth, two sixteenths, four eighths" characterizes a "Tragic" piece in F-sharp minor based on a dance from this country. Arthur Rubinstein, a pianist from this country, has recorded (*) "Military" and "Heroic" pieces in a namesake dance form. This country's poetry inspired four ballades ("buh-LAHDS") by a native son who wrote over 50 mazurkas and the "Revolutionary" and "Winter Wind" études while exiled in Paris. For 10 points, name this birth country of Frédéric Chopin. ANSWER: Poland [or Republic of Poland or Rzeczpospolita Polska] (the unnamed composer is Maria Szymanowska.) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~30056~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub> NSC 2025 - Round 01 - Bonuses

1. This event causes the bookstore employee Pollux to be hospitalized in Louise Erdrich's novel The Sentence. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this real-world event that began in early 2020. Zadie Smith wrote the collection Intimations to support a fund for people affected by lockdowns due to this event. ANSWER: COVID-19 pandemic [or COVID pandemic; or coronavirus pandemic; prompt on pandemic] [10h] Gaspery-Jacques reveals information about the upcoming COVID pandemic while investigating a time anomaly in this author’s 2022 novel Sea of Tranquility. ANSWER: Emily St. John Mandel [10m] This author's mother, who died shortly before the pandemic, inspired the title character of Violeta. Eva Luna’s mother chokes on a chicken bone in the first part of one novel by this author. ANSWER: Isabel Allende [or Isabel Angélica Allende Llona] <Steven Yuan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24790~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

2. The oak tree symbolizes a Slavic deity who fights using these objects as weapons. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these non-axe objects made of stone when wielded by Perun. In his Theogony, Hesiod relates Brontes, Steropes, and Arges forging many of these objects for a Greek god. ANSWER: lightning bolts [or thunderbolts; prompt on thunder or bolts alone] (Brontes, Steropes, and Arges forge Zeus’s thunderbolts.) [10h] This Slavic god of earth and the underworld steals cattle from Perun until he is killed, causing everything he steals to rain from the sky. This god symbolized by the willow also protects musicians and livestock. ANSWER: Veles [or Volos] [10e] Perun may be called on to protect against these figures, known as vedma in Slavic folklore. These figures may use bat's blood and nightshade to make an ointment for flying on broomsticks. ANSWER: witches [accept sorceresses or hags; accept sorcerers or warlocks; reject "wizards"] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~23016~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

3. The plans for the American Freedom satellite and Soviet Mir-2 satellite were combined to create this mission in the wake of the Cold War. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this manned satellite in low-earth orbit where astronauts conduct experiments in microgravity. ANSWER: International Space Station [or ISS] [10h] Most of the Space Station's US Orbital Segment was built at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in this metropolitan area. About 200 Nazi scientists were brought to this metropolitan area in Operation Paperclip. ANSWER: Huntsville, Alabama [prompt on Redstone Arsenal by asking "what city is that adjacent to?"] [10m] Construction of the ISS was paused from 2003 to 2005 after damage to the left wing of this space shuttle caused it to disintegrate on re-entry, killing all seven crew members. ANSWER: space shuttle Columbia [accept OV-102 or Orbiter Vehicle-102] <Forrest Weintraub, History - American - 1945+> ~26206~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. This subfield of classical mechanics studies the motion of bodies, but not its causes. For 10 points each: [10e] Give this field, the namesake of a set of four equations, that is contrasted with dynamics and statics. ANSWER: kinematics [reject "kinetics"] [10m] Description acceptable. The kinematic equations rely on this assumption that allows the time integral of velocity to be simplified to the expression "v-nought-t plus one-half-a-t-squared." ANSWER: constant acceleration [accept answers describing acceleration not changing or jerk equal to zero; accept "a" instead of "acceleration"; prompt on "change in velocity" or "delta-v" instead of "acceleration"] [10h] A kinematic coupling provides six of these mathematical statements, each of which decrements the number of degrees of freedom in a system. "Change in acceleration equals zero" is not a holonomic one of these statements because it is not just a function of coordinates and time. ANSWER: constraints [accept holonomic constraints or nonholonomic constraints] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24762~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. X-ray analysis of the layers under a cracked painting of one of these objects revealed the title of a racist artwork by Alphonse Allais ("al-AY"). For 10 points each: [10h] Name these objects, one of which is hidden in the lower right corner of a self-portrait as a doge ("dohj"). A painting of one of these objects was staged like a traditional Orthodox icon at the 0,10 ("zero-ten") exhibition. ANSWER: squares [accept Black Square or Chernyi Kvadrat; prompt on shapes or quadrilaterals or rectangles] (All clues are from the work of Kazimir Malevich.) [10e] The 0,10 exhibition called itself the "last exhibition" of paintings from this movement, heralding the rise of Suprematism. Filippo Marinetti wrote a manifesto for this art movement that exalted modern technology. ANSWER: futurism [accept Russian futurism or Italian futurism; accept The Last Futurist Exhibition of Paintings] [10m] Another Kazimir Malevich ("mull-YEV-itch") painting depicts an angled square of this color against the same color background. A circle of this color overlaps with a red wedge in a poster by El Lissitzky. ANSWER: white [accept White on White; accept Beat the Whites with the Red Wedge] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~24510~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

6. As the sole survivor of a Danish expedition to Arabia, adventurer Carsten Niebuhr published the first modern copies of this script in 1778. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this Mesopotamian writing system deciphered in 1802 by Georg Friedrich Grotefend using Niebuhr's copy of several wedged inscriptions. ANSWER: cuneiform [or Old Persian cuneiform] [10m] Niebuhr's son Barthold was the leading German scholar of this civilization, subject of a six-volume history first published in 1776 by Edward Gibbon. ANSWER: Ancient Rome [accept the Roman Empire or Romans or Western Roman Empire; accept the Byzantine Empire or Eastern Roman Empire; prompt on Italians or Latins] [10h] Gibbon himself was inspired by this author's Considerations on the Causes of the Greatness of the Romans and their Decline. Viscount ("VYE-count") Bolingbroke inspired this Frenchman to write about the English constitution. ANSWER: Montesquieu ("mon-tess-KYOO") [or Charles Louis de Secondat, baron de La Brède et de Montesquieu] <Cooper Roh, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~24702~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. This technique prepares cultures by using an inoculation loop to dilute an inoculum over successive sections of a Petri dish. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this technique, contrasted with spreading, that yields a namesake pattern on an agar-containing dish. ANSWER: streaking [10e] Prior to streaking, agar is often treated with cycloheximide in order to eliminate eukaryotic microbes from this kingdom that includes yeasts and molds. ANSWER: Fungi [or fungus] [10h] This unit is the number of distinct microbial masses in a dish. This unit is typically given as a ratio with the dilution factor in milliliters because it is calculated in a dish that is sufficiently diluted to count microbial masses manually. ANSWER: CFUs [or colony-forming units; prompt on answers describing the number of colonies] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~24568~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. For 10 points each, answer the following about New Testament passages not appearing in the earliest available manuscripts. [10m] The "longer ending" of this book is the origin for the practice of snake handling. This book is likely the earliest gospel account. ANSWER: Gospel of Mark [10e] In John 5's account of Jesus healing a paralyzed man at the pool of Bethesda, a two-verse interjection describes these supernatural beings stirring up the pool. Uriel and Michael are "arch" examples of these beings. ANSWER: angels [accept archangels] [10h] Description acceptable. In the later added first half of John 8, Jesus does this action before saying, "Let him who is without sin among you be the first to throw a stone at" an adulterous woman. ANSWER: writes on the ground [accept word forms such as writing or wrote] <Jon Suh, RMP - New Testament> ~25371~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: W. Somerset Maugham ("MAWM") In this short story by Maugham, the missionary Davidson kills himself after hypocritically praying over the sex worker Sadie Thompson. ANSWER: "Rain" Maugham's Ashenden stories, including "R." and "The Hairless Mexican," deal with a man with this profession. The vacuum cleaner salesman James Wormold is recruited to this job in Cuba in a Graham Greene novel based on his actual job. ANSWER: spy
Text: 9. In a short story by this author, a priest's wife in Pago Pago brags that "no one has danced in our district for eight years." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this author of The Moon and Sixpence, who wrote about Philip Carey's affair with Mildred in Of Human Bondage. ANSWER: W. Somerset Maugham ("MAWM") [or William Somerset Maugham; be lenient with pronunciation] [10h] In this short story by Maugham, the missionary Davidson kills himself after hypocritically praying over the sex worker Sadie Thompson. ANSWER: "Rain" [10m] Maugham's Ashenden stories, including "R." and "The Hairless Mexican," deal with a man with this profession. The vacuum cleaner salesman James Wormold is recruited to this job in Cuba in a Graham Greene novel based on his actual job. ANSWER: spy [accept secret agent; accept MI6 agent; accept espionage; prompt on Our Man in Havana by asking, "what is the profession he acquires?"] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~24622~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

10. American beavers introduced into this archipelago in the 1940s now number over 100,000 and are devastating local forests. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this archipelago whose Navarino Island is home to many Yahgan people. The End of the World Train services this archipelago. ANSWER: Tierra del Fuego [accept Fireland; prompt on Patagonia] [10e] A 2019 study found that these islands had 10 times more alien marine species than initially thought. The vegetarian finch is one of the birds native to these islands observed on a voyage of the HMS Beagle. ANSWER: Galapagos Islands [or Islas Galápagos] [10h] In 1957, some of these animals escaped a Brazilian quarantine and three decades later made their way to North America. These animals often live in "gums" and "skeps." ANSWER: bees [accept honey bee or killer bee or Africanized honey bee or Anthophila; prompt on insects] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~25116~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

11. While playing this character in Germany, Hedwig Niemann-Raabe ("HED-vig NEE-man-RAH-buh") requested an alternative ending in which this character declares "Oh, this is a sin against myself." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this character who, in an original ending, imagines that "you and I would have to be so changed" and insists "I can receive nothing from a stranger." ANSWER: Nora Helmer [prompt on Helmer] [10m] In the original ending of A Doll's House, Nora leaves her husband, which is signified by this action. James Gibbons Huneker claimed that this action "reverberated across the roof of the world." ANSWER: slamming a door [or equivalents identifying closing a door; prompt on partial answers] [10e] Both endings of A Doll's House were written by this Norwegian playwright of Hedda Gabler. ANSWER: Henrik Ibsen [or Henrik Johan Ibsen] <Caroline Mao, Literature - European - Drama> ~11931~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

12. These mathematical objects express kinetic energy and the exchange-correlation energy in terms of the squared modulus of the wavefunction. For 10 points each: [10h] Identify these objects that name a quantum mechanical paradigm governed by the Hohenberg–Kohn theorem. ANSWER: density functionals [or functionals of electron density; accept density functional theory; accept energy functionals; prompt on functionals by asking "of what quantity?"; prompt on DFT; reject "functions"] [10e] The Hohenberg–Kohn theorem says that a system's electron density is uniquely determined by the energy of this state. A system in this state has its lowest possible energy. ANSWER: ground state [10m] Density functional theory provides approximate solutions to the Schrödinger equation for atoms other than this element. The Bohr model only describes atoms that are "[this element]-like." ANSWER: hydrogen [or H] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~24514~ <Editor: June Yin>

13. Milton Friedman argued for increasing this variable by a fixed amount every year to curb inflation. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this variable that, along with liquidity preference, names a curve in the IS-LM model. This variable is measured by M1, M2, and M3. ANSWER: money supply [or supply of money; prompt on money by asking "what particular variable related to money?"; reject "supply"] [10h] The economic costs of inflation include these ones incurred by firms when they raise their prices. These costs partly explain price stickiness. ANSWER: menu costs [10e] Inflation also imposes shoe-leather costs, which arise when agents visit these institutions. "Runs" at these institutions may lead to financial crises when too many people visit them at the same time. ANSWER: banks <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Economics> ~25006~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

14. An early endonym for Syriac calls it this city's language since it developed from its dialect of Aramaic. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this former capital of the Kingdom of Osroene ("oss-ro-EE-nee"), where St. Ephrem founded a theology school. Jesus' face was imprinted on the Mandylion, a cloth called this city's "Image." ANSWER: Edessa [accept School of Edessa; accept Image of Edessa] [10m] The sixth-century Chronicle of Edessa claims the city's church was founded after the ratification of an edict named for this city, which ended the Diocletianic persecution. ANSWER: Milan [or Milano; accept Edict of Milan or Edictum Mediolanense] [10e] After four centuries of Muslim rule, the Christian County of Edessa was established during this conflict. Pope Urban II initiated this conflict at the 1095 Council of Clermont. ANSWER: First Crusade [prompt on the Crusades] <Forrest Weintraub, History - European - Middle Ages> ~24512~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

15. In a film by this director, a photographer's wife meets an actor promoting a whiskey brand in Tokyo. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this director of Lost in Translation and The Virgin Suicides who interspersed pop music such as "I Want Candy" in a 2006 biopic of Marie Antoinette. ANSWER: Sofia Coppola [prompt on Coppola; reject "Francis Ford Coppola"] [10e] Sofia Coppola appeared as a baptized baby in this film by her father, in which Marlon Brando plays the title mafia don. ANSWER: The Godfather [reject "The Godfather Part II" or "The Godfather Part III"] [10h] The two protagonists of Lost in Translation whisper a conversation unheard by the viewer in a style inspired by the use of rain to mask dialogue in this director's "trilogy of alienation." A view of Mount Etna ends this Italian director's film L'Avventura ("lah-ven-TOOR-ah"). ANSWER: Michelangelo Antonioni <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Film> ~25018~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

16. Minimizers serve as seeds in this task. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this task of comparing sequence data that is performed by the Needleman–Wunsch algorithm. NCBI's BLAST server performs this task in order to find matches between genetic databases and a user's query reads. ANSWER: sequence alignment [accept aligning sequences; prompt on sequence mapping] [10e] Sequence alignment is central to a field named for "bio-[this word]." This word is the "I" in "I·T" and names a "theory" pioneered by Claude Shannon. ANSWER: information [or bioinformatics or informatics] [10h] Reads are summarized with examples of these constructs called minimizers. The namesake quantity of these overlapping uniform-length substrings of sequences, which are the bioinformatic analog of n-grams, is set to 31 for humans. ANSWER: k-mers <David Bass, Science - Other Science> ~24576~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. A "lullaby with variations" portrays the title character's childhood in the second movement of Kullervo, sometimes called this composer's zeroth symphony. For 10 points each: [10e] Identify this namesake of a popular notation software who wrote the nationalist tone poem Finlandia. ANSWER: Jean Sibelius [or Johan Julius Christian Sibelius] [10m] Sibelius represented his wife, Aino, with a theme introduced by solo trombone in this C major symphony. This one-movement symphony is the last by Sibelius. ANSWER: Symphony No. 7 [or Sibelius' Seventh Symphony] [10h] Sibelius' seventh inspired a one-movement symphony by this composer. Ivo Briselli refused to premiere this composer's 1939 violin concerto due to the difficulty of its finale, which is marked presto in moto perpetuo. ANSWER: Samuel Barber [or Samuel Osmond Barber II] <Geoffrey Wu, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~24578~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

18. The Sachar Committee report found that Muslims lived in poorer conditions than these people. For 10 points each: [10h] Identify this broad group of people who benefit from the Reservation system, which sets aside special seats for them in government. ANSWER: Scheduled Castes [or Scheduled Tribes; accept SCs or STs; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, Dalits or Untouchables or Depressed Classes or Depressed Castes by asking "can you be less specific?"] [10e] Many members of the Scheduled Castes come from this subgroup, whose champions included B. R. Ambedkar. These traditionally low-status people are sometimes considered a fifth varna. ANSWER: Dalits [or Harijans; or Untouchables] [10m] In 1927, Ambedkar led a protest known by this word in Mahad where his followers drank from a public water tank. This term, translated as "truth force," refers to a form of nonviolent resistance. ANSWER: satyagraha <Michael Bentley, History - World - Asian> ~25153~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

19. This person included a diagram of a sunlight-activated bomb in a letter that implied his name was Alfred E. Neuman, the mascot of MAD magazine. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this person who sent the Z340 cipher to the San Francisco Chronicle in 1969. ANSWER: Zodiac Killer [10e] In 2020, a team of mathematicians used part of this company's Mathematica program to crack Zodiac's Z340 cryptogram. This computing company runs an answer engine that appends "Alpha" to its name. ANSWER: Wolfram Research [accept Wolfram Mathematica or Wolfram Alpha] [10h] In 1969, a pair of married teachers cracked the Z408 cipher by identifying "KILLING" as one of these commonly used words. This four-letter term refers to a word that is guessed correctly in known plaintext attacks. ANSWER: cribs <Ganon Evans, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~24928~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: Transcendentalism (The other poet mentioned is Ralph Waldo Emerson.)
Text: 20. Answer the following about the sonnet-writer Jones Very, for 10 points each: [10m] Very was a member of this literary movement, until he left to declare himself the second coming of Christ. Another poet in this movement described being a "transparent eye-ball" and "part or particle of God." ANSWER: Transcendentalism (The other poet mentioned is Ralph Waldo Emerson.) [10e] Jones Very was born in this town, which is also home to the House of the Seven Gables. Tituba and John Proctor are tried in this town in Arthur Miller's The Crucible. ANSWER: Salem, Massachusetts [accept the Salem Witch Trials] [10h] This Transcendentalist editor of The Dial wrote the first review of Very's book Essays and Poems. This author expanded the essay "The Great Lawsuit" into her Woman in the Nineteenth Century. ANSWER: Margaret Fuller [or Sarah Margaret Fuller; or Margaret Fuller Ossoli] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~25339~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

21. Joshua Knobe used the methods of a philosophical field named for this word to propose his "side effect effect." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this word that follows "thought" in the name of hypothetical philosophical scenarios like the Chinese room and Schrödinger's cat. ANSWER: experiments [accept word forms like experimental; accept thought experiments; accept experimental philosophy; accept gedankenexperiment; prompt on X-phil or X-philosophy by asking "what word does the X stand for?"] [10h] A 2004 study led by the experimental philosopher Eduoard Machery concluded that, unlike Westerners, East Asians did not follow the causal-historical view of reference posited in this book that introduced "rigid designators." ANSWER: Naming and Necessity (by Saul Kripke) [10m] Machery's study used an example from Naming and Necessity concerning the hypothetical Schmidt discovering this logician's two incompleteness theorems. ANSWER: Kurt Gödel ("GUR-tle") [or Kurt Friedrich Gödel] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~25081~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

Answer: fashion shows (The second line is the Versace Fall 1991 RTW Runway Show.)
Text: 1. One of these events in 1973 dubbed the "Battle of Versailles" pitted Frenchmen against Americans like Bill Blass. Linda Evangelista and Christy Turlington unusually locked arms to George Michael's "Freedom! '90" at one of these events in 1991 that preceded the "waif" era. At these events, which may be organized by people like Oscar de la Renta, people in the highly-sought "frow" (rhymes with "mow") watch as someone who created their (*) concept leads a finale. One of these events hosted by Alexander McQueen included a hologram of Kate Moss. The "Big Four" are week-long collections of these events which show off haute couture ("oht coo-tyur") collections in cities like New York and Milan. For 10 points, name these events in which models catwalk a runway. ANSWER: fashion shows [or fashion events; accept a fashion week; accept a runway show; prompt on trade shows or trade fairs or trade exhibitions or trade expositions; prompt on shows; prompt on catwalks] (The second line is the Versace Fall 1991 RTW Runway Show.) <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~31042~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. One character tests people with this occupation with three questions about signatures, time, and blindness and is answered with three narratives for each. A character with this occupation uses the point of view of a dog and a tree to criticize Nusret Hoja for his opposition to coffee and this occupation. An apprentice in this occupation uses it for an expression of affection based on Nizami's story of (*) Husrev and Shirin that is returned twelve years later by Esther. One novel opens with a member of this profession who's just been murdered and thrown down a well and is named Elegant Effendi. For 10 points, name this occupation of the central characters of My Name is Red, who primarily work with colors. ANSWER: illustrator [accept miniaturist or artist or painter; reject "calligrapher"] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30441~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

3. The day this agreement was enacted, the First Declaration and Revolutionary Laws were also announced by a far-left group. The assassination of Donaldo Colosio after the passage of this agreement hurt the presidency of Carlos Salinas de Gortari. A crisis after this agreement's enactment led to the Debt Disclosure Act during Ernesto Zedillo's presidency. This agreement triggered the (*) Zapatista Uprising in Chiapas. The peso crisis occurred shortly after this agreement, despite the economic opportunities it was promised to create. Following this agreement, maquiladoras ("mah-KEE-lah-DOR-ahz") popped up en masse in various border cities. For 10 points, name this 1994 agreement that allows Mexico to trade freely with the USA. ANSWER: NAFTA [or North American Free Trade Agreement] <Lalit Maharjan, History - World - Latin American> ~30033~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. An 1898 short by George Albert Smith titled for this person was the first use of the double-exposure special effect in film. Peter the Knook joins this person at the end of a "Life and Adventures" by L. Frank Baum. This person's modern iconography comes from commercial illustrator Haddon Sundblom, who drew on the best-known work by General Theological Seminary professor (*) Clement Clarke Moore. An 1897 letter about this person addressed to The New York Sun earned lifelong fame for eight-year-old Virginia O'Hanlon. Allegedly, a misprint of a department store hotline led NORAD to begin "tracking" this person's location. For 10 points, name this person who gives presents to nice children on Christmas Eve. ANSWER: Santa Claus [or Santa Claus; or Saint Nicholas; or Saint Nick; or Kris Kringle; accept Father Christmas until "Christmas" is read] <Steven Yuan, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~27327~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

5. Description acceptable. These regions are constrained by maladaptive gene flow in the genetic swamping hypothesis. Rapoport’s rule constrains these regions if they appear in extreme locations. These regions are subdivided by vicariance. In one model, a series of these regions forms a "ring" with incompatible ends. If one of these regions spans much of the Earth, then it is "cosmopolitan." The latitudes of these regions cause allometric variation according to (*) Allen's and Bergmann's rules. These regions are respectively extended, split, and maintained in peripatric, allopatric, and sympatric speciation. These regions are expanded by dispersal and migration. For 10 points, name these ecological regions in which a given species lives. ANSWER: species ranges [accept species distributions or habitats or geographic ranges; accept answers describing a region where a given species lives before the end; prompt on ring species] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30454~ <Editor: David Bass>

6. Description acceptable. Ceremonial procedures of these events are described in a 15th century Johannes Burchard text published 400 years later. Special coins featuring a parasol and two crossed keys were issued during these events. The secretary of these events traditionally receives a red zucchetto at their end. A three-year one of these events that ended in 1271 resulted in the proclamation of Ubi periculum. These events coincide with a period known as (*) sede vacante. The fumata bianca indicates a two-thirds majority has been reached, concluding these events. Participants in these events sleep in bunk beds under the painted ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. For 10 points, name these events where a new head of the Catholic Church is chosen. ANSWER: papal conclaves [accept papal elections or answers such as electing a new pope] <Michael Bentley, RMP - Christian Practice> ~30164~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

7. A campaign whose name starts with this word was targeted in the Anniston bombing attacks. Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner were murdered by the KKK while participating in a campaign whose name starts with this word. To protest the lack of enforcement of the Boynton v. Virginia ruling, CORE founder James Farmer led a campaign whose name starts with this word. Volunteers flooded into Mississippi to help (*) register Black voters in a "summer" named for this word. This word identifies protestors against bus segregation who rode buses through Southern states. In "I Have a Dream," Martin Luther King, Jr. quoted the patriotic lyric, "Let [this word] ring." For 10 points, a group of "Riders" were named for what synonym of liberty? ANSWER: freedom [accept Freedom Riders or Freedom Summer] <Rohan Kher, History - American - 1945+> ~29646~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

8. Pirates steal the key to a city on this body of water in a festival run by Ye Mystic Krewe of Gasparilla. A city on this body of water is the more northern claimant to a sandwich made of mojo pork and cheese invented by immigrants. The American Salvador Dalí Museum is in a city on this body of water connected to Terra Ceia by the Sunshine Skyway Bridge. The Big Bend Power Plant near this body of water's Apollo Beach releases warm water that attracts (*) manatees. Cigar factories in Ybor City along this body of water drew in Cuban immigrants. Tropicana Field is in St. Petersburg, a city on this body of water that forms a metropolitan area with Clearwater. For 10 points, name this large bay in western Florida. ANSWER: Tampa Bay [accept the Lower Tampa Bay; accept Old Tampa Bay; accept Tampa; prompt on the Gulf of Mexico; or Atlantic Ocean; prompt on Hillsborough Bay or McKay Bay by asking "what larger body of water is it a part of?"] <Ganon Evans, Geography - United States> ~27582~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. The use of cyano·biphenyls as discotics in these materials was popularized by George Gray. Stephanie Kwolek's work with polymer solutions of these materials led to her discovery of Kevlar. In-plane switching improves the performance of devices that use these materials, which typically have an order parameter between 0.3 and 0.9. The "cholesteric" type of these materials form unaligned layers, unlike their (*) smectic type. An electric field polarizes these materials to make them transparent or opaque in the twisted nematic effect. These materials display properties of both fluids and ordered solids, and organic LEDs are replacing them in namesake displays. For 10 points, name these materials, the "LC" in LCD. ANSWER: liquid crystals [or mesogens; accept liquid crystal displays; prompt on LCDs until "LC" is read; reject partial answers] <Sean Farrell, Science - Chemistry> ~29652~ <Editor: June Yin>

Answer: Robert Frost (The poem in the first line is "The Pasture.")
Text: 10. This author wrote "I'm going out to fetch the little calf" in two quatrains ending "I shan't be gone long - you come too." This poet wrote about an animal "not to blame for his key" in "A Minor Bird," and described "a dimpled spider, fat and white, holding up a moth" in "Design." In one work, this poet complains of hunters who "would have the rabbit out of hiding" and create (*) gaps in stones, before noting "But here there are no cows" to question whether "Good fences make good neighbors." This poet wrote "My little horse must think it queer / To stop without a farmhouse near" in a poem ending "And miles to go before I sleep." For 10 points, name this poet of "Mending Wall" and "Stopping By Woods on a Snowy Evening." ANSWER: Robert Frost [or Robert Lee Frost] (The poem in the first line is "The Pasture.") <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~30067~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 in E-flat major (The second clue refers to the Eroica Variations.)
Text: 11. The Orchestre Révolutionnaire et Romantique ("or-KESS-truh ray-vo-loo-see-oh-NAIR ay ro-mahn-TEEK") performed this symphony in a 2003 BBC film dramatizing its first rehearsal. Its composer's opus 35 and this symphony's finale are sets of variations on a contredanse beginning "pickup E-flat, long G, short E-flat, long D." This symphony was written a year after its composer resolved not to kill himself in the Heiligenstadt ("HIGH-lih-gen-shtat") Testament. This symphony uses the relative C minor for its second movement (*) funeral march. The start of the Romantic era is often traced to the two forte E-flat major chords that open this symphony. The subtitle "composed to celebrate the memory of a great man" replaced a dedication to Napoleon in, for 10 points, what Beethoven symphony about heroism? ANSWER: Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 in E-flat major [or the Eroica Symphony; or Sinfonia Eroica; accept Eroica - The Day That Changed Music Forever; accept the Heroic Symphony until "heroism"; prompt on Symphony No. 3 until "Beethoven" is read and accept thereafter] (The second clue refers to the Eroica Variations.) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Classical> ~27620~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

12. This deity must wade through a boiling river to reach the well Urðarbrunnr ("ur-thur-BROO-nur") instead of crossing Bifrost. Shaking mountains alert the servant Beyla of this deity's arrival during a flyting. This deity kills a jötunn ("YO-tun") who is enraged by the horse Svaðilfari ("SVAH-thil-far-ee") chasing a god disguised as a mare. This deity smashes a chalice against the skull of (*) Hymir, a jötunn ("YO-tun") this deity goes fishing with, in a story that features the creature that kills this deity at Ragnarok. Utgard-Loki tricks this deity into drinking from the ocean and lifting Jörmungandr ("YOR-mun-gahn-dur"). This deity uses a set of iron gloves to wield a weapon whose accidentally shortened handle led it to be used with one hand. For 10 points, name this strong god who owns Mjölnir. ANSWER: Thor [accept Thuner or Donar] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~29530~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

13. This period's rock formations include Old Red Sandstone and the Rhynie Chert, which names this period's vascular plant genus Rhynia. Phacopid trilobites went extinct at the end of this period in the Hangenberg event, which was smaller than the Kellwasser event that separates its Frasnian and Famennian ages. While it's mostly in the following period, Romer's gap in the fossil record began in this period. The crocodile-like transitional fossil Tiktaalik is from this period that contained the earliest appearances of (*) ammonites, four-legged amphibians, and forests. The Silurian and Carboniferous periods bookend this "Age of Fishes." For 10 points, a southwest England county names what period abbreviated "D"? ANSWER: Devonian period [prompt on D until read; prompt on Age of Fishes until read] <David Bass, Science - Other Science> ~31111~ <Editor: David Bass>

14. The first UN award named for this variable was co-won by Qian Xinzhong, chair of China's NFPC. This variable declines after the year 2030 according to the 1972 World3 computer simulation funded by the Club of Rome. A 1970 Tonight Show appearance sparked panic about this variable when Paul Ehrlich discussed his book on its (*) "bomb." A campaign to reduce this variable during The Emergency led by Sanjay Gupta forced many men to get surgeries. People who violated a policy begun in 1979 to decrease this variable were denied a hukou. 19th century fears that an increase in this variable led to poverty sparked the formation of the Malthusian League. For 10 points, name this variable reduced via China's One Child policy. ANSWER: human population [accept descriptions such as size of the global population or the population of China or India; accept over-population; accept The Population Bomb; accept number of people in the world; prompt on family size or fertility rate or number of children or number of people by asking "what global variable does that contribute to?"] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~29953~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

15. In a play by this writer, a man declares that he does not "like the months of the year" after he is asked to imitate February. A character created by this writer tells the story of a calf who eats too much glass and has to give birth. In a play by this writer, capital letters are used to write "ANGELFOOD" by the Orator after the Old Man and the Old Woman shout "Long live the Emperor" and jump out the window. (*) Surreal dialogue is exchanged by English couples called the Smiths and Martins with the Fire Chief in a play by this writer of The Chairs. In another play by this writer, Bérenger ("BAY-ron-zhay") opposes turning into the title animal. For 10 points, name this absurdist playwright of The Bald Soprano and Rhinoceros. ANSWER: Eugène Ionesco ("ur-ZHEN ee-oh-NESS-koh") [or Eugen Ionescu] <Alyssa Jorgensen, Literature - European - Drama> ~21062~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

16. A pamphlet co-authored by this thinker includes cartoons with captions such as "people are gentle or warlike depending on their training." In one introduction, this colleague of Gene Weltfish stated that "the goal is a world made safe for differences." This thinker included "Coyote and Badger" in a compilation of Zuni folktales. This thinker introduced a dichotomy to which "fear" has since been added. This thinker defined (*) culture as "personality writ large" in an influential textbook. This student of Franz Boas performed "anthropology from a distance" upon Japan, contrasting its shame culture to Western guilt cultures. For 10 points, name this anthropologist who wrote The Chrysanthemum and the Sword. ANSWER: Ruth Benedict [or Ruth Fulton Benedict] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Anthropology> ~30300~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

17. Accusations that the son of this city's king was poisoned by Joseph ibn Naghrela led to a 1066 pogrom. Zawi ibn Ziri sailed north to establish the Zirids in this city. A ruler of this city was told, "Weep like a woman for a kingdom you could not defend like a man." The Rebellion of the Alpujarras ("AL-poo-hah-ras") responded to forced conversions of people who had lived in a kingdom centered on this city, which was last ruled by (*) Boabdil ("BOH-ahb-dil") and was the longest-lasting taifa kingdom. The Court of the Lions was built by this city's Nasrid dynasty in a building that named the decree expelling Jews from Spain. Ferdinand and Isabella's conquest of this city ended the Reconquista. For 10 points, name this Spanish city home to the Alhambra. ANSWER: Granada [accept Emirate of Granada or Kingdom of Granada] <Rohan Kher, History - European - Middle Ages> ~30043~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

18. The floor function around a coefficient of one-half distinguishes an expression describing a 1D system named for this scientist from the energy of a particle-in-a-box. This scientist names a gas that exhibits degeneracy pressure at absolute zero and is used to derive the Chandrasekhar limit. This scientist names a quantity, often conflated with the chemical potential, that lies within the (*) band gap for insulators. This scientist names the highest occupied energy level in metals. Particles named for this scientist do not condense at low temperatures because they obey statistics named for him and Dirac. For 10 points, identify this physicist who, in contrast to Bose, names particles with half-integer spin. ANSWER: Enrico Fermi [accept Fermi gas; accept Fermi energy; accept fermions] (The lead-in describes the expression for the Fermi energy of a 1D uniform Fermi gas.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~29774~ <Editor: David Bass>

19. A version of this painting commissioned by the Prince Regent of Waldeck and held at Michigan’s Clements Library exemplifies its artist's concept of "epic representation." William Pitt the Elder complained about "too much dejection" in the expression of this painting’s title figure. Beads were used to model the contemporary dress of a man in this painting who also wears (*) moccasins ("MOCK-uh-sins"). Henry Browne holds a flag and looks down at this painting’s central figure, whose right hand is wrapped in a white tourniquet. In the bottom left of this painting, a tattooed First Nations man crouches in front of the St. Lawrence River near the title commander. For 10 points, name this Benjamin West painting titled for a man who died at the Battle of Quebec. ANSWER: The Death of General Wolfe [accept The Death of Wolfe or The Death of General James Wolfe] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~30100~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

20. In this novel, a man seated under a television remembers a box of Snakes and Ladders and cries "two gin-scented tears." The claim "anyone under forty-five is perfectly capable of touching his toes" is made by a TV fitness instructor in this novel. A man in this novel writes about "a wonderful shot of a child's arm going up up up" in war films in his diary, and hears a TV play "I sold you and you sold me," (*) "Under the spreading chestnut tree." A dark-haired girl with a red Junior Anti-Sex League sash throws a book at Emmanuel Goldstein’s face on a huge screen during the Two Minutes Hate in this novel. For 10 points, the Thought Police watch residents of Oceania through telescreens in what George Orwell novel? ANSWER: Nineteen Eighty-Four [or 1984] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~30503~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

21. Deactivation of a component in this technique enables "modulation" via either "interference" or "activation," yielding variants that append "i" or "a" to the name of this technique. George M. Church joked that his lab "[focuses] on inventions" when Feng Zhang did not receive the Nobel for this technique, despite holding its patent. This technique is the most prominent successor of TALENs ("talons") and Fok·I-based ZFNs. This technique acts near a length 8-to-10 seed region and an adjacent (*) PAM sequence. This technique, which is derived from a microbial antiviral mechanism, uses tracr·RNA in guide RNA to bring an endonuclease to a DNA target. For 10 points, name this technique that uses Cas proteins to edit the genome. ANSWER: CRISPR/Cas9 [or CRISPR/Cas or CRISPRi or CRISPRa or CRISPRi/a or CRISPRmod or clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats; prompt on answers describing gene editing] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~29642~ <Editor: David Bass> NSC 2025 - Round 02 - Bonuses

Answer: Charlotte Charlotte Mew wrote a poem about the Nunhead one of these places declaring "There is something terrible about a child." Another poem about this type of place references "mute inglorious Miltons" and begins "the curfew tolls the knell of parting day." ANSWER: cemetery This Imagist poet of Helen in Egypt and Sea Garden praised Charlotte Mew’s monologues. This poet wrote "Whirl up, sea…cover us with your pools of fir" in "Oread." ANSWER: H. D.
Text: 1. A poet with this first name wrote about a woman "afraid of love and me and all things human" in a poem ending "the brown of her - her eyes, her hair, her hair!" For 10 points each: [10e] The poet of "The Farmer's Bride" had what first name and last name Mew? Mew wrote an introduction to the poems of Emily Brontë, whose literary sisters had first names Anne and this name. ANSWER: Charlotte [accept Charlotte Mew or Charlotte Brontë] [10m] Charlotte Mew wrote a poem about the Nunhead one of these places declaring "There is something terrible about a child." Another poem about this type of place references "mute inglorious Miltons" and begins "the curfew tolls the knell of parting day." ANSWER: cemetery [or churchyard; or graveyard; or burial ground; accept "Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard"; accept "In Nunhead Cemetery"; prompt on church or grave] [10h] This Imagist poet of Helen in Egypt and Sea Garden praised Charlotte Mew’s monologues. This poet wrote "Whirl up, sea…cover us with your pools of fir" in "Oread." ANSWER: H. D. [or Hilda Doolittle] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Poetry> ~25546~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

2. Note to moderator: read the answerline carefully. Note to players: description required. Shemwindo seals the title character of the Mwindo epic in a drum and performs this action to him, leading him to be raised by his aunt Iyangura. For 10 points each: [10h] Describe this action that Jochebed ("yo-HEH-bed") performs to her son to save his life in another story. ANSWER: putting him in a river [accept any equivalent description involving placing the child in or next to a river; accept Nile in place of "river"; prompt on putting the child in a basket by asking "where was the basket placed?" prompt on putting him in a body of water; prompt on hiding or abandoning the child] [10m] While saving his father from the underworld, Mwindo almost gambles away all of his stuff with Sheburungu, the god of this domain. A deity of this domain is given hornets, a fairy, and a leopard by a hero. ANSWER: sky [10e] The lightning god Nkuba is enraged when Mwindo kills his brother Kirimu, a seven-headed one of these animals. Another many-headed example of these creatures is the Lernaean Hydra. ANSWER: serpents [or dragons; accept snakes] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~25410~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

3. As Louis XIV's court composer, Jean-Baptiste Lully wrote for a five-part string orchestra that included the haute-contre ("oat CON-truh"), taille ("tie"), and basse ("bahss") forms of this instrument. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this string instrument pitched between the violin and cello. ANSWER: viola [or viola da braccio; or alto; reject "viola da gamba" or "viol"] [10m] "Taille" also refers to a tenor form of this instrument first used in Lully's ballet Alcidiane. The shawm developed into this wind instrument whose "d'amore" ("da-MO-ray") form is pitched in A. ANSWER: oboe [or hautbois; accept oboe d'amore] [10h] In his ballets, Lully developed this musical form consisting of a slow section with dotted rhythms followed by a fast fugal section. Bach's Clavier-Übung II pairs the Italian Concerto with one of these pieces. ANSWER: French overture [accept Overture in the French style or Ouvertüre nach Französischer Art; prompt on overture] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~24554~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

4. Successors to Peccei–Quinn theory seek to explain why this theory, but not electroweak theory, preserves CP symmetry. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this predominant theory of the gluon-mediated strong interaction among quarks. ANSWER: quantum chromodynamics [or QCD] [10h] These particles are the Goldstone bosons of Peccei–Quinn theory. Modern theories include "invisible" instances of these dark matter candidates that were independently theorized by Steven Weinberg and Frank Wilczek. ANSWER: axions [or invisible axions] [10e] Theories of axions are motivated by the anomalously small value for a QCD parameter denoted with this letter. Alongside phi, this is the most common Greek letter used to denote angles. ANSWER: lowercase theta <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24534~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. John Milton refuted a book attributed to this author point-by-point in Eikonoklastes. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this author who allegedly wrote the pious diary Eikon Basilike. This ruler's death was preceded by Pride's Purge, in which some members of Parliament were blocked from entering the House of Commons. ANSWER: Charles I [or Charles Stuart; prompt on Charles; prompt on Stuart] [10e] Some attribute the Eikon Basilike to John Gauden, who claimed to have written it shortly after this 1660 event in which the Stuart monarch was reinstated under Charles II. ANSWER: English Restoration [or Stuart Restoration] [10h] Like Charles I, this man was posthumously executed after the 1403 Battle of Shrewsbury. This rebel against Henry Bolingbroke was nicknamed for his quickness in battle. ANSWER: Henry Percy [or Harry Hotspur] <Forrest Weintraub, History - European - Misc> ~24937~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. At this novel's end, a character turns pale upon seeing Marcello Solara ("mar-CHEL-loh soh-LAH-rah") wearing a pair of shoes she had made, which had been bought by her fiancé Stefano ("steh-FAH-noh"). For 10 points each: [10h] Name this 2011 novel, the first in a series about Lila ("LEE-lah") and Lenù ("lay-NOO"). ANSWER: My Brilliant Friend [or L'amica geniale] [10m] My Brilliant Friend is the first of this author's Neapolitan Novels. This anonymous author's chosen pseudonym is a reference to the novelist Elsa Morante ("moh-RAN-tay"). ANSWER: Elena Ferrante ("EL-eh-nah feh-RAN-tay") [10e] Ferrante wrote the text for a 2021 lecture series named after this other author, which was delivered by an actor. This Italian author wrote The Name of the Rose. ANSWER: Umberto Eco <Tim Morrison, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~11941~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

Answer: Python (Python is not named after the snake.)
Text: 7. Anaconda is a distribution of this programming language that comes with Conda, which can be used instead of pip. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this language that, despite featuring utilities like Spyder, Pandas, and Polars, shares its name with a snake. ANSWER: Python (Python is not named after the snake.) [10h] Pip and Conda are examples of this type of software that respectively use Py·P·I and a network of independent channels. npm is this type of software for JavaScript. ANSWER: package manager [accept node package manager; prompt on manager or package installer or environment manager] [10m] Code in Python packages should contain the condition "if name is equal to [this word]" in order to prevent extraneous code execution upon import. Any C++ program must contain an integer-valued global function named for this word. ANSWER: main <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25413~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. Answer the following about some of the artists referenced in the Great American Muse series by Roger Shimomura, for 10 points each. [10m] One of this Pop artist's fighter jet paintings hangs in the background of the series' first entry. This artist painted I Know...Brad. ANSWER: Roy Lichtenstein [or Roy Fox Lichtenstein] [10e] The 16th entry references Andy Warhol with a painting of one of these fruits in the foreground. Maurizio Cattelan's 2019 piece Comedian consists of a real example of this fruit duct-taped to a wall. ANSWER: bananas [10h] A painting by this artist hangs above a toilet in the 29th entry in Shimomura's series. This artist moved away from Expressionism after a series of studies like 1908's Evening; Red Tree. ANSWER: Piet Mondrian [or Pieter Cornelis Mondriaan] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - 1945+> ~25076~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

9. This function occurs twice in the middle stage of Jespersen's cycle, as in the French "ne… pas" that is currently evolving into just "pas." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this function whose repetition is often considered ungrammatical but is common in spoken English sentences like "I didn't do nothing." ANSWER: negation [or negative; accept double negation or double negative] [10m] Alan Gardiner described what we now call Jespersen's cycle when studying double negation in this language. Scripts for this Afro-Asiatic language include hieratic and demotic. ANSWER: Ancient Egyptian [or er en kemet; accept Middle Egyptian or Late Egyptian] [10h] Speakers of this broad dialect often repeat the word for "no" before and after a verb for emphasis. This large Romance dialect palatalizes "d" and "t" sounds. ANSWER: Brazilian Portuguese [or Português brasileiro; prompt on Portuguese or Português] <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Linguistics> ~24786~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

10. This city's chief crop was a legendary contraceptive, medicine, and seasoning called silphium. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this city in modern-day Libya that was the birthplace of the skeptic philosopher Carneades ("car-NAY-uh-deez") and the polymath Eratosthenes ("air-uh-TOSS-thuh-neez"). Colonists from Thera founded this city's Battiad dynasty. ANSWER: Cyrene [or Kyrene] [10m] The myth that the heart symbol is shaped like a silphium seed can be traced to this Muslim author's 11th Century Canon of Medicine. ANSWER: Ibn Sina [or Avicenna; or Abū ʿAlī al-Husayn bin ʿAbdullāh ibn al-Hasan bin ʿAlī bin Sīnā al-Balkhi al-Bukhari] [10e] Alexander the Great's army mistook a relative of silphium called asafoetida ("ASS-uh-feh-tih-duh") for a new source of the plant while returning from a campaign near this river. Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro were cities on this river. ANSWER: Indus River [or Sindh] <Forrest Weintraub, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~24934~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: lucidum (The structures are the stratum lucidum and the tapetum lucidum.)
Text: 11. This word names a layer of the epidermis that is present in the thick skin of palms and soles. For 10 points each: [10h] Give this word that names a thin layer of the epidermis that can appear below the stratum corneum. This is the second word in the name of an iridescent layer of the eye that improves night vision in nocturnal animals. ANSWER: lucidum (The structures are the stratum lucidum and the tapetum lucidum.) [10m] The epidermis is primarily composed of cells named for this protein, which can differentiate into corneocytes. The intermediate filaments formed by this protein are rich in disulfide bridges. ANSWER: keratin [or alpha-keratin] [10e] Keratinocytes of the epidermis receive this polymer from the stratum basale. This pigment drives the coloration of human skin. ANSWER: melanin <Rohan Kher, Science - Biology> ~24601~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Andrew Marvell (The poem is "To His Coy Mistress.")
Text: 12. A poem by this author addressed "to my Lord Fairfax" asks, "Why should of all things man unrul'd / Such unproportioned dwellings build?" For 10 points each: [10m] Name this author of the country house poem "Upon Appleton House." This author's most famous poem ends, "though we cannot make our sun / Stand still, yet we will make him run." ANSWER: Andrew Marvell (The poem is "To His Coy Mistress.") [10h] A character in this novella takes his nickname "Starry" from "Upon Appleton House." This novella ends with a poem named for its title character "in the Darbies" ending "the oozy weeds about me twist." ANSWER: Billy Budd, Sailor (An Inside Narrative) [or Billy Budd, Foretopman; prompt on "Billy in the Darbies" by asking "what novella is that poem from?"] [10e] Billy Budd was written by this author, who created a hymn describing "The ribs and terrors in the whale" in his novel Moby Dick. ANSWER: Herman Melville <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Misc> ~24621~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

13. This man's ranch was foreclosed upon by Edward Doheny in the aftermath of a criminal case in which Doheny himself was acquitted. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this man who became the first Cabinet minister to go to prison following a case in which Harry Sinclair was convicted of contempt of court after a mistrial. ANSWER: Albert Bacon Fall [10m] Fall was imprisoned for his role in this event, in which he was bribed to illegally lease the US Navy's oil reserves to private companies. ANSWER: Teapot Dome scandal [10e] The Teapot Dome scandal retrospectively tarnished the Presidency of this Republican, whose sudden death in 1923 led to his replacement by Calvin Coolidge. ANSWER: Warren G. Harding [or Warren Gamaliel Harding] <Jamie Burchett, History - American - 1865-1945> ~26116~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

14. In Race Matters, Cornel West called the adoption of this philosophical view "the major enemy of Black survival in America." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this philosophical view often summarized as "nothing matters." ANSWER: nihilism [accept word forms like nihilist] [10h] According to Keiji Nishitani, nihilism is a Western notion derived from a form of negativity that he contrasted with this Sanskrit term. This term, central to Buddhist philosophy, is often translated as "emptiness." ANSWER: śūnyatā ("shoon-yuh-tah") [10m] Nishitani defined Western "nihility" in a book titled for this practice and Nothingness. William James contrasted healthy-minded and sick-souled approaches to this practice in a book on the varieties of its experience. ANSWER: religion [accept religious experiences or mystical experiences; accept Religion and Nothingness; accept The Varieties of Religious Experience] <Sean Farrell, RMP - Philosophy> ~24703~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

15. Although these apps are banned in China, many of the most popular ones come from that country. For 10 points each: [10e] Identify these programs, which include TunnelBear. YouTube ads often tout how these programs trick Netflix into thinking you're logging in from another country. ANSWER: VPNs [or virtual private networks] [10m] This security company purchased TunnelBear in 2018. This company's founder and namesake hanged himself in a Barcelona prison in 2021 after learning he would be extradited to the US to face tax evasion charges. ANSWER: McAfee Corp. [accept John McAfee] [10h] This senator has called for an investigation into the use of VPNs as spying tools. This Oregon Democrat and privacy advocate introduced the 2019 Mind Your Own Business Act. ANSWER: Ron Wyden [or Ronald Lee Wyden] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~24683~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. This city's namesake investigated an incident in which two drunk men celebrated Bastille Day by blowing up an African man. For 10 points each: [10h] Identify this African city named for an Italian who died on return to France before he could deliver his anti-imperial report. ANSWER: Brazzaville [accept Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza] [10m] Although de Brazza is still honored, all cities named for this racist Welsh author of In Darkest Africa have been renamed. This man discovered a doctor on the shores of Lake Tanganyika ("tan-gan-YEE-kuh"). ANSWER: Henry Morton Stanley [10e] The Republic of Congo's city of Nkayi was once named Jacob after a French engineer who surveyed the route for one of these projects. Cecil Rhodes proposed one of these projects from Cape Town to Cairo. ANSWER: railway [or railroad] <Michael Bentley, History - World - African> ~24924~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

17. Pyotr Tchaikovsky was apocryphally challenged to write a melody using just a major scale when composing the pas de deux ("pah duh doo") for this character and Prince Coqueluche ("coke-LOOSH"). For 10 points each: [10e] Name this queen of the Land of Sweets from The Nutcracker whose namesake "Dance" is scored by a celesta. ANSWER: the Sugar Plum Fairy [or la Fée-Dragée] [10m] The Nutcracker was rarely performed outside Russia until 1954, when this Georgian-American choreographer's staging for the New York City Ballet turned it into a Christmas classic. ANSWER: George Balanchine [or Giorgi Balanchivadze] [10h] This dancer played the Sugar Plum Fairy in Balanchine's hit production of The Nutcracker. The New York City Ballet's first major success under Balanchine featured this Native American dancer as the Firebird. ANSWER: Maria Tallchief [or Elizabeth Marie Tall Chief] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Ballet/Dance> ~25005~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

18. In a Haruki Murakami short story, one of these animals from Shinagawa steals the names of women he is attracted to. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these animals. In a short story by another author, a painter's daughter burns to death with one of these animals after her father creates the title artwork. ANSWER: monkeys [accept "Confessions of a Shinagawa Monkey"; accept "Shinagawa Saru no Kokuhaku"] [10m] The narrator of Murakami's story "With the Beatles" reads this other author's story "Cogwheels". Murakami was twice nominated for an award named for this author of the aforementioned "Hell Screen". ANSWER: Ryunosuke Akutagawa [accept names in either order] [10e] The Akutagawa prize is awarded annually in this home country of Murakami, where he often set his stories in Tokyo. ANSWER: Japan [or Nihon-koku or Nippon-koku] <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24658~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

19. A bracketed alpha denotes a form of rotation named for this adjective that is equal and opposite for L and D-isomers. For 10 points each: [10h] Give this adjective that describes reactions where the stereochemistry of the reactants entirely determines the stereochemistry of the products.
