ANSWER: specific [accept stereospecific; accept specific rotation] [10m] Stereospecific reactions can either produce dia•stereomers or these isomers. Specific rotation can be used to measure ratios of these isomers, which are respectively denoted "R" and "S." ANSWER: enantiomers [accept enantiomeric excess] [10e] Stereospecific reactions may also form achiral meso isomers, which have at least this many chiral centers. Ethanol and ethane both have this number of carbon atoms. ANSWER: two <Sean Farrell, Science - Chemistry> ~24611~ <Editor: June Yin>

20. The Gayatri ("GUY-uh-tree") mantra is dedicated to Savitr ("SAH-vee-tur"), a member of the Adityas, who govern this domain. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this celestial domain governed by Surya, who is venerated by flying kites during Makar Sankranti. ANSWER: the Sun [10h] Kites are also flown during this festival, observed on the last day of Shravana. It's not Bhai Dooj, but during this festival, sisters tie a piece of string around their brothers' wrists as a symbol of protection. ANSWER: Raksha Bandhan [or Rakhi; or Saluno; or Silono; or Rakri] [10m] The kite fighting game of changa chait is played during this country's festivals of Dashain and Tihar. Hindus often pilgrim to the Pashupatinath ("PUH-shoo-PUH-tin-aath") temple in this modern-day country, where Queen Maya gave birth to the Buddha. ANSWER: Nepal [or Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Hinduism> ~25337~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

21. Description required. The town of Lepakshi is attributed to be a place where Jatayu fell trying to stop this event. For 10 points each: [10m] Describe this event, facilitated by a rakshasa who lures his target outside of Lakhsmana's protective boundary. ANSWER: abduction of Sita [accept synonyms for abduction like kidnapping] [10e] Jatayu had tried in vain to save Sita from this ten-headed rakshasa, the primary antagonist of the Ramayana. ANSWER: Ravana [accept Ravana Dashagriva or Ravanasura or Ravanaeshwaran or Dasis Sakvithi Maha Ravana; accept Lankapati or Lankeshwar or Lankeshwaran; accept Dashaanan] [10h] Jatayu and his brother Sampati are both depicted as these creatures. They are nephews of another of these creatures who forced Kaliya to leave Ramanaka Dwipa. ANSWER: birds [accept vultures; accept eagles] (Lepakshi, mentioned in the lead-in, translates to "get up, bird.") <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - World Mythology> ~25293~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

1. The "sprezzatura" in this artist's works is often compared to another artist's "terribilità" and was first described by Baldassare Castiglione ("kah-steel-YO-nay"), who wears a fur-lined robe in this artist's portrait of him. This artist planned four paintings depicting the life of Constantine that his student Giulio Romano helped create. This artist's Marriage of the Virgin was based on that of his teacher (*) Perugino. In a painting by this artist displayed across from his Disputa, a group of men watch Euclid draw a circle. Leonardo da Vinci modeled for a central figure who points upwards in a fresco that this artist made for the Stanza della Segnatura in the Apostolic Palace. For 10 points, name this painter of The School of Athens. ANSWER: Raphael [or Rafaello; or Rafaello Sanzio da Urbino] (The contemporary is Michelangelo.) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~30016~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. An average of 100 religious burials per day take place in this country's Valley of Peace. A religious group mostly found in this country uses phragmites ("frag-MY-teez") reeds to construct a building called a mudhif ("moo-deef"). A modern tradition in this country involves men wearing chains and whip handles around their necks as drums beat and celebrants symbolically (*) hurt themselves. The majority of Ahwaris or Marsh Arabs live in this country, where 25 million people travelled in 2023 for Arba'in. One city in this country is the burial site of Ali ibn Abi Talib. This country is home to the Shia pilgrimage cities of Najaf and Karbala. For 10 points, name this country whose religious minority of Sunni Kurds were persecuted by Saddam Hussein. ANSWER: Iraq [or Republic of Iraq or Jumhuriyyat al-'Iraq] <Michael Bentley, RMP - Islam> ~30084~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

3. Workers producing this resource forced corporate executives to hide in the wilderness during a revolt partly incited by a forced American food diet. Frank Seiberling established a company for this resource that helped produce the F4U Corsair. Because it headquartered four different producers of this resource, including one created by B.F. Goodrich, this resource's "capital of the world" was in the Ohio city of (*) Akron. A breakthrough in this resource occurred when an American chemist accidentally dropped this resource mixed with sulfur in a frying pan. Fordlandia was a settlement created to harvest this material in Brazil. Charles Goodyear rediscovered the vulcanization of, for 10 points, what material the Model T used for its tires? ANSWER: rubber [prompt on tires] <Lalit Maharjan, History - American - 1865-1945> ~29808~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. This character was defended with the line that "it is an equal error…to blame the praiseworthy and to praise the blameworthy" in an encomium by Gorgias. In a namesake play, this character swears an oath to the river Eurotas before asking about the fate of her husband. This character escapes with her presumed dead husband after promising to marry (*) Theoclymenus, an Egyptian king, in a play by Euripides. Euripides also wrote about this character as part of the title group of women in a play where it is revealed at the end that she avoided her death sentence from her husband, Menelaus. For 10 points, what Greek woman is known as the "face that launched 1000 ships" because her capture started the Trojan War? ANSWER: Helen [or Helen of Troy; or Helen of Sparta; or Helene ("heh-LAY-neigh")] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~29792~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

5. Tom B. Brown et al. 2020 describes power law-based empirical scaling laws that restrict analysis of this type of data. This is the canonical type of data whose analysis is tailored via "indexing" and "retrieval" steps in RAG. A mechanism for processing this type of data is parallelized in a "multi-head" approach. Seq2seq ("seek two seek") inspired the paper "Attention Is All You Need," which improved encoder-decoder architecture for handling this type of data. This (*) autoregressive type of data is the focus of tools like PaLM, Chinchilla, and Meta’s Llama. Transformers typically handle this non-visual type of data, which is studied in NLP and processed by LLMs. For 10 points, name this type of data that is processed by translators. ANSWER: natural language [or text or words or languages or text corpus or text corpora; prompt on strings or books or objects that contain text by asking "what type of data does that contain?"; prompt on sequential data or sequence data or sequences] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~29656~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Japan (Capital in the Anthropocene was written by Kohei Saito.)
Text: 6. An economist from this country argued "degrowth" was necessary to save the planet in his book Capital in the Anthropocene. A decline of 22% of this country's GDP resulting from a severe drop in corporate investment caused what economist Richard Koo labeled a "balance sheet recession." This country's central bank drastically increased bond purchases in an early use of (*) quantitative easing. The collapse of this country's real estate and stock markets in 1991 preceded its low-growth "Lost Decades." This rapidly aging country has the highest elderly dependency ratio in the world. For 10 points, name this country whose "economic miracle" included conglomerates such as Mitsubishi. ANSWER: Japan (Capital in the Anthropocene was written by Kohei Saito.) <Michael Bentley, Social Science - Economics> ~27702~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

7. As a student, this politician unsuccessfully lobbied to rename a football stadium for Ernie Davis and later married a lawyer who represented Delaware North in a controversial NFL stadium deal. In January 2025, this governor stated "the cost of living is just too damn high" in support of a law to ban hedge funds buying single family homes. This politician, who in 2022 narrowly defeated Republican (*) Lee Zeldin, decided not to use their power to fire a mayor implicated in a scandal involving Turkish Airlines. This governor vetoed but later supported a bill that raises revenue for the MTA by imposing the country's first congestion pricing zone. For 10 points, name this woman who succeeded Andrew Cuomo as Governor of New York. ANSWER: Kathy Hochul [or Kathleen Hochul; or Kathleen Courtney] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~29952~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: free radicals (The technique in the first clue is EPR spectroscopy.)
Text: 8. A technique developed to study these molecules can also be used to study F-centers in crystals. These molecules both begin and are products of hydrogen atom abstractions. These molecules rapidly undergo disproportionation or dimerization when they are reaction intermediates. These molecules' energy levels experience Zeeman ("ZAY-mun") splitting since they are paramagnetic. The formation of these molecules through (*) homolytic cleavage is denoted by fish-hook arrows. Reactive oxygen species are often examples of these molecules, whose chemical symbols contain a dot. These DNA-damaging molecules are neutralized by antioxidants. For 10 points, name these molecules with unpaired valence electrons. ANSWER: free radicals [accept reactive oxygen species or ROS until "reactive"] (The technique in the first clue is EPR spectroscopy.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~30297~ <Editor: June Yin>

9. In this city, Rabbi Israel Lipkin founded the counter-Enlightenment Musar movement. This city was the center of a movement of "opponents," or "misnagdim," ("mees-nog-DEEM") who later adopted a demonym with the suffix "-vak." Napoleon called this city the "Jerusalem of the North." An eighteenth-century rabbi who opposed the rise of Hasidism is commonly known as "the genius from [this city]," or "[this city] (*) Gaon ("gah-OWN"). A ruler of a state centered on this city secured his cousin Jogaila's rule in another state. Vytautas the Great ruled a Grand Duchy centered on this city. This Baltic city, founded by Gediminas, was the capital of half of a large commonwealth along with Jagiellonian ("yog-yuh-LO-nee-in") Poland. For 10 points, name this capital of Lithuania. ANSWER: Vilnius [or Vilna or Wilna or Wilno; accept Vilna Gaon] <Forrest Weintraub, History - European - 1500-1900> ~30193~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. A poem in this language describes three "half-men," of whom "one whistles, another meows, a third snivels." A cycle in this language begins with the lines "No foreign sky protected me, / no stranger's wing shielded my face" before describing waiting in a line for "seventeen months." The "laughing cockroaches" on the top lip of a politician are described in an (*) "Epigram" in this language by Osip Mandelstam ("OH-sip MAN-dul-shtam"). The question "Can you describe this?" is asked in "Instead of a Preface," part of a cycle in this language by an acmeist ("ACK-me-ist") poet titled Requiem. This was the most-spoken language of a country which, in 1934, required poets to use socialist realism. For 10 points, name this language used by Anna Akhmatova ("ack-MAH-tuh-vuh"). ANSWER: Russian [or Russkiy] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - European - Poetry> ~30282~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

11. The inability to perform this behavior distinguishes reproductive adults called ergatoids. Two orders that are indirectly named for this behavior, alongside the prefixes "Strepsi" and "Di," facilitate this behavior with teardrop-shaped stalks called halteres. Alates ("AY-lates") can perform this behavior, which is performed concurrently with mating in the (*) "nuptial" form of this behavior that creates new colonies. Structures for this behavior are patterned with dark lateral veins and crossveins in Dipterans. The orientation and magnitude of this form of taxis ("TACK-sis") is directed by the "circle" and "waggle" dances that communicate pollination routes among bees. For 10 points, name this behavior enabled by wings. ANSWER: flight [or flying; accept nuptial flight; prompt on swarming by asking "what behavior do individuals perform while swarming?"] <Rohan Kher, Science - Biology> ~30044~ <Editor: David Bass>

12. The rising motif "E-flat, F, C" permeates a piece for this ensemble consisting of a chaconne, an intermezzo, and a march. Robert W. Smith wrote most of his works for this ensemble, one of which was founded by Frederick Fennell ("fuh-NELL") at the Eastman School of Music. Pieces for this ensemble that can be played as uptempo "screamers" include Julius Fučík's ("YOOL-ius FOO-cheek's") Entry of the Gladiators. Pieces for this ensemble include (*) Percy Grainger's Lincolnshire Posy and two suites by Gustav Holst. Some of these ensembles contain a relative of the tuba that can be carried on the shoulder, which is named for John Philip Sousa. For 10 points, name these ensembles common in high schools that consist mainly of woodwinds, brass, and percussion. ANSWER: concert band [or wind ensemble; or symphonic band; or military band; or wind band; or marching band; reject "brass band"] <Joseph Chambers, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~30251~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

13. This book's second edition argues against people who view "outer experiences" as "doubtful and indemonstrable" in a section titled "Refutation of Idealism." This book uses a diamond shape to arrange four headers that categorize twelve "categories of understanding." This book criticizes both Newton and Leibniz in a section arguing that space and time cannot be understood as concepts. This book distinguishes between objects of inquiry called (*) noumena ("NOO-men-uh") and observable properties called phenomena that are understood through the "transcendental analytic." This book uses mathematical statements like "7+5=12" to demonstrate that synthetic a priori judgments exist. For 10 points, name this first critique by Immanuel Kant. ANSWER: Critique of Pure Reason [or Kritik der reinen Vernunft] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~29579~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

Answer: Tom Stoppard (The unnamed play in the third line is Stoppard's Travesties. The Invention of Love is about A. E. Housman.)
Text: 14. In a play by this author, a poet's "Darkness" is recited before a flashback of 200 years to when a girl asked if that poet would marry her. In a play by this man, a real-life poet reviews his unrequited love for Moses Jackson while waiting by the River Styx. James Joyce runs a production of an Oscar Wilde work in a play by this author of The Invention of Love. The discovery that a man died of a (*) monkey bite disproves Bernard's theory that Lord Byron killed Ezra in a play by this man. Alfred and the Tragedians rehearse The Murder of Gonzago in a play by this author where two men flip a coin 92 times. For 10 points, name this playwright of Arcadia who parodied Shakespeare in his Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead. ANSWER: Tom Stoppard [or Tomáš Sträussler] (The unnamed play in the third line is Stoppard's Travesties. The Invention of Love is about A. E. Housman.) <Kevin Wang, Literature - British - Drama> ~29809~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

15. A mass use of this tactic in 1923 was inspired by the example of Lord Mayor of Cork, Terence MacSwiney. 5,000 people took to the streets of West Berlin in 1974 after this tactic was used by RAF member Holger Meins. Marion Wallace Dunlop engaged in this tactic in Holloway after stenciling the Bill of Rights on the House of Commons. People who engaged in this tactic were awarded medals by the (*) WSPU and were allowed to recover under the 1913 Cat and Mouse Act. This tactic was employed for 36 days in 1988, the last of several uses of it by Cesar Chavez. In 1981, Bobby Sands died while employing this tactic in a Northern Ireland prison. For 10 points, name this type of non-violent protest that may lead to force feeding. ANSWER: hunger strikes [or dry hunger strikes; accept answers like not eating or self-starvation; prompt on protests or non-violent protests or non-violent resistance or civil disobedience or strike] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30120~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. "Extremal" examples of these objects, for which a equals one, violate a "third law" due to another quantity vanishing. The denominator of a formula for these objects' power contains the coefficient 15,360 times pi. These objects motivated development of the holographic principle. Jacob Bekenstein helped to describe the proportionality between the (*) surface area of these objects and entropy. The only knowable information about these objects is their mass, charge, and angular momentum, according to the no-hair theorem. These objects may evaporate via Hawking radiation, which causes their Schwarzschild radius to decrease. For 10 points, name these objects from which light cannot escape. ANSWER: black holes [prompt on event horizon by asking "what objects contain an event horizon?"] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~30045~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. The step dances of this city's Jenkins Orphanage Band were adapted into the musical Runnin' Wild. A competition named for this city ends as dancers fall into a pool in a scene from It's a Wonderful Life. A song named for this city featuring a dotted quarter, eighth rhythm by James P. Johnson involves "rock steps." In one opera, dancers perform to Jasbo Brown in this city before a (*) craps game. Performers swing their arms as they kick with their toes in and heels out in a dance named for this city and performed by flappers in a 1920s craze. An opera character in this city's Catfish Row sings that "Fish are jumpin' and the cotton is high" in the lullaby "Summertime." For 10 points, Porgy and Bess is set in what city in South Carolina? ANSWER: Charleston [accept the Charleston] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Ballet/Dance> ~30568~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

18. In this novel, a man declares "there ain’t no sin and there ain’t no virtue. There’s just stuff people do" when describing how he always slept with women after church. Passages describing how "the smell of rot fills the country" and "the men sat still - thinking - figuring" are among this novel’s sixteen "inner chapters." A woman threatens her son with a jack handle for suggesting to split their family up in this novel. At this novel's end, a woman gives birth in a flooding (*) boxcar and breastfeeds a starving man. This novel's protagonist goes on the run after clubbing a man who murdered an ex-preacher and labor organizer, Jim Casy. For 10 points, Tom Joad travels to California during the Dust Bowl in what John Steinbeck novel? ANSWER: The Grapes of Wrath <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~29726~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

19. Sexually explicit graffiti may depict an affair between this non-Jewish ruler and the architect of the "holy of holies" in which it was found. An artwork commissioned by this ruler depicts another kingdom's overweight queen Ati. The architect Senenmut designed a room called the Djeser-Djeseru ("JEH-ser jeh-SEH-roo") and two obelisks flanking the entrance to the Temple of Karnak for this ruler. Reliefs in this ruler's mortuary temple at (*) Deir el-Bahri depict shipments of frankincense and myrrh from an expedition to Punt. This ruler's likeness was systematically defaced by Thutmose III, for whom this pharaoh had previously served as regent. For 10 points, a false beard was often used to depict what longest-reigning female pharaoh? ANSWER: Hatshepsut [or Hatchepsut; or Hatasu] <Forrest Weintraub, History - World - African> ~29542~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

20. These people refer to a type of shapeshifting witch by how they "go on all fours." Insect and bat humans existed in the Black World, the first of four worlds formed in these people's creation story. A child-eating giant in these people's myths is tricked into breaking his own leg by a figure who also helps his wife Changing Bear murder her brothers. These people are largely reluctant to discuss their legends of (*) skin-walkers with outsiders. They're not the Hopi, but these people believe a rock formation in the Canyon de Chelly ("shay") houses the Grandmother Spider, who leads the creatures in their creation story Diné Bahane. For 10 points, name this largest federally recognized Native American nation, located in the southwest. ANSWER: Navajo nation [accept Diné before read] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~29780~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

21. According to his son Christopher, this artist was highly influenced by Mozart's music and desired to "raise painting to the level of poignancy of music." Clyfford Still inspired this artist's late-career shift from surrealist to "multiform" paintings. This artist's visit to the Villa of the Mysteries may have inspired the use of lithol red in a series of nine paintings intended for a New York City (*) skyscraper. Fourteen large canvases painted in dark hues decorate an octagon-shaped chapel named for this artist in Houston. This artist aimed to "ruin the appetite" of anyone who saw his murals of dark rectangles that were originally commissioned for the Seagram Building. For 10 points, name this Latvian-American color field painter. ANSWER: Mark Rothko [or Markus Yakovlevich Rothkowitz; accept Rothko Chapel] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - 1945+> ~29857~ <Editor: Ganon Evans> NSC 2025 - Round 03 - Bonuses

1. The oldest temple to this goddess at Cytherea depicts her "armed." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this Greek goddess whose main domain stands in stark contrast to her warlike "Areia" aspect, which may come from her Sumerian origins in the goddess Inanna. ANSWER: Aphrodite [accept Aphrodite Areia; accept armed Aphrodite; reject "Venus"] [10e] Pausanias claimed that Aphrodite Areia was actually a female version of this Greek war god, with whom Aphrodite committed adultery. ANSWER: Ares [reject "Mars"] [10h] In a possible attempt to de-emphasize her war aspect, Zeus tells Aphrodite "war is not your department" after she approaches him in response to a long one of these passages in which Pandarus is killed and Aeneas's hip is crushed by a rock-wielding hero. ANSWER: aristeia [or aristia; accept aristeia of Diomedes] (Diomedes wounds Aphrodite during his aristeia in the Iliad.) <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~24595~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

2. Wnt ("WINT") and Notch are pathways for the "paracrine" and "juxtacrine" types of this process, respectively. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this general process by which cells communicate with each other and their environments. Hormones are involved in this process in which second messengers perform transduction. ANSWER: signaling [accept paracrine signaling or juxtacrine signaling or cell signaling or cell–cell signaling or signal transduction] [10m] Wnt signaling involves a family of these receptors called Frizzled. These GTP-hydrolyzing receptors with an acronymic name pass through the cell membrane seven times. ANSWER: GPCRs [or G-protein-coupled receptors] [10h] Frizzled forms a co-receptor with receptors of these particles, LRP5 and 6. ApoB blood tests measure concentrations of these particles alongside similar "intermediate" ones. ANSWER: low-density lipoproteins [or LDLs; accept VLDLs or ULDLs or very low-density lipoproteins or ultra low-density lipoproteins; prompt on lipoproteins or cholesterols; prompt on chylomicrons by asking "to what class of structures do they belong?"] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~24575~ <Editor: David Bass>

3. This play originally ended with a family taking up arms in defense against their new neighbors, inspired by the author's father Carl's involvement in a Supreme Court case against restrictive covenants. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this play, which ends with Mama grabbing a houseplant as the Younger family moves out.  ANSWER: A Raisin in the Sun [10e] This playwright of The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window wrote A Raisin in the Sun. ANSWER: Lorraine Hansberry [or Lorraine Vivian Hansberry] [10h] Robert O'Hara's staging of A Raisin in the Sun for this group drew controversy for adding an ending scene in which the Youngers see the n-word graffitied onto their new home. This organization’s eponymous Off-Broadway venue in Lower Manhattan premiered For Colored Girls, Topdog/Underdog, and Hamilton. ANSWER: the Public Theater <Michael Bentley, Literature - American - Drama> ~25045~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

4. Philip Ewell's article "Music Theory and the White Racial Frame" quotes this theorist's belief that notes in the octave don't have "equal rights." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this virulently racist Austrian music theorist. This theorist's namesake analysis reduces music to a fundamental progression called the ursatz. ANSWER: Heinrich Schenker [accept Schenkerian analysis] [10e] Because the minimal ursatz outlines the scale degrees "3, 2, 1," a common parody of Schenkerian analysis holds that all music reduces to this nursery rhyme whose title animals get their tails cut off. ANSWER: "Three Blind Mice" [10m] Harmonically, the minimal ursatz outlines a progression from tonic to this function and back to tonic. The V ("five") chord has this function. ANSWER: dominant function <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~24531~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

5. During World War II, the US 1st Marine Division adopted this ballad by Banjo Paterson as their official march. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this song, which "the Band Played" in an Eric Bogle song memorializing the Gallipoli campaign. It is considered Australia's "unofficial national anthem." ANSWER: "Waltzing Matilda" [or "And the Band Played Waltzing Matilda"] [10h] Bogle's song laments how Australian troops "were butchered" at Suvla Bay during Gallipoli, though they mostly fought at a cove with this name. William Birdwood commanded a corps of this name. ANSWER: ANZAC [or Australian and New Zealand Army Corps] [10e] Bogle's song was written to protest participation in this war. Harold Holt pledged he was "all the way with LBJ" during this war, which included the Tet Offensive. ANSWER: Vietnam War [or Second Indochina War; prompt on Indochina War] <Cooper Roh, History - World - Miscellaneous> ~24695~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. The nth term in this series includes a rank-n tensor with two-n-plus-one components. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this mathematical series that is used to approximate the electrostatic potential at large distances from a charge distribution. ANSWER: multipole expansion [10e] The monopole term in the multipole expansion is given by this law. A Frenchman names this inverse-square law that is central to electrostatics. ANSWER: Coulomb's law [10m] Higher-order terms of the multipole expansion feature Legendre polynomials evaluated at this function of the quantity alpha, which relates the vectors r and r-prime. Via Taylor expansion, this function is often approximated as "one minus x-squared-over-two." ANSWER: cosine <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24779~ <Editor: David Bass>

7. One of the first works of "big history" was this author's The Outline of History, which sold 10 times more than any of his novels in his lifetime. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this author who also advocated for a "World-State" of unified nations, which inspired the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights. ANSWER: H. G. Wells [or Herbert George Wells] [10e] Later "big history" writer Jared Diamond argued that these weapons, along with "Germs" and "Steel," were key to Eurasian hegemony. ANSWER: guns [accept firearms or muskets or rifles] [10m] Yuval Noah Harari's "big history" book Homo Deus has also been called an "end of history book," a reference to this political scientist’s influential 1992 book The End of History and the Last Man. ANSWER: Francis Fukuyama [or Francis Yoshihiro Fukuyama] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~21072~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: Patricia Highsmith Guy and Bruno trade murders in a Patricia Highsmith novel titled for Strangers on one of these vehicles. Anna Karenina kills herself by being hit by one of these vehicles. ANSWER: a train A clock ticking during this event titles a story in Highsmith's Mermaids on the Golf Course. In the third stave of a novella titled for this event, the protagonist is asked, "Are there no prisons? Are there no workhouses?" ANSWER: Christmas
Text: 8. This one-time comics writer often stuffed some of her 300 pet snails in her pockets while traveling. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this author whose time working in Bloomingdale's toy department inspired the character Carol in her lesbian novel The Price of Salt. ANSWER: Patricia Highsmith [or Claire Morgan; or Mary Patricia Plangman] [10e] Guy and Bruno trade murders in a Patricia Highsmith novel titled for Strangers on one of these vehicles. Anna Karenina kills herself by being hit by one of these vehicles. ANSWER: a train [accept Strangers on a Train] [10m] A clock ticking during this event titles a story in Highsmith's Mermaids on the Golf Course. In the third stave of a novella titled for this event, the protagonist is asked, "Are there no prisons? Are there no workhouses?" ANSWER: Christmas [accept A Clock Ticks at Christmas; accept A Christmas Carol]  <Michael Bentley, Literature - British - Other> ~25066~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

9. This animal received little attention in classical Chinese culture, making it a safe symbol during the Maoist era. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this animal, two of which were gifted to the US during Nixon's visit to China. Its diet is mostly bamboo. ANSWER: giant panda [or panda bear; or Ailuropoda melanoleuca; or dàxióngmāo] [10h] Two brothers from this family described hunting a giant panda in the book Trailing the Giant Panda. At his estate of Sagamore Hill, the patriarch of this family wrote the book Through the Brazilian Wilderness. ANSWER: Roosevelt [accept Theodore Roosevelt or Kermit Roosevelt] [10m] A panda named Chi Chi brought to this city's zoo in 1958 inspired the logo of the World Wildlife Fund. The now-abandoned Penguin Pool in Regent's Park in this city is a celebrated Modernist structure. ANSWER: London <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~24925~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

10. The 9th Aga Khan Award for Architecture recognized two buildings named for this company that use an eight-pointed star floor plan inspired by the Rub el Hizb. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this state-owned company that names a pair of César Pelli-designed towers connected by an iconic sky bridge. ANSWER: Petronas [accept Petronas Towers] [10e] The Petronas Towers' star-shaped floor plan has drawn comparisons to Delhi's Qutb complex, the site of one of these tall, slender towers found at mosques. ANSWER: minarets [or manāra or midana; accept Qutb Minar] [10h] This architect's star-shaped complex for the Petronas University of Technology won in the 10th Aga Khan Award cycle. This architect's firm designed Hong Kong International Airport and the HSBC Building. ANSWER: Norman Foster [or Norman Robert Foster] <Sean Farrell, Fine Arts - Architecture> ~24709~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

11. The TV show Zum Blauen Bock was largely set at one of these locations. For 10 points each: [10h] Identify these locations, one of which is next to a thousand-year-old business in Munich called Weihenstephan. Patrons historically bring their own food to eat at tables in these outdoor locations. ANSWER: beer garden [or Biergarten; prompt on gardens or pubs or taverns or drinking establishments] [10e] Beer gardens first developed in Munich, the capital of this state in southern Germany, the largest state by area in Germany. ANSWER: Bavaria [or Free State of Bavaria; or Bayern] [10m] At the Zur Sonne beer garden in this city, you can still buy pretzels from roaming brezelbuben. West Germany's busiest airport was in this city, which is the most populous city in the state of Hesse. ANSWER: Frankfurt [or Frankfurt am Main] <Michael Bentley, Geography - Europe> ~25523~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

12. Using larger electrodes in this technique requires safety equipment with a higher shade number. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this technique that, when performed with a namesake electric arc, uses either an inert shielding gas or the byproduct slag to prevent contamination. ANSWER: welding [or arc welding] [10h] Arc welding can produce slag by melting this type of material that composes the core of a consumed wire. This type of material, which shares its name with a physical quantity, removes oxides in soldering. ANSWER: flux [10e] Shielding gas is needed when welding with a non-consumable electrode made of this metal. Incandescent lightbulb filaments are made of this metal with atomic symbol W. ANSWER: tungsten <Sean Farrell, Science - Other Science> ~24618~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: songs (Dàndàn yōuqíng is a Teresa Teng album.)
Text: 13. Dàndàn yōuqíng ("yoh-CHING") was an adaptation of many poems from the Tang and Song dynasties into works in this medium. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this medium. The cí ("tsih") style of poetry was typically paired with a work in this medium such as Shuǐdiào Gētóu, whose most notable pairing was written by Sū Shì. ANSWER: songs [accept melodies or reasonable descriptions of musical pieces] (Dàndàn yōuqíng is a Teresa Teng album.) [10m] Sū Shì wrote a cí lyrical work and two fù-style odes about this location inspired by a Three Kingdom's battle in which Zhūgē Liàng legendarily summoned the eastern wind. ANSWER: Red Cliffs [accept Chìbì or Battle of Chìbì or Battle of Red Cliffs] [10e] The last line of Sū Shì's cí "Riverside City" depicts this celestial object which Lǐ Bái legendarily died trying to embrace the reflection of. ANSWER: moon [or yuè] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24543~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

14. This philosopher wrote the Misopogon ("miss-aw-PO-gohn"), or Beard-Hater, to satirize philosophers after he was mocked for his beard in Antioch. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this philosopher and nephew of Constantine I, who, according to Libanus, was assassinated by a Christian soldier at Samarra for espousing Neoplatonic Hellenism. ANSWER: Julian the Apostate [or Julian the Philosopher; or Flavius Claudius Julianus; or Ioulianos] [10e] Julian wrote the satirical The Caesars, in which he praised this stoic Roman emperor who wrote Meditations. ANSWER: Marcus Aurelius [or Marcus Aurelius Antoninus] [10m] While Julian was Caesar in this province, he wrote a consolation after Salutius was reassigned. Galba put down the Vindex revolt in this region, some of whose inhabitants performed a wicker man sacrifice. ANSWER: Gaul [accept Gallia; prompt on France] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~25103~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

15. This thinker's model of impression management analogizes social interaction as a theatrical performance. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this sociologist who analyzed total institutions in Asylums. His contributions to the symbolic interactionist tradition include The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life. ANSWER: Erving Goffman [10h] This social marker reduces the bearer "from a whole and usual person to a tainted, discounted one" according to Goffman's book titled for it. This perception is related to labeling. ANSWER: stigma [or word forms such as stigmatization] [10e] In one work, Goffman analyzed ads containing stereotypes of this concept. Judith Butler discussed performativity in a book titled for this concept's "trouble." ANSWER: gender [accept Gender Advertisements or Gender Trouble] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Sociology> ~26008~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

16. Shen-hsiu ("shen-sh'YO") anonymously wrote a verse comparing the body to this object. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this object in the Platform Sutra that Huineng ("HWAY-nung") compares to the mind and a mirror with no stand. The demon king Mara tempted a man who placed his hand on the ground near this object for the "earth witness" mudra. ANSWER: Bodhi tree [or Mahabodhi tree or Bo tree; accept tree of awakening or tree of enlightenment; prompt on fig tree or sacred fig or Ficus religiosa] [10m] In a scene from the Platform Sutra, Huineng ("HWAY-nung") hears a man recite the Diamond Sutra, which is grouped with sutras on the perfection of this concept referred to by the Sanskrit word prajñā ("PRUJ-nyah"). ANSWER: wisdom [accept Perfection of Wisdom Sutras] [10e] The Platform Sutra claims wisdom is of one essence with this action, which the Buddha did to attain enlightenment under the Bodhi tree. ANSWER: meditation [accept word forms such as meditate or meditating] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Buddhism> ~25437~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

17. This character states that "there's no question of heroism" in what he does and that it is only "a matter of common decency." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this character who hears of his wife's death in a sanatorium right after his close friend, Tarrou, succumbs to illness. Soon after, he finally reveals himself to be the narrator of events such as Paneloux's ("PAH-nuh-loo's") death. ANSWER: Dr. Bernard Rieux ("bair-NAR ree-UR") [or Dr. Bernard Rieux] [10e] Bernard Rieux narrates The Plague, a novel by this French author of The Stranger. ANSWER: Albert Camus ("al-BAIR kah-MOO") [10m] In The Plague, Tarrou frequently visits these locations in Oran before they are closed due to the epidemic. In The Stranger, Meursault ("mur-SOH") shoots an Arab man at one of these locations. ANSWER: beaches [or plages; prompt on answers identifying shores or coasts] <Tora Husar, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~11830~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

18. Answer the following about grass in the military history of the American frontier, for 10 points each: [10m] Thinking it was laden with silver, this man raided a Mexican mule train carrying grass. Davy Crockett died alongside this man at the Alamo, where illness forced him to cede command to William Travis. ANSWER: James Bowie ("BOO-ee") [10h] After Andrew Myrick allegedly told members of this tribe to "eat grass," his corpse's mouth was found stuffed with it. 38 members of this tribe were hanged in America's largest one-day mass execution. ANSWER: Dakota Sioux [or Santee; or Yanktonai; prompt on Sioux; reject "Lakota"] [10e] Many Plains Indians refer to Little Bighorn as the "Battle of the Greasy Grass," while many other Americans know it as this cavalry commander's "Last Stand." ANSWER: George Custer [or George Armstrong Custer; accept Custer's Last Stand] <Cooper Roh, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24818~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

19. Kelly Grovier argues that the choice of using an exotic cockatoo in this device makes it an updated version of the Annunciation. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this title device of a 1768 painting, which is managed by a philosopher while a young man holds a stopwatch. ANSWER: air pump [accept An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump; prompt on pump] [10e] Joseph Wright of Derby's ("darby’s") candlelit paintings like An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump exhibit tenebrism, an example of this technique championed by Caravaggio that uses highly contrasting colors. Its name is derived from the Italian for "light" and "dark." ANSWER: chiaroscuro [10m] This other British artist’s own experiments included developing wax-infused paint and verdigris pigment. This founder of the Royal Academy painted Sarah Siddons as the Tragic Muse. ANSWER: Sir Joshua Reynolds  <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~25040~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

20. A Julia package known as this type of substance .jl ("dot J-L") is used to model chemical reaction networks. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these substances that lower the activation energy of a reaction, causing it to speed up. ANSWER: catalysts [or catalytic] [10h] Chemical reaction networks can be simplified by applying this assumption to zero out certain ODEs. This assumption is applied to the concentration of the enzyme–substrate complex in Michaelis–Menten kinetics. ANSWER: quasi-steady state approximation [or QSSA] [10m] Fitting a CRN model involves estimating examples of this quantity that have subscripts "plus one," "minus one," and "cat" in Michaelis–Menten kinetics. This quantity fully determines the kinetics of a zeroth-order reaction. ANSWER: reaction rate constant [or reaction rate coefficient; prompt on lowercase k; prompt on reaction rate; reject "capital K"] <David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~24550~ <Editor: June Yin>

21. A wartime organization for women with this profession required them to attend charm school in the spring. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this profession that some women took up during World War II. Black members of this profession included Bullet Rogan and Oscar Charleston. ANSWER: baseball players [prompt on athletes or sports or players] [10e] This major league team's owner founded the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League in 1943 to maintain interest in the sport. His father names this team's home stadium Wrigley Field. ANSWER: Chicago Cubs [prompt on Chicago] [10m] Women in World War II were also encouraged to fill newly vacant factory jobs, as exemplified by a poster of an athletic woman saying this four-word phrase. ANSWER: We Can Do It! <Forrest Weintraub, History - American - 1865-1945> ~24486~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

1. A crank appeared on an accessible model of these devices with a REX-fader called the Bolex H16. One of these objects appears to walk in a 1929 work titled for it that focused on machine workers in Kiev and Odessa. An early standard for gauge for these devices, which has been eclipsed by types named for 35 or 70, names a type of them called the Super 8. People who handle these objects may be assisted by a focus puller or clapper loader. A "kino-eye" film by Dziga (*) Vertov ("JEE-guh VARE-tov") is titled for a "Man" with one of these objects. The Lumière brothers developed pins on celluloid within these objects, which may be tilted for a Dutch angle or moved back for a dolly zoom. For 10 points, name these objects that output stock onto film reels. ANSWER: movie camera [or motion-picture camera or film camera or cine-camera; accept Man with a Movie Camera] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Film> ~30058~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. "Graveyards" formed by this process are a putative source of LLSVPs. Folds occurring at this process’s "hinges" can cause rollback or serve as "anchors." Flux melting occurs within regions into which this process introduces volatiles like water. Accretion is often paired with this process, which is the driving force behind ultra-high-pressure metamorphism. Deep-focus earthquakes can be driven by this process at the (*) Wadati–Benioff zones that it creates. During slab suction, masses undergoing this process contribute to mantle convection. Volcanic island arcs are formed by this process, whose namesake "zones" make up the Ring of Fire. For 10 points, name this process in which one tectonic plate slides beneath another. ANSWER: subduction [prompt on continental collision or tectonic plate collision or underthrusting] <Sean Farrell, Science - Other Science> ~29663~ <Editor: David Bass>

3. Inflatables shaped like these objects were hoisted as tear gas shields during 2020 Thai democracy protests. A Chinese meme from the 2010s placed giant Florentijn Hofman ("floor-en-TINE HOFF-man") sculptures of these objects in front of Tank Man. A picture book titled for 10 of these items by Eric Carle and a Curtis Ebbesmeyer study that modeled ocean currents were based on a 1992 spilling of thousands of these objects from a cargo ship. Explaining lines of (*) code to one of these objects is one approach to debugging. Ernie from Sesame Street had a #16 hit with a song about these toys, which, despite their name, are usually made from plastic vinyl and not a vulcanized material. For 10 points, name these yellow bath toys. ANSWER: rubber ducks [or rubber duckies; accept rubber duck programming or rubber duck debugging or rubberducking or 10 Little Rubber Ducks; prompt on toy duck or duck or duckie or Friendly Floatees; prompt on toys or bath toys; prompt on big yellow duck] <Ganon Evans, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~30324~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

4. "Twenty-five-thousanders" migrated to help these places. A term meaning "fist" was used to characterize people who operated large examples of these places as enemies of the state. Theft from these places was punishable by death under the Law of Spikelets. A sovkhoz ("sohv-KOHZ") was one of these places run by the state, in contrast to a kolkhoz ("kol-KOHZ"). Successful owners of these places were prosecuted during the first (*) Five-Year Plan. These places were forced to cooperate with each other under the policy of collectivization, and they were often owned by kulaks. Policies that lowered the output of these places caused the Holodomor in Ukraine. For 10 points, Joseph Stalin imposed impossibly high quotas on grain production from what places? ANSWER: farms [accept answers describing where farming or agriculture is done; accept (grain or wheat) fields; accept collective farms or collectives; accept ferma; accept kolkhoz or sovkhoz until read] <Rohan Kher, History - European - 1900+> ~29673~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

5. This play's premiere was derailed when an actor lost her voice while playing a character who asks of an elm "what is that tree?" This play inspired the logo of the MAT ("M A T") theater, whose breakout production of it featured the author's wife Olga Knipper as a character who complains about "decadent rubbish." In this play, the appearance of a pair of red eyes is accompanied by (*) sulfur as part of a lakeside Symbolist performance, which is enjoyed by the doctor Dorn but ridiculed by Sorin's sister Irina Arkadina. In this play, Boris Trigorin is loved by the amateur actor Nina, who is in turn loved by the writer Konstantin Treplev. For 10 points, name this Anton Chekhov play in which Nina compares herself to the title bird. ANSWER: The Seagull [or The Gull or Cháyka] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Drama> ~29756~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

6. A Gustave Le Bon book titled for these things claimed that they were "feminine" and caused "deindividuation." "Information cascades" are described in a book by James Surowiecki titled for these things. These things "can sooth or threaten to break out in storms" according to a book on them "and Power" by Elias Canetti. An account of an ox-weighing contest spawned a thesis named for the (*) "wisdom" of these things. A visit to Brussels by the photographer Nadar prompted the first use of "French barriers," which are often used to control these things. Crushes named for these things have occurred at Hillsborough Stadium and the Astroworld Festival. For 10 points, name these things that may form at mass gatherings. ANSWER: crowds [accept The Crowd: A Study of the Popular Mind; accept The Wisdom of Crowds; accept Crowds and Power; reject synonyms like "groups" and "masses"] <Michael Bentley, Social Science - Other> ~30098~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

7. This essay complains that novelists rarely describe meals before recalling a lunch of soles and partridges, where its narrator laughs at the thought of people humming poems. A beadle scares off a "little fish" of a thought by telling this essay’s narrator to keep off the grass. This essay laments that the narrator could have been talking about "astronomy, relativity, geography" if (*) Mary Seton's mother had learnt "the great art of making money," and discusses a novel in which "Chloe liked Olivia." This essay imagines a woman impregnated by the actor Nick Greene who kills herself—the hypothetical Judith Shakespeare. For 10 points, name this Virginia Woolf essay which asserts that women need money and the title place to write. ANSWER: "A Room of One's Own" <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Other> ~31138~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

8. This industry was the main focus of Lawrence C. Wroth, who highlighted the work of Dinah Nuthead and Sarah Updike Goddard. A Nipmuc man called James, who was named for working in this industry, collaborated with the missionary John Eliot. The oldest surviving product of this industry from what is now the U.S. is a 1640 psalter ("SOL-tur"). Quick-to-produce objects in this industry produced by people like John Dunlap were termed (*) "broadsides." William Cosby was the target of a leader of this industry named John Peter Zenger. Many products of this industry had to bear a revenue mark per a 1765 act. For 10 points, the Stamp Act affected what industry, whose practitioners used presses with movable type? ANSWER: printing industry [or publishing industry or printers or publishers; accept James Printer; prompt on book industry or newspaper industry or journalism or press or movable type by asking "what's the broader industry they are a part of?"; prompt on religion or evangelizing by asking "in what medium were these products?"] <Joseph Krol, History - American - Pre-1865> ~28771~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

9. This is the geometry with the smallest coordination number that has the point group D-sub-3h. This molecular geometry is found at the transition state of a nitrogen atom that undergoes umbrella inversion. The most common Lewis acid catalyst for Friedel–Crafts reactions has this geometry. In an SN1 reaction, the loss of a leaving group forms a carbocation ("carbo-CAT-ion") with this geometry. An empty p-orbital explains why molecules such as phosgene and (*) formaldehyde have this geometry. This geometry is found in molecules with sp2 hybridization, such as boron trifluoride, whose bonds form 120 degree angles with each other. For 10 points, name this flat molecular geometry that consists of three substituents around a central atom. ANSWER: trigonal planar [prompt on triangular or triangle; prompt on planar] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~30791~ <Editor: June Yin>

10. Interesting insects from this country include Rhytidoponera mayri, a gold-collecting ant, and the cathedral termite, which build 26-feet-tall towers and feast on spiky spinifex grass. The name "Benjamin" was wrongly given to the last-known member of a species in this country noted for its stiff tail. Another mammal from this country with electroreception delivers venom through (*) spurs on their hind legs. Long-toed stints gather at the salty Lake Paruku in this country's Great Sandy Desert. A part of this country provides the common name for the now-extinct Thylacine. To protect sheep farmers in this country, a gigantic fence was erected to keep out dingos. For 10 points, name this large country home to the kangaroo. ANSWER: Australia [or Commonwealth of Australia] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~30170~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

11. After this figure banishes the moon to practice witchcraft, Selene laughs at this figure for being distressed at preventing the deity's coupling with Endymion. A shell worn by this figure holds the sap of a crocus-like flower that sprung from Prometheus's ichor and grants invulnerability to bronze and fire. This figure throws chopped-up remains into a boiling pot to de-age a ram. This figure summons the keres ("KEE-reez") to bewitch the bronze guardian of (*) Crete. King Aegeus offers refuge to this figure in exchange for an infertility cure. Burning poison is slathered onto robes this figure gifts to her ex-husband's new bride Glauce ("GLAU-kay"). For 10 points, name this princess of Colchis who uses magic to aid her husband, Jason. ANSWER: Medea <Kevin Thomas, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~29677~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

12. One of this author’s characters tries to start a relationship with his friend’s sister, whose piano playing mesmerized him when she was 17. At the start of a novel by this author, adults fear a child is trying to trick them by claiming to remember the time of his birth. The title concept of a novel by this author collapses due to a man with a peony tattoo on his chest. Guido Reni's painting (*) Saint Sebastian exemplifies one of this author's narrators' obsession with dying young men. At the end of a novel by this author, Mizoguchi decides to live after failing to burn down a temple. For 10 points, what author wrote about the repressed Kochan in Confessions of a Mask and also wrote The Temple of the Golden Pavilion? ANSWER: Yukio Mishima [or Kimitake Hiraoka; accept names in either order] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30756~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

13. An ear made from this material by the Bolognese sculptor Anna Morandi wowed Catherine the Great. Dr. Philippe Curtius moved from making anatomical models from this material to exhibiting sculptures made from it in Paris. John Flaxman created models and designs with this material, which were then turned into pottery by Josiah Wedgwood. A sculptor in this material opened a gallery known for its Chamber of Horrors, which featured (*) masks of people guillotined during the French Revolution. A molten form of this material is poured in following the mold-making step in a process for bronze casting called the "lost [this material]" method. For 10 points, name this material used to make the bodies of the sculptures displayed at Madame Tussaud's. ANSWER: wax [accept beeswax; accept lost wax method] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~25187~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

14. "Base–emitter" and "collector–base" forms of this quantity appear in ratios of this quantity that are exponentiated and then decremented in the Ebers–Moll model. A form of this quantity that equals four-R-k-T-delta-f is caused by thermal agitation in Johnson–Nyquist noise. This quantity is the left-hand side of an elementary equation whose "microscopic" form states "E equals J over sigma." A spike in (*) current through a diode arises upon surpassing the "threshold" value for this quantity. Values for this quantity around a closed loop sum to zero in one of Kirchhoff's laws. Electric field can be expressed as this quantity over a given distance. For 10 points, name this quantity that Ohm's law gives as current times resistance. ANSWER: voltage [prompt on V; prompt on potential difference or electric potential] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~29570~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. Griselda Blanco used affectionate names to refer to this man in letters suggesting a secret romance. This man instructed Alberto Prieto, nicknamed "The Swiss," to activate a voice recorder that turned out to be a bomb. Virginia Vallejo ("vah-LAY-hoh") claimed that an organization led by this man funded M19's siege of the Palace of Justice. This man used a phrase meaning "lead or silver" when carrying out (*) bribes. This man's Hacienda Nápoles ("NAH-poh-less") housed many exotic animals, including four hippos that would create an ongoing ecological crisis. Steve Murphy and Javier Peña wrote about their time investigating an organization led by this man with the DEA. For 10 points, name this leader of the Medellín ("meh-day-YEEN") cartel, a Colombian "king of cocaine." ANSWER: Pablo Escobar [or Pablo Emilio Escobar Gaviria] <Lalit Maharjan, History - World - Latin American> ~29643~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

16. A folk song from this ethnic group uses a compound triple meter called semachi and inspired a set of variations for band by John Barnes Chance. A conductor of this ethnicity will succeed Riccardo Chailly ("sha-YEE") as La Scala's music director. A composer of this ethnicity wrote the opera Alice in Wonderland and a cello concerto whose first movement "Aniri" imitates pansori music. The lyrics to a folk song from this ethnicity begin with the title nonsense word and the word (*) "arariyo." Nationalists of this ethnicity often use its folk song "Arirang" to promote unity between two countries. For 10 points, Unsuk Chin and Myung-Whun Chung are members of what ethnicity whose music notation was standardized under Sejong the Great? ANSWER: Koreans [or Hanguk-in; or Hanminjok; or Hancha; or Joseon-in; accept North or South Korean; accept Variations on a Korean Folk Song] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~29693~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

17. Maurice Strong was the first CEO of a Crown Corporation primarily in this industry, which PM Joe Clark attempted to dismantle. By the 1970s, half of this industry in Canada was controlled by the multinational "Seven Sisters." Price swings in this industry caused problems in "equalization" under Pierre Trudeau, whose NEP targeting this industry exacerbated "Western alienation." Canadian centers for this industry have included Leduc No. 1 and (*) Fort McMurray. Prices in this industry have an outsized effect on the budget of Alberta. Canada's alliances in the Yom Kippur War made it an initial target in a 1970s "crisis" in this industry. For 10 points, name this industry serviced by the Dakota Access Pipeline. ANSWER: oil industry [or petroleum or petrochemical industry; accept oil drilling or oil sands industry or crude oil industry or natural gas industry or fossil fuel industry or gasoline industry; prompt on energy industry or power industry] <Lalit Maharjan, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~29665~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

18. In this book, God praises the son of Eleazar, a priest named Phinehas, for turning people away from idolatry. A king tries to get a prophet to curse Israel from a mountain peak named Peor ("PAY-or") in this book. A group in this book describe themselves as grasshoppers in comparison to the Nephilim. In this book, Balak is instructed three times to build seven altars to idol gods by (*) Balaam, whose donkey refuses to move upon seeing the Angel of the Lord blocking the road. After the twelve spies are dispatched in this book, only Joshua and Caleb return with a good report of milk and honey flowing in the Land of Canaan. Two censuses taken of the Israelites inspired the name of, for 10 points, what fourth book of the Hebrew Bible? ANSWER: Book of Numbers [or Bemidbar or Arithmoi] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Hebrew Bible> ~30547~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

19. This poet asks "who dares to…Buy Him a Coca-Cola or a beer" in a poem musing "I think it must be lonely to be God." This poet wrote a mock epic about a girl "whom the higher gods forgot, whom the lower gods berate." This poet of "My dreams, my works, must wait till after hell" wrote "The loveliest lynchee was our Lord." This poet of The Anniad wrote that "dinner is a casual affair" for "Two who have lived their day" and are "Mostly Good" in a poem about an (*) "old yellow pair." People who "sing sin" and "thin gin" are "Seven at the Golden Shovel," in a poem by this author of A Street in Bronzeville and "The Bean Eaters." For 10 points, name this African American poet who wrote "We / Jazz June. We / die soon" in "We Real Cool."  ANSWER: Gwendolyn Brooks [or Gwendolyn Elizabeth Brooks] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~29759~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

20. This adjective names cells whose size is subject to Henneman’s size principle. This adjective names two structures that provide much of the input to the CST and lie adjacent to the "[this adjective] supplementary area." This adjective and "upper" name cells of the CST whose malfunction can cause Babinski's sign. This adjective and "lower" name cells of the anterior horn that are targeted by (*) poliovirus. Two cortices in the frontal lobe are named for this adjective preceded by "pre" and "primary." Efferent neurons, which are also known by this adjective, release acetylcholine and carry signals out from the CNS, unlike sensory neurons. For 10 points, give this adjective that describes neurons responsible for movement. ANSWER: motor [accept motor cortex or primary motor cortex or premotor cortex or supplementary motor area or motor neurons or upper motor neurons or lower motor neurons or motor units; accept motoneurons; prompt on efferent until read by asking "what is the more common name for efferent neurons?"] <Rohan Kher, Science - Biology> ~30090~ <Editor: David Bass>

21. James Puckle's square-bullet machine gun was intended for use against this empire. A different kingdom's nobles plotted the Magnate Conspiracy after an unpopular peace with this empire was signed at Vasvár. Bakers may have created a food called a kipferl to celebrate a victory over this empire. This empire relinquished control over Morea in the Treaty of (*) Karlowitz. Troops fleeing a rout of this empire's army at Kahlenberg Mountain left bags of coffee beans used to establish cafés. That battle included history's largest cavalry charge and resulted in defeat for this empire at the hands of Jan Sobieski's Winged Hussars. For 10 points, what empire's failed 1683 siege of Vienna saw the defeat of its Janissary troops? ANSWER: Ottoman Empire [or the Sublime Ottoman State or Devlet-i Aliye-i Osmaniye; accept Sublime Porte or Sublime Gate; accept the Turkish Empire; reject "Turkey"] <Cole Hartung, History - European - 1500-1900> ~29681~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower> NSC 2025 - Round 04 - Bonuses

Answer: Amy March Amy is the youngest March sister in this Louisa May Alcott novel. ANSWER: Little Women Amy draws contrasting sketches of this character lying on the grass and taming a horse to scold him for laziness. Amy marries this man, who proposes to her on a boat in the Alps after proposing to Jo. ANSWER: Laurie
Text: 1. This character is given a lobster watch charm after her basket is overturned, spilling out a lobster intended for a dinner of her art school classmates. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this character, based on the author's artist sister. This girl complains about people who "label your father if he isn't rich" and is made to throw out pickled limes. ANSWER: Amy March [prompt on March] [10e] Amy is the youngest March sister in this Louisa May Alcott novel. ANSWER: Little Women [10m] Amy draws contrasting sketches of this character lying on the grass and taming a horse to scold him for laziness. Amy marries this man, who proposes to her on a boat in the Alps after proposing to Jo. ANSWER: Laurie [or Theodore Laurence; or Theodore Laurence; or Laurie Laurence] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~26083~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: Thomas Eakins (The unnamed painting is The Gross Clinic.)
Text: 2. As part of a 2023 Super Bowl wager, Kansas City's Nelson-Atkins Museum exhibited this artist's painting Sailing on loan from the Philadelphia Art Museum. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this artist, who, in an 1875 painting, depicted a clerk taking notes above a mother recoiling from her son receiving a surgery. ANSWER: Thomas Eakins (The unnamed painting is The Gross Clinic.) [10e] For 2025, the Nelson-Atkins loaned out a painting of a croquet ("crow-KAY") match by this artist. This French artist depicted Victorine Meurent ("muh-RAHN") in Luncheon on the Grass and Olympia. ANSWER: Édouard Manet [10h] After a Bengals loss in 2022, the Cincinnati Art Museum gave up Patience Serious by Robert Henri, a leading member of this art movement, whose gritty paintings include Cliff Dwellers and The Wrestlers. ANSWER: Ashcan School [accept The Eight; prompt on realism] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - U.S. to 1945> ~25512~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

3. Titus Salt made Bradford, England a center of processing fiber imported from this country's alpacas. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this coastal Andean country that, with Bolivia, fought the War of the Pacific against its southern neighbor, Chile. ANSWER: Peru [or Republic of Peru] [10m] Charles Ledger's scheme to steal a bunch of Peruvian alpacas violated a Peruvian export law that sentenced offenders to hard labor mining this resource, which was harvested on the Chincha Islands. ANSWER: guano [accept fertilizer or bird poop or manure; prompt on phosphate or nitrogen by asking "what type of product is that used in?"] [10h] Ledger avoided capture on his alpaca heist by placing this substance in his captor's drink. In the Victorian era, this opium-infused drink was often given to infants and to women suffering from menstrual cramps. ANSWER: laudanum <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22170~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: periodic (The publication is "Periodic cooking of eggs.")
Text: 4. This property names a method for hard boiling eggs published by Di Lorenzo et al. 2025. For 10 points each: [10m] Give this property possessed by both functions that can be represented as Fourier series and the trigonometric functions summed in Fourier series. Bloch's ("block's") theorem describes wavefunctions in potentials with this property. ANSWER: periodic [prompt on sinusoidal] (The publication is "Periodic cooking of eggs.") [10e] Fourier series were pioneered to study this thermodynamic quantity's namesake PDE. This form of energy, denoted "Q," equals m c delta-T. ANSWER: heat energy [prompt on thermal energy] [10h] Di Lorenzo et al. model this quantity via distinct affine functions of temperature for egg white versus yolk. Fourier names the statement that heat flux equals this quantity times the negative gradient of temperature. ANSWER: thermal conductivity [prompt on k or kappa or lambda] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~25519~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. These figures are the Satya Yuga manifestations of Jaya and Vijaya, two gatekeepers who are cursed by the Four Kumaras to be reincarnated and killed. For 10 points each: [10h] Name either of these two asuras who, with their sister Holika, torment the child Prahlada. One of these two similarly named brothers is killed by Varaha for attacking Bhumi, while the other is killed by Narasimha. ANSWER: Hiranyaksha ("HEE-rahn-YAK-shuh") OR Hiranyakashipu ("hee-RAHN-yah-kah-SHEE-poo") [accept Hiranyanetra in place of "Hiranyaksha"; accept Hiranyakashyap in place of "Hiranyakashipu"] [10e] Hiranyakashipu torments Prahlada for his bhakti to this god, leading him to be killed by Narasimha, an avatar of this preserver deity. ANSWER: Vishnu [10m] The deaths of Hiranyaksha and Hiranyakashipu are recounted in the "Bhagavata" ("BAH-guh-VUH-tuh") one of these texts, of which there are 18 major and 18 minor ones. ANSWER: Puranas [accept Bhagavata Purana; accept Mukhya Puranas or Major Puranas; accept Upa Puranas or Minor Puranas] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~25488~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

6. David Harrington founded one of these ensembles named Kronos after hearing George Crumb's piece Black Angels. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this chamber music ensemble consisting of two violins, a viola, and a cello. ANSWER: string quartet [prompt on quartet or Kronos quartet] [10h] Critic Robert Greenberg argued that the title "electric insects" of Black Angels' first movement represent these objects. The third scene of the opera Mittwoch aus Licht ("MITT-voke aus LISHT") consists of a string quartet titled for these objects. ANSWER: helicopters [accept Helicopter String Quartet or Helikopter-Streichquartett] (Mittwoch aus Licht is by Karlheinz Stockhausen.) [10m] "Night of the Electric Insects" is a movement in this genre written to lament the Vietnam War. Krzysztof Penderecki ("k'SHISH-toff pen-de-RETS-kee") wrote a piece in this genre "to the victims of Hiroshima." ANSWER: threnody ("THREN-uh-dee") [accept Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima or Tren pamięci ofiar Hiroszimy] <Aum Mundhe, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~24584~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

7. Answer the following about Saddam Hussein's relationship with ancient Mesopotamia. For 10 points each: [10m] Hussein restored the staircases to the terraces of the Great Ziggurat of Ur and placed planes created by this company next to it. Soviet fighter planes created by this company included the "25" variant. ANSWER: Mikoyan [or MiG; or Mikoyan-Gurevich] [10e] An elite division of Hussein's Republican Guard was named for this Babylonian king, whose namesake "Code" outlines "an eye for an eye." ANSWER: Hammurabi [or Hammurabi's Code; accept the 1st Hammurabi Armoured Division] [10h] Eric Cline compared Hussein's invasion of Kuwait to this ruler's war against King Hezekiah. This son of Sargon II reveled in the torture of Elamites from Nineveh. ANSWER: Sennacherib [or Sin-akheeriba] <Ganon Evans, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~24785~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

8. Small archaeal modifier proteins, or "SAMPs," may serve the same purpose as this protein. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this protein that can be conjugated in chains to either lysine residues or N-termini of other proteins by the E3 ligase activity of a SCF ("SKIFF") complex. ANSWER: ubiquitin [or ubiquitination or ubiquitinylation or ubiquitylation or polyubiquitination or polyubiquitinylation or polyubiquitylation; accept ub] [10m] The SCF-Dia2 complex poly·ubiquitin·ates Cdc6 to prevent ectopic "licensing" of this process. This process begins at "origins," or "ORIs," that are "recognized" by proteins like ORC1. ANSWER: DNA replication [10e] Cdc6 and ORC1 are the same protein in Archaea, indicating that they have this evolutionary relationship, contrasted with "analogous," in which two proteins share an ancestral origin. ANSWER: homologous [or homologs or homology] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~24573~ <Editor: David Bass>

9. In a semi-autobiographical novel, Gisèle Pineau describes Man Ya's "exile" from this archipelago by her patriotic son Maréchal. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this archipelago that's also home to the Belles-Feuilles estate in Maryse Condé's Wuthering Heights adaptation, Windward Heights. ANSWER: Guadeloupe [10e] In Exile According to Julia, Pineau describes the racism she faced while growing up in this capital city that forms the setting of The Hunchback of Notre Dame. ANSWER: Paris, France [10m] Pineau's writings are associated with a Caribbean offshoot of this literary movement, whose founder described his return to the Antilles in a Notebook of a Return to the Native Land. ANSWER: négritude (The other author is Aimé Césaire.) <Cole Hartung, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24781~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

10. Possessed individuals rub themselves with clarin rum mixed with hot peppers during a Vodou festival held in these places named Fèt Gede ("fet gay-day"). For 10 points each: [10e] Name these non-ofrenda places that people often visit during Día de los Muertos to be with their ancestors. ANSWER: cemeteries [or cemetery; or graveyards; accept equivalents to tombs or graves or burial sites] [10h] During Fèt Gede, offerings are made to the first man buried in a cemetery as well as the first woman in honor of this lwa. Like Erzulie Dantor, this mother of the Gede has a heart vèvè and is a protector of women. ANSWER: Maman Brigitte ("ma-MA bree-ZHEET") [or Manman Brigit; accept Gran Brigitte; prompt on Maman or Manman] [10m] Similar to Día de los Muertos, Fèt Gede begins on a day named for these people. Matanza sacrifices honor orishas in a Yoruba-derived religion named for these people. ANSWER: saints [or santos; accept All Saints' Day; accept Santería] <Sean Farrell, RMP - Other Religion> ~24719~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: EM algorithms (Andrew Ng's CS229 lecture notes use this motivating example.)
Text: 11. A use case for this method is to fit a mixture of Gaussians to data when the Gaussians to which observations belong are unobservable. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this class of iterative optimization algorithms that alternate between two namesake steps by first probabilistically defining a latent variable and then performing MLE to update parameter values. ANSWER: EM algorithms [or expectation–maximization algorithms] (Andrew Ng's CS229 lecture notes use this motivating example.) [10m] The "E" step uses this statement to get posterior probabilities for the latent variable from prior probabilities. This statement names a statistical approach contrasted with frequentism. ANSWER: Bayes’ theorem [or Bayes’ law or Bayes’ rule; prompt on Bayes or Bayesian statistics] [10e] "E" stands for expectation, which is a name for this quantity that equals the sum of n values divided by n. ANSWER: mean [accept sample mean or arithmetic mean or average; prompt on mu] <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~24577~ <Editor: David Bass>

12. Jean-Jacques Rousseau, who wrote that "this little island [would] astonish Europe," was later invited to contribute to this island's law code. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this Mediterranean island. In 1755, Pasquale Paoli founded an early Enlightenment republic on this island. ANSWER: Corsica [or Corse] [10h] Paoli was popularized internationally by this author's An Account of Corsica. The Whig historian Thomas Macaulay claimed this man, who chronicled the author of Rasselas, lived "without delicacy, without shame." ANSWER: James Boswell [10e] Leo Damrosch wrote that Corsica did end up astonishing Europe, but only because it produced this future French emperor who invaded Russia in 1812. ANSWER: Napoleon Bonaparte [or Napoleon Bonaparte; or Napoleone di Buonaparte; or Napoleon I] <Yingzhi Nyang, History - European - 1500-1900> ~25156~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

13. For 10 points each, identify the following about ethics dumping, a practice where scientists go abroad to conduct unethical research. [10e] A 2015 trial for a vaccine for this virus in Africa violated the Declaration of Helsinki. This virus has an innocuous Reston strain and a deadlier one that killed 10,000 West Africans in the 2010s. ANSWER: Ebolavirus [accept Ebola virus disease or Ebola hemorrhagic fever] [10m] An Indian control group was offered no screening for this type of cancer. Gardasil protects against the virus that causes most instances of this fourth-most-common cancer in women. ANSWER: cervical cancer [or cancer of the cervix] [10h] Liliane Bettencourt once controlled this French company, which has outsourced its animal testing to Africa. This company bought Aesop in 2023. ANSWER: L'Oréal Paris <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~13348~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. A "Stranger" named for this city appears in Plato's dialogue The Statesman. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this city. In a namesake Platonic dialogue, the founder of a philosophical school named for this city attacks the theory of forms with the "Third Man" infinite regress. ANSWER: Elea [accept word forms like Eleatic; accept the Eleatic Stranger; accept the Eleatic School] (That dialogue is Plato's Parmenides.) [10e] These rhetoricians, whom Socrates often criticizes for fallacious arguments, title the first Platonic dialogue to feature the Eleatic Stranger. Their name comes from the Greek for "wisdom." ANSWER: Sophists [accept The Sophist or Sophista; accept word forms like Sophism] [10m] Most dialogue in The Sophist occurs between the Eleatic Stranger and Theaetetus, the namesake of a Platonic dialogue that argues that this three-word phrase is equivalent to knowledge. ANSWER: justified true belief [accept "orthos doxa with a logos" or true belief with an account; prompt on JTB by asking "what phrase does that stand for?"; reject partial answers] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~24484~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

15. Answer the following about 20th-century French novels with musical motifs, for 10 points each: [10e] Charles Swann comes to associate a sonata by Vinteuil ("van-TOY") with Odette in the first volume of this author's very long novel In Search of Lost Time. ANSWER: Marcel Proust ("proost") [or Valentin Louis Georges Eugène Marcel Proust] [10m] In this novel by Jean-Paul Sartre ("SART-ruh"), "Some of These Days" is the favorite song of the existentially-obsessed writer Antoine Roquentin ("an-twan ROH-kun-tan"). ANSWER: Nausea [or La Nausée] [10h] A musical direction from a Diabelli sonatina, which the protagonist's son is learning, titles this author's novel Moderato cantabile ("mod-eh-RAH-toh can-TAHB-ee-lay"). This author's other works adapted to film include The Lover and the screenplay Hiroshima mon amour. ANSWER: Marguerite Duras ("doo-RAHSS") [or Marguerite Germaine Marie Donnadieu] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~25956~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

16. Richard Fenno names a paradox questioning why these people are so popular, given the unpopularity of the body they belong to. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these people, whom Fenno theorized as having a "Hill style" and a "Home style." These people possess the franking privilege. ANSWER: members of Congress [accept Congresspeople or Congressmen or Congresswomen or representatives; accept Senators; accept members of the House of representatives; prompt on politicians or legislators or incumbents by asking "what office do they hold?"] [10e] Description acceptable. The "Home style" hypothesis seeks to explain the "advantage" named for candidates of this type. Candidates of this type win roughly 90% of House elections. ANSWER: incumbent [accept word forms; accept answers indicating that the candidate is currently in Congress, or is running for reelection] [10h] Edmund Burke argued that good representatives act as these people, often contrasted with delegates. These people use their wisdom and judgment to legislate in the best interest of the whole. ANSWER: trustees <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Other> ~25611~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

17. You are the loader in an M1 Abrams tank. Answer the following about the science of your ammunition, for 10 points each. [10e] The "depleted" form of this element comprises the dense, dart-like penetrator in your armor-piercing shell. As it contains only a small amount of this element's 235 isotope, you shouldn't worry about radioactivity. ANSWER: uranium [or U] [10m] You are also equipped with a shell that creates a smokescreen by exposing this allotrope of phosphorus to air. This flammable allotrope owes its volatility to its strained tetrahedral structure. ANSWER: white phosphorus [or yellow phosphorus; or tetraphosphorus; or P4] [10h] Both depleted uranium and white phosphorus spontaneously ignite upon contact with air, a property known by this term. ANSWER: pyrophoricity [prompt on combustible or combustibility] <Cooper Roh, Science - Chemistry> ~24747~ <Editor: June Yin>

18. For over 30 years until her death, Marion Stokes recorded American TV channels 24/7, amassing over 70,000 tapes. For 10 points each: [10m] Stokes began her 24/7 recording of TV with news footage of what 444-day event, which was nearly stopped by Operation Eagle Claw? ANSWER: Iran hostage crisis [accept descriptive answers like the hostage situation in Iran] [10h] Four shipping containers sent Stokes' collection to this nonprofit organization. In 2001, this organization publicly released a search tool named for a fictional device used by Mister Peabody and Sherman. ANSWER: Internet Archive [reject "Internet" alone] (the search tool is the Wayback Machine) [10e] Upon her death on December 14, 2012, Stokes' last tape included news footage of this mass shooting at a Connecticut elementary school. ANSWER: Sandy Hook Elementary shooting [accept Newtown shooting] <Lalit Maharjan, History - American - 1945+> ~24615~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>
