19. Two answers required. Melody Maker critic Richard Williams praised the "subliminal, uneven 'beat'" of the blank C and D sides to Wedding Album, a release by these two artists. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these two artists who collaborated on two albums titled Unfinished Music. These artists also staged performance pieces such as the Bed-In. ANSWER: John Lennon AND Yoko Ono [or John Lennon AND Ono Yōko] [10h] Two of these sounds are prominent on side one of Wedding Album. One of these sounds features on the intro and outro of Pink Floyd's album The Dark Side of the Moon. ANSWER: heartbeats [or human heartbeats; accept word forms such as the beating of the heart; prompt on heart or beat] [10e] Side two of Wedding Album features John Lennon singing part of the Beatles' "Good Night" in this musical style that imitates instruments using only the human voice. ANSWER: a cappella <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~24743~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

Answer: Rossetti Dante Gabriel Rossetti described a woman with seven stars in her hair waiting in heaven in a poem about a "Damozel" described by this adjective. ANSWER: blessed Another Rossetti poem describes a "Lazy laughing languid" woman of this name, "fond of a kiss and fond of a guinea." A woman of this name "kiss'd me" in a Leigh Hunt poem, and a "Low-Dive" woman of this name imagines becoming a pirate in The Threepenny Opera. ANSWER: Jenny
Text: 20. A poet from this family coined the word "yesteryear" in his translation of François Villon's ("vee-YON’s") Ballad of Dead Ladies. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this family of the author Dante Gabriel, who illustrated his sister Christina's poem "Goblin Market." ANSWER: Rossetti [accept Dante Gabriel Rossetti; accept Christina Rossetti] [10m] Dante Gabriel Rossetti described a woman with seven stars in her hair waiting in heaven in a poem about a "Damozel" described by this adjective. ANSWER: blessed [accept "The Blessed Damozel"] [10h] Another Rossetti poem describes a "Lazy laughing languid" woman of this name, "fond of a kiss and fond of a guinea." A woman of this name "kiss'd me" in a Leigh Hunt poem, and a "Low-Dive" woman of this name imagines becoming a pirate in The Threepenny Opera. ANSWER: Jenny [accept "Jenny Kiss’d Me" or "Pirate Jenny" or Low-Dive Jenny or Jenny Diver] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - British - Poetry> ~24591~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: Norman Mailer (The "fug" book was The Naked and the Dead.)
Text: 21. This author coined the word "factoid." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this author who made his name with a war novel that used the word "fug" as a euphemism for the f word. A 1957 essay by this author helped define "hipster." ANSWER: Norman Mailer [or Nachem Malech Mailer] (The "fug" book was The Naked and the Dead.) [10e] Mailer, who also coined the word "ballsy," first used "factoid" in a book on this actress, a blonde sex symbol of the 1950s who was photographed standing over a subway grate in publicity for her film The Seven Year Itch. ANSWER: Marilyn Monroe [or Norma Jeane Mortenson; prompt on Marilyn] [10m] Mailer defined "factoid" as "newspaper creations ... to manipulate emotion in" this group. A 1969 Richard Nixon speech was addressed to this group which opposed the counterculture and supported the Vietnam War. ANSWER: silent majority [accept great silent majority; prompt on majority] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~26026~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: Qur'an (The lead-in is the Blue Qur’an.)
Text: 1. A widely distributed example of these objects is decorated with gold leaf on indigo and right-angled designs. A "new style" for these objects includes ovals against vegetal backgrounds, like in one commissioned by a Zirid nursemaid. Carpet-like designs on the front of these objects were replaced by sun medallions called shamsa. These objects traditionally have triangles of five gold circles to separate sections marked by red and blue signs. The size of the (*) word "alif" in these objects decides the size of naskh creations. The technique of mashq stretched letters in these objects to take up whitespace produced by kufic ("KOO-fick") script. For 10 points, name this book decorated with calligraphy of surahs about Allah. ANSWER: Qur'an [or Koran; accept musaf or mushaf; prompt on books or manuscripts or folios] (The lead-in is the Blue Qur’an.) <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - World> ~30588~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. A 1960s change to a law of this type led to a rash of "Kennedy husbands" and "Kennedy fathers." The acronym "O H I O" was used to protest a 1940 law of this type, also called the Burke-Wadsworth Act. Destroying documents used to enforce these laws was ruled illegal in the case of US v. O'Brien. On his first day in office, Jimmy Carter issued Proclamation 4483 that pardoned people who had violated one of these laws and (*) fled to Canada. Cards used to enforce one of these laws were widely burned in the 1960s. These laws were enforced by the Selective Service System until a move to an all-volunteer system. For 10 points, name these laws that were "dodged" by young American men who did not want to be sent to Vietnam. ANSWER: the draft [or military conscription; accept selective service; accept mandatory military service] <Michael Bentley, History - American - 1945+> ~29703~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: antibodies (The dimer is CD79, which consists of CD79a and CD79b.)
Text: 3. A variant of these proteins with two additional transmembrane alpha-helices complexes with a dimer of "79a" and "79b" proteins. In CUT&RUN, these proteins are captured by Staph·ylo·coccus aur·eus's protein A and protein G. Components of these proteins consist of 110-peptide repeats characterized by beta-sandwiches. A second rearrangement is needed to include diversity segments in these proteins. Genes for receptors and these proteins are diversified via (*) VDJ recombination. In these proteins, the hinge region connects the Fab ("FAB"), or constant, and Fc, or variable, regions. These proteins' heavy and light chains form a "Y" shape. For 10 points, name these immune system proteins that target antigens. ANSWER: antibodies [immunoglobulins or Abs or Igs or IgGs or membrane-bound antibodies] (The dimer is CD79, which consists of CD79a and CD79b.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~29609~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. Parts of this concept are famously analogized to an arrow shot by an archer and the arrows left in the quiver to be shot. In Shaivism, people are bound by māyā, aṇava, and this concept, which gave rishis their power along with tapasya ("thuh-PUS-ya"). Depending on the quality of this concept, it can either yield papa or punya, analogized by fruits. This concept is usually divided into agami, kriyamana ("kree-uh-MAA-nuh"), prarabdha ("PRAA-rub-dhuh"), and (*) sanchita ("SUN-chih-thuh"). According to Tulsidas, until that sanchita form of this concept is exhausted, moksha cannot be achieved. Because this concept primarily dictates a soul’s path after reincarnation, a bad form of it might lead to a lower-caste birth. For 10 points, name this Hindu concept in which past actions influence future outcomes. ANSWER: karma [or karmo; or kormo; or kawrmaw; or karam] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Hinduism> ~31261~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

5. This man asks a woman, "Shall I live in hope?" and is told, "All men I hope live so." This man crows, "All the world to nothing! Ha!" in a speech in which he muses, "I'll have her, but I will not keep her long." In contrast to a concept which "capers nimbly…to the lascivious pleasing of a lute," this man says he is "rudely (*) stamp'd" and "not shaped for sportive tricks." This man asks, "Was ever woman in this humour won?" after seducing a woman whose husband he killed. This man resolves, "since I cannot prove a lover…I am determined to prove a villain" and yells, "My kingdom for a horse!" For 10 points, name this hunchbacked king who declares "Now is the winter of our discontent" to open his namesake Shakespeare play. ANSWER: Richard III [or Richard Plantagenet; or Richard, Duke of Gloucester; prompt on Richard] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Drama> ~30496~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

6. Shimshon Vigodar organized an Israeli group of this name that staged a 1971 demonstration for better treatment of the Mizrahim. A protest outside the American Embassy by a British group of this name resulted in the arrest of the Mangrove Nine. Seattleites rioted for three days in 1968 after Aaron Dixon, a leader of a group of this name, was arrested for stealing a typewriter. Another group with this name tortured one-time member Alex Rackley and staged a protest of the (*) Mulford Act by open-carrying firearms into a state capitol. A leader of a group of this name, Fred Hampton, was killed by the Chicago PD. For 10 points, give this name of an American party co-founded by Huey P. Newton that advocated for Black power. ANSWER: Black Panthers [or Black Panther Party; accept HaPanterim HaShchorim or British Black Panthers; prompt on Panthers] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~29955~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. This quantity is obtained by performing a Legendre ("luh-ZHON-druh") transform in two variables on internal energy. The derivative of this quantity with respect to the extent of reaction equals zero at equilibrium. This quantity equals the sum over all components of the chemical potential times particle number. For a half-cell, the change in this quantity equals negative the number of (*) electrons transferred times Faraday's constant times the potential difference. At constant temperature and pressure, this quantity is the maximum work extractable from a system. This quantity is defined as enthalpy minus the product of temperature and entropy. For 10 points, what thermodynamic quantity denoted G is named for an American chemist? ANSWER: Gibbs free energy [or Gibbs energy; prompt on free energy; prompt on G or delta-G until read; reject "energy"] <June Yin, Science - Chemistry> ~29744~ <Editor: June Yin>

8. This country's Pentecostal prime minister is served by spiritual advisor Daniel Kibret and is building a ten-billion-dollar "Chaka" palace based on a "seventh king" prophecy. In 2024, this country announced it was leasing another country's land to build a naval base in Berbera. Two hundred people were killed in this country following the 2020 assassination of Hachalu Hundessa, who, like its Prime Minister, was a member of its plurality (*) Oromo ethnic group. This country's Prime Minister won the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize, but a year later, its National Defense Force was accused of ethnic cleansing in a civil war against the Tigray People's Liberation Front. For 10 points, Abiy Ahmed leads what country in the Horn of Africa? ANSWER: Ethiopia [or Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~29752~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. A "deviant" form of this discipline developed by Jan Łukasiewicz ("woo-kuh-SHAY-vitch") was inspired by Aristotle's sea-battle scenario. As a teenager, Saul Kripke introduced models for a form of this discipline concerning applicability in some versus all possible worlds. A many-valued form of this discipline is used to analyze vagueness. In this philosophical discipline, the symbols of a backwards (*) E and an upside-down A are used to represent quantifiers. In classical forms of this field, bivalence implies the "law of the excluded middle." This discipline's "zeroth-order" form concerns propositions and connectives like NOT and OR. For 10 points, what field of philosophy concerns the use of inductive and deductive reasoning? ANSWER: logic [accept zeroth-order logic; accept fuzzy logic; accept first-order logic or predicate logic; accept modal logic; accept three-valued logic or trivalent logic; prompt on mathematics or philosophy of mathematics] <Jim Fan, RMP - Philosophy> ~28086~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

10. A character of this ethnicity notes that a girl "likes looking at the walls" and "linoleum roses on the floor." That character of this ethnicity claims, "I'll shake the sky / like a hundred violins" in a poem that leads her aunt to say, "You must keep writing." An angry dentist leads an author of this ethnicity to wonder how to "tame a wild tongue" in an essay from Borderlands. A character of this ethnicity lives in the title "sad red" (*) building that "says goodbye sometimes." In a series of vignettes, a girl of this ethnicity walks in heels with Lucy and Rachel and is assaulted at a carnival after Sally leaves her. For 10 points, the narrator of The House on Mango Street is of what ethnicity of Chicana authors Gloria Anzaldúa and Sandra Cisneros? ANSWER: Mexican-American [or Chicano or Chicana until "Chicana" is read; prompt on Latino or Latina or Hispanic or Chicanx or Latinx or Latine] <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Misc> ~30459~  <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

11. Angela Gheorghiu ("g'YORR-g'yoo") interrupted a tenor encore in a 2024 performance of this opera to say, "It's a performance. It's not a recital. Respect me." A spinto tenor remembers "sweet kisses, languorous caresses" in an aria from Act III of this opera that begins with a wistful clarinet solo. In Act I of this opera, that tenor describes the "contrasting beauties" of his lover and of a blonde woman he (*) painted as Mary Magdalene. This opera's title soprano gives a safe-conduct pass to the singer of "Recondita armonia" and "E lucevan le stelle" ("ay loo-CHAY-von lay STELL-ay"). In this opera, Baron Scarpia orders a firing squad to execute Mario Cavaradossi. For 10 points, name this Puccini opera that ends with the title diva jumping off the Castel Sant'Angelo. ANSWER: Tosca <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Opera> ~29588~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

12. "[This word] mixing" is a process in which trajectories in non-linear dynamical systems separate linearly, rather than exponentially. This first word in the name of a two-n-dimensional object central to Hamiltonian mechanics is synonymous with "complex argument." In classical mechanics, graphs of momentum versus position that are spanned by the coordinates p-comma-q depict "[this word] (*) space." This word names the value that is multiplied by i in an exponential in solutions to physical systems. This word names a quantity that determines whether interference is destructive. For 10 points, give this word for an angle-like quantity denoted "phi" that describes an offset in the frequency of a wave. ANSWER: phase [accept phase space or phase diagram or phase factor or phase difference] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~29636~ <Editor: David Bass>

13. One of these events is commemorated in a "Luminarie" each December with lights designed by Valerio Festi. That event of this type contributed to a stock market panic that bankrupted Barings Bank. These events were historically visualized in a genre of art named for a catfish deity. Bonds issued in response to one of these events caused a 1927 financial panic that bankrupted many (*) zaibatsu. The Fukuda Village Incident was part of a massacre that followed one of these events. US Ambassador Cyrus Woods relocated to the Imperial Hotel following one of these events in 1923, in which some 10,000 Koreans were scapegoated and massacred. For 10 points, name these natural disasters that include the Great Kanto one. ANSWER: earthquakes [prompt on natural disasters until read] <Michael Bentley, History - World - Asian> ~30943~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

14. It's not anthropology, but the imaginary language Bongo-Bongo is most often used to conceptualize this subfield that titles the magnum opus of Isidore of Seville. This subfield studies rebracketing, in which sets of morphemes are misdivided to yield erroneous results. Scholars within this subfield put asterisks at the beginning of certain words to indicate that they are (*) reconstructions. This subfield partially names a phenomenon in which foreign or unfamiliar words are altered to fit more common linguistic rules, its "folk" type. The comparative method of this subfield can deduce roots from groups of cognates. For 10 points, what subfield of linguistics studies the origin of words? ANSWER: etymology [accept folk etymology; prompt on historical linguistics; prompt on linguistics until read] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Social Science - Linguistics> ~30280~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

15. In a novel by this author, two art specialists fall in love while planning a "Cemetery of Reconciliation." A "scuttling" structure inspired the title of a novel by this author in which a torpedo hits an ocean liner just before the birth of Paul Pokriefke ("powl poh-KREEF-kuh"). This author's late novels include The Call of the Toad and Crabwalk. In a novel by this author, a man fishes for eels near the protagonist's (*) "presumptive fathers" Alfred and Jan ("yan") Bronski. Cat and Mouse and Dog Years end a trilogy by this author, whose first novel describes a boy who prefers to use a third birthday gift rather than speak as he grows up under the Nazi regime. For 10 points, what author wrote about Oskar Matzerath ("MAT-zuh-rat") in The Tin Drum? ANSWER: Günter Grass [or Günter Wilhelm Grass] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~29794~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

16. A religious "League" in this region was tied together by a festival held at the Panionium sanctuary. A naval fleet composed of manpower from Lesbos and this region was defeated at the Battle of Lade ("LAH-day") by opposing forces, possibly led by Datis. This region, which names the first school of pre-Socratic philosophy, houses a city home to A·nax·i·man·der and (*) Thales ("THAY-leez"). An architectural practice named for this region is topped with a design containing two spiral elements above the shaft. Revolts in this region were the first major conflict of the Greco–Persian wars. Along with "Doric" and "Corinthian," this region names an order of classical columns. For 10 points, what region shares its name with a sea to the west of the Greek mainland? ANSWER: Ionia [accept Ionian League; accept Ionian School; accept Ionian Revolt; accept Ionic order; accept Ionian Sea; prompt on Miletus or other cities in Ionia by asking "what larger ancient region was that a part of?"; prompt on Anatolia or Asia Minor] <Lalit Maharjan, History - European - Classical> ~29749~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

17. This adjective describes spaces in which any closed subset C and any point not in C can be separated by neighborhoods. Kolmogorov spaces described by this adjective are Hausdorff because they obey the separation axiom T3. n-dimensional objects described by this adjective are determined by length-n-minus-one Schläfli symbols. Symmetries of objects described by this adjective compose dihedral groups. Uniform (*) tilings consist of shapes described by this adjective. The golden ratio gives the diagonal-to-side length ratio of pentagons described by this adjective. For 10 points, give this adjective that describes the faces of platonic solids, which are polygons whose angles and side lengths are all equal. ANSWER: regular <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~29619~ <Editor: David Bass>

18. A flute solo near the start of this composer's eighth symphony imitates birdsong with the repeated motif "D, short B, E, short B." A fanfare for two trumpets opens the last movement of this composer's G major eighth symphony. A symphony by this composer influenced the first symphonies of Florence Price and Amy Beach. The motif "F, short A-flat, long A-flat" from a slow symphonic movement by this composer was inspired by (*) Harry Burleigh's singing; that symphony's scherzo was inspired by The Song of Hiawatha. An English horn solo in the Largo of this composer's ninth symphony inspired the faux-spiritual "Goin' Home." For 10 points, what Czech composer moved to Spillville, Iowa after completing the New World Symphony? ANSWER: Antonín Dvořák ("d'VORE-zhahk") [or Antonín Leopold Dvořák] <Sinecio Morales, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~27868~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

Answer: sumo (The film in the first line is A Sumo Wrestler's Tail.)
Text: 19. A folk tale about a mouse who performs this activity after eating rice cakes inspired a Ghibli Museum-exclusive film. The Nihon Shoki credits Nomi no Sukune with the first instance of this activity while acting under Emperor Sunin, though the Kojiki instead partially credits the kami Takemikazuchi. The tate-gyoji ("TAH-tay GYOH-jee") wield a large fan to judge this activity and are responsible for the Shinto rites performed for it, including pouring sake ("SAH-kay") at four (*) inner corners. Purification rituals taken before this activity include rinsing the mouth with chikara-mizu or "power water." The dohyō-iri tradition before performing this activity involves walking around a ring-shaped area. For 10 points, name this national sport of Japan. ANSWER: sumo [or sumo wrestling; prompt on wrestling] (The film in the first line is A Sumo Wrestler's Tail.) <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~29605~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: Farsi (The poem in the first line is the Bani Adam from Saadi's Gulistan; the unnamed poem in the third line is Ferdowsi's Shahnameh.)
Text: 20. A poem in this language states, "The sons of Adam are limbs of each other" and is inscribed in the United Nations building. Seven principal voices are used in a 50,000-line poem in this language whose prologue describes an object that makes a "crying sound" after being separated from its bed. In a poem in this language, a character realizes he killed his son after seeing a jewel on his arm. That man rides the stallion (*) Rakhsh and was saved at birth by the simurgh. A poem in this language of the Masnavi begins with a command to "AWAKE!" and consists of AABA rhyme scheme quatrains. For 10 points, what language was used to describe how the "Moving Finger writes; and, having writ, Moves on" in Omar Khayyam's Rubáiyát? ANSWER: Farsi [or Persian] (The poem in the first line is the Bani Adam from Saadi's Gulistan; the unnamed poem in the third line is Ferdowsi's Shahnameh.) <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~29723~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

21. A man in this novel dreams about Jabez Branderham, who preaches a sermon with 491 sections. In this novel, a man sees a name graffitied on a wall with three different last names. In this novel, a man says he was "thrown into the company of a most fascinating creature: a real goddess" before admitting he’s talking about a dog, whose family promptly attacks him. In this novel’s beginning, a man meets (*) Zillah and the "vinegar-faced" servant Joseph, and sees a ghost wailing "I’d lost my way on the moor!" In this novel’s frame story, the housekeeper Nelly Dean tells Mr. Lockwood a story about the history of Thrushcross Grange. For 10 points, name this novel about the doomed romance of Catherine Earnshaw and Heathcliff, by Emily Brontë. ANSWER: Wuthering Heights <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~31302~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson> NSC 2025 - Round 05 - Bonuses

1. Kappa are typically seen as reptilian kami who kill disrespectful humans in this manner. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this fate that befell all humans except Deucalion ("doo-KALE-yun") and Pyrrha in a Greek myth analogous to the Biblical story of Noah. ANSWER: drowning [accept word forms such as being drowned; accept being flooded; prompt on dying or being killed] [10h] In this country, a mythical swamp monster called the Berberoka sucks water out of ponds to drown humans who come to grab dead fish. This country's myths include shapeshifters like the silagan and mandurugo among its aswang. ANSWER: the Philippines [or Republic of the Philippines or Republika ng Pilipinas] [10m] The tale of this ghost is widespread in Latin America, where it is said she can be heard mourning her drowned children near bodies of water, bringing death and misfortune to those who hear her. ANSWER: La Llorona ("yoh-ROH-nah") [accept the Crying Woman or the Weeping Woman or the Wailing Woman or the Wailer] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~25510~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

2. Susanna Clarke has ascribed the statues in Piranesi to various sources, including one based on Mr. Tumnus, a faun from this location. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this world depicted in a set of "Chronicles" including The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. ANSWER: Narnia [accept Chronicles of Narnia] [10m] Piranesi was also influenced by the ideas of Owen Barfield, a member of the informal literary group called the Inklings, which was founded by C.S. Lewis and this other author. ANSWER: J.R.R. Tolkien [10h] The real-life 18th-century artist Piranesi was referenced in this first novel by Susanna Clarke, whose two title characters are magicians in Napoleonic-era England. ANSWER: Jonathan Strange and Mr. Norrell <Sinecio Morales, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25538~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

3. This woman stopped making shirts for her husband when her replacement, Anne Boleyn, ordered that deliveries of linen to her castle be stopped. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this Spanish first wife of Henry VIII. ANSWER: Catherine of Aragon [prompt on Catherine] [10h] A Venetian ambassador wrote about Henry's "fair skin glowing through a shirt of the finest texture" after watching this activity. Anne Boleyn was summoned from watching this activity and placed in the Tower of London. ANSWER: tennis [or real tennis; reject "lawn tennis"] [10m] Henry executed Anne Boleyn a year after he suffered a head injury in this activity that left him unconscious for two hours. Henry II of France was killed after an injury during this activity. ANSWER: jousting [or competing in a tournament; prompt on horseback riding or riding] <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~24942~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. The small features that cover the surface of the Sun are named for their resemblance to these materials. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these materials that form mounds that collapse when above the angle of repose, which equals the arctangent of the coefficient of friction. ANSWER: granular materials [accept solar granules; prompt on grains] [10e] A "granular" analog of this process causes large particles to rise in the Brazil nut effect. The main modes of heat transfer are conduction, radiation, and this process. ANSWER: convection [accept granular convection] [10m] With "convection," this word describes moving bodies of fluid such as solar granules. Circulation in the Earth's atmosphere occurs within structures named for this word and "Hadley," "Ferrel," or "polar." ANSWER: cells [accept convection cells or Hadley cells or Ferrel cells or polar cells] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24977~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. A rumba craze surrounding Cuban music in 1930s America began with a son-pregon ("sohn-pray-gohn") by Moisés Simons ("moy-SAYSE see-MOHNS") named for a seller of this good. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this good whose name is sung on alternating low and high Fs in a 1941 song later used as its artist’s presidential campaign slogan. ANSWER: peanuts [accept "Salt Peanuts; accept maní or "El manisero" or "The Peanut Vendor"] [10e] This jazz musician composed "Salt Peanuts" and pioneered Latin jazz in the United States with songs like "Manteca." This pioneer of bebop played a bent trumpet. ANSWER: Dizzy Gillespie [or Dizzy Gillespie; or John Birks Gillespie] [10m] This Italian-American pianist wrote songs based on Peanuts characters like "Christmas Time Is Here" and "Linus and Lucy" for a jazz album, which, after Kind of Blue, is the second best-selling ever. ANSWER: Vince Guaraldi [accept Vince Guaraldi Trio] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~24509~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

6. This wavelength names the telescope array in Chile that initially reported phosphine in Venus's atmosphere. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this wavelength that, when multiplied by 2.9 kelvin, gives the constant in Wien's ("veen’s") displacement law. ANSWER: one millimeter [or one mm; accept clear equivalents, like 0.1 centimeters or 0.1 cm or 0.001 meters or ten-to-the-negative-three m] [10m] Millimeter astronomy with ALMA detects this compound in interstellar gas via its 2.6-millimeter line. This diatomic compound consists of the third and fourth-most-abundant elements in the Milky Way. ANSWER: carbon monoxide [or CO] [10e] ALMA's 66 dishes are combined by being treated as one of these devices by the ALMA correlator. The Michelson–Morley experiment was performed with one of these devices, which are the "I" in "LIGO." ANSWER: interferometers [accept astronomical interferometers or Michelson interferometers or laser interferometers] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~24590~ <Editor: David Bass>

7. This author wrote about students at a seminary in Kyiv in a tale from the collection Mirgorod. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this author born in modern-day Ukraine, who wrote "The Nose" and "The Overcoat" as well as the novel Dead Souls. ANSWER: Nikolai Vasilyevich Gogol [or Mykola Vasyliovych Hohol or Nikolai Vasilyevich Gogol-Yanovsky or Mykola Vasyliovych Hohol-Yanovskyi] [10h] In this aforementioned story from Mirgorod, a student is forced to pray over the body of the witch he has killed. The witch then summons this story's title creature, who is the king of the gnomes. ANSWER: "The Viy" ("vee") [or "Viy"] [10m] In Mirgorod, "The Viy" is followed by a "tale" of a "quarrel" between two people with this first name. A 19th-century author with this first name wrote Diary of a Superfluous Man and the collection A Sportsman's Sketches. ANSWER: Ivan ("ee-VAN") [accept Ivan Sergeyevich Turgenev or "The Tale of How Ivan Ivanovich Quarreled with Ivan Nikiforovich" or "Povest o tom, kak possorilsja Ivan Ivanovich s Ivanom Nikiforovichem"] <Juliet Mayer, Literature - European - Short Fiction> ~15066~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

8. The Jackbox minigame Decisions Decisions features a variant of this game in which everyone survives if no one takes the money. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this game whose Nash equilibrium is reached when both captives defect. ANSWER: prisoner's dilemma [10h] The prisoner's dilemma arises because defection is a strategy described by this adjective. This adjective denotes strategies that improve a player's payoff regardless of other players' moves. ANSWER: dominant [accept dominance] [10m] In another game, participants secretly choose how many tokens to donate to a shared pot. It models the market for these namesake products, which are non-excludable and non-rival. ANSWER: public goods [or social good or collective good] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Social Science - Economics> ~25531~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

9. The execution of Antonio de Arriaga instigated a rebellion led by a man with this regnal name. For 10 points each: [10m] Give this two-word name of an indigenous Peruvian rebel leader who claimed descent from the final Sapa Inca. That Neo-Incan ruler with this regnal name was executed by the Spanish in 1572. ANSWER: Túpac Amaru [accept Túpaq Amaro] [10e] The first Túpac Amaru claimed descent from Atahualpa, who was executed by this Spanish conquistador, despite offering to pay his ransom with a room of gold. ANSWER: Francisco Pizarro [10h] Túpac Amaru II held this title given to the heads of ayllus ("AYE-loos"), which was the Andean equivalent of a title whose name is the Taíno ("tah-EE-no") word for "chieftain." Name either title. ANSWER: kuraka OR cacique [accept curaca in place of "kuraka"; accept kasike in place of "cacique"] <Cole Hartung, History - World - Latin American> ~24650~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. In major-key pieces in this form, a first theme in the tonic key is contrasted with a second theme in the dominant key. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this form used for the first movements of Classical symphonies and concertos. ANSWER: sonata form [or sonata-allegro form] [10e] Many of this composer's sonata form movements are monothematic since the second theme is a transposed version of the first theme, like in his symphony no. 104. This composer is considered the "father of the symphony." ANSWER: Franz Joseph Haydn [10h] This concerto's introduction immediately subverts the conventions of sonata form by modulating from G major to the distant key of B major. This concerto premiered in 1808 alongside its composer's Choral Fantasy. ANSWER: Ludwig van Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4 [prompt on Piano Concerto No. 4; prompt on Beethoven 4 by asking "for which instrument?"] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Classical> ~24481~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

11. A hypothesis assigns this namesake role to microbes that "shoot the moon" by becoming leaky helpers. For 10 points each: [10m] Give the namesake role of a hypothesis that characterizes evolution as perpetual and cyclic in order to explain sexual reproduction as a response to parasitism. ANSWER: queens [or Red Queen or Black Queen] [10h] Non-Black Queens evolve this trait that is contrasted with prototrophy. The "one gene, one enzyme" hypothesis arose from the study of strains of mold with this trait, which survive on supplemented minimal medium. ANSWER: auxotrophy [or auxotrophic] [10e] Evolution of auxotrophy decreases the length of this construct, the C-value. This construct is the collection of all genetic information in an organism. ANSWER: genome <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~24592~ <Editor: David Bass>

12. Korean hojakdo paintings depict magpies alongside goofy drawings of these other animals meant to satirize the ruling elite. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these animals, one of which cowers in a bush from a lightning strike in an Henri Rousseau painting sometimes titled Surprised! ANSWER: tigers [accept Siberian tigers; prompt on cats] [10m] In the 1800s, a Korean still-life craze centered on trompe l'oeil ("tromp loy") still lifes of teapots and clocks along with these objects. Thousands of meaningless glyphs appear in a Xu Bing ("shoo beeng") installation titled for one of these things. ANSWER: book [accept bookshelves or bookcases; accept chaek or chaekgeori; accept Book from the Sky; accept shu or Tianshu; reject "scrolls"] [10e] A 17th-century "Koreanization" of this genre of painting away from Chinese subjects was led by Jeong Seon. Ink shan shui paintings in this genre in China depicted natural sites like rivers and mountains. ANSWER: landscapes <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - World> ~25251~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

13. This phrase titles an anonymous 1693 novel about an Irish princess that interpolates the tales of the Celtic princess Cluaneesha and of the Inca woman Faniaca. For 10 points each: [10h] Give this two-word subtitle of a novel in which the title teenage maid, Pamela, spurns her employer Mr. B's advances until he makes a proposal of marriage. ANSWER: virtue rewarded [accept Vertue Rewarded; or, the Irish Princess; accept Pamela; or, Virtue Rewarded] [10m] This author's Pamela; or, Virtue Rewarded is one of the first English novels. This author also wrote the epistolary novel Clarissa. ANSWER: Samuel Richardson [10e] This contemporary of Richardson reimagined Pamela as a prostitute who schemes to entrap Squire Booby into marriage in the parody Shamela. This author wrote Joseph Andrews and Tom Jones. ANSWER: Henry Fielding <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~25219~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

14. Answer the following about the feminist and labor activist Luisa Capetillo ("cah-puh-TEE-yoh"). For 10 points each: [10h] In 1915, Capetillo became notorious across the Caribbean after being arrested for performing this action in Havana. William J. Sharkey, a convicted murderer, earned notoriety for performing this action to escape prison. ANSWER: crossdressing [or equivalents like wearing pants or wearing mens' clothes or dressing as a man] [10m] Capetillo organized strikes among workers producing this good in Puerto Rico and Cuba. Hawaii allowed the US military to build a base at Pearl Harbor in exchange for lowering tariffs on this good. ANSWER: sugar [or sugarcane] [10e] At the 1908 AFL convention, Capetillo presented a motion advocating for this cause in Puerto Rico. In 1917, the Silent Sentinels picketed the White House to support this cause. ANSWER: women's suffrage [or equivalents like women's right to vote; or passing the 19th Amendment; prompt on suffrage or suffragette movement] <Jamie Burchett, History - American - 1865-1945> ~24816~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

15. Some art described by this adjective escaped a bonfire in the hope to "at least to make some money from this crap." For 10 points each: [10m] Identify this adjective which names a mocking 1937 exhibition of works by George Grosz and others, staged by the Nazis. ANSWER: degenerate [accept degenerate art or Entartete] [10e] A catalogue of degenerate art was used to prove that Cornelius Gurlitt had a huge trove of stolen art. Gurlitt lived in this neutral European country, whose secretive banking industry was used to launder Jewish gold. ANSWER: Switzerland [or Swiss Confederation] [10h] Some degenerate art is now on view at this city's Art of the Lost Generation museum. An annual music festival in this city always performs Hugo von Hofmannsthal's play Everyman. ANSWER: Salzburg [accept Salzburg Festival or Salzburger Festspiele] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~25062~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. The Marmur–Doty formula enables back-of-the-envelope estimation of this quantity as "four GC plus two AT." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this temperature, greater than the annealing temperature, at which a dsDNA molecule denatures. ANSWER: melting temperature [or melting point; or melting temp; or T-sub-m] [10e] A thermocycler decreases the temperature to below the melting temperature for the "elongation" stage of this technique for amplifying nucleic acids, which is used in many COVID tests. ANSWER: PCR [or polymerase chain reaction] [10h] The melting temperature of qPCR's TaqMan probe is increased by the fusion of a minor groove binder to a peptide with this role at the probe's 3-prime end. Molecules with this role decrease fluorescence, like chloride ions for quinine. ANSWER: chemical quencher [accept word forms like quenching; accept non-fluorescent quencher; prompt on NFQ] <David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~24551~ <Editor: June Yin>

17. In Eastern Orthodoxy, the kairos is said prior to this sacrament as part of the Divine Liturgy. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this sacrament that Catholics hold as having real presence. Many high altars were destroyed when the Council of Trent ordered priests to perform this sacrament facing the entrance to the church. ANSWER: Eucharist [or Holy Communion; prompt on Blessed Sacrament; prompt on but DO NOT REVEAL Lord's Supper] [10e] The Eucharist draws from this event, in which Christ told his apostles that the bread and wine he was giving them were his body and blood and announced that he would be betrayed. ANSWER: The Last Supper [or the Lord's Supper] [10h] This numerically-named text from the Book of Common Prayer affirms the doctrine of real presence in the Eucharist and denies transubstantiation. ANSWER: Thirty-nine Articles of Religion <Michael Bentley, RMP - Christian Practice> ~25072~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

18. A poem titled for these people describes how "Autumn is desolation in the plot / Of a thousand acres." For 10 points each: [10m] Name these people whose headstones "yield their names to the element" "row by row" in an Allen Tate ode. ANSWER: the Confederate dead [accept equivalents such as Confederate soldiers or Confederates; accept "Ode to the Confederate Dead"; prompt on dead people; prompt on soldiers or veterans] [10e] This poet responded to "Ode to the Confederate Dead" in a poem about a monument to Colonel Shaw and his Black soldiers, "For the Union Dead." This Boston confessional poet of "Skunk Hour" was mentored by Tate and lived on his lawn in a tent.  ANSWER: Robert Lowell [or Robert Traill Spence Lowell IV] [10h] "Ode to the Confederate Dead" describes how these objects "plunge and expire." An Oliver Wendell Holmes poem titled for one of these objects describes "the old three-cornered hat" worn by Thomas Melvill. ANSWER: leaves [accept "The Last Leaf"] <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Poetry> ~24678~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

19. In the 1850s, the chemist Henri Étienne Sainte-Claire Deville made an extremely expensive breastplate from this material for Napoleon III. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this essential war material, the major profit center of Charles Martin Hall's Pittsburgh Reduction Company. ANSWER: aluminum [or aluminium or Al] [10m] Alcoa lends its name to a city in this state's Blount County that's home to an aluminum smelting plant. The Clinton Engineer Works at a "secret city" in this state enriched uranium for the Manhattan Project. ANSWER: Tennessee [or TN] [10e] Alcoa left a toxic legacy in Suriname, a country that was a longtime colony of this European country. This modern-day country's East India Company also colonized Indonesia. ANSWER: The Netherlands [or Kingdom of the Netherlands; accept Dutch East Indies; prompt on VOC] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~23041~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. Reporter Jill Burcum chronicled a roof collapse at the Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School in this state's Leech Lake Indian Reservation. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this state whose curling-mad city of Bemidji is near the Red Lake and White Earth reservations. The Vermillion and St. Croix Rivers meet in this state's city of Hastings. ANSWER: Minnesota [or MN] [10e] Bemidji is home to the oldest statue of this legendary lumberjack and his companion, Babe the Blue Ox. This figure's footprints created the 10,000 Lakes. ANSWER: Paul Bunyan [prompt on Paul] [10h] Bemidji hosts one of these events named for Babe the Blue Ox. One of these events traditionally held on Patriots' Day typically starts in Hopkinton and includes the "Heartbreak Hill." ANSWER: a marathon [accept half-marathon or 26k or 5k or 10k; prompt on long-distance running event or athletic competition or race] (The unnamed event is the Boston Marathon.) <Forrest Weintraub, Geography - United States> ~25161~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

21. This property names techniques that are contrasted with regularization. For 10 points: [10m] Name this property of a wavefunction for which the integral of its squared modulus equals one. Dividing Boltzmann factors by the partition function Z imposes this property because their sum equals Z. ANSWER: normalized [accept normalization or renormalization] [10e] A wavefunction's squared modulus gives this quantity by the Born rule. This quantity equals 50% for each state of Schrödinger's cat. ANSWER: probability [or likelihood] [10h] This term describes systems whose eigenbases consist of non-normalized plane waves, motivating a Fourier transform that writes the solution as a wave packet. This term describes a particle subjected to uniform potential everywhere. ANSWER: free [accept free particle] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~25008~ <Editor: David Bass>

1. Activist Margaret Gordon is at the center of Alexis Madrigal's 2025 book about how containerization changed this port city. After this city's Hmong-American mayor Sheng Thao was recalled, 78-year-old Barbara Lee was elected mayor in a 2025 special election. In 2020, this city settled a lawsuit from victims of the Ghost Ship warehouse fire in its (*) Fruitvale neighborhood. A stadium in this city home to the view-ruining "Mount Davis" was home to a team owned by John Fisher that now plays in Sutter Health Park. In 2025, that sports team based in this city temporarily moved to the state capital after failing to secure a replacement for its Coliseum. For 10 points, name this California city, once home to the Athletics. ANSWER: Oakland, California [prompt on Bay Area or San Francisco Bay Area; reject "San Francisco"] <Steven Yuan, Current Events - U.S.> ~30194~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

2. "Exclusion zones" inside of this structure are maintained by the mammalian protein Tpr. Transport of molecules greater than 60 kilodaltons into this structure relies on liquid–liquid phase separation facilitated by intrinsically disordered FG-Nups. This structure contains RCC1, which is a bound GEF that maintains a gradient of high Ran-GTP concentration inside this structure. This organelle's (*) eight-fold-symmetric openings contain cytoplasmic filaments and namesake “baskets.” Traffic into and out of this organelle is mediated by importins and exportins. This organelle's "pore complexes" facilitate transport through its double-bilayer "envelope." For 10 points, name this primary storage center of the cell's DNA. ANSWER: nucleus [or nuclei] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~29614~ <Editor: David Bass>

3. Six months after the end of the Civil War, a member of this organization named R. N. Paynter received James Waddell's surrender of the final Confederate combatants. Members of this organization hosted a dinner where the release of Dr. William Beanes was negotiated. In an 1807 affair, this organization seized four of its ex-members from James Barron as part of a practice that (*) Jay's Treaty had failed to end. A cartoon turtle named "Ograbme" mocked an act that was passed to counter this organization's use of impressment. This force's bombardment of Fort McHenry inspired Francis Scott Key to write "The Star-Spangled Banner." For 10 points, name this military force that opposed US warships during the War of 1812. ANSWER: Royal Navy [or RN; or British Navy; or navy of the United Kingdom; prompt on English Navy or navy; prompt on British military; reject "army"] <Cooper Roh, History - American - Pre-1865> ~29675~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. In a novel by this author, a girl promises to carry a woman off to the moon on a winged horse. That girl chooses "melody Gloucester pegasus" as magic words and is followed with the chant "would you like a cup of tea?” in a novel by this author. Uncle Julian dies when villagers burn the home of Constance and Merricat Blackwood, years after Merricat poisoned their parents, in a novel by this author. This author wrote a story in which (*) Old Man Warner disparages a “pack of crazy fools” and says “[one event] in June, corn be heavy soon.” In that story by this author of We Have Always Lived in the Castle, Tessie Hutchinson cries "It isn't fair, it isn't right" while being stoned to death. For 10 points, name this author of “The Lottery.” ANSWER: Shirley Jackson [or Shirley Hardie Jackson] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Short Fiction> ~30534~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

5. A purported dialogue between a king of this ethnicity and the monk Nagasena that analogizes the five parts of the self to a chariot is collected in the Theravada Buddhist "Questions of Milinda." Eight percent of the inscriptions in Buddhist caves in India represent donors of this ethnicity called "Yavanas." A historical text describes how a king of this ethnicity was outwitted by 10 Indian ascetics called "naked wise men" or (*) gymnosophists. Thomas McEvilley argued that Buddhism influenced Pyrrho, a thinker of this ethnicity, to found his namesake school of skepticism. For 10 points, name this Mediterranean ethnicity whose contacts with Buddhism were facilitated by the Indian conquests of Alexander the Great. ANSWER: Greek [or Hellene or Hellenic; accept Indo-Greek; accept Macedonian] <Weijia Cheng, RMP - Buddhism> ~20451~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

6. Jena's monopoly on manufacturing the "precision" form of this good caused a so-called famine in Britain during World War I that ended with a deal for rubber. Pliny the Elder related how Phoenician sailors accidentally discovered how to make this good when cooking on blocks of natron. George Ravenscroft developed a method to turn coal into the "flint" version of this good. A museum about the history of this good is located in the company town of (*) Corning, New York. People who made this good were confined to the island of Murano in medieval Venice. For the 1851 Great Exhibition, cast iron and plates of this good were used to build the Crystal Palace. For 10 points, name this material essential in making windows. ANSWER: glass [accept plate glass or precision glass or flint glass or crystal glass or lead glass or optical glass; accept lenses; prompt on crystal until read] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~27721~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: Tess of the D'Urbervilles: A Pure Woman Faithfully Presented
Text: 7. A woman in this book is reminded of a Confirmation ceremony when a blind woman recognizes her chickens by touch. While delivering beehives, a man in this novel says that humans live "on a blighted star" after a mail-cart gores the horse Prince. The narrator concludes "It was to be" after asking whether God was distracted or asleep at the end of this novel's first part. A vicar in this novel relents to allow the baby (*) Sorrow to be buried in a churchyard even though he wasn’t formally baptized. This novel's protagonist marries the preacher's son Angel Clare, and is arrested at Stonehenge for stabbing her rapist Alec. For 10 points, name this Thomas Hardy novel named for a milkmaid from an ancient family. ANSWER: Tess of the D'Urbervilles: A Pure Woman Faithfully Presented <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~30502~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

8. The number of fixed points under this operation co-determines a corresponding rencontres ("ruhn-CON-truh") number. This operation is described in the subscript of the Levi-Civita ("LEV-ee chih-VEE-tuh") symbol. This operation's order equals the least common multiple of the lengths of its cycles. This operation has a sign of one if it is equivalent to an even number of transpositions. This operation is an automorphism because it involves (*) bijecting a set onto itself. One in every e ways of performing this operation yields a derangement. Symmetric groups consist of n-factorial ways to perform this operation on n objects. For 10 points, name this operation that yields an ordered rearrangement of a set, contrasted with combination. ANSWER: permutation [prompt on bijection or automorphism until read] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~29578~ <Editor: David Bass>

9. Bryan van Norden questions the authenticity of a part of this book that claims "loyalty and reciprocity" are all that matter. This book condemns licentious musicians and declares that both music and reverence stem from goodness. In this book, the "small man" is contrasted with the humane "gentleman." This book originated the argument that disorder arises when things are not given appropriate (*) names. This book prescribes a less demanding analog of the "Golden Rule" often called the "Silver Rule." "Ruler-subject," "elder and younger brother," and "father-son" are among the five "cardinal relationships" discussed in this book that are governed by filial piety. For 10 points, what book collects the sayings of Confucius? ANSWER: The Analects [or Lúnyǔ] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~30148~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

10. A solo for this instrument beginning "long B-flat, D-flat, C-flat - E-flat, B-flat" opens a ballet suite's slow movement, which precedes a B major finale in 7/4 time. The melody [read slowly:] "long C, grace notes B - C, B, G, E, up to B, long A" begins a solo for this instrument based on a Lithuanian folk song, which is notated in tenor clef. This instrument's solo puts Koschei's court to sleep at the start of a ballet's (*) berceuse ("bair-SOOZ"). A solo in this instrument's highest register opens the orchestral prelude to "The Adoration of the Earth," which is followed by a scene whose irregular stomping was controversial at its 1913 premiere. For 10 points, Stravinsky's Rite of Spring begins with a solo for what low double-reed woodwind? ANSWER: bassoon <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~29692~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

11. This figure names a "cycle" described by Alhena Gadotti that begins with a text often abbreviated "GEN." Samuel Kramer translated a text titled for this figure's death that repeatedly calls him the "lord of Kullab." While in a bar, this figure is told how to cross the sea by Siduri. This figure names a text whose incipit either claims he "saw the deep" or (*) "surpass[es] all other kings." An ax falls from the sky in one of this figure's dreams that his mother, Ninsun, claims foretells the arrival of a companion. An early poem describing this figure's battle in the Cedar Forest is titled for him and Humbaba. For 10 points, name this king of Uruk who travels with Enkidu in a Sumerian epic named for him. ANSWER: Gilgamesh [or Bilgames; accept Epic of Gilgamesh] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~30609~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

12. The number of distinct values of this quantity appears in the superscript of term symbols. This quantity changes in phosphorescence, but not fluorescence, in an example of intersystem crossing. Antisymmetric wavefunctions are often written as Slater determinants of constructs named for this quantity. This quantity and one symbolized L interact in the Russell-Saunders scheme of a "coupling" named for this quantity and (*) "orbit." The multiplicity of this quantity is maximized when filling orbitals using Hund's rule. Due to the Pauli exclusion principle, this quantity must be paired for the two electrons in the same orbital. For 10 points, name this quantity that, for an electron, is symbolized with an up or down arrow. ANSWER: spin angular momentum [accept spin multiplicity; accept spin orbitals; accept spin-orbit coupling; accept spin quantum number; accept multiplicity before read; prompt on intrinsic angular momentum; prompt on s; reject "momentum"] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~30854~ <Editor: June Yin>

13. A pioneer of this profession used his mom's iron to fashion the first slipmat, a felt object that helps in the technique of matching. The high torque of the Technics SL-1200 helps people with this job avoid overshooting. At a back-to-school party in a rec room in the Bronx in 1973, one man in this profession pioneered the technique of preparing another (*) break on a second LP. These people use tools with long switches for crossfading and cueing. Members of this profession may prepare for a transition by listening to headphones with one ear while hearing speakers with the other. For 10 points, name this profession of Grandmaster Flash, who might scratch a turntable while providing a beat for a rapper. ANSWER: DJ [or disc jockey; prompt on producer or record producer or music producer; prompt on musician or rapper or hip-hop artist] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~27350~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

14. This organization sent two letter bombs twenty years apart to Alois Brunner but failed to kill him both times. This organization targeted scientists working at "Factory 333" in Operation Damocles. While working for this organization, Peter Malkin was taught to say the words "un momentito, señor," for a mission that staked out a house on Garibaldi Street occupied by the so-called Ricardo Klement. (*) Simon Wiesenthal briefly worked for and often tipped information to this organization. This organization led several missions to capture criminals who fled to South America, including a 1960 initiative in Buenos Aires that captured Adolf Eichmann. For 10 points, name this Israeli foreign intelligence agency. ANSWER: Mossad [or al-Mōsād; accept Institute for Intelligence and Special Operations; accept HaMossad leModiʿin uleTafkidim Meyuḥadim] <Rohan Kher, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~29657~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: Voltaire ("vole-TAIR") (The first line is about "Poem on the Lisbon Disaster.")
Text: 15. Anthony Hecht translated a poem in which this author asks "would you thus limit God?" and addresses "Woeful mankind, born to a woeful earth!" 73 anti-religious articles in alphabetical order form the "portable" first edition of this author's Philosophical Dictionary. After an attack on a castle in a novella by this author, a Bulgarian captain captures a woman whom he later sells to (*) Don Issachar ("ISS-uh-kar"). In that novella by this author, the Oreillons ("OH-ray-ons") release a protagonist who later finds jewels and gold on the ground in El Dorado. Cacambo tracks down Cunégonde ("koo-nay-GOND") in a novella by this author in which the "best of all possible worlds" is described by Dr. Pangloss. For 10 points, name this author of Candide ("con-DEED"). ANSWER: Voltaire ("vole-TAIR") [or François-Marie Arouet] (The first line is about "Poem on the Lisbon Disaster.") <Ridge Ren, Literature - European - Other> ~21146~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

16. Two sets of artworks in this medium on the lives of Abraham and Cyrus the Great are found in a namesake room of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. An "AE" monogram appears in several artworks in this medium at the Met Cloisters, one of which depicts a "love chain" attached to a pomegranate tree. An artwork named after this medium depicts a club-wielding man who "gives strength to the boys" and may have been its commissioner, (*) Bishop Odo. A Flemish series titled The Hunt of the Unicorn is in this medium, which also names an artwork in which Halley's Comet appears above the coronation of Harold Godwinson. For 10 points, name this medium that popularly titles an embroidered depiction of the Norman Conquest in Bayeux (“BYE-yoo”). ANSWER: tapestries [or tapestry; accept Bayeux Tapestry or The Unicorn Tapestries or Tapestry Room; prompt on embroidery or textiles or fabric or cloth] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~30606~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

17. One of these works that was written after the death of the author's daughter describes a "dewdrop world." A phrase declaring how “spring is passing” in one of these works is used by the author alongside an analogy of the birds and the fishes to describe the sadness of eternal parting with friends. One type of these works found in the collection The Spring of My Life uses a class of words associated with (*) seasons. One travelogue contains a work of this type that describes a thatched hut changing ownership to become a doll's house. A celebrated one of these works describes a frog leaping into an old pond. For 10 points, name these works created by Kobayashi Issa and Matsuo Basho in a traditional 5-7-5 pattern. ANSWER: haiku [accept haikus by Kobayashi Issa or Matsuo Basho; prompt on haibun; prompt on poem] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~31038~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

18. An approach first developed to treat this disorder uses collaborative empiricism. Maria Kovacs developed an assessment for this disorder in children, which is also measured by PHQ-9. An inventory first proposed for diagnosing this disorder assesses beliefs about the world, the future, and the self and was developed by (*) Aaron T. Beck. Sexual dysfunction and emotional blunting are side effects associated with a class of drugs that treat this disorder by limiting the reuptake of a certain neurotransmitter. Cognitive behavioral therapy was first developed to treat this disorder. SSRIs, such as Prozac, are drugs used to treat this condition. For 10 points, name this mental disorder whose symptoms include low mood. ANSWER: depression [or major depressive disorder; or MDD; or clinical depression] <Michael Bentley, Social Science - Psychology> ~30099~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

19. This leader sought to unify his country's churches by espousing a non-denominational movement called Positive Christianity. This leader, whose policies were condemned in the Christmas address, is likely the "mad prophet" described in a work written "with burning anxiety." At Barmen, a declaration rejecting this leader's influence was issued by the Confessing Church. A 1999 book pejoratively labeled (*) Pius XII as this leader's Pope. A pastor wrote about the rise of this leader in his poem "First they came…" Following the 20 July plot, this leader hanged theologian Dietrich Bonhoeffer, an opponent of his euthanasia program. For 10 points, name this dictator who incarcerated priests at Dachau during the Holocaust. ANSWER: Adolf Hitler (The second line refers to Pius XI's encyclical Mit brennender Sorge. "First they came…" is by Martin Niemöller.) <Cooper Roh, History - European - 1900+> ~29708~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

20. Plasma beta is a ratio of two analogs of this quantity, one of which equals B-squared over two-mu-nought. This quantity is recorded in the lower three diagonal elements of the stress–energy tensor. This quantity ceases to decrease when a system reaches choked flow, which is a breakdown of its decrease with cross-sectional area in the Venturi effect. A transducer measures the difference of two forms of this quantity to calculate flow speed in a (*) Pitot ("PEE-toh") tube. A "stagnation" form of this quantity equals the sum of its "static" and "dynamic" forms. The sum of three forms of this quantity, including one written "rho-g-h," is constant via Bernoulli's principle. For 10 points, name this quantity measured in bars or pascals. ANSWER: pressure [or fluid pressure; accept plasma pressure or magnetic pressure; prompt on P; prompt on energy density or normal stress] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~29658~ <Editor: David Bass>

21. In 2019, the "scaly-foot" Chrysomallon squamiferum became the first species from one of these habitats to be added to the IUCN Red List. In 1996, the 60-meter-tall "Godzilla" structure at one of these habitats near Oregon collapsed. One species that congregates in these habitats has hair-like extensions of their shells where colonies of chemosynthetic bacteria live, and is commonly described by the adjective (*) "yeti." The Knorr discovered the first of these habitats in 1977 about 250 miles northeast of the Galápagos. In 1979, researchers from Scripps found the first of these habitats powered by a Black Smoker while using ALVIN. For 10 points, name these deepwater habitats that can get as hot as 700 degrees Fahrenheit. ANSWER: hydrothermal vents [or geothermal vent; accept Black Smokers or White Smokers until "Black Smokers" is read; prompt on underwater or deepwater or deep ocean] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~30165~ <Editor: Michael Bentley> NSC 2025 - Round 06 - Bonuses

1. Description acceptable. To dispel rumors that he was Calvinist, Christophe Plantin produced a Bible with this unique property. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this property first possessed by the Complutensian Bible, drawing from the Vulgate and the Septuagint. ANSWER: polyglot [or diglot; accept descriptions like multiple languages side by side; accept having both Hebrew and Latin translations; accept having both Greek and Latin translations] [10e] Plantin produced his polyglot Bible to prove his loyalty to this king, who sent the Spanish Armada. ANSWER: Philip II [or Felipe II; or Philip the Prudent; or Felipe el Prudente; prompt on Philip or Felipe] [10m] Plantin's Bible is alternatively named for this city, which was sacked in 1576 by soldiers who weren't paid by Philip II. The Spanish later besieged this city in 1585 during the Eighty Years' War. ANSWER: Antwerp [or Antwerpen or Anvers] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - 1500-1900> ~25309~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: cannibalism (The satire is Jonathan Swift's A Modest Proposal.)
Text: 2. A manifesto titled for this practice created the pun "Tupi or not Tupi, that is the question." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this practice that titles that Oswald de Andrade ("jee uhn-DRAH-jee") manifesto. A satire suggests this practice as a way of "lessening the number of Papists" and making certain people "beneficial to the public." ANSWER: cannibalism [accept anthropophagy; accept the Anthropophagic Manifesto or the Cannibalist Manifesto or the Manifesto Antropófago; accept any answer describing eating children or babies; prompt on eating] (The satire is Jonathan Swift's A Modest Proposal.) [10h] Augusto de Campos was inspired by the Cannibalist Manifesto and founded a branch of a poetry movement named for this substance. That poetry movement most notably creates “shaped” poems. ANSWER: concrete [or concreta; accept concrete poetry] [10e] Both Oswald de Andrade and Augusto de Campos were from this South American country where authors wrote in Portuguese. ANSWER: Brazil [or Federative Republic of Brazil or República Federativa do Brasil] <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24821~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

3. In the Völuspá, a völva states that these three figures engraved their names on a wooden tablet. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this group made up of Urðr ("URR-thur"), Verðandi ("VER-thun-dee"), and Skuld, three goddesses who weave the threads of fate. ANSWER: Norns [or Nornir] [10e] The Norns also ensure the health of this object. To gain knowledge of the runes, Odin hung himself from this world tree for nine days and nine nights. ANSWER: Yggdrasil [accept Hoddmímis holt or Mímameiðr] [10h] The third of the Norns, Skuld, is described as holding one of these objects that represents another role. Two members of a group sometimes named in English for these objects, Göndul and Skögul, are sent to choose who should join Odin as einherjar ("ayn-HAIR-yahr") in the Hákonarmál. ANSWER: shields [accept shieldmaidens or shield-goddesses; prompt on valkyries by asking "what object are they alternatively named for?"] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~25555~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

4. Answer the following about art in the films of the late David Lynch, for 10 points each. [10e] On Twin Peaks, the hallway of the "red room" contains this ancient Greek sculpture of a love goddess lacking both her arms. ANSWER: Venus de Milo [or Aphrodite of Melos] [10m] Also on Twin Peaks, the imagery of Laura Palmer's body may have been inspired by this artist's early work "Wrapped Woman." This artist hung orange nylon from hundreds of gates in Central Park with his partner Jeanne-Claude. ANSWER: Christo [or Christo Vladimirov Javacheff] [10h] Several Lynch sets were inspired by abandoned textile factories in this country, the implied setting of Inland Empire. A sculptor from this country used burlap to create headless sculptures, recreated in the installation Agora. ANSWER: Poland [or Republic of Poland or Rzeczpospolita Polska] (The unmentioned artist is Magdalena Abakanowicz.) <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~25545~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

5. The DZero and CDF experiments analyzed data from a device named for this unit. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this unit, 13.6 of which can be reached by collision energies in the LHC. This unit is the approximate rest mass energy of eight Higgs bosons or six top quarks. ANSWER: TeV [or tera·electron·volt; accept equivalents like one trillion electron volts or 10-to-the-12 eV; reject "electronvolt" or "eV"; prompt on Tevatron] [10m] Despite the nine TeV energy of the sphaleron, the LHC cannot sufficiently concentrate energy to observe sphalerons converting these particles into antileptons. These hadrons consist of odd numbers of quarks. ANSWER: baryons [10e] Sphalerons require such high energy concentration because their length scale is one percent of these baryons’ length scale. These particles contribute positive charge to atomic nuclei. ANSWER: protons [prompt on p] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~25552~ <Editor: David Bass>

6. Michael Spence's cost-minimizing model concludes that this activity contributes to economies of scale. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this economic activity that may promote welfare by reducing search costs. This activity, a component of marketing, is done to increase the demand for a product and may use commercials. ANSWER: advertising [or ads or advertisement; prompt on promotion] [10m] In saturated markets, advertising may operate as this type of cost unrelated to the level of output. These costs often form a barrier to entry. ANSWER: fixed costs [10h] Advertising may mitigate or exacerbate this economic situation whose extreme form is a monopoly of knowledge. George Akerlof discussed how this situation leads to adverse selection. ANSWER: asymmetric information [accept information asymmetry] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~26173~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

7. Historian John Livengood argued against the prevailing wisdom that Richard Willstätter prevented the widespread adoption of this technique until the 1930s. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this technique invented by Mikhail Tsvet, in which the mobile phase separates into components as it passes through a stationary phase. ANSWER: chromatography [accept column chromatography] ("Tsvet" is the Russian word for "color," which is sometimes cited as an example of nominative determinism.) [10h] Livengood cites a debate between Tsvet and Leon Marchlewski to argue that chromatography was initially unpopular because it didn't employ this then-ubiquitous process, whose products are separated from the mother liquor. ANSWER: crystallization [or recrystallization; or recrystallizing] [10m] Tsvet developed chromatography to extract this biomolecule whose porphyrin ("POR-fur-in") ring contains a central magnesium atom. ANSWER: chlorophyll [accept chlorophyll a or chlorophyll b] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~25529~ <Editor: June Yin>

8. A 1959 book by Philippe Halsman is titled for this action, which he encouraged people like Grace Kelly to do in portrait photos so that the "real person" appeared. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this physical action performed by a man near an overturned ladder in a puddle in an Henri Cartier-Bresson photo. ANSWER: jumping [accept synonyms such as leaping or bouncing or hopping or springing; accept being in the air; prompt on falling] [10h] The Jump Book features a snapshot of this curator of the Family of Man photo exhibition. A 1904 picture by this artist depicts moonlight faintly glowing through a line of trees and onto a body of water. ANSWER: Edward Steichen [or Edward Jean Steichen] [10e] A more pensive series by Halsman depicts this scientist in his library. Arthur Sasse captured this scientist with wild hair and sticking his tongue out at a camera. ANSWER: Albert Einstein <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Photography> ~25489~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

9. The Valencian-language book Tirant lo Blanch ("blahnk") belongs to this genre's "chivalric" subtype. For 10 points each: [10m] What genre of historical fiction has a name now used in English for a type of genre fiction? This genre's name is cognate to the French and German for "novel." ANSWER: romance [accept roman or chivalric romance] [10e] Tirant lo Blanch is saved from being burned in this Miguel de Cervantes novel, whose protagonist reads so many romances that he acts like a knight. ANSWER: Don Quixote [or The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha or El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quixote de la Mancha] [10h] The title character of Tirant lo Blanch fights for this state, whose own romance genre inspired Cervantes's last novel. This historical state's literature included Acritic songs and a history that a princess wrote about her father. ANSWER: Byzantine Empire [or Eastern Roman Empire; accept Byzantine romances or Byzantine novels; prompt on Roman Empire] (The history is the Alexiad.) <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~24508~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

10. The British defeated the forces of a sultanate on this archipelago in the shortest recorded war. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this archipelago which the Sultan of Oman seized in 1698. This archipelago later merged with Tanganyika. ANSWER: Zanzibar [10h] Under the Omani Sultan Said bin Sultan, Zanzibar increased production of this spice, giving the archipelago its nickname of "Spice Islands." ANSWER: cloves [10e] The Anglo-Zanzibar war was partly incited by British orders to end this practice in Zanzibar. Tippu Tip built an empire based on this practice, whose chattel form was later abolished. ANSWER: slave trade [accept slavery; accept word forms like selling or enslaving people] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - World - African> ~25528~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

11. The Sunshine Protection Act passed the Senate in 2022 to make this system permanent. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this system of setting the clocks forward one hour so the sun is out longer in the evening. ANSWER: daylight saving time [or daylight savings time; or DST] [10m] Congress overrode this man's veto and abolished daylight saving time a year after it was first instituted. This president passed the Underwood–Simmons Act to lower tariffs and was supported by his wife Edith. ANSWER: Woodrow Wilson [or Thomas Woodrow Wilson] [10h] After permanent DST was passed into law again in 1973, this state's governor Reubin Askew asked for its repeal. Two congressmen from this state sponsored iterations of the Sunshine Protection Act. ANSWER: Florida [or FL] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - American - 1945+> ~25291~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

12. According to some stories, this site was discovered in 1940 by a dog named Robot pursuing a rabbit down a hole. For 10 points each: [10m] Identify this site near Montignac (“mon-teen-YAHK") home to the Hall of the Bulls. It was closed to the public in 1963 by Andre Malraux because tourists were causing it to deteriorate. ANSWER: Lascaux ("la-SKOH") cave paintings [10e] Andre Malraux was culture minister to this French President, who once asked, "How can you govern a country which has 246 varieties of cheese?" He led the Free French during World War II. ANSWER: Charles de Gaulle [or Charles André Joseph Marie de Gaulle] [10h] Another set of French cave paintings at Chauvet are the subject of this filmmaker's Cave of Forgotten Dreams. This man also directed Fitzcarraldo. ANSWER: Werner Herzog [or Werner Herzog Stipetic] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~25075~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

13. In a Caryl Churchill play, one of these events is attended by historical women such as Isabella Bird, Lady Nijo, and Dull Gret. For 10 points each:  [10e] Name this type of event at the center of Top Girls. Mrs. Dalloway buys flowers herself while preparing to host an event of this type. ANSWER: dinner party [or a dinner party; accept synonyms like celebration; prompt on meal] [10m] In a play by this author, a woman throws some slippers and asks “What’s to become of me?” after she wins a bet by impressing the Hungarian translator Nepommuck at a dinner party.  ANSWER: George Bernard Shaw (The play is Pygmalion.) [10h] At the dinner party in Top Girls, a woman of this name recounts being stoned to death after giving birth while dressed as a man. A Shaw play about a woman of this name ends with her talking to a man from the 1920s while awaiting a death sentence. ANSWER: Joan [accept Pope Joan or Saint Joan; accept Joan of Arc or Jeanne d’Arc] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Drama> ~22918~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

14. Answer the following about your knee surgery tomorrow, for 10 points each. [10m] Surgeons use this type of minimally invasive procedure to investigate a joint via a fiber optic camera prior to surgery. This procedure is used for routine colon cancer screenings. ANSWER: endoscopy [or arthroscopy or endoscopic surgery or arthroscopic surgery; prompt on colonoscopy by asking "what is the more general term?"] [10e] To make space for arthroscopic surgery, surgeons can use the "normal" type of this crystalloid fluid as an irrigation fluid. This solution of NaCl is provided intravenously to prevent dehydration. ANSWER: saline [or saline solution or normal saline solution; prompt on NSS or NS or N-slash-S] [10h] This condition can result from extravasation of the irrigation fluid into soft tissue around a joint. This condition is swelling in response to the buildup of fluid in a tissue. ANSWER: edema [prompt on fluid retention or hydropsy] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~25551~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. The "desperate lives and troubled times" that led to this work's creation are studied in a 2024 book by Charles King, which calls it "the greatest piece of participatory art ever created." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this choral work with a libretto by Charles Jennens whose opening French overture in E minor is labeled a Sinfony. This work depicts shepherds in its "Pifa." ANSWER: Messiah [or HWV 56] [10h] King's book has this two-word title. After the accompanied recitative ("re-sit-uh-TEEV") "Comfort ye, my people," the first aria in Messiah claims "[this phrase] shall be exalted." ANSWER: Every Valley [accept "Ev'ry valley shall be exalted"] [10e] The most famous excerpt of Handel's Messiah is the final scene of Part II, which is a chorus titled for this word. ANSWER: hallelujah <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~24504~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

16. Intrinsic alignment causes correlation patterns that get conflated with the presence of this phenomenon. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this phenomenon whose "weak" form is observed from shared properties of adjacent bodies and whose "micro" form is observed as a brightening. ANSWER: gravitational lensing [accept weak gravitational lensing or weak lensing or microlensing] [10e] The cosmic shear from weak gravitational lensing is computed by measuring the extent to which faraway galaxies deviate from this shape. Most large galaxies are either spirals or have this shape. ANSWER: elliptical [or ellipse] [10m] Weak gravitational lensing converts this field's E-mode polarization into B-mode polarization. The Planck satellite observed this 2.7-kelvin blackbody. ANSWER: CMBR [or cosmic microwave background radiation] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~24680~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. Answer the following about the history of in vitro fertilization, for 10 points each. [10m] The government of this country suppressed news about the birth of the second-ever "test-tube baby" in 1978. This country's IIT system has produced many scientists. ANSWER: India [or Republic of India; or Bhārat Gaṇarājya] [10h] This man expressed fear about women becoming "baby factories" when interviewed about test-tube baby Louise Brown. This man died just 33 days after being elected the successor of Paul VI in 1978. ANSWER: Pope John Paul I [or Albino Luciani; or Ioannes Paulus I or Giovanni Paolo I; prompt on John Paul; reject "John" or "Paul" alone] [10e] International surrogacy, made possible by IVF, has largely replaced international adoption from countries such as this one, whose orphanages overflowed during the reign of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceaușescu ("chow-SHESS-koo"). ANSWER: Romania [or Socialist Republic of Romania] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25471~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

18. Giovanni di Paolo violated a papal edict by depicting this woman receiving the stigmata. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this Sienese patron saint of Italy who was canonized by Pope Pius II. She vigorously petitioned Pope Gregory XI to return the papacy to Rome from Avignon. ANSWER: Saint Catherine of Siena [or Caterina Benincasa; or Caterina] [10e] Catherine underwent a mystical one of these rituals with Jesus. Anglican priests performing this ritual often use phrases like "in sickness and health."
