ANSWER: marriages [or weddings; accept mystical marriage] [10h] John Paul II made Catherine a patron saint of Europe, a distinction shared by this Swedish mystic who names a religious order established in Vadstena in 1369. This woman is credited with authoring prayers sometimes called the Fifteen O's. ANSWER: Saint Bridget of Sweden [or Birgitta Birgersdotter; or Birgitta of Vadstena; or heliga Birgitta; or Birgitta Birgersdotter] <Michael Bentley, RMP - Christian Practice> ~25073~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

19. Activists who oppose this region's merger with two others in 2016 often fly the "red-and-white" flag. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this French region in the Grand Est that is home to a flatbread called tarte flambée. This region's largest city is Strasbourg, and 90 percent of it was ceded to Germany in 1871. ANSWER: Alsace [prompt on Alsace-Lorraine] [10h] These mountains, whose highest point is Grand Ballon, shelter the vineyards of Alsace. Garibaldi led an army named for these mountains during the Franco-Prussian War. ANSWER: Vosges Mountains [or Vogesen] [10e] An Alsatian mountain range that separates part of France from Switzerland lends its name to this geological period. The Stegosaurus lived during this period that followed the Triassic. ANSWER: Jurassic Period [accept Late Jurassic Period or Jura Mountains] <Forrest Weintraub, Geography - Europe> ~25521~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. The 2013 film Reaching for the Moon depicts this poet's lesbian relationship with Lota de Macedo Soares ("LOH-tah jee mah-SAY-doo SWAH-ress"). For 10 points each: [10m] Name this poet who referenced her time in Brazil with the line "some realms I owned, two rivers, a continent" in "One Art," which claims "the art of losing isn't hard to master." ANSWER: Elizabeth Bishop [10h] With her partner Louise Crane, Bishop lived in one of the "three loved houses" described in "One Art" in this American city, where she befriended Pauline Pfeiffer Hemingway and wrote “The Fish.” ANSWER: Key West, Florida [10e] Several years after Soares's suicide, Bishop wrote a poem about this castaway from a novel by Daniel Defoe. In Bishop’s poem, this character laments the death of his lover, Friday. ANSWER: Robinson Crusoe [or Robinson Crusoe; accept "Crusoe in England"] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - American - Poetry> ~24698~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

21. A member of this group published an article criticizing Hai Rui Dismissed from Office, which its author said glorified Peng Dehuai. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this numeric group led by Jiang Qing, or Madame Mao, during the 1960s and 1970s before its arrest. ANSWER: Gang of Four [or Sì rén bāng] [10e] The Gang of Four’s influence grew during this movement launched by Mao Zedong, which purged capitalist elements from society through cadres called the Red Guards. ANSWER: Cultural Revolution [or Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution; or Wénhuà Dà Gémìng] [10h] This second Chinese premier, who succeeded Zhou Enlai, arrested the Gang of Four and served as Chairman of the Central Military Commission. ANSWER: Hua Guofeng [or Su Zhu] <Noah Sheidlower, History - World - Asian> ~26101~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

1. Since the 1920s, Pakistanis in this job have often paid artists to create distinctive "jingle" designs. "Doublestuffs" in this profession own their own equipment and must abide by the "14-hour rule" enforced by eLogs. The 1980 MCA deregulated this job, hurting a union now led by Sean O'Brien. A 1970s novelty song by C. W. McCall romanticizing this job led to a surge in (*) CB radio sales. Since 9/11, Americans with this job need a background check to get an "H" clearance on their CDL to work with hazardous materials. A chain of businesses catering to people in this job that offers CAT Scales and showers is called Pilot Flying J. For 10 points, name this job of people who might take an 18-Wheeler on a long-haul freight drive. ANSWER: truckers [or truck drivers; or lorry drivers; or truckie; or delivery truck drivers; or teamsters; prompt on drivers; reject "bus driver"] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29701~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: infections (The lead-in described the SEIR model.)
Text: 2. These events increase, but do not accelerate the increase in, an intermediate "E" state in a compartmental model named for four states. Kermack and McKendrick introduced an ODE model in which the rate of these events equals a difference involving the coefficients beta-over-population size and gamma. These events act on "susceptible" individuals, who can later become (*) "removed" or "recovered." The expected number of these events following a single one of them is the basic reproductive number, R-nought. These events increase the number of individuals in the "I" state of the SIR model, and they occur over large ranges in a pandemic. For 10 points, name these events in which a pathogen spreads to new patients. ANSWER: infections [accept disease transmissions or contagions; prompt on I; prompt on epidemics or disease outbreaks; prompt on pandemics until read] (The lead-in described the SEIR model.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30598~ <Editor: David Bass>

3. The poor performance of the Krag-Jørgensen at this battle led to its replacement by a rifle modeled on the losing side's rapid-firing Mausers. "Gatling Gun" Parker earned his nickname for supporting the Buffalo Soldiers and "Wood's Weary Walkers" at this battle, where they captured a feature named for its many sugar pots. Santiago was besieged following this battle and the surrender of El Caney. A former Assistant Secretary of the (*) Navy was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor for his leadership at this 1898 battle, making him the only president to have received it. For 10 points, name this battle of the Spanish-American War where Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders "charged up" a set of Cuban heights. ANSWER: Battle of San Juan Hill [or Battle for the San Juan Heights; prompt on Battle of San Juan; prompt on Battle of Kettle Hill] <Cooper Roh and Lalit Maharjan, History - American - 1865-1945> ~29761~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. One of these events inspired a story ending with the line "knot it" in which Mrs. Hale and Mrs. Peters find a bird in a sewing basket. In Emma Cline's The Girls, Evie narrowly avoids taking part in one of these events; Joan Didion recounted buying a dress for a participant in that event in The White Album. A quote from Elise Pachen's poem "Wi'-gi-e" ("weh-gee-uh") titles a 2017 David Grann book about these events. A (*) "non-fiction novel" about one of these events and its aftermath centers on Dick Hickock and Perry Smith. Harper Lee researched the Clutter family to aid with Truman Capote's In Cold Blood, a book about one of these events. For 10 points, Helter Skelter documents what type of crime done by the Manson Family? ANSWER: murders [or murder case; or murder trial; accept synonyms such as homicide or killing; accept the Clutter family murders; accept the Manson murders; accept Killers of the Flower Moon; prompt on crimes until read; prompt on trial by asking "what event caused that trial?"; prompt on helter skelter until read] (The story in the first line is Susan Glaspell's "A Jury of Her Peers." The David Grann book is Killers of the Flower Moon.) <Sean Farrell, Literature - American - Nonfiction> ~29691~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

5. Giovanni Benedetti showed that Gioseffo Zarlino's method for performing this task was susceptible to "pumping." A "beta" object is produced by Wendy Carlos's method for performing this task, which is very similar to 19-TET. Commas that arise when performing this task often lead to an undesirable "wolf" effect. The term "scordatura" refers to alternate methods for performing this task. A 3-to-2 ratio is used in both the (*) "just" and "Pythagorean" methods for performing this task. The title of Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier refers to a system for performing this task, which in modern orchestras is done when the principal oboist plays an A. For 10 points, name this task that involves adjusting an instrument's pitches. ANSWER: tuning [or word forms such as tune; accept Pythagorean tuning or just intonation; accept equal temperament or 19-tone equal temperament or well temperament until "Well-Tempered" is read] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~30252~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

Answer: John Keats (The unnamed poem in the third line is Keats' "Ode to a Nightingale.")
Text: 6. A poem by this author abruptly ends with the word "Celestial" after the title character stares into Mnemosyne's ("neh-MO-see-nee's") eyes. A poem asks where Urania was when this poet died and commands this poet's mourners to go to Rome. The speaker of a poem by this author is "Not charioted by Bacchus and his pards / But on the viewless wings of Poesy" and notes "tender is the night." A work by this poet about Cynthia's love for the title shepherd prince begins (*) "A thing of beauty is a joy forever." This author of Endymion ("en-DIM-ee-on") and Hyperion asks "What men or gods are these?" in a poem to an "Attic shape" that ends "Beauty is truth, truth beauty." For 10 points, name this subject of Percy Shelley's Adonais who wrote "Ode on a Grecian Urn." ANSWER: John Keats (The unnamed poem in the third line is Keats' "Ode to a Nightingale.") <Kevin Wang, Literature - British - Poetry> ~29707~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

7. Water and this molecule are the typical components of structures indicated by bottom-simulating reflectors at the base of a "stability zone." Organisms that consume this molecule via AOM may reside in a transition zone of sulfate and this compound. Microbial production of this molecule may have promoted the P–T extinction event. A "gun hypothesis" describes this molecule's release from underwater (*) clathrates. This is the most impactful molecule released from the "active layer" in a seasonal positive feedback loop that accelerates its release from melting permafrost. This common greenhouse gas is 30 times more potent than CO2. For 10 points, name this primary component of natural gas, a hydrocarbon with formula CH4. ANSWER: methane [accept CH4 until read] <Rohan Kher, Science - Other Science> ~29941~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. The Kangxi Emperor sponsored a 10-year project to create these objects sometimes named for the Jesuits. In the 16th century, Diego Ribero contributed to a secret Spanish collection of these objects called the Padrón Real. High-quality British examples of these objects were made by the Board of Ordnance. The historically suspect Soderini Letter inspired a maker of one of these objects named (*) Martin Waldseemüller ("VALD-see-moo-ler") to name a part of one for a Florentine navigator. Muhammad al-Idrisi created one of these objects for Roger II of Sicily that was more accurate than one described in the magnum opus of Ptolemy. For 10 points, name these objects often made using a projection developed by Gerardus Mercator. ANSWER: maps [accept map of China or map of Britain or map of England or world map or map of the new world or map of Europe or map of Eurasia; accept globe; prompt on atlas or projection or guides or geological surveys or geographic surveys or navigational charts] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30128~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: Caspar David Friedrich (The first clue refers to Moonrise by the Sea.)
Text: 9. This artist depicted two women sitting side-by-side and a man sitting a few feet away watching the moon rise in a painting paired with The Lonely Tree. A painting by this artist inspired a scene of crashed Luftwaffe planes by Paul Nash. This artist depicted his wife Caroline staring out a window at a ship’s mast on the Elbe River. This artist, whose lifelong trauma over his brother’s drowning inspired an (*) arctic landscape, included a monk staring at the ocean as one of his trademark rückenfiguren ("ROOK-in-fee-GOOR-in"). An 1818 painting by this artist depicts a man with a walking stick standing with his back to the viewer atop a rocky precipice. For 10 points, name this Romantic artist of Wanderer Above the Sea of Fog. ANSWER: Caspar David Friedrich (The first clue refers to Moonrise by the Sea.) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~30034~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

10. For throwing a rock at one of these animals, Oeonus ("oi-oh-NUS") was killed by Hippocoön's ("hip-aw-KO-own’s") sons. In a Senecan tragedy, Juno complains that the protagonist parades one of these animals, which can hear ghosts, through Argive cities. A person who was turned into one of these animals had a son Troïlus ("troh-EE-lus") with Apollo. After stabbing the eyes of the murderer of her son Polydorus, that woman, Hecuba, became one of these animals. After Amphitryon ("am-PHIH-tree-on") pitted one of these animals destined (*) never to miss his prey against the uncatchable Teumessian fox, they were both turned to stone. While rescuing Eurydice, Orpheus bypassed one of these animals with music. For 10 points, a three-headed kind of what animal named Cerberus guards the underworld? ANSWER: dogs [accept hellhounds; accept canis; accept kuon; reject "wolf" or "coyote"] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~29527~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

11. This theory inspired a book that coined the phrase "cake of custom," by Walter Bagehot ("BADGE-it"). An interpretation of this theory was refuted in a book about "a factor in" its central process by the author of The Conquest of Bread, Peter Kropotkin ("kro-POT-kin"). Henri Bergson modified this theory, positing an élan vital. This theory inspired the first description of (*) correlation and regression to the mean by the founder of psychometrics, Francis Galton. This theory was combined with genetics in the modern synthesis. This theory influenced the book Social Statics by Herbert Spencer, who coined the phrase "survival of the fittest." For 10 points, what theory was applied to politics by eugenicists and social Darwinists? ANSWER: Darwinian evolution [or evolution by natural selection; accept social Darwinism until read; accept Mutual Aid: A Factor in Evolution; accept Creative Evolution; prompt on eugenics by asking "what theory is that based on?"] <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Other> ~30228~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

12. An ionized state of this molecule is the only confirmed carrier of diffuse interstellar bands. In 1999, Markus Arndt et al. showed that this molecule exhibits wave-particle duality. This molecule's 6-6 ("six six") bonds resemble single bonds, while its 6-5 ("six five") bonds resemble double bonds. This black solid forms a purple solution in aromatic solvents. Curl, Kroto, and Smalley discovered this molecule using laser evaporation of (*) graphite. This molecule names a class of allotropes that includes nanotubes. This molecule's pentagonal and hexagonal rings combine to form a truncated icosahedron, leading it to be named after the architect who popularized the geodesic dome. For 10 points, name this soccer-ball-shaped allotrope of carbon. ANSWER: buckminsterfullerene [accept buckyballs; accept endohedral buckminsterfullerene; accept C60; prompt on fullerene; prompt on endohedral fullerene] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~30589~ <Editor: June Yin>

13. The years-long closure of one of these systems named for Elijah V. White has hurt the economy of Poolesville, Maryland. A hand-cranked chain device is still used in one of these systems that serves Mount Baldhead Park in Saugatuck, Michigan. One of these systems called the AMHS that serves the Inside Passage town of Hoonah extends as far south as Bellingham, Washington. Another of these systems connects Woods Hole to the vacation town of (*) Vineyard Haven. One of these systems that is serviced by Whitehall Terminal near The Battery is how Cornelius Vanderbilt earned the nickname "Commodore" and offers a low-cost way to see the Statue of Liberty. For 10 points, what type of system connects Manhattan with Staten Island? ANSWER: water ferries [accept water taxis; accept car ferries or vehicle ferries; prompt on boat or steamboat or steamship or water transport systems or public transit] <Michael Bentley, Geography - United States> ~30075~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. A woman from this family insists that her son stays in most evenings, variously looking at train timetables or using his fretsaw, when confronted by his employer. One member of this family eats a hardened white sauce with cheese and partly rotted vegetables. At the end of the work in which they appear, three members of this family consider moving into a smaller apartment as they ride in a (*) tram. After his son chases him round a room, the patriarch of this family throws apples at him until one lodges in his back. A member of this family called Grete ("GRAY-tuh") cares for another member of this family who turns into a "monstrous vermin." For 10 points, Franz Kafka's The Metamorphosis features what family, which includes Gregor? ANSWER: Samsa family [or the Samsas; accept Gregor Samsa or Grete Samsa or Mr. Samsa or Mrs. Samsa] <Joseph Chambers, Literature - European - Short Fiction> ~30303~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

15. A 2006 historical novel recounts Inés Suárez defending this modern-day country's capital. After the Disaster of Curalaba, colonizers of this country gradually abandoned settlements in the Destruction of the Seven Cities. Natives razed this country's modern capital to the ground to resist the wars of Pedro de Valdivia. Colonial rule of this country was resisted at the Battle of Maipu and Battle of (*) Chacabuco and fought by Bernardo O'Higgins. As a colony, this country was Spain's leading supplier of saltpeter. In the 1800s, this country and its eastern neighbor led southern conquests targeting the Mapuche. Colonists first settled this country's port of Valparaíso. For 10 points, name this country led from Santiago. ANSWER: Chile [or Republic of Chile or República de Chile] <Rohan Kher, History - World - Latin American> ~30310~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

16. The brief marriage between this novel's author and an architecture school classmate may have inspired its description of a character's failed marriage to Larry McCaslin. In this novel, the observation "it is best to be prepared" is one of "Two Thoughts" sealed in a jam container. A metaphor used by the Rhodes Scholar Chacko in this novel leads its narrator to refer to an abandoned hut as the (*) History House. During a screening of The Sound of Music, a character in this novel is molested in a cinema by the Orangedrink Lemondrink Man. This novel's "Love Laws" are broken when Ammu falls in love with Velutha ("VEL-oo-tuh"), a Dalit. For 10 points, name this debut novel by Arundhati ("uh-ROON-duh-tee") Roy whose protagonists are the twins Estha and Rahel. ANSWER: The God of Small Things <Aum Mundhe, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30229~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

17. Ken Burns's Jazz promoted this musician's dubious claim to have met Bix Beiderbecke on a steamboat. Okeh Records published a recording on which this musician legendarily dropped his lyric sheet. Gunther Schuller called this musician "The First Great Soloist" for shifting the focus of jazz from collective to individual improvisation, as shown by his cadenza at the start of his mentor (*) King Oliver's song "West End Blues." This artist wishes "It's so nice to have you back" in the title song of his album Hello, Dolly! This musician's "Hot Seven" recorded "Potato Head Blues," and his "Hot Five" recorded "Heebie Jeebies." For 10 points, scat singing was pioneered by what New Orleans-born trumpeter nicknamed Satchmo?  ANSWER: Louis Armstrong [accept Satchmo until read] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~30299~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

18. Scriptures like Revelation 22:2 are used to associate this substance with the Tree of Life by the Church of the Universe. Members of an International Church of this substance founded in Denver call themselves Elevationists and emphasize living by the Golden Rule. One religion’s nyabinghi ("nyah-BIN-ghee") sessions and "reasoning" sessions involve practitioners using this substance. To strengthen their "livity," members of (*) "mansions" like the Bobo Ashanti use this substance. Despite prohibiting drugs, the mostly vegan I-tal diet allows the use of this substance by practitioners who drink it for wisdom as a gift from Jah. For 10 points, name this plant that dreadlock-wearing practitioners of Rastafarianism call "ganja." ANSWER: cannabis [accept marijuana or weed or other equivalent terms; accept ganja until read] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Other Religion> ~30608~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: Feynman diagrams (The lead-in describes Julian Schwinger.)
Text: 19. A scientist who banned these objects from his classes described them as "Like the silicon chips ... bringing computation to the masses." Freeman Dyson helped popularize these objects, which are equivalent to his namesake perturbative series. Infrared or ultraviolet divergences arise when these objects are "one-loop." Namesake "rules" are used to translate these objects into transition (*) amplitudes. Virtual photons are wavy lines in these objects, whose straight lines and vertices represent propagators and interactions. Arrows show antiparticles traveling backwards in time in these objects. For 10 points, name these graph-like illustrations pioneered by a much-mythologized Caltech physicist. ANSWER: Feynman diagrams [prompt on diagrams] (The lead-in describes Julian Schwinger.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~30055~ <Editor: David Bass>

20. Vulcacius Gallicanus ("wool-KAH-kee-us gall-ih-KAH-nus") wrote a biography of a ruler of this region to whom Herodes Atticus sent a one-word letter translating to "you are insane" after a rebellion. That rebellion was started in this region by Avidius Cassius, who thought Marcus Aurelius had died. During a battle against a monarch from this region, the winning side, aided by Lucius Arruntius, used its Liburnian ships to outmaneuver the loser's (*) quinqueremes. Octavian ordered the death of a ruler of this region named Caesarion, whose name appeared in a "Donation." The last of three triumphs in 29 BC celebrated the conquest of this region by Augustus after the Battle of Actium. For 10 points, Mark Antony died in what region where Cleopatra ruled? ANSWER: Roman Egypt [or Aegyptus; prompt on Roman Africa; prompt on North Africa or the Nile; reject "Libya" or "Roman Libya"] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~29604~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

21. This group is characterized as being forced to go beyond its "immediacy" in a chapter titled "The Standpoint of [it]." The importance of a part of this group often characterized as unthinking "social scum" is argued for in a 1961 book beginning with the section "On Violence." That part of this group is named for the word "ragged." The Paris Commune is often used as an example of transitory periods described in Critique of the Gotha Program called the (*) "dictatorship of [this group]." Part of this group given the prefix "lumpen-" is devoid of class consciousness. This group operates, but does not own, the means of production. For 10 points, name this Marxist industrial working class contrasted with the bourgeoisie. ANSWER: proletariat [accept proles; accept lumpenproletariat; accept dictatorship of the proletariat; accept "The Standpoint of the Proletariat"; prompt on descriptions of a working class or lower class by asking "what specific term is used to refer to this?"] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~29533~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe> NSC 2025 - Round 07 - Bonuses

1. Answer the following about periodic table trends, for 10 points each. [10e] This dimensionless quantity tends to increase from left to right across the table. Fluorine has a value of 3.98 for this quantity on the Pauling scale. ANSWER: electronegativity [prompt on chi] [10m] This quantity, which also increases left-to-right, equals the energy released in the formation of a given element’s minus-one anion. Mulliken electronegativity equals the average of this quantity and ionization energy. ANSWER: electron affinity [accept E-sub-ea] [10h] This quantity, which tends to decrease down a group, equals approximately half the difference between ionization energy and electron affinity. Ralph Pearson developed a theory where small, highly charged species have high values of this quantity. ANSWER: chemical hardness [accept Pearson's absolute hardness; prompt on eta] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~25553~ <Editor: June Yin>

2. In a play, the Bolom promises to make this character and his brothers rich if they complete his challenge. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this character created by Derek Walcott, whose brothers are eaten after being provoked by the Planter. Unlike his brothers, the Frog helps this character because he doesn't insult him. ANSWER: Ti-Jean [accept Ti-Jean and His Brothers] [10e] In Ti-Jean and His Brothers, the Old Man and the Planter are actually this figure in disguise. This figure partly titles a Washington Irving story about the greedy Tom Walker. ANSWER: the Devil [accept Satan or Lucifer; accept "The Devil and Tom Walker"] [10m] In another Walcott play, Makak has one of these titular experiences after being thrown in a jail cell by Corporal Lestrade. In a play by a different author, Nick Bottom has one of these titular experiences that punningly has no bottom. ANSWER: dream [accept Dream on Monkey Mountain; accept A Midsummer’s Night Dream; accept Bottom’s Dream] <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25402~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

3. American "soccer moms" are not the only symbolically important demographic in world politics. For 10 points each: [10h] This country's "tiger" economy of the 2000s was exemplified by "Breakfast Roll Man." In the 2010s, taxes on royalty payments from multinationals like ASI greatly inflated this country's GDP. ANSWER: Ireland [or Republic of Ireland] [10e] This politician insulted Southern Europeans by comparing them with the idealized "schwäbische Hausfrau" ("SHVAY-bish-uh HOUSE-frow"). In 2021, Olaf Scholz succeeded this long-serving German chancellor. ANSWER: Angela Merkel [or Angela Dorothea Merkel; or Angela Kasner] [10m] This politician frequently contrasts "Henk and Ingrid" with their immigrant counterparts, "Mohammed and Fatima." This man leads the Netherlands' Party for Freedom. ANSWER: Geert Wilders ("heert VILL-ders") <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~24927~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

4. The no-trade theorem strengthens the assumptions of this hypothesis. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this hypothesis with weak, strong, and semi-strong forms described by Eugene Fama. This hypothesis predicts that it’s impossible to reliably beat the market, and that asset prices follow a random walk. ANSWER: efficient markets hypothesis [or EMH] [10m] Alongside Amos Tversky, this behavioral economist developed prospect theory, which challenges the EMH. This author of Thinking, Fast and Slow emphasized loss aversion and other economic biases. ANSWER: Daniel Kahneman [10e] The EMH is most often applied to the market for these instruments, which represent equity in a company. Bonds and these securities comprise the bulk of most mutual funds. ANSWER: stocks [accept shares; prompt on equities] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~25559~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

5. To flout a Prussian ban on this flag, farmers bred a so-called "protest pig" whose coloration was meant to resemble it. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this national flag. After a prayer by Archbishop Anders Sunesen, this flag supposedly fell from the sky during the 1219 Battle of Lyndanisse ("lin-duh-NISS-uh"). ANSWER: Danish flag [or flag of Denmark; or Dannebrog] [10e] Lyndanisse evolved into Tallinn, where the Danish-built Toompea Castle houses the parliament of this country. ANSWER: Estonia [or Republic of Estonia; or Eesti Vabariik] [10h] The second Danish king of this name won the Battle of Lyndanisse. The fourth king of this name sold Estonia to the Teutonic Order and signed the Treaty of Stralsund after losing a war to the Hanseatic League. ANSWER: Valdemar [or Valdemar II; or Valdemar the Victorious; or Valdemar IV Atterdag; or Valdemar Christoffersen; accept Waldemar; reject "Vladimir"] <Cooper Roh, History - European - Middle Ages> ~24694~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. Fukagawa, Sannō, and Kanda Matsuri are the three central festivals of this religion. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this kami-venerating religion from Japan whose shrines are marked by red torii gates. ANSWER: Shinto [or Shintoism] [10h] This festival, one of the five seasonal matsuri known as gosekku, is held on March 3 and involves creating tiered platforms covered with red carpet on which namesake ornamental dolls are displayed. ANSWER: Hinamatsuri [accept Girls' Day; prompt on Doll's Day] [10m] Doburoku Matsuri involves offering this substance to the gods. When it is sanctified, doburoku becomes a more honored type of this drink called omiki that is only fit for religious offerings or rituals. ANSWER: saké [or saki; accept Japanese rice wine; prompt on alcohol or alcoholic drinks or beverages; reject other specific alcoholic drinks like "beer" or "wine"] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - East Asian Religion> ~25556~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

7. The speaker of one poem imagines "that some day, emerging at last from the terrifying vision, I may burst into jubilant praise" to these figures. For 10 points each: [10h] In another poem published in 1923, the speaker asks "where are the days of Tobias" following an opening line about what figures? ANSWER: angels [or Engel or Engels] [10m] Both of those poems are from this 10-poem collection, whose second poem opens "Every angel is terrible" in Stephen Spender and J. B. Leishman's translation from German. ANSWER: Duino Elegies [or Duineser Elegien] [10e] This Austrian poet of the Duino Elegies had earlier written of a creature moving in "circles" in his poem "The Panther." ANSWER: Rainer Maria Rilke ("RYE-nur mah-REE-uh RIL-kuh") [or René Karl Wilhelm Johann Josef Maria Rilke] <Tim Morrison, Literature - European - Poetry> ~11940~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

8. The common statement of this equation omits gamma, so it only applies to non-relativistic objects. For 10 points each: [10e] Give this simple equation that summarizes Einstein's statement of mass–energy equivalence. ANSWER: E equals m c squared [or E equals gamma m c squared; or energy equals mass times the speed of light squared] [10m] Gamma is this quantity that serves as a coefficient describing how relativistic effects scale physical quantities. This quantity equals one minus v-squared-over-c-squared, all to the negative-one-half power. ANSWER: Lorentz factor [or gamma factor] [10h] At low speeds, the Lorentz factor can be binomially expanded into a MacLaurin series that starts with one plus this term, which is the classical kinetic energy term. Give your answer in terms of beta, which equals v-over-c. You have ten seconds. ANSWER: one-half-beta-squared [accept clear equivalents, like square of beta all over two] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24979~ <Editor: David Bass>

9. Despite the decline of sansukumi-ken games following World War II, this game lived on in the West. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this game where two players would choose a hand gesture while saying "jan. ken. pon," corresponding to the names of three items that name its English iteration. ANSWER: rock, paper, scissors [accept in any order; accept Rochambeau or Roshambo] [10m] The earliest ken games are named for this city, where they were brought from China. During the Tokugawa Shogunate, Dutch books were traded in this city and nearby Dejima. ANSWER: Nagasaki [10h] Tora-ken is a ken game that uses the names of a tiger, this person, and his mom. This Japanese-born Ming Dynasty general, who titles a 1715 play, defeated Dutch outposts to take control of Taiwan. ANSWER: Koxinga [or Zheng Chenggong] <Lalit Maharjan, History - World - Asian> ~24892~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. Because this architect couldn't get a visa due to his Communist leanings, Yale hired Louis Kahn instead. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this architect who included both a chapel and a heliport in his building for a head of state, the Palácio da Alvorada, in a modernist city whose grid resembles an airplane. ANSWER: Oscar Niemeyer ("NEE-my-er") [or Oscar Ribeiro de Almeida Niemeyer Soares Filho] [10e] Niemeyer designed a hyperboloid cathedral in this planned Latin American capital. ANSWER: Brasilia [10h] Meanwhile, Kahn improved on the low lighting of his Richards Medical labs with the floor-to-ceiling glass walls of a research institute designed for and named after this man with a prominent paved plaza in La Jolla ("HOY-uh"), California. ANSWER: Jonas Salk [accept Salk Institute for Biological Studies] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Architecture> ~24736~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

11. Warriors in this modern-day country once constructed a fake whale from dog skin to gain access to the hard-to-penetrate hill forts that decorated this country's landscape in the 19th century. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this country where the "first fish," or the first person to be killed in a battle, would have their hearts cut out and offered to the gods. ANSWER: New Zealand [or Aotearoa] [10e] The pa hill forts were constructed by these native people of New Zealand. ANSWER: Maori [prompt on Polynesians] [10m] The rohe, the traditional boundaries of the Maori, were thrown into chaos during these conflicts in the early 19th century, named for a newly introduced type of weapon. ANSWER: Musket Wars <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25083~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

12. Ira Aldridge was the first Black actor to depict this character on a London stage. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this "Moor of Venice" who titles a tragedy by William Shakespeare. ANSWER: Othello [or Othello; the Moor of Venice] [10h] Aldridge was nicknamed the "African" Roscius, a Roman actor who names a history of Restoration comedy commissioned by a holder of this title. Richard Burbage, who premiered as Othello, was part of an acting troupe named for this title and later the King at the Globe Theatre. ANSWER: Lord Chamberlain [or Lord Chamberlain of the Household; accept Lord Chamberlain's Men; accept King's Chamberlain; prompt on Chamberlain] [10m] Aldridge smoked a pipe during his death scene while starring as Oroonoko in a Thomas Southerne play adapted from a novel by this author. This Restoration playwright wrote The Rover.  ANSWER: Aphra Behn [or Astraea] <Ganon Evans, Literature - British - Drama> ~24929~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

13. Contemporaries gave this epithet to a 9th-century philosopher who signed his translations of Pseudo-Dionysius as "Eriugena," ("air-YOO-juh-nuh") or "Irish-born," and had the first name John. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this epithet also given to the later philosopher John Duns as a reference to his nationality. ANSWER: Scotus [or the Scot; accept John Duns Scotus; accept John Scotus Eriugena or John Scotus Erigena or Johannes Scottus Eriugena] [10h] In De Divisione Naturae, John Scotus Eriugena argued that God can only be described as "more-than-good" or "more-than-eternal," exemplifying this approach to theology practiced by Maimonides. ANSWER: apophatic theology [or negative theology] [10e] St. Augustine influenced John Scotus Eriugena's argument that this faculty exists in spite of predestination. Hard determinists deny this faculty's existence. ANSWER: free will [or freedom of the will] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~24700~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

14. After a disastrous marriage to his ex-student Antonina Miliukova, Tchaikovsky took an extended vacation to this country, inspiring an orchestral caprice titled for it. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this home country of a violinist who also wrote 24 caprices, Niccolò Paganini. ANSWER: Italy [or Italian Republic; or Republic of Italy; or Italia; accept Capriccio Italien] [10m] While in Italy, Tchaikovsky wrote a piece in this genre that opens with a Mozartian "pezzo ("PET-so") in forma di sonatina." Mozart's Eine Kleine Nachtmusik ("EYE-nuh KLY-nuh NOKT-music") is in this genre. ANSWER: serenade for strings [10h] A trip Tchaikovsky took a decade later inspired a piece for this ensemble nicknamed "Souvenir de Florence." A D minor piece for this ensemble was inspired by a poem about a woman confessing to adultery at night. ANSWER: string sextet [or sextet for strings; prompt on sextet] (The other piece is Arnold Schoenberg's Transfigured Night.) <Sinecio Morales, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~23336~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

15. This mathematician, but not the 2008 Maxis game, inspired Nevermann et al.'s Spore Life. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this English mathematician whose namesake grid-based "Game of Life" was popularized by Martin Gardner. ANSWER: John Horton Conway (Nevermann et al. 2025 is "A Game of Life with dormancy.") [10m] Spore Life can feature the stochastic death of "dormant" cells, thus removing this algorithmic property of Conway's Game of Life. The "N" in "P equals NP" stands for "non-[this property]." ANSWER: deterministic [10h] Spore Life's alpha parameter is the probability of this property for a dormant spore between generations. A field of statistics named for the "analysis" of this property uses the Kaplan–Meier estimator to predict the namesake complement of the CDF. ANSWER: survival [or word forms such as surviving; accept survival analysis; accept survival function] <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25500~ <Editor: David Bass>

16. This series was inspired by a 17th-century series of acid-etched prints by Jacques Callot ("ZHAHK ka-LO") accompanied by six-line verse captions by Michel de Marolles. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this series whose entries' brief titles include The Same, I Saw It, and This is Worse. This series was created after its artist's caprichos. ANSWER: The Disasters of War [or Los desastres de la guerra] [10e] Callot's Great Miseries of War series inspired this Spanish artist's Disasters of War series. The Peninsular War inspired this artist's painting The Third of May, 1808. ANSWER: Francisco Goya [or Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes] [10m] An entry from The Great Miseries of War is parodied by this English artist's Emblematical Print on the South Sea Scheme, which is sometimes considered the first political cartoon. He also created A Rake's Progress. ANSWER: William Hogarth <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~24687~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

17. Answer the following about the Public Universal Friend, a colonial-era genderless evangelist, for 10 points each. [10e] The Friend's teachings derived from this nonviolent Protestant denomination, whose member William Penn founded Pennsylvania as a "holy experiment." ANSWER: Quakers [or Society of Friends] [10m] The Friend was expelled by the Quakers after attending Baptist revivals in this modern-day state. A religious reformer was expelled [emphasize] to this state for advocating "free grace" in the Antinomian Controversy. ANSWER: Rhode Island (The reformer was Anne Hutchinson.) [10h] The Friend established a town with this religious name in New York. During a rebellion, Nat Turner led a march on a town of this name in Virginia, where he was later tried and executed. ANSWER: Jerusalem <Cole Hartung, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24975~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

18. Signal-sensing domains that alter the rate of this process are found in some of its namesake "factors" that bind to DNA. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this process in which DNA is used as a template to produce RNA. ANSWER: transcription [or tx] [10m] Transcription factors like STAT are activated when a tyrosine residue in their signal-sensing domain undergoes this chemical modification due to the action of a Janus kinase. ANSWER: phosphorylation [accept word forms such as phosphorylate; prompt on adding a phosphate group] [10h] The ability of transcription factors to bind to DNA can be sterically blocked by histone acetylation, an example of this process that controls chromatin accessibility. The ATP-dependent form of this process translocates nucleosomes. ANSWER: chromatin remodeling [or nucleosome remodeling; prompt on histone modification] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Biology> ~25194~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: W. H. Auden The February House was also home to a married couple with this last name, one member of whom wrote Two Serious Ladies and the other The Sheltering Sky. Christopher Isherwood created a singer with this last name in Goodbye to Berlin. ANSWER: Bowles This author based characters in her novella The Ballad of the Sad Cafe on people she met in the February House's local bar. In a novel by this author, the Deaf man John Singer misses his institutionalized friend Spiros Antonapoulos. ANSWER: Carson McCullers (The novel is The Heart is a Lonely Hunter.)
Text: 19. Name some authors who were roommates in the February House, for 10 points each. [10e] While living in the February House, this author collaborated with Benjamin Britten on an operetta about Paul Bunyan. This poet also wrote "Funeral Blues" and "September 1, 1939." ANSWER: W. H. Auden [or Wysten Hugh Auden] [10h] The February House was also home to a married couple with this last name, one member of whom wrote Two Serious Ladies and the other The Sheltering Sky. Christopher Isherwood created a singer with this last name in Goodbye to Berlin. ANSWER: Bowles [accept Paul Bowles or Jane Bowles or Sally Bowles] [10m] This author based characters in her novella The Ballad of the Sad Cafe on people she met in the February House's local bar. In a novel by this author, the Deaf man John Singer misses his institutionalized friend Spiros Antonapoulos. ANSWER: Carson McCullers [or Lula Carson Smith] (The novel is The Heart is a Lonely Hunter.) <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~25441~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

20. Unlike the more ritualized Star Wars, Mayan wars named for these objects focused on destruction and conquest. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this type of object which emits smoke like a cigar or torch while stuck in K'awiil's ("kah-WEEL's") forehead. In a fearsome critter tale, a hound shaped like this object consumes unprotected tools. ANSWER: axes [accept ax-heads or ax-handles; accept the Axehandle Hound; accept celts] [10m] This Mayan god struck the clouds with his lightning ax to summon storms. This counterpart of Tlaloc ("TLAH-lohk") was appeased by human sacrifices thrown into cenotes ("say-NO-tays"). ANSWER: Chaac [10e] The Popol Vuh ("VOOH") features a set of heroes with this relationship to each other, who clear their grandmother's garden with a single ax-swing and defeat Seven Macaw. ANSWER: twins [accept Hero Twins; accept twin brothers; prompt on brothers; prompt on siblings] <Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~23841~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

21. Science Fiction World is the biggest magazine that publishes sci-fi short stories in this language. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this language. A novel in this language describes an alien society that uses a simulation game to introduce to humans their struggles with stable and chaotic periods. ANSWER: Chinese [accept Zhōngwén or Hànyǔ; accept Mandarin] [10e] This aforementioned Liú Cíxīn novel describes an incoming Trisolarian invasion and opens his Remembrance of Earth's Past trilogy. ANSWER: The Three-Body Problem [accept Sāntǐ] [10h] Rickshaw Boy's author Lao She wrote his only science fiction novel about crash-landing on Mars and finding a country of these creatures. In another novella, one of these creatures observes people like Mr. Sneaze. ANSWER: cat [accept māo or neko; accept I Am a Cat] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~26009~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

1. In a play from this country, a doctor tests the hypothesis that monkeys randomly typing will eventually write Hamlet with chimps named Kafka, Milton, and Swift. That playwright from this non-Russian country wrote the plays Words, Words, Words and Variations on the Death of Trotsky. In a play partly titled for this country, Teach strikes Bob on the head after their plan to steal a (*) buffalo nickel goes wrong. In the first act of a play from this country set in a Chinese restaurant, a man working in the real estate industry attempts to convince his boss Williamson to give him a list of "leads." For 10 points, the playwright David Ives and the author of Glengarry Glen Ross, David Mamet, are from what country? ANSWER: the United States of America [or equivalents such as America or the USA, accept American Buffalo] <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Drama> ~29680~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

2. When these processes occur in axially symmetric systems, they are assumed to occur in a set of infinitely thin "plugs." A surrounding jacket maintains the temperature of systems that undergo these processes in "batches." These processes name devices that deviate from ideality if the residence time is less than a fifth of the mixing time; that device is a CSTR. The rate of these processes is decreased by (*) poisoning. Car exhaust undergoes one of these processes in devices that are often stolen because they contain precious metals. Magnetic stir bars increase the rates of these processes, during which transition states can temporarily form. For 10 points, name these processes that may involve the rearrangement of bonds. ANSWER: chemical reactions [accept redox reactions; accept batch reactors or continuous stirred tank reactors; prompt on catalysis] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~30276~ <Editor: June Yin>

3. Religious women of this ethnicity braid their hair into over 100 braids and owned a type of coral called dzi beads. Each night in these people's capital, a giant cauldron of tea was brewed with hundreds of kilos of butter. A British expedition to these people was led by Francis Younghusband. A period called dhulok ("doo-LOHK") followed the 1951 Seventeen Point Agreement forced on these people. Since (*) 1960, a leader of these people has lived in Dharamshala. Richard Gere was active in a campaign to "free" these people, whose leaders once lived in Potala Palace in a high-elevation capital. An exiled leader of these people was born Tenzin Gyatso. For 10 points, name this ethnic group whose spiritual leader is the Dalai Lama. ANSWER: Tibetans [accept Tibetan Buddhists; prompt on Buddhists or Chinese people] <Michael Bentley, History - World - Asian> ~30123~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: concert hall (The third line is Carnegie Hall.)
Text: 4. Note to moderator: read the answerline carefully. A costly one of these buildings in Copenhagen designed by Jean Nouvel with a cobalt-blue exterior drew inspiration from a "vineyard" design for the interior of these buildings pioneered in Berlin by Hans Scharoun ("shah-ROON"). The interior of a building of this type was designed to be a "living room for the city" that contrasts with the cozier interior of the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. William Tuthill designed a Neo-Renaissance example of these buildings, which hosted a 1938 event that climaxed with (*) "Sing Sing Sing." One of these buildings has created 140-degree Fahrenheit sidewalks due to its curved, silver panels reflecting light onto Los Angeles. For 10 points, name these venues, including one designed by Frank Gehry and named for Walt Disney. ANSWER: concert hall [or symphony halls or orchestra halls or philharmonies or philharmonics; accept answer indicating a venue where classical music or an orchestra plays; accept performance venue or music venue or performance hall; prompt on hall; prompt on theater or auditorium; reject "opera house"] (The third line is Carnegie Hall.) <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Architecture> ~28389~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

5. In Acts 2, Peter calls this man a "prophet" who foresaw and wrote about the resurrection of Jesus. Jesus stumps the Pharisees by asking how this man could describe Christ as "his Lord" in his writings. In Matthew 20, two blind men ask Jesus, "Son of [this man], have mercy on us." In Luke 2, an angel calls (*) Bethlehem the "city of" this man. The genealogy in Matthew 1 references "the wife of Uriah" as this man's wife, omitting Bathsheba's name. New Testament writers frequently quoted the messianic Psalms 95 and 110, which are traditionally attributed to this king. Acts 7 recounts, for 10 points, the unfulfilled desire of which king of Israel to build the temple, which was completed by his son Solomon? ANSWER: David [or King David] <Jon Suh, RMP - New Testament> ~29534~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: rRNAs (The first two sentences discuss RNA45S5.)
Text: 6. Adjacent sequences that encode these molecules can be separated by internal transcribed spacers. Many copies of a gene encoding three of these molecules appear in the p12 regions of humans' acrocentric chromosomes. Identification of prokaryotes via barcoding can utilize the nine hypervariable regions of one of these molecules, which contains the anti-Shine–Dalgarno sequence. These molecules are named for their (*) sedimentation coefficients in Svedbergs, like their 18S, 5.8S, and 28S types, which are transcribed by eukaryotic Pol I ("paul one"). Alongside proteins, these molecules compose the "small" 40S subunit and the "large" 60S subunit. For 10 points, name these nucleic acids found in the structures that synthesize proteins. ANSWER: rRNAs [or ribosomal RNAs or ribosomal ribonucleic acids; accept 16S rRNAs or 45S pre-rRNAs or 18S rRNAs or 5.8S rRNAs or 28S rRNAs; prompt on RNAs or ribonucleic acids; prompt on ribosomes] (The first two sentences discuss RNA45S5.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~29617~ <Editor: David Bass>

7. A politician who represented this non-Missouri state died in a plane crash while campaigning with Hale Boggs but was elected anyway three weeks later. A pervasive television biography subtitled "A Man for [this state]" ran during a race that unseated Ernest Gruening. A politician from this state, who was mentored by "Scoop" Jackson, entered the Pentagon Papers into the congressional record. A senator representing this state who opposed (*) net neutrality claimed that the "Internet is a series of tubes." Mike Gravel represented this state, as did a mayor of Wasilla and Tea Party member who ran alongside John McCain in 2008. For 10 points, Ted Stevens and Sarah Palin represented what northernmost U.S. state? ANSWER: Alaska [or AK] <Cole Hartung, History - American - 1945+> ~29683~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

8. This piece's left hand ostinato is quoted at the climax of Leopold Godowsky's passacaglia ("pass-uh-CALL-ya") based on a B minor symphony by its composer. This piece, written when its composer was 18, is catalogued as his opus 1 and D. 328. Performers like Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau use four distinct combinations of range and timbre to represent this piece's narrator and three characters. This piece's opening triplet G octaves represent the (*) gallop of a horse that "rides so late through night and wind." This lied's ("LEED's") title creature tries to lure a boy away from his father, who assures him the creature isn't real before the boy dies in his arms. For 10 points, name this song by Franz Schubert based on a Goethe ("GUR-tuh") poem about an elf-king. ANSWER: "Erlkönig" [or "Der Erlkönig"; or "The Erlkönig"; or "The Erlking"; accept "The Elf-King" until mention] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~29513~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

9. A novel from this country details a woman journeying to an island through a snowstorm to feed her friend's pet bird. In a different novel from this country, one character gets flowers painted all over his body prior to assaulting his sister-in-law. An author from this country wrote We Do Not Part as "a pair" for an earlier novel that covers seven different points of view of an event in this country and is titled (*) Human Acts. A woman stands in the rain imitating a tree after escaping a psychiatric hospital in one novel from this country. Earlier in that novel from this country, that woman slits her wrists after being force fed pork. For 10 points, The Vegetarian is a novel from what home country of the 2024 Nobel Prize winning author, Han Kang? ANSWER: South Korea [accept Republic of Korea or Daehanminguk; prompt on Korea] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~31113~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

10. Queen Katherine befriends, then later summons this figure in a folk song preserved in the Percy folio. This figure stops an arranged marriage between an old knight and a woman who actually desires the minstrel Alan-a-Dale. 19th century literature named for this figure introduced Maude Lindsay as the love interest of Will Scarlet. An origin for a possible love interest for this figure is a shepherdess character at May Day celebrations who marries him after he's (*) pardoned by the king. This figure gives a ring to the wife of his rival at the shooting competition he attends in disguise. At times, Maid Marian is a member of this figure's Merry Men. For 10 points, name this English outlaw who steals from the rich. ANSWER: Robin Hood [accept Robin of Locksley] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~29735~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

11. A Russian-backed nuclear plant in this country is at the center of a scandal implicating UK minister Tulip Siddiq. In 2022, this country issued digital certificates to clamp down on fraud in its "freedom fighter" quota system. CRI-funded statues of this country's first president were torn down in 2024 by so-called "Razakar" students as part of its (*) "non-cooperation movement." An interim government that took power in this country in 2024 is led by a Nobel Peace Prize winner who founded Grameen Bank. This country's "Monsoon Revolution" ousted Sheikh Hasina of the Awami League. For 10 points, name this country home to Muhammad Yunus, where in 2024 protestors seized the Prime Minister's residence in Dhaka. ANSWER: Bangladesh [or People's Republic of Bangladesh] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~30074~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

12. Stoic philosophy influenced this thinker's claim that freedom is our unlimited ability to respond to the external world in Sketch for a Theory of the Emotions. This philosopher described a gay man who refuses to admit to his own homosexuality as a free transcendence who ignores his facticity in a book subtitled "Essay on Phenomenological Ontology." This philosopher wrote that "man is condemned to be free" in a lecture that describes a concept that (*) "precedes essence" and calls the title movement "a humanism." This philosopher used a waiter who moves too precisely to illustrate bad faith. For 10 points, name this author of Being and Nothingness who wrote "hell is other people" in his existentialist play No Exit. ANSWER: Jean-Paul Sartre <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~29577~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

13. Whether this isotope achieves self-sufficiency depends on the TBR. This isotope is the desired product of lithium breeding blankets. This is the lightest isotope that can be studied with liquid scintillation counting. Neutron generators can use either zero or one atoms of this isotope. This isotope is the lighter of two atoms that are produced from upper-atmosphere collisions of nitrogen-14 and a fast neutron. This is the heaviest isotope that is central to the pellets in (*) inertial confinement reactors. This isotope, which has a half-life of 12 years, undergoes beta-minus decay into helium-3. This isotope has two neutrons and one proton. For 10 points, name this isotope that is one dalton heavier than deuterium. ANSWER: tritium [or hydrogen-3 or H-3 or 3H or T; reject just "hydrogen"] ("TBR" is "tritium breeding ratio.") <Rohan Kher, Science - Physics> ~30059~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Anne Frank (The Ghost Writer is by Philip Roth.)
Text: 14. This author remarked that a fountain pen was "cremated, just as I would like to be" after accidentally melting it in a stove. The narrator imagines that this real-life author of Cady's Life emigrated to study under E. I. Lonoff in the novel The Ghost Writer. A work by this author describes potatoes being urinated on by the cat Mouschi ("MOOS-ghee"). Meetings with "Hello" Silberberg are described early in a work by this author that was preserved by (*) Miep Gies ("meep khees"), and which used pseudonyms for the dentist Mr. Düssel and the van Daans. This author described how her sister Margot being called up prompted them to live with their father Otto in a "secret annex." For 10 points, name this author of The Diary of a Young Girl. ANSWER: Anne Frank [or Annelies Marie Frank] (The Ghost Writer is by Philip Roth.) <Sean Farrell, Literature - European - Other> ~29687~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

15. Jewish athlete Daniel Mendoza gained fame in this sport in 18th century England. Tex Rickard capitalized on the 1920 Walker Law legalizing this sport in New York. A star in this sport triggered 1910 race riots and was arrested for violating the Mann Act with Lucille Cameron. Eva Braun was obsessed with a star of this sport named (*) Max Schmeling. John Graham Chambers authored rules for this sport more commonly named for the Marquess of Queensberry. Mobutu Sese Seko hosted a 1974 match in this sport in Zaire. Black champions in this sport include Jack Johnson and an athlete who struggled to get reporters to not call him by his "slave name" of Cassius Clay. For 10 points, name this sport of Muhammad Ali. ANSWER: boxing [or prizefighting or pugilism; accept heavyweight boxing; prompt on fighting] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30119~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. This character sees men with "stony eye-balls" lift their right hands glowing like torches, in a passage later removed from a collection. An author coined the term "suspension of disbelief" while recalling his creation of this "bright-eyed" man in the Biographia Literaria. This man meets a Pilot and a Hermit in a work where his "life-blood seemed to sip" after a "Night-mare" with (*) "skin...white as leprosy" wins a dice game. A poem's narrator tells this "gray-beard loon" that he fears his "glittering eye." This man blesses water snakes and tells the Wedding-Guest how he saw "Water, water every where, / Nor any drop to drink." For 10 points, what title man shoots an albatross in a "Rime" by Samuel Taylor Coleridge? ANSWER: the Ancient Mariner [accept "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"; prompt on the Mariner] <Kevin Wang, Literature - British - Poetry> ~29804~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

17. These people's overrepresentation in the Royal Society led to the development of modern science, according to the Merton thesis. A book titled for these people claims that the "philosophy of avarice," exemplified by Ben Franklin's claim that "time is money," employs the notion of a "sacred calling." A behavior being more common among these people was the first "social (*) fact" to be described. Due to weaker social integration, Émile Durkheim claimed these people are more likely to commit suicide. The "iron cage of rationality" was theorized in a book arguing that the "spirit of capitalism" derives from these people's exaltation of work. For 10 points, Max Weber theorized the "ethic" of what religious denomination? ANSWER: Protestants [accept specific denominations like Puritans, Lutherans, or Calvinists; accept The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism; accept Die protestantische Ethik und der Geist des Kapitalismus; prompt on Christians; prompt on religious people until "religious"] <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Sociology> ~30574~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

18. A member of this family wears a turquoise outfit designed by Jason Wu and sits on a red sofa in a painting by Sharon Sprung. An artist copied a Manny Garcia photo for an artwork of a member of this family with a hidden "obey" star. A member of this family sits against a sky-blue background in a flowing print dress compared to Gee's (“jee’s”) Bend quilts in a 2018 greyscale portrait of her by (*) Amy Sherald. Jasmine flowers symbolize the birth state of a member of this family as he sits surrounded by shrubbery in a painting in the National Portrait Gallery. A member of this family is portrayed in red, beige, and blue in the "Hope" poster. For 10 points, Kehinde Wiley created a presidential portrait for what family's patriarch Barack? ANSWER: Obama family [or the Obamas; accept Barack Hussein Obama II or Michelle LaVaughn Robinson Obama; prompt on Michelle Robinson by asking "what is her married surname?"] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - 1945+> ~30592~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

19. Walter Map's writings contributed to a "black legend" about this non-Spanish ruler, which was later contradicted by "golden myths" promoted by Amy Kelly. This ruler was blamed for a defeat at Mount Cadmus during a campaign in support of Raymond of Antioch. This ruler was put under house arrest after supporting a rebellion led by Henry the Young King. During the Third Crusade, Leopold of (*) Austria captured this ruler's son, after which she raised ransom money. On the basis of consanguinity, this ruler annulled her marriage to Louis VII before marrying Henry II of England. A "court of love" at Poitiers ("pwaht-YAY") was maintained by, for 10 points, what noblewoman who hailed from southwestern France? ANSWER: Eleanor of Aquitaine [accept Aliénor d'Aquitaine or Éléonore d'Aquitaine; prompt on Eleanor] <Cole Hartung, History - European - Middle Ages> ~30012~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

20. A limit on these objects was proven in 2024 by an anonymous contributor to b·b·challenge, which seeks to solve a class of problems about these objects that Tibor Radó introduced. Rice’s theorem can be stated in terms of the inability of these objects to "recognize" non-trivial properties. The utility of these objects is described in the typical formulation of a conjecture co-named for (*) Alonzo Church. Busy beavers are a case of these objects, which are often contrasted with a less general class of "finite-state" objects that cannot write. These objects consist of cells read from an infinitely-long shifting tape. For 10 points, name these computational models named for a pioneering English computer scientist. ANSWER: Turing machines [accept busy beavers before read; prompt on computer programs or effective methods or effective procedures; prompt on computers before “computational” is read] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~29662~ <Editor: David Bass>

21. Because metals in the atmospheres of old stars strongly absorb radiation in this region of the electromagnetic spectrum, the spectra of elliptical galaxies have a distinctive "break." A feature in this region is created by cool gas clouds at many points along the line of sight to a quasar. Star formation is the dominant source of radiation in this region that contains the (*) Lyman-alpha line. Blackbodies were erroneously assigned infinite radiative power in this region by the Rayleigh–Jeans law, resulting in this region's so-called "catastrophe." 315 and 400 nanometers bound the moderately dangerous "A" part of this region. For 10 points, the ozone layer absorbs what kind of radiation that causes sunburn? ANSWER: ultraviolet [or UV; accept ultraviolet A or UVA] (The lead-in refers to the 4000-angstrom break. The second sentence refers to the Lyman-alpha forest.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~29653~ <Editor: David Bass> NSC 2025 - Round 08 - Bonuses

1. In this artwork, a polyhedron sits next to a building decorated with a magic square, which includes this artwork’s creation date of 1514. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this engraving whose central angel rests her head in her hand while surrounded by woodcutting tools. ANSWER: Melencolia I ("one") [prompt on Melancholy] [10e] A painting by Jacopo de' Barbari (“ya-KO-po day bar-BAR-ee”) may have inspired the polyhedron in this German artist's Melencolia I, one of his "master prints" whose others include Knight, Death, and the Devil. ANSWER: Albrecht Dürer [10h] This other artist created a tile mosaic of a stellated dodecahedron for the Basilica of St. Mark. This artist depicted dogs disappearing into a dark background in his massive The Hunt in the Forest. ANSWER: Paolo Uccello ("oo-CHELL-oh") <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~25520~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. Identify the following about Lost World fiction, for 10 points each. [10m] Perhaps the seminal work in the genre is The Lost World, a book by this author where Professor Challenger and the reporter Edward Malone visit a land of dinosaurs in South America.  ANSWER: Arthur Conan Doyle [10h] Allan Quatermain finds treasure inside a mountain in this author's novel King Solomon's Mines. This author's enormously popular Lost World boys' novels include She. ANSWER: H. Rider Haggard [or Henry Rider Haggard] [10e] The crew of the U-33 encounter dinosaurs on Caprona in The Land That Time Forgot, a novel by Edgar Rice Burroughs, who is probably best known for creating this character. This character falls in love with Jane Porter and is raised by Kala and other great apes in the African jungle. ANSWER: Tarzan [or John Clayton II or Viscount Greystoke; prompt on John] <Michael Bentley, Literature - British - Other> ~23754~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

3. Mankin et al. 2017 describes a "curious case" of simultaneously increasing dryness and this property. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this property of vegetation. This color is generically used to describe climate-friendly efforts. ANSWER: green [accept word forms like greenness or greener or greening] [10h] Mankin et al. measures dryness with PDSI, which they criticize as overly reliant on measurements of P·E·T, or the "potential [this process]." This process is the combination of all processes by which water enters the atmosphere. ANSWER: evapotranspiration [10m] Greening may increase dryness by preventing this process, which is a primary driver of eutrophication. This major source of soil erosion occurs when the soil is saturated with water. ANSWER: surface runoff [or terrestrial runoff; prompt on overland flow] <David Bass, Science - Other Science> ~25570~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. This is the first of three nouns to title a David Anthony book whose first chapter discusses a "mother language." For 10 points each: [10e] Name these work animals. Anthony credits these animals with forming a "steppe bridge," allowing herders to travel great distances across Europe and Asia. ANSWER: horses [10h] Anthony's work revised this hypothesis associated with Marija Gimbutas. This hypothesis, named for burial mounds, holds that Proto-Indo-Europeans originated in the Pontic steppe. ANSWER: Kurgan hypothesis [10m] A less-popular hypothesis developed by Colin Renfrew claims that Proto-Indo-Europeans came from this region. The archaeological site Göbekli Tepe is located in this region. ANSWER: Anatolia [accept Turkey or Türkiye; accept Asia Minor; accept Turkish Asia; prompt on Asia] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Anthropology> ~25784~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

5. Identify the following about African conflicts in Britain's Edwardian Age, for 10 points each. [10m] The British punished the Nandi by handing over 10,000 of their cattle to these people. These traditionally pastoral people of Kenya and Tanzania subsisted almost entirely on the blood, meat, and milk of their cows. ANSWER: Maasai [or Wamasai] [10e] Ekumeku guerillas clashed with British forces in the forests of this modern-day country. The British policy of indirect rule in this modern-day country delegated some power to Yoruba Obas. ANSWER: Nigeria [or Federal Republic of Nigeria] [10h] A leader of these people named Muhammad Abdullah Hassan earned the nickname the "Mad Mullah" for his wars against the British. These people belong to kinship groups called reer. ANSWER: Somali [or Soomaalida; prompt on Somalians] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25089~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

6. This city lends its name to "violets," a fizzy British candy that looks like a Smartie. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this Italian city northwest of Bologna in the Emilia-Romagna region that also lends its name to a type of prosciutto and cheese. ANSWER: Parma [accept Parmesan cheese] [10e] The Madonna della Steccata in Parma was constructed using Bramante’s initial design for a basilica named for this saint, also the namesake of a large square that surrounds the Vatican Obelisk in Vatican City. ANSWER: Saint Peter [accept Saint Peter’s Basilica or Saint Peter’s Square; or Peter the Apostle; or Simon Peter; or Simeon; or Simon; or Cephas] [10h] A giant museum complex in Parma built by Ottavio Farnese ("far-NAY-zay") derives its name from this type of activity. A fronton is used in some Basque versions of this activity. ANSWER: ball game [or playing a ball game; accept pelota or Pilotta or Complesso monumentale della Pilotta; prompt on game or sport with “involving what kind of object?”] <Michael Bentley, Geography - Europe> ~22859~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. The six central disciplines of studying these texts include vyākarana ("VYAH-kuh-ruh-nuh"), jyotiṣa ("jyo-TEE-shuh"), and śikṣā ("shick-SHAH"). For 10 points each: [10e] Name these four Sanskrit scriptures foundational to Hinduism including ones whose names start with "Atharva" and "Rig." ANSWER: Vedas [accept Rigveda or Atharvaveda; accept Vedanga] [10m] Kalpa is an especially important part of the Vedanga disciplines for discussing these 19 texts that comment on the Samhita rituals detailed in the Vedas. ANSWER: Brahmanas [or Brāhmanam] [10h] The Brahmanas and the Vedas are both classified under one of these two similar-sounding terms while texts like the Puranas are classified as the other. One of these two Sanskrit terms refers to the written and remembered, while the other refers to "that which is heard." Name either. ANSWER: smriti ("SMUR-tee") OR shruti [accept smrti or smruti in place of "smriti"] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Hinduism> ~25566~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

8. In Keeley and Sherrard's translation, these people are said to be "bored by rhetoric and public speaking." For 10 points each: [10m] A Constantine Cavafy poem is about a city expecting the arrival of what title people, whom the poem calls "a kind of solution"? ANSWER: barbarians [or barbaroi or barbaros; accept "Waiting for the Barbarians" or "Perimenontas tous Barbarous"] [10e] Cavafy wrote "Waiting for the Barbarians" in this language. An ancient poem in this language inspired Cavafy's poem "Ithaka." ANSWER: Greek [or Ellinika or Hellenike; accept Modern Greek or Ancient Greek] [10h] Another Cavafy poem tells this historical figure "say goodbye to her, to" a city "you are losing." That poem is titled "The God Abandons" this historical figure. ANSWER: Marc Antony [or Marcus Antonius; accept "The God Abandons Antony" or "The God Forsakes Antony" or "Apoleipein O Theos Antonion"] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Poetry> ~23312~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

Answer: William Rowan Hamilton (The PDE is the Hamilton–Jacobi equation.)
Text: 9. A function named for this scientist whose inputs are q, d-S-d-q, and time-equals-d-S-d-t. For 10 points each: [10h] Give the first namesake scientist of that nonlinear PDE, which can be solved to determine the action. This scientist’s “principle” is a statement of the principle of least action that can be written “d-S-d-q equals zero.” ANSWER: William Rowan Hamilton (The PDE is the Hamilton–Jacobi equation.) [10m] The action also equals the time integral of this quantity, which is named for a naturalized Frenchman and equals the difference of kinetic and potential energy. ANSWER: Lagrangian [prompt on L] [10e] In Hamiltonian mechanics, q is a vector of the "generalized" type of these quantities. Systems for these quantities include spherical, Cartesian, and polar. ANSWER: coordinates [accept generalized coordinates or spherical coordinates or Cartesian coordinates or polar coordinates; accept coordinate systems] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24982~ <Editor: David Bass>

10. The trainwreck film Megalopolis somehow featured some accurate Roman history. For 10 points each: [10h] Mayor Frank Cicero recites the opening lines of this speech, saying, "How much longer will you abuse our patience?" This speech was delivered at the temple of Jupiter Stator ("STAH-tore") in 63 BC. A description is acceptable. ANSWER: first Catilinarian oration [accept answers that mention the first speech given against Catiline by Cicero; prompt on Cicero's speeches] [10m] Megalopolis features a character with this last name, in reference to a rich Roman with this cognomen. This Roman died after a defeat at Carrhae ("CAR-aye") when the Parthians poured molten gold down his throat. ANSWER: Crassus [accept Hamilton Crassus III; accept Publius Licinius Crassus] [10e] Instead of being a politician and soldier, Catalina holds this occupation in the movie held by ancient Romans like Vitruvius, who crafted a guide for building projects. ANSWER: architect [or architectus] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~24770~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

11. A series of "Hard Times Tokens" was minted during this president's tenure. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this president mocked by those Tokens, whose passage of the Specie Circular contributed to the Panic of 1837 under his successor, Martin van Buren. ANSWER: Andrew Jackson [10m] During this election year, coins bearing slogans criticizing one candidate's support for Free Silver were minted by the other's campaign manager, Mark Hanna. ANSWER: Election of 1896 [prompt on 96] [10h] This politician was dubbed the "Sage of Chappaqua" by a token distributed during his campaign. The quote "If I could save this union without freeing any slave, I would do it!" comes from a letter by Abraham Lincoln to this politician. ANSWER: Horace Greeley <Cole Hartung, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24630~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

12. These dancers perform upwards of three pirouettes at a time because they usually spin on the ball of the foot. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this type of dancer, who almost exclusively perform tour de l'air (“toor deh leh air”). These dancers typically travel across the stage instead of performing a fouetté ("fou-eh-TAY") turn. ANSWER: men [or males or boys or guys or other synonyms for men; or danseur or ballerino; prompt on ballet dancers; reject "ballerina"] [10m] This dancer was one of the first men to perform the entrechat ("on-truh-SHA") six in his performances for the Ballet Russes ("roose"). The role of Petrushka was written for this dancer, who choreographed the Rite of Spring and Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun. ANSWER: Vaslav Nijinsky [or Vaslav Fomich Nijinsky; or Vatslav Fomich Nizhinsky] [10e] Examples of these objects worn by male ballet dancers usually don't have a box intended to support the toes during en pointe ("awn pwant"). ANSWER: shoes [or pointe shoes; or ballet slippers; prompt on footwear] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Ballet/Dance> ~25571~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

13. In Octavia Butler's novel Kindred, Dana rescues a boy from drowning after doing this action for the first time, and loses an arm after performing it to return home. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this action that allows Dana to meet her ancestors, including the slave owner Rufus. An H. G. Wells character meets the Morlocks and Eloi by performing this action.  ANSWER: time travel [accept word forms such as time traveling; accept answers indicating the ability to go back in time or go to the future or go to the past or to manipulate space-time; prompt on The Time Machine by asking "what is the action performed?"] [10h] Shock collars control slaves in the second of two Butler novels titled as works of this type. In those novels whose titles begin with this word, Lauren brings the Earthseed religion while traveling through a dystopian California.  ANSWER: parables [accept Parable of the Sower or Parable of the Talents or Parable duology] [10m] Butler was mentored by an author with this surname who penned "I Have No Mouth, and I Must Scream." Another author with this surname created the dying Adam Sunraider in his novel Juneteenth. ANSWER: Ellison [accept Harlan Jay Ellison or Ralph Waldo Ellison] <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~24705~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

14. This man's house is said to have contained cushions decorated with images of birds. For 10 points each: [10e] Identify this prophet whose house in Medina inspired all subsequent mosque architecture. ANSWER: Muhammad [or Mohammed; or the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him] [10h] The Prophet's Mosque, built on the site of Muhammad's house in Medina, was the first building in the Arabian Peninsula to have this feature added to it. Hawaii's Iolani Palace had this feature five years before Benjamin Harrison added it to the White House. ANSWER: electric lighting [accept electricity; prompt on lighting] [10m] Many Islamic heritage sites in Medina were destroyed in the early 19th century by followers of this conservative religious movement, whose founder allied with Muhammad bin Saud in the 18th century. ANSWER: Wahhabism [al-Wahhābiyya] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~25063~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

15. In letters to Darwin, Lydia Becker reported changes in this variable due to smut fungus infection. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this variable that differs among certain structures on monoecious ("muh-NEE-shus") organisms, which are not perfect. This variable is separated among organisms in dioecious species, thus enforcing self-incompatibility. ANSWER: sex [prompt on answers describing being male or being female] [10e] Becker observed fungal spores forming in infected examples of these male flower sex organs. These pollen-producing structures lie atop the filament in the stamen. ANSWER: anthers [10m] Plants display flowers while in the sporophyte stage of the alternation of generations, which is contrasted with this "reduced" haploid stage that is named for sex cells. ANSWER: gametophyte [reject "gametes"] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~25522~ <Editor: David Bass>

16. Description required. Iarbas ("YAR-bas") did this action after the Carthiginian queen Dido rejected him. For 10 points each: [10h] Describe this action performed by Aeacus ("ay-AH-kus") to solve his loneliness, leading to the local population of ants being transformed into people later called Myrmidons ("MUR-mih-dahnz"). ANSWER: praying to father Zeus [accept Jupiter or Hammon in place of "Zeus"; prompt on praying with "to whom?"; prompt on praying to their father with "who is their father?"] [10e] Also by praying to Zeus, Aeacus ended a terrible drought in all of Greece except for the area around this city. This city was named after a goddess of wisdom who bested Poseidon for its patronage. ANSWER: Athens [or Athena or Athina] [10m] One of these two people prayed to his father Zeus to share his immortality with the other. These two Spartan brothers of Helen and Clytemnestra supposedly aided the Romans at the Battle of Lake Regillus.
