ANSWER: Castor AND Pollux [or Dioscuri; or Dioskouroi; or Gemini; or Castores; or Tyndaridae; or Tyndarids] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~24488~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

17. Bernard Förster and Elisabeth Nietzsche founded this country's town of Nueva Germania as an Aryan colony. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this country that committed genocide against the indigenous Aché ("ah-CHAY") people during the reign of Alfredo Stroessner ("strohss-NAIR"). ANSWER: Republic of Paraguay [or República del Paraguay] [10h] The Paraguayan government encouraged Mennonites fleeing Soviet persecution to settle in this region, where they founded the city of Filadelfia. Eusebio Alaya and Daniel Salamanca led countries in a conflict over this oil-rich region. ANSWER: Chaco [or Gran Chaco; or Dry Chaco; or Chaco Plain] [10e] Rutherford B. Hayes awarded land in the Chaco to Paraguay after this war. Paraguay's de facto first lady, Eliza Lynch, was vilified by Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay in this war. ANSWER: War of the Triple Alliance [or Guerra de la Triple Alianza; prompt on Paraguayan War] <Forrest Weintraub, History - World - Latin American> ~25530~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

18. A language discovered in this place is said to be "a Samoyed-Lithuanian dialect of Guaraní" with "inflections from classical Arabic." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this "unlimited but periodic" place that contains The Vindications. "Spherical fruits" provide light in this place composed of indefinitely many hexagonal galleries. ANSWER: the Library of Babel [or La biblioteca de Babel] [10e] In an interview, this Argentinian author of "The Library of Babel" described English as a "far finer language than Spanish." ANSWER: Jorge Luis Borges [or Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges Acevedo] [10h] One language family in this place created by Borges lacks nouns, as seen in its translation of the phrase "The moon rose above the river." The language of this place rejects a sophism involving nine coins. ANSWER: Tlön [prompt on "Tlön, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius"; reject "Uqbar" or "Orbis Tertius"] <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24697~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

19. "ADME" is a list of facets of these molecules whose delivery is modeled in pharmacokinetics. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this broad class of medicinal molecules studied in pharmacology. ANSWER: drugs [or pharmaceuticals] [10m] Transdermal delivery can be facilitated by this polar aprotic solvent that differs from acetone by having sulfur as its central atom. When deuterated, this non-chloroform compound with a four-letter name is a common NMR solvent. ANSWER: DMSO [or dimethyl sulfoxide] [10h] Because diffusion of DMSO through the skin creates a garlic taste for patients, its action lacks this desirable property of drugs. Reactions with this property neither interfere with, nor are affected by, other reactions occurring in the same time and place in vivo. ANSWER: bio·orthogonality [prompt on orthogonality] <David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~25772~ <Editor: June Yin>

20. Haydn's extensive use of timpani in the finale of a piece in this genre lends it the nickname "Pauken" ("POW-ken"), although he titled it "in tempore belli" ("in tem-POH-ray BEH-lee"). For 10 points each: [10m] In the Classical period, what genre split into a shorter "brevis" form and a longer "solemnis" form that was famously used by Beethoven? ANSWER: mass [or missa or messe; accept missa solemnis or missa brevis; accept Paukenmesse or Missa in tempore belli] [10h] Another German composer wrote his first missa solemnis at the same time as this opera, so they share many melodies. This early Romantic opera's third act features the "Huntsmen's Chorus." ANSWER: Der Freischütz ("dare FRY-shoots") [or The Free-Shooter] (by Carl Maria von Weber) [10e] This composer wrote an ironically-titled Petite messe solennelle ("puh-TEET MESS soh-luh-NEL") over thirty years after composing his last opera, William Tell. ANSWER: Gioachino Rossini [or Gioachino Antonio Rossini] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Classical> ~24555~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

21. Moscow's expensive Barvikha village is a popular destination for deposed politicians. For 10 points each: [10e] The highest profile recent dictator to take up residence in Barvikha is this man, who fled from Syria after his regime collapsed in 2024. ANSWER: Bashar al-Assad [10h] This politician fled to the village following the 2014 Euromaidan protests. This loser in the 2004 Orange Revolution election was stripped of his Ukrainian citizenship in 2023. ANSWER: Viktor Yanukovych [or Viktor Fedorovych Yanukovych] [10m] Aslan Abashidze, a pro-Russian ruler of this country's autonomous region of Ajaria, fled to Barvikha in 2005. In December 2024, people in this country formed human chains to protest the government's suspension of talks to join the EU. ANSWER: Georgia [or Sakartvelo] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~25114~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

1. In Ovid's Fasti, Flora gives an herb to this deity, who is angry about the birth of another deity. This deity was given the epithet "Caelestis" ("kye-LESS-tiss") after syncretization with the Carthaginian deity Tanit. This non-archer deity sometimes bears the name of her daughter Lucina as an epithet. Similarly to men during Saturnalia, women prepared meals for slaves during a festival celebrating this goddess. This goddess may have earned the epithet "Moneta" from her sacred (*) geese warning of an attack by the Gauls. Minerva and this goddess were worshiped as part of the Capitoline Triad. Two snakes sent by this deity were strangled by the infant Hercules. For 10 points, name this Roman goddess who was the wife of Jupiter. ANSWER: Juno [accept Juno Moneta or Juno Caelestis or Juno Lucina; prompt on Hera] (The festival is Matronalia.) <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~29576~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

2. A piece titled for this concept is "easy to enter, difficult to exit" according to its composer Pietro Locatelli. This concept titles an air and variations for harpsichord whose theme begins with the eighth notes "E, G-sharp, F-sharp, high B." An opus 3 set of Concerti a sette that alternately feature four, two, or one solo violins are titled for this sort of "inspiration." The popular finale of Handel's E major keyboard suite is titled for this concept and a (*) blacksmith. Antonio Vivaldi's opus 3 is this sort of "estro," and he included The Four Seasons in The Contest Between [this concept] and Invention. For 10 points, name this result of multiple notes sounding simultaneously that supplements rhythm and melody. ANSWER: harmony [accept The Harmonic Labyrinth or Il Laberinto Armonico; accept The Harmonious Blacksmith; accept L'estro armonico or The Harmonic Inspiration; accept The Contest Between Harmony and Invention or Il cimento dell'armonia e dell'inventione] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~29724~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

3. This character convinces four people in a row to sing "Sonny Boy" at a talent show. One man admires how this character studies "the psychology of the individual," and samples his hangover cure of egg and red pepper. This man advises wearing a devil costume to a masquerade ball to Gussie Fink-Nottle. Although he has a "feudal spirit," stories often end with this man convincing his "mentally negligible" (*) employer to give up a questionable fashion choice. Story collections are named Right Ho, [this character] and Carry On, [this character]. This man frequently gets a member of the Drones Club out of trouble with his Aunt Agatha. For 10 points, name this valet of Bertie Wooster, created by the author P. G. Wodehouse. ANSWER: Reginald Jeeves [or Reginald Jeeves; accept Right Ho, Jeeves; accept Carry On, Jeeves] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~30394~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

4. This adjective names a "spectroscopic instrument" at KPNO that is the largest 3D galaxy survey. This adjective describes a component whose EOS has a negative value for w because it has negative pressure. This adjective describes a discovery that Perlmutter, Schmitt, and Riess made by observing the nonlinear relationship between the magnitude of Type (*) Ia ("one A") supernovae and their redshift, indicating a deviation from Hubble's law. This adjective describes the discovery that validated Einstein's inclusion of Lambda, the cosmological constant. The accelerating expansion of the universe is driven by "energy" named for this adjective. For 10 points, give this adjective that describes galactic halos of unobservable "matter." ANSWER: dark [accept dark energy or dark matter] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~29694~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. In this election year, a primary challenger attempted to pass Rule 16C forcing his opponent to declare his running mate before the final party nominee vote. In this year, one candidate's inactive campaign strategy was derisively termed "Rose garden campaigning." In an interview with Playboy, the winning candidate in this election year confessed to committing "adultery in [his] (*) heart." In a debate during this year, a candidate asserted that there was "no Soviet domination of Eastern Europe." The first vice presidential debate took place in this year between Bob Dole and Walter Mondale shortly after the fall of Saigon. For 10 points, name this election year in which Gerald Ford was defeated by Jimmy Carter. ANSWER: U.S. Presidential election of 1976 [prompt on 76] <Jeffrey Liu, History - American - 1945+> ~29669~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: like (The beatnik variety is found in the phrase, "like, wow, man.")
Text: 6. A "wonderment" usage of this word is called its "beatnik" variety but may never have been used by beatniks. This word's explosion in use in computing stems from Vimeo looking for an alternative to the word "digg." The widespread use of this word as a discourse marker is characteristic of a dialect popularized by a 1982 Frank Zappa song where vocal fry and upspeak are also used. One use of this word won out against (*) "goes" in a dialect stereotypically spoken by California's Valley Girls. This English word's many uses include introducing quoted speech, as well as substituting for "for example." For 10 points, name this word that in the 2000s got an additional meaning relating to affirming something on Facebook. ANSWER: like [accept word forms such as liking or like button] (The beatnik variety is found in the phrase, "like, wow, man.") <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29754~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. The terms "scud" and "tilt" are defined in "notes" by this author, who recalled buying his French governess "Mademoiselle" a hearing aid in one memoir. Despite his requests, this author's wife did not destroy his unfinished The Original of Laura after his death. Edmund Wilson feuded with this butterfly collector over his translation of Eugene Onegin. In a novel by this author of (*) Speak, Memory framed as a manuscript edited by John Ray Jr., the title character is enrolled at Beardsley by a man whose first love is named for Poe's "Annabel Lee." That man created by this author marries the widow Charlotte Haze and murders the playwright Clare Quilty. For 10 points, Humbert Humbert pursues the title "nymphet" in what author's novel Lolita? ANSWER: Vladimir Nabokov (The unnamed work in the first line is Nabokov's Notes on Prosody.) <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~29727~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

8. Boston receives a Christmas tree each year for humanitarian efforts following one of these events involving a Belgian Relief ship. The Lehigh Valley Railroad was sued by Russia following a giant one of these events near Jersey City in 1916. One of these events provides the English title of a historical novel focusing on the career of Victor Hugues by Alejo Carpentier. The painter Carel Fabritius was killed in one of these events in (*) Delft in 1654. A giant one of these events followed a collision between the SS Imo and SS Mont-Blanc in Halifax in 1917. Robert Catesby schemed to kill James I in one of these events. For 10 points, a failed plot to cause one of what events in Parliament is commemorated on Guy Fawkes Day? ANSWER: an explosion [or setting off gunpowder; or igniting gunpowder; or ship explosion; accept the Delft Thunderclap or Halifax Explosion or or Explosion in a Cathedral; prompt on shipwreck or ship collision by asking "what happened next?"; prompt on killing or overthrowing government or staging a coup or engaging in sabotage by asking "through what means?"; prompt on fire by asking "what caused it?"] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~17537~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. At one of these events, two operatic characters speak in mock French as they pretend to be a Chevalier and a Marquis. At that one of these events, a Russian man states his motto is "chacun à son gout" ("sha-CUHN a sohn GOO"). An opera's Act II ends at one of these events, where the lead tenor gambles with Baron Douphol ("doo-FOLE") and throws his winnings at his ex-lover's feet. The maid Adele ("ah-DAY-luh") sings her "Laughing Song" at one of these events at Prince (*) Orlofsky's house. The courtesan Violetta sings "Sempre libera" after one of these events. La Traviata begins at one of these events where characters sing a brindisi, a type of drinking song. For 10 points, Johann Strauss' operetta Die Fledermaus ("dee FLAY-der-mouse") is set at what sort of event held on New Year's Eve? ANSWER: parties [accept balls or feasts or masquerades or dances; prompt on celebrations] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Opera> ~30591~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

10. This scientist names a formalism whose time-reversibility is exploited to generate paradoxical non-determinism in Norton's dome. Mordehai Milgrom developed a "modified" theory named for this scientist in an attempt to explain the dynamics of galaxies. While building on work by this scientist, Émilie du Châtelet formalized the law of conservation of energy. This non-Kepler scientist proposed the (*) three-body problem and solved the two-body problem. Galilean transformations preserve conditions named for this scientist by converting between inertial reference frames. This scientist's Principia includes his inverse-square law for "universal gravitation." For 10 points, name this scientist who developed three laws of motion. ANSWER: Isaac Newton <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~30623~ <Editor: David Bass>

11. This character flunks out of school after spending time in taverns playing dominoes. This character's first wife starts coughing up blood a week after he learns she lied about her wealth. This character is told to conjugate the Latin phrase "ridiculus sum" twenty times after being mocked for being the only boy in the classroom who does not throw his cap on the floor. This character accidentally causes Hippolyte's ("ih-poh-LEET'S") leg to be (*) amputated after trying to treat a club foot. After the death of Heloise ("el-oh-EEZ"), this character marries a woman who has affairs with Léon ("LAY-on") and Rodolphe ("roh-DOLF") before killing herself with arsenic. For 10 points, name this country doctor, who is the husband of the title character of a Gustave Flaubert ("goo-STAHV flow-BAIR") novel. ANSWER: Charles Bovary ("sharl BOH-vuh-ree") [or Charles Bovary or Monsieur Bovary or M. Bovary or Mr. Bovary; accept Emma Bovary's husband or Madame Bovary's husband or Emma's husband or equivalents; reject "Madame Bovary" or "Emma Bovary"] <Ai Xing, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~28127~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

12. Practitioners "hopping" between celebrations of this holiday may observe strings of 91 apples hung as decoration. For Samaritans who celebrate this holiday, it is the last time in the Gregorian calendar year to make pilgrimages to Mount Gerizim. White sheets are often installed to represent "Clouds of Glory" during this holiday. Seven "exalted guests" are invited via the (*) ushpizin ("ush-PEE-zin") prayer during this holiday. A s'chach ("s’KHAKH") is created from materials like bamboo or palm leaves for this holiday. This holiday involves the practice of na'anu'im, in which the four species are shaken in the four directions as well as up and down inside the central temporary structures. For 10 points, name this Jewish festival of booths. ANSWER: Sukkot [or Sukkos; accept Feast of Ingathering; accept Feast of Tabernacles; accept Feast of Booths until "booths" is read and prompt after] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Jewish Practice> ~30799~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: Sparta (The colony in the first line is Tarentum.)
Text: 13. A colony named after the son of Satyrion and Poseidon was founded by people from this city led by Phalanthus, where rain was said to fall from a clear sky. A prince from this city founded the colony of Cinyps ("KYE-nips") in modern-day Libya, which was destroyed three years later by the Macae ("mah-KAI"). That prince of this city was Dorieus, whose sister-in-law erased wax from a wooden tablet to reveal a secret message from (*) Demaratus warning of a pending invasion. The husband of that woman, Gorgo, died in battle fighting for this city after Ephialtes told the Persian Army about a secret mountain path. For 10 points, name this city that took a last stand against Xerxes at the Battle of Thermopylae, led by King Leonidas. ANSWER: Sparta [or Lacedaemonia] (The colony in the first line is Tarentum.) <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~29835~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

14. In 2025, the New York Times examined the mass tort industry through a Montana hotline named for this person. Makeup artist Mylah Morales is a talking head in a Peacock documentary partly about this man's role in a 1991 crowd crush at a CCNY charity basketball game. In April 2025, Arun Subramanian ruled that a surveillance video of this man beating his girlfriend was admissible. Danity Kane member (*) Dawn Richard ("rih-SHARD") testified about her relationship with this man, who notoriously owned 1,000 bottles of baby oil. A lawsuit filed against this man by his one-time girlfriend Cassie Ventura detailed "freak-off" parties involving drugs and male prostitutes. For 10 points, a criminal trial has begun for the alleged sex crimes of what hip-hop mogul? ANSWER: P. Diddy [or Sean "Puffy" Combs; or Puff Daddy; or PD; or Love; or Sean John Combs] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~31099~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: forearms (The answer to this question is not a joint.)
Text: 15. The Krukenberg procedure modifies this part of the body by severing the inter·osseous membrane up to the pronator teres. A bone central to this structure and an adjacent joint features the olecranon process and C-shaped trochlear notch. This non-joint structure's palmaris longus muscle is missing in one-quarter of people. A bone in this non-joint structure names the (*) UCL, problems with which can be fixed by operating on an adjacent joint in Tommy John surgery. This part of the body is proximal to the carpals and contains both radioulnar joints. This structure is distal to the humerus and contains the radius. For 10 points, name this part of the body between the wrist and the elbow. ANSWER: forearms [or lower arms; prompt on arms] (The answer to this question is not a joint.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30620~ <Editor: David Bass>

16. During this war, Biuku Gasa and Eroni Kumana paddled a canoe for over 40 miles to deliver an inscribed message to an operative. The "Tanna Army" venerated a figure popularized during this war who reportedly lives in the volcanic Mount Yasur. Natives who aided one side in this war were hailed as "Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels" for guiding wounded men down the Kokoda Trail. The soldier John (*) Frum legendarily served in this war, whose end spurred the growth of various cargo cults. During this war, the shipwrecked crew of the PT-109, including a young JFK, was rescued by two Solomon Islanders. For 10 points, name this war in which Fijian and Tongan troops supported Allied forces during the Guadalcanal campaign in 1942. ANSWER: World War II [or Second World War; or Pacific War; or Pacific Theater; or Asia–Pacific War; reject "War of the Pacific"] <Cooper Roh, History - World - Miscellaneous> ~29638~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: Africa (The essay in the first line is "How To Write About Africa" by Binyavanga Wainaina; the collection in the third line is Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o's Decolonising the Mind.)
Text: 17. The author of "Discovering Home" advised using "broad brushstrokes" when writing about this title place, whose "taboo subjects" include "ordinary domestic scenes." This place's "rudimentary souls" are discussed in an essay noting Marco Polo's omissions of the Great Wall of China. "The Quest for Relevance" is one of four essays about this place's literature in a collection that is its author's (*) "farewell to English." This "other world" contains a river described as the "antithesis of the Thames." An essay titled "An Image of" this place criticizes a Joseph Conrad novel for its racism. For 10 points, Heart of Darkness primarily takes place in what home continent of Chinua Achebe? ANSWER: Africa [accept "How to Write About Africa"; accept "An Image of Africa"] (The essay in the first line is "How To Write About Africa" by Binyavanga Wainaina; the collection in the third line is Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o's Decolonising the Mind.) <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30215~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

Answer: crosses (The first line is the Cross of Lothair.)
Text: 18. One of these objects contains a cameo of Augustus and is housed in Aachen's Treasury. Giotto painted a buried skull at the bottom of one of these objects found in the Santa Maria Novella. Gero names a half-gilded, half-painted one of these objects in Cologne, which was contemporary to free-standing "high" ones sculpted in the British Isles. Gothic cathedrals were often built in the (*) shape of these objects. Ornate types of these objects include roods, jewel-encrusted "processional" ones found in medieval churches, and Celtic ringed examples. The physical shape of these objects inspired the shape of a Heitor da Silva Costa statue above Rio de Janeiro. For 10 points, sculptures of Christ on what objects depict the crucifixion? ANSWER: crosses [accept crucifixes until "crucifixion" is read: accept Cross of Lothair or Gero Cross; accept high cross or standing cross] (The first line is the Cross of Lothair.) <Sean Farrell, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~29725~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

19. This term describes a sort of innovation in which an increasing variety of intermediate goods raises productivity. The rightmost portion of an indifference curve for perfect complements is best described by this term. Mergers described by this term are evaluated by the HHI index. As price elasticity increases, a supply curve approaches this (*) shape. This adjective describes a demand curve faced by a firm in perfect competition, since consumers are maximally sensitive to price changes. This term describes a sort of business expansion that may lower costs through economies of scale. For 10 points, name this adjective that describes a sort of "integration" contrasted with its vertical type. ANSWER: horizontal [accept word forms; accept flat or level after "complements" is read; prompt on linear after "complements" is read by asking "what specific shape?"] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~30622~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

20. This element is bonded to two oxygen and two chlorine atoms in a compound that, like bromine, is a volatile red-brown liquid at room temperature. Only this element is antiferromagnetic at room temperature. An anion with seven oxygen atoms contains two atoms of this metal in its +6 oxidation state, which is also found in a common yellow pigment. Ions of this element in (*) corundum cause the red color of ruby. This is the first element to violate the aufbau principle, since its electron configuration is "argon 3d5 4s1." This transition metal's main industrial uses are a namesake decorative electroplating process and its addition to stainless steel. For 10 points, name this element with atomic number 24 and symbol Cr. ANSWER: chromium [accept Cr until read; accept chromyl chloride; accept chrome yellow; accept dichromate] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~30587~ <Editor: June Yin>

Answer: Jules Verne (The first line references Five Weeks in A Balloon.)
Text: 21. This author wrongly described part of the African interior as a desert in a novel in which the servant Joe Wilson and hunter Dick Kennedy assist Dr. Samuel Ferguson. In a novel by this author, a man is arrested in Liverpool after being mistaken for the bank robber James Strand, making him miss a train on a day he thinks is December 21. The remains of the Battle of Vigo Bay are described in a novel by this author, in which the (*) Abraham Lincoln's passengers Conseil ("con-SAY") and Ned Land help pursue a sea monster that turns out to be a submarine operated by Captain Nemo. For 10 points, what author's adventure novels include Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea and Around the World in Eighty Days? ANSWER: Jules Verne [or Jules Gabriel Verne] (The first line references Five Weeks in A Balloon.) <Elaijah Lapay, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~21095~ <Editor: Joseph Krol> NSC 2025 - Round 09 - Bonuses

1. A man shields his face with his hands in an entry with this title from Ecuadorian painter Oswaldo Guayasamín's ("gua-YA-sa-min's") Age of Anger series. For 10 points each: [10e] Give this title of an Edvard Munch ("moonk") painting whose agonized central figure may have been inspired by a Peruvian mummy. ANSWER: The Scream [or Skrik; accept The Scream of Nature or Der Schrei der Natur; or El grito] [10h] Guayasamín studied alongside this artist, whose fiery murals include one of a priest extending out a torch. A group of skeletal gods dissect another in a massive artwork this artist created at a university's Baker Library. ANSWER: José Clemente Orozco (The second sentence is the The Epic of American Civilization.) [10m] Guayasamín and Orozco met at a gallery hosted by this family, whose member David commissioned over 30,000 works of Mexican folk art. A member of this family ordered Vladimir Lenin to be removed from the mural Man at the Crossroads. ANSWER: Rockefeller [accept David Rockefeller or Nelson Rockefeller] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - World> ~25252~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. Johnson and Rao induced this process in He·La cells with UV-inactivated Murine respiro·virus. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this process that yields syncytia like animal skeletal muscle cells. ANSWER: cell fusion [or cell–cell fusion] [10e] Johnson and Rao observed that fusing a cell in this stage with another cell causes the second cell's chromatin to condense, leading them to hypothesize a "maturation-promoting factor," or MPF. Prophase is the first part of this stage that follows G1, S, and G2. ANSWER: mitosis [or M phase or meiosis or M stage] [10m] MPF is a dimer of the "B" type of these proteins and CDK1, which is a kinase "dependent" on these proteins. The "E" and "A" types of these proteins dimerize with CDK2 to facilitate the G2–S transition. ANSWER: cyclins [or cyclin E or cyclin A or cyclin B; reject "cyclin-dependent kinases"] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~24570~ <Editor: David Bass>

3. The creator of many of these things refers to himself as "Beloved of the Gods." For 10 points each: [10m] Name these things that often used the Kharosthi script. One of these things is topped by four back-to-back lions. ANSWER: rock edicts of Ashoka [or pillar edicts of Ashoka; accept answers that describe monuments or inscriptions of Ashoka; prompt on edicts by asking "of whom?"] [10e] Ashoka created his edicts while serving as this empire's ruler. This empire defeated the Kalinga in a bloody 261 BCE war. ANSWER: Mauryan Empire [or Maurya Empire] [10h] Fifty years after the death of Ashoka, the Mauryan empire was succeeded by this dynasty founded by Pushyamitra. Kalidasa wrote a play on this dynasty's king Agnimitra. ANSWER: Shunga dynasty [or Sunga dynasty] <Geoffrey Wu, History - World - Asian> ~25513~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. A festival called Mother's Night celebrated on the eve of this holiday is only attested by Bede's The Reckoning of Time. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this Germanic winter holiday that was syncretized with Christmas, whose season is called its "tide." ANSWER: Yule [accept Yuletide] [10m] Heitstrenging is the practice of swearing a solemn oath over a sacrificial one of these animals on Yule. Jesus exorcises a demon out of a man and into a herd of these animals who drown themselves. ANSWER: pigs [or boars; or swine; or hogs] [10h] Participants go to orchards and sing to the trees to promote a good harvest in this practice that has been mostly displaced by caroling. A traditional carol is titled "Here We Come a-[doing this practice]." ANSWER: wassailing ("WOSS-ell-ing") [accept "Here We Come a-Wassailing"; prompt on drinking] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Christian Practice> ~24579~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

5. While ranking the top ten authors in this genre, Volcacius Sedigitus ("wole-KAH-kee-us se-DIH-gih-tus") claims "if anyone should feel differently, they would feel nothing." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this Roman genre which uses stock characters like the braggart soldier and the parasite. Much Ado About Nothing is a Shakespearean play in this genre. ANSWER: comedy [accept comoedia; or fabula palliata] [10m] Sedigitus places Terence in this spot, the same number of comedies that he wrote. Aeneas' men finally reach Italy in this book of the Aeneid, halfway through the work. ANSWER: six [accept sixth; accept sex; accept sextus] [10h] Sedigitus places an author with this cognomen who wrote the Plocium in first place. A later author with this cognomen wrote the Thebaid and an unfinished Achilleid. ANSWER: Statius [accept Caecilius Statius; accept Publius Papinius Statius] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24607~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

6. Human factors psychology is considered part of this field. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this field of psychology. Hugo Münsterberg studied this field of psychology, which studies interpersonal relations and well-being in corporate workplaces. ANSWER: industrial and organizational psychology [or industrial-organizational psychology or I-O psychology; prompt on partial answers; reject "industrial organization"] [10h] Hugo Münsterberg was a student of this psychologist, who also taught Edward Titchener. This "father of experimental psychology" founded the first psychology laboratory. ANSWER: Wilhelm Wundt ("voont") [or Wilhelm Maximilian Wundt] [10e] Frederick Herzberg distinguished between hygiene and this phenomenon as two factors that lead to job satisfaction. Abraham Maslow proposed his hierarchy of needs in A Theory of Human [this phenomenon], which is the drive to complete a goal. ANSWER: motivation [accept A Theory of Human Motivation] <Geoffrey Wu, Social Science - Psychology> ~25899~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

7. The first stage of the Ostwald process reacts this compound with oxygen. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this compound, the output of the Haber–Bosch process with formula NH3. ANSWER: ammonia [reject "ammonium"] [10h] This metal, alloyed with 10% rhodium, serves as the main catalyst in the Ostwald process. Until 2019, the kilogram was defined based on a cylinder made of this element combined with 10% iridium. ANSWER: platinum [or Pt] [10m] Water and this compound are the end products of the Ostwald process. This compound can be mixed with hydrochloric acid to produce a mixture capable of dissolving platinum and gold. ANSWER: nitric acid [or HNO3] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Chemistry> ~25586~ <Editor: June Yin>

Answer: Prague (The novels are Austerlitz and The Unbearable Lightness of Being.)
Text: 8. W. G. Sebald ("SAY-balt") used photos to illustrate a novel in which Jacques Austerlitz meets his former nursemaid Vera in this city. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this city that, in another novel, is the home of Sabina, who poses for photos while wearing a bowler hat. ANSWER: Prague [or Praha] (The novels are Austerlitz and The Unbearable Lightness of Being.) [10e] Photos by Ara Güler ("GOO-lair") appear in an edition of Orhan Pamuk's book Istanbul, whose subtitle mentions these phenomena "and the city." An alternative title for Marcel Proust's ("proost's") In Search of Lost Time refers to these phenomena "of things past." ANSWER: memories [or memory or remembrances or recollections; accept Istanbul: Memories and the City or Istanbul: Hatiralar ve Sehir or Remembrance of Things Past] [10h] Descriptions of photos are interspersed in this author's memoir The Years, one of many that contributed to her winning the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature. ANSWER: Annie Ernaux ("ur-NO") [or Annie Thérèse Blanche Ernaux or Annie Thérèse Blanche Duchesne] <Sean Farrell, Literature - European - Other> ~24649~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

9. Identify the following about London's International Health Exhibition of 1884, for 10 points each. [10h] One of the "insanitary" buildings showed wallpaper colored with Scheele's Green, which contains this chemical. James Marsh developed a test for this chemical used in Victorian police investigations. ANSWER: arsenic [accept arsenic poison or copper arsenite or acidic copper arsenite; prompt on poison] [10e] The flush toilets in the sanitary exhibitions helped prevent this disease. John Snow identified a pump on Broad Street as the source of transmission of an outbreak of this disease, which causes watery diarrhea. ANSWER: cholera [10m] This magazine mocked the entire "Insane-itary" exhibition. This magazine with a one-word title, co-founded by Henry Mayhew, employed cartoonists such as John Tenniel. ANSWER: Punch <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~25074~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. Florida governor Ron DeSantis competed in the 1991 Little League World Series while growing up in a city with this name. For 10 points each: [10h] The capital of New Zealand's Otago region also has what name, as the Free Church of Scotland named it after the Gaelic for Edinburgh? ANSWER: Dunedin ("dun-EE-din") [10m] A Scottish city on the River Tay provides the name of this Australian state capital, whose larger metro area includes the suburbs of Singleton and Two Rocks. The Swan River Colony was centered in this city. ANSWER: Perth [10e] Scotland's Caisteal Chalgairidh ("KASH‑tyal KHAL‑GAH‑ree") inspired the name of this Canadian province's city of Calgary. ANSWER: Alberta <Benjamin Chapman, Geography - World> ~25051~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

11. Gilbert Ryle coined the term "ghost in the machine" to criticize this philosopher's mind-body dualism. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this French philosopher who wrote Meditations on First Philosophy. ANSWER: René Descartes [accept Cartesian dualism] [10h] In The Concept of Mind, Ryle argues Descartes' dualism is one of these mistakes. Ryle demonstrates these mistakes by imagining a visitor to Oxford being shown its buildings and then asking "where is the university?" ANSWER: category mistakes [or category errors; accept word forms like categorical errors] [10m] Wilfrid Sellars imagined the Ryleans, a tribe who interact with a non-Cartesian mind, in a book titled for this view and the Philosophy of Mind. W. V. O. Quine attacked logical positivism in an essay titled "Two Dogmas of [this view]." ANSWER: empiricism [accept word forms; accept Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind; accept "Two Dogmas of Empiricism"] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~24493~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

12. Identify the following about people who have written about metaphorical liberty trees. For 10 points each: [10e] In 1787, this future president declared, "The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants." He also wrote the Declaration of Independence. ANSWER: Thomas Jefferson [10h] This abolitionist wrote, "A traitor is good fruit to hang from the boughs of the tree of liberty." In 1872, a paper run by Victoria Woodhull publicized this man's affair with Elizabeth Richards Tilton. ANSWER: Henry Ward Beecher [10m] Boston's Liberty Tree inspired this two-word phrase for lynching victims. A Billie Holiday song of this name describes "Blood on the leaves and blood at the root." ANSWER: "Strange Fruit" <Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~25069~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

13. The last movement of one of these works by this composer is a frenzied B-flat major toccata in 7/8 time, marked precipitato ("pre-CHEE-pee-ta-to"). For 10 points each: [10h] Name these works. The 6th, 7th, and 8th of these works by this composer are often grouped together since they were written during World War II. ANSWER: Sergei Prokofiev's piano sonatas [or Sergei Sergeyevich Prokofiev's piano sonatas; prompt on Sergei Prokofiev's sonatas] [10m] This Russian composer's seventh and ninth piano sonatas have the contrasting nicknames "White Mass" and "Black Mass." This synesthetic composer developed the mystic chord. ANSWER: Alexander Scriabin [or Alexander Nikolayevich Scriabin] [10e] A furious allegro molto movement concludes this other Russian composer's B-flat minor piano sonata. This composer of Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini was known for his large hands. ANSWER: Sergei Rachmaninoff [or Sergei Vasilyevich Rachmaninoff] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~25192~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

14. AC flow is improved by supplying DC to a "saturable" type of these devices. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these devices whose dissipative characteristic is measured by the Q factors, which was introduced while studying them. These devices produce magnetic fields to oppose changes in current. ANSWER: inductors [or coils or chokes; prompt on saturable reactors or reactors or by asking "what is a more common name?"] [10e] This scientist, who names a "law of induction," invented electromagnetic field-blocking "cages" that are used in microwave ovens. ANSWER: Michael Faraday [10h] This quantity for an LC circuit equals one over the square root of LC. This quantity exists for the sinusoidal driving force of a damped harmonic oscillator if the damping ratio exceeds one over root-two. ANSWER: resonant frequency [or resonance frequency; accept natural frequency; prompt on frequency or omega-sub-r or omega-sub-zero or omega-nought] <Rohan Kher, Science - Physics> ~25607~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. Charles Dickens' youngest son, who bore the unfortunate nickname "Plorn," was named for this author. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this English author who convinced Dickens to write a happier ending for Great Expectations. The lovers Glaucus and Ione appear in his novel The Last Days of Pompeii. ANSWER: Edward Bulwer-Lytton [or Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Baron Lytton; or Edward Bulwer Lytton Dickens] [10e] Bulwer-Lytton is more famous for the oft-mocked opening line of his novel Paul Clifford, which proclaims, "It was a…night" with these two classically Gothic qualities. Name both. ANSWER: dark AND stormy [reject synonyms] [10m] Bulwer-Lytton wrote the play Not So Bad As We May Seem for a charity event, with a cast including Dickens and this author. This man wrote about the switching of Laura Fairlie and Anne Catherick in The Woman in White. ANSWER: Wilkie Collins [or William Wilkie Collins] <Cooper Roh, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~24766~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

16. A space is locally Euclidean if there exists one of these functions between a neighborhood of each point and some subset of R-n. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these functions that preserve all topological properties. These continuous bijections between topological spaces have continuous inverses. ANSWER: hom·e·o·morphisms [prompt on bicontinuous functions or topological isomorphisms by asking "what is the more common name?"; prompt on isomorphisms; reject "homomorphisms"] [10m] Homeomorphisms preserve this property that is possessed by some subset of any neighborhood. A set with this property equals its interior and contains none of its boundary points. ANSWER: openness [10e] As bijections, homeomorphisms map precisely one element of this set to each element of this set's image. This set of inputs to a function is contrasted with the range. ANSWER: domain <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~24608~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. A character with this profession claims to want to do one "meaningful deed" while confessing to a fake priest who wears whiteface and a long black robe. For 10 points each: [10m] Give this profession of a Max von Sydow-played character who, in a 1957 film, makes a wager for his life with a hooded stranger he meets on a rocky beach. ANSWER: knight [accept riddare; accept cavalier or chevalier; prompt on sir or nobleman; prompt on military man or soldier; prompt on crusader] [10e] The knight Antonius Block loses a chess game to Death in this Swedish director's film The Seventh Seal. ANSWER: Ingmar Bergman [10h] Description acceptable. When Death comes for the knight, a servant girl identified in the credits as having this condition whispers "it is the end." In Bergman's Persona, the nurse Alma cares for an actress with this condition. ANSWER: mute [accept nonverbal; accept descriptions of them not speaking or not being able to talk] <Sean Farrell, Fine Arts - Film> ~24610~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

18. The high priests of a god with this animal form were the de facto rulers of Upper Egypt during the Third Intermediate Period. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this animal form of a deity whose high priestess was called his "god's wife." That chief god of the Theban triad, Amun, had this animal form. ANSWER: ram [prompt on sheep] [10e] Amun was frequently syncretized with the chief gods of neighboring kingdoms, such as the lion-headed Nubian god Apedemak and the Lower Egyptian god of this domain, Ra. ANSWER: the Sun [10h] This ram-headed god placed the ka within mothers' wombs after making it at a potter's wheel. Atum and this chief male god of Elephantine were identified with the setting sun. ANSWER: Khnum [accept Khnum-Ra] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - World Mythology> ~24616~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: Maxine Hong Kingston The protagonist of Kingston’s novel Tripmaster Monkey is punningly named for this poet, and his poem, "I Sing the Body Electric." ANSWER: Walt Whitman . Tripmaster Monkey quotes from "Song of Myself," which claims "I loafe and invite" . "I Sing the Body Electric" ends "O I say now these are !" and asks "what is ?" ANSWER: the soul
Text: 19. This author of the book-length poem I Love a Broad Margin to My Life wrote a memoir of "a girlhood among ghosts" which was reviewed as "a poem turned into a sword." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this author, who described how her mother cut the membrane of her tongue and told her stories of Fa Mu Lan in The Woman Warrior. ANSWER: Maxine Hong Kingston [10e] The protagonist of Kingston’s novel Tripmaster Monkey is punningly named for this poet, and his poem, "I Sing the Body Electric." ANSWER: Walt Whitman [or Walter Whitman Jr., or Wittman Ah Sing; prompt on Wittman Ah Sing]. [10m] Tripmaster Monkey quotes from "Song of Myself," which claims "I loafe and invite" [this thing]. "I Sing the Body Electric" ends "O I say now these are [this word]!" and asks "what is [this thing]?" ANSWER: the soul <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~24623~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

20. One of these people complained, "It dims your eyes, makes your back ache, and knits your chest and belly together" about laboring in the scriptorium. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these men who might copy manuscripts while belonging to orders such as the Carthusians or Benedictines. ANSWER: monks [accept Carthusian monks or Benedictine monks or lay brothers; prompt on clergy or priests or scribes] [10m] This dynasty lends its name to a variant of Latin script used in many 8th century manuscripts. This dynasty was founded by Clovis I in 509. ANSWER: Merovingian dynasty [accept Merovingian script] [10h] Baghdad's House of Wisdom both copied manuscripts and made original work like this man's Al-Jabr. This Persian polymath spread Hindu numerals to the West and is the source of the word "algorithm." ANSWER: Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25172~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

21. The size of a CD was increased from 11.5 to 12 centimeters to allow this symphony, the favorite of Sony president Norio Ohga, to fit on one disc. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this symphony whose deaf composer had to be turned by Caroline Unger at its 1824 premiere to see the audience applaud. ANSWER: Beethoven's Ninth Symphony [or Beethoven's Symphony No. 9] [10m] In 1988, the Voyager Company released a pioneering CD-ROM of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Voyager once owned this other company, which restores classic films for its namesake "Collection." ANSWER: Criterion [or The Criterion Collection, Inc.] [10h] Voyager also released a CD-ROM version of this book, which included special features such as taped transcripts with Vladek, a character often seen on an exercise bike. ANSWER: Maus [or The Complete Maus] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~22557~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

1. Note to moderators: you're doing a great job! Thanks for staffing! This person holds an open book in front of a tiered, conical mountain in a fresco by Domenico di Michelino. This person clutches a companion as they watch a wrestling man bite his opponent's neck in a painting by William Bouguereau ("boo-GRO"). This person and his lover watch as hundreds of bodies create concentric circles around a beam of light as part of a series of illustrations by Gustave (*) Doré ("door-AY"). A statue of this real-life person appears below the Three Shades in an installation whose other pieces include The Kiss and Ugolino and his Children. Renaissance portraits of this author often depict him wearing a laurel over a red cap. For 10 points, Auguste Rodin's Gates of Hell were inspired by what author's Divine Comedy? ANSWER: Dante [or Dante Alighieri] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~30578~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. Gabriele Veneziano's application of the Euler beta function to mesons inspired work on these objects by Nielsen and Susskind. The groups S·O-32 and E8-times-E8 characterize the two descriptions of the hybrid "heterotic" type of these objects. These objects imply compactification on Calabi–Yau manifolds in successors to Kaluza–Klein theory. Worldsheets are traced out by these objects whose size is on the order of the (*) Planck length. The "bulk" contains generalizations of these objects called "branes," spelled like "membranes." M-theory uses eleven-dimensional supergravity to describe these objects. For 10 points, a potential theory of everything replaces particles with what vibrating, one-dimensional objects? ANSWER: strings [accept string theory; accept superstrings or superstring theory; prompt on branes before read] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~31184~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Oscar Wilde (The poem in the third line is A. E. Housman's "Oh Who Is That Young Sinner.")
Text: 3. In a poem by this author, a "snare / Strangled into a scream" after singers evoke men who play "with Sin / In the Secret House of Shame." That poem by this author published under the name "C.3.3." describes a cricket-cap-wearing man "who looked / So wistfully at the day." This man inspired a poem in which the title "young sinner" can curse God "for the colour of his hair." This poet addressed his "Dear Bosie" in the letter (*) De Profundis. This lover of Alfred Douglas described how, "The coward does it with a kiss, / The brave man with a sword" in a poem titled for the place where he was jailed for being gay. For 10 points, name this Irish poet who claimed that "each man kills the thing he loves" in his "The Ballad of Reading Gaol" ("RED-ing jail"). ANSWER: Oscar Wilde [or Oscar Fingal O'Flahertie Wills Wilde] (The poem in the third line is A. E. Housman's "Oh Who Is That Young Sinner.") <Kevin Wang, Literature - British - Poetry> ~29811~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

4. This thinker names a philosophical school inspired by Middle Platonism whose adherents, such as Nigidius Figulus ("nih-GIH-dih-us FIG-oo-lus"), attempted to infuse mysticism into Hellenistic philosophy. The earliest source on this thinker's philosophy mocks his belief of metempsychosis, or the "transmigration of souls." Aristotle's On the Heavens refutes this thinker's belief that the proportions in the movements of (*) celestial bodies is a form of music. Hippasus, a follower of this thinker, was supposedly drowned for discovering irrational numbers. This thinker died after refusing to run through a field of fava beans, whose consumption he forbade. For 10 points, what Greek thinker's namesake theorem relates the side lengths of right triangles? ANSWER: Pythagoras [accept Pythagoreanism or Neopythagoreanism] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Philosophy> ~29760~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

5. After an assassination attempt on this man, the family name "Tsuda" was outlawed. This man's cousin Prince George of Greece and Denmark saved him from a fatal saber blow in the Otsu incident. This ruler and his foreign minister proposed the First Hague Conference. Rumors about a lack of beer and pretzels during this man's coronation led to the deaths of over 1,000 subjects at Khodynka ("koh-DIN-kah") Field. A prime minister of this monarch who extended the (*) zemstvo system into Poland was assassinated by Dmitrii Bogrov and was named Pyotr Stolypin. This ruler's bones were dissolved in acid and thrown down a mineshaft. An advisor to this ruler treated the hemophilia of his son, Alexei. For 10 points, name this final emperor of Russia. ANSWER: Nicholas II [or Nikolai II; or Nikolai Alexandrovich Romanov; prompt on Nicholas or Nikolai; prompt on Romanov] <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1900+> ~30093~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. Similar and dissimilar people in diverse societies are respectively linked by this concept's "bonding" and "bridging" forms. It's not power, but the "symbolic" form of this concept enables people to commit symbolic violence. The mannerisms and aesthetic tastes of the upper class act as the "cultural" form of this concept according to Pierre Bourdieu ("boor-d'YUH"). Robert Putnam adapted an essay studying the decline of this concept's (*) "social" form into the book Bowling Alone. Knowledge and education are often classified as the "human" type of this concept, which is tied to productivity. Land, labor, and this concept are the three main factors of production. For 10 points, what concept titles an economic treatise by Karl Marx? ANSWER: capital [accept bonding capital; accept bridging capital; accept social capital; accept symbolic capital; accept cultural capital; accept human capital; accept Das Kapital] <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Sociology> ~30575~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

7. Early research on this process is surveyed in Yuri Lazebnik's paper "Can a biologist fix a radio?" During this process, certain enzymes perform auto·proteo·lytic cleavage of their pro·domains, allowing them to form "initiator" tetra·mers that activate "effector" tetra·mers. A pathway central to this process in C. elegans involves CED-9, CED-4, CED-3, and the BH3-only protein EGL-1. The DISC is formed by (*) Fas receptors in the "extrinsic" pathway for this process, whose "intrinsic" pathway involves BCL2 family proteins regulating the release of cytochrome c in the mitochondria. Caspases drive markers of this process like blebbing and DNA fragmentation. For 10 points, name this process of programmed cell death. ANSWER: apoptosis [prompt on programmed cell death] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~29612~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. A ruler of this empire [emphasize] completed a canal passing through the Bitter Lakes, whose construction began under Necho ("NECK-oh") II. A ruler of this empire was apocryphally so enraged that a traditional festival was being celebrated after a military defeat that he slew the Apis bull. This empire's army crushed Psamtik ("SAHM-tick") III's forces at the Battle of Pelusium. A ruler of this empire authored a text detailing the overthrown of the magus Gaumata, called the (*) Behistun Inscription. This empire conquered Egypt under Cambyses II, whose father conquered the Neo-Babylonians and the Median empire. The Gordian knot was split by Alexander the Great during his conquest of, for 10 points, what Iranian empire ruled by Darius I and Cyrus II? ANSWER: Achaemenid Empire [or the first Persian Empire; or Persia] <Forrest Weintraub, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~29582~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

9. An Avignon-based tradition called the "subtler art" colored these symbols red to indicate diminutions. These symbols were altered by ficta and grouped according to mensuration signs in the Renaissance. Ottaviano Petrucci printed these symbols with movable type. A mnemonic used to read a kind of these symbols called neumes ("n'YOOMS") was developed in the Micrologus of Guido d'Arezzo, based on the hymn (*) "Ut Queant Laxis." Some British names for these symbols are borrowed from old Latin and French terms like minim, breve ("BREEV"), and crotchet ("CROTCH-et"). Ledger lines make it easier to read these symbols, which are sometimes read using solfège syllables. For 10 points, name these symbols written on a staff that specify pitch and duration. ANSWER: musical notes [accept neumes until read; prompt on music notation] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~29802~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

10. In this play, a man quotes "The Moor, I know his trumpet" to mock his father's snoring. In this play, a man concludes "We are such stuff as manure is made on, so let's drink up and forget it," and describes his brother reciting Dowson's Cynara to a fat brothel worker. The sound of a foghorn recurs in this play, in which a man claims that another man could play Old Gaspard the (*) miser for hiring the cheap Dr. Hardy. In this play, a man is slapped for yelling "The Mad Scene. Enter Ophelia!" as his mother walks downstairs in a trance holding a wedding dress. In this play, Mary tries to hide her morphine addiction from her sons, the alcoholic Jamie and the consumptive Edward, and her actor husband. For 10 points, name this Eugene O'Neill play about the Tyrone family. ANSWER: Long Day's Journey into Night <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Drama> ~30497~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

11. It's not pancakes, but a specialty of Phnom Penh ("puh-NAHM PEN") is a THC-infused "happy" version of this food. São Paulo's Bexiga neighborhood has many restaurants selling this food with calabresa sausage. Velveeta was originally used in a variety of this food named for the Altoona Hotel. Canadian contributions to this food include ginger-flavored "Indian-style" ones offered at Supreme and a polarizing variety invented by Greek immigrant Sam Panopoulos named for a brand of canned (*) pineapples. A popular variety of this food whose colors represent a national flag was named for Queen Margherita of Savoy and contains green basil and white mozzarella. For 10 points, name this food that is often sold in Chicago deep dish shops. ANSWER: pizza [accept margherita pizza or deep dish pizza or Hawaiian pizza or Indian pizza or desi pizza or Punjabi pizza or Altoona pizza or happy pizza] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~30198~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

12. Primus homo was created by the "father of" this quality. The word for either this quality or "juiciness" appears in the name of an event in which it is created by a river of molten metal, called frashokereti ("FRAH-shoh-kuh-REH-tee"). ʻAbdu'l-Bahá endorsed the idea that another quality is just the "privation" of this one, as theorized by Augustine. The phrase Vohu Manah refers to this sort of (*) "mind" or "thought." This adjective is part of the etymology of "gospel." It's not truth, but this concept is defended by divinities called yazatas against the daevas and by the creator Ahura Mazda against Angra Mainyu. For 10 points, dualistic religions like Zoroastrianism hold the world is a battleground between the forces of what concept and evil? ANSWER: goodness [or word forms; accept greatness; accept excellence; accept purity; accept vohu until read; accept Father of Greatness or abbā ḏ-rabbūṯā; accept frashokereti until read; accept good news; prompt on light; reject "asha" or "truth"] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Other Religion> ~30626~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

13. A novel by this author that ends with a teacher buying a black necktie also details the political rise of that man's gay nephew. In a novel by this author whose translation was managed by Jackie Kennedy, a woman who always wakes at midnight without an alarm clock is kicked out of her home for visiting a shrine. In another novel by this author, a man who is rejected by the lute player Zanuba mourns his lawyer son (*) Fahmy's shooting during a protest. This author of The Thief and the Dogs described Amina being exiled from her home after being struck by a car because she left home without permission. For 10 points, name this author who chronicled three generations of the al-Jawad family in his Cairo Trilogy. ANSWER: Naguib Mahfouz [or Naguib Mahfouz Abdelaziz Ibrahim Ahmed Al-Basha] <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~29720~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

14. This process names a form of blistering that can cause epoxy resins to delaminate. Loeb and Sourirajan developed a type of power named for this process, which is maintained in one technique by recovering the draw solution to keep a steady TDS level. Strongly dissociating compounds have a high molarity named for this process, which also names industrial (*) "forward" and "pressure-retarded" techniques. This process' pressure is proportional to temperature, concentration and the van't Hoff factor. Hypertonic solutions naturally undergo this process, unlike in desalination plants where a "reverse" form is forcibly carried out. For 10 points, name this process in which water diffuses across a semipermeable membrane. ANSWER: osmosis [accept reverse osmosis; accept forward osmosis; accept pressure-retarded osmosis; accept osmotic blistering; prompt on osmolarity; prompt on diffusion until "diffuses" is read] <Sean Farrell, Science - Chemistry> ~29690~ <Editor: June Yin>

15. This activist left Bache & Company to work on a production of the musical Hair. This activist worked with Allan Baird of the Teamsters during a boycott of Coors Beer. This activist said his election would be a "green light" in his "Hope Speech," which opposed the Briggs Initiative. The title of a Randy Shilts biography of this person references a camera store he owned on (*) Castro Street. This man's death inspired Cleve Jones to begin the NAMES Project. Dianne Feinstein discovered this man's body after an event whose perpetrator used the "Twinkie defense." Dan White murdered this man alongside George Moscone. For 10 points, name this politician, the first openly gay member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors. ANSWER: Harvey Milk [or Harvey Bernard Milk] <Yaj Jhajhria, History - American - 1945+> ~31158~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: inheritance (The third sentence refers to C++, then Java.)
Text: 16. This technique is regulated by the "L" in the mnemonic "SOLID," which stands for the Liskov substitution principle. Ambiguity in this technique causes the diamond problem. In one common language, the keyword "virtual" facilitates overriding with this technique, while another language simulates this technique with interfaces. Polymorphism often arises from this technique, which creates an "is a" relationship contrasted with (*) composition's "has a" relationship. Java's keyword "extends" denotes this technique. This technique defines a subclass that gains the attributes of a superclass, or parent. For 10 points, name this technique in object-oriented programming that is named for receiving things from a family member. ANSWER: inheritance [accept multiple inheritance or shared inheritance or replicated inheritance or subclassing; accept word forms like inherited; prompt on object-oriented programming or OOP; prompt on word forms of extends until read by asking "what is the more general name?"; prompt on polymorphism until read by asking "what technique gives rise to polymorphism in this context?"] (The third sentence refers to C++, then Java.) <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~29664~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. Ada Louise Huxtable ridiculed a building with a facade of this material as "the Lollipop." A type of this material named for a peacock was paired with a golden variety for inlaid opus sectile artworks. Scagliola imitates this material, which was commonly clad as veneers on bricks. Historical sources for this building material include Pentelicon and (*) Carrara. Henry Bacon designed a building made of this material which contains a monumental statue with an open hand and closed fist by Daniel Chester French. One building of this material is decorated with ninety-two metopes carved in high relief and depicting the Gigantomachy. For 10 points, name this material used to build the Parthenon. ANSWER: marble [prompt on stone or rock] (The lead-in is 2 Columbus Circle in New York. The second line refers to pavonazzetto and giallo antico.) <Joseph Chambers, Fine Arts - Architecture> ~30305~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

18. The first mass-application of this technique in England used the secret Suttonian Method. Emmanuel Timoni introduced this technique into England, having learned it from the Turks. Thomas Dimsdale introduced this technique into Russia and personally applied it to Catherine the Great. An enslaved man named Onesimus transferred knowledge of this technique to his master, (*) Cotton Mather. This technique was probably developed in China, where it killed about 2% of people who received it. A less-deadly alternative to this technique was based on observations of milkmaids by Edward Jenner. This technique involved placing pus into a non-infected person. For 10 points, name this predecessor to smallpox vaccination. ANSWER: inoculation [or variolation; or insufflation; accept smallpox inoculation; reject "vaccination"] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30247~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

19. Bhīma killed Maṇimān at one of these locations called Gandhamadana to which Kubera was driven from Lanka by his half-brother. One of these locations named Mainaka was hidden by Vayu to protect it from Indra. One of these locations made of crystal, ruby, gold, and lapis lazuli was used to trap Ravana for 1000 years. The (*) Sanjivani herb was located on one of these locations that Hanuman carried to heal Lakshmana. To protect Vrindavan, one of these locations is lifted above it by Krishna using one finger. The Pandavas all died except for Yudhishthira on a journey to one of these locations to reach the heavens. For 10 points, name these geographical locations, examples of which include Meru in the Himalayas. ANSWER: mountains [or mounts; or peaks; or mounds; or hills; or mountain ranges; accept Mount Kailasha; accept Mount Meru] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - World Mythology> ~30478~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

20. A history of this object by the astronomer Flegetanis ("fleh-guh-TAH-niss") was supposedly found by the probably-fictional Kyot the Provençal ("prov-on-SAHL"). This object provides part of an alternative title for the Vulgate Cycle. This object was introduced in a verse romance whose protagonist fails to ask who it serves during a procession. A dubious etymology based on this object's French name linked it to "royal blood." A poem by (*) Robert de Boron ("roh-BAIR duh boh-RON") claimed that this object was looked after by Joseph of Arimathea ("ah-rih-muh-THEE-uh"). This object sometimes names Corbenic, the castle where it is kept by the Fisher King. The seeker of this object is named as Perceval or Galahad. For 10 points, in Arthurian poems, what object is sometimes identified with Jesus's chalice? ANSWER: Holy Grail [or Saint Graal; accept Lancelot-Grail Cycle or Perceval, the Story of the Grail or Perceval ou le Conte du Graal or Grail Castle; accept Holy Chalice until read] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Other> ~29591~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

21. Two Baha'i holidays commemorating these events were moved to the first and second days of the Islamic month of Muharram. At a feast for one of these events held by Pharaoh, Joseph's prophecies concerning the baker and the cupbearer come true. A fourth century treatise links two of these events involving John the Baptist and Jesus Christ to the solstices. In medieval times, these events were celebrated by nobility, while peasants instead celebrated namesake (*) saints. In Islam, one of these events is commemorated by Mawlid. Due to supposed pagan origins, Jehovah's witnesses reject the celebration of these events. For 10 points, name these events that include one involving Jesus celebrated on December 25th. ANSWER: birthdays [accept births; accept birthday of Jesus; accept birthday of Muhammad; accept birthday of John the Baptist; accept Twin Holy Birthdays or birthday of Baha'u'llah or birthday of the Bab; prompt on Christmas] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Other Religion> ~30795~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales> NSC 2025 - Round 10 - Bonuses

Answer: trans-Neptunian (The lead-in describes "Generation of Low-Inclination, Neptune-Crossing TNOs by Planet Nine." The 2016 claim is the existence of Planet Nine.)
Text: 1. Batygin and Brown are co-authors on a 2024 study of 17 objects with this property and low-q orbits. For 10 points each: [10h] Give this specific term that describes objects whose high inclinations and clustered orbits provide evidence of a 2016 claim by Batygin and Brown. An object has this property if its orbit has a value greater than 30.1 AU for a. ANSWER: trans-Neptunian [accept trans-Neptunian objects or TNOs] (The lead-in describes "Generation of Low-Inclination, Neptune-Crossing TNOs by Planet Nine." The 2016 claim is the existence of Planet Nine.) [10m] Certain TNOs are classified based on having values of 2-to-3 or 1-to-2 for this property. Cubewanos ("kyoo-bee-WUN-ohs") lack this property that is possessed by Io and Europa with respect to Ganymede. ANSWER: orbital resonance [or resonant] (Cubewanos are contrasted with resonant Kuiper Belt objects.) [10e] The largest observed TNOs have this classification. Following efforts by Brown, Pluto was demoted to this classification in 2006. ANSWER: dwarf planet [or dwarfs] <Rohan Kher, Science - Other Science> ~25640~ <Editor: David Bass>

2. These are the two main families respectively descended from Adélaïde Fouque's ("ah-day-lie-EED fooc's") marriage to a gardener and affair with a smuggler. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these two literary families, one upper-class and one working-class, members of which respectively appear in the novels L'Argent ("larzh-ON") and L'Assommoir ("lass-om-WAHR"). ANSWER: Rougon ("roo-GON") family and Macquart ("mah-CAR") family [or the Rougons and the Macquarts; accept answers in either order; accept Rougon-Macquart cycle or Les Rougon-Macquart; reject partial answers] [10m] The penultimate Rougon-Macquart novel, The Debacle, is set during this war. A story set during this war ends with Elisabeth weeping as Cornudet ("COR-noo-day") whistles. ANSWER: Franco-Prussian War [or Franco-German War] (The story is "Boule de Suif.") [10e] This naturalist French author included Germinal ("zhair-mih-NAL") in the Rougon-Macquart cycle. This author defended Alfred Dreyfus in his open letter "J'Accuse" ("zhah-COOZ"). ANSWER: Émile Zola ("ay-meel ZOH-lah") [or Émile Édouard Charles Antoine Zola] <Noah Chin, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~24813~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

3. The word "massacre" was popularized following an incident on this island in 1623 where twenty English traders were beheaded by the Dutch East Indies Company. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this Indonesian island, long the principal source of the world's cloves. ANSWER: Ambon [or Amboyna or Amboina] [10e] The massacres of these French Protestants also helped popularize the word in English. These Calvinists were granted toleration in the Edict of Nantes. ANSWER: Huguenots [10m] Another early use of "massacre" was in a translation of Johannes Sleidanus's account of this 1282 rebellion. 2,000 French people were killed in this rebellion against Charles I of Anjou that began on Easter Monday. ANSWER: Sicilian Vespers [or Vespri siciliani; or Vespiri siciliani; or War of the Sicilian Vespers; prompt on Vespers] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25416~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

4. This artist interplayed with the production sounds of his partner Terrace Martin from the jazz group Dinner Party on the track "u." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this tenor saxophonist who played on Kendrick Lamar's album To Pimp A Butterfly. His own albums include 2015's The Epic and 2018's Heaven on Earth. ANSWER: Kamasi Washington [or Kamasi Tii Washington] [10m] Washington's frequent collaborator Thundercat played this instrument on To Pimp A Butterfly. Other players of this instrument include Esperanza Spalding and Jaco Pastorius. ANSWER: bass [or electric bass; reject "double bass" or "string bass" or "upright bass"] [10e] Over a Fela Kuti sample on the track "Mortal Man," Kendrick alludes to this leader, whose prison cell inspired him to make the album. Paul Simon’s album Graceland recorded South African bands during this leader’s imprisonment on Robben Island. ANSWER: Nelson Mandela <Jamie Burchett, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~24648~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

5. "The Maidens' War" is a legend from this modern-day country where women slaughtered men who drank mead laced with a sleeping potion. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this modern-day country whose ancestor was separated from his brothers Lech and Rus during a hunting trip in a series of founding myths. A legendary creature was stored in an attic in this country by a man called "the Maharal." ANSWER: Czechia [or Czech Republic; or Česká republika; prompt on Bohemia] [10e] During 16th century pogroms in Prague, Rabbi Loew used river clay to create one of these protective beings from Jewish folklore. ANSWER: golems [accept Golem of Prague] [10m] This Bohemian saint was executed by his brother Boleslaus ("BOL-eh-slaff") the Cruel. A journey taken by this man inspired a carol for St. Stephen's Day. ANSWER: Wenceslas I, Duke of Bohemia [accept Vaclav the Good] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~25761~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

6. An exonym for these people provides the name for carved moki steps that can be found around Lake Powell. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these people who used core-and-veneer walls to build "great houses" in the San Juan Basin. These people's pithouses evolved into modern-day kivas. ANSWER: Ancestral Puebloans [or Anasazi; prompt on but do not reveal Chaco culture] [10h] The Ancestral Puebloans developed core-and-veneer masonry at this canyon, whose Pueblo Bonito has provided evidence of cacao use and domesticated macaws. ANSWER: Chaco Canyon [10e] Before building houses out of brick, the Ancestral Puebloans built jacal walls out of sticks and this material. Many modern pueblos are constructed with sun-baked adobe bricks made of this material. ANSWER: mud [accept earth or clay or soil or dirt] <Sean Farrell, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24605~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

7. This country's music inspired the chant "¡Mayombe—bombe—mayombé!" in a poem depicting the ritualistic killing of a snake called "Sensemaya." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this home country of a poet who wrote "I cultivate a white rose" in a poem from Versos Sencillos. ANSWER: Republic of Cuba [or Republica de Cuba] [10h] Cuban poet José Martí described cultivating a white rose for a "friend" described by this adjective. The first poem of Versos Sencillos is titled, "I am [this sort of] Man." ANSWER: sincere [or sincero; accept "I am a Sincere Man" or "Yo soy un hombre sincero"] [10e] "Sensemaya" author Nicolas Guillén was inspired to publish his first collection, Motivos de son, after seeing this author's enthusiasm for Cuban music. This Harlem Renaissance poet wrote "The Weary Blues." ANSWER: Langston Hughes <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25540~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

8. In 2012, this city's Times-Picayune newspaper moved to a three-days-a-week publication schedule. For 10 points each: [10e] Identify this Southern city where on January 1, 2025 a man drove a pickup truck into pedestrians on Bourbon Street. ANSWER: New Orleans [10h] New Orleans news source nola.com won a Pulitzer for a series on a Jim Crow-era Louisiana law that unusually allowed disagreement in these groups. Warner Bros. buried the release of a 2024 Clint Eastwood film titled for one of these groups. ANSWER: juries [or criminal jury; accept Juror #2] [10m] Another nola.com investigation exposed corruption of Burl Cain, the notorious warden of this state penitentiary that shares its most common name with a country in Southern Africa. ANSWER: Angola [accept Angola Plantation; prompt on Louisiana State Penitentiary or The Farm or the Alcatraz of the South] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~25030~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. Das and Pappu's kappa measures the "mixing" of these moieties' charge. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these moieties that distinguish amino acids. An amino acid consists of an amino group, a carboxyl group, a hydrogen atom, and one of these components around the alpha carbon. ANSWER: side chains [prompt on R groups] [10h] At neutral pH, these two amino acids have negatively charged side chains. These two amino acids are respectively symbolized D and E. ANSWER: aspartic acid AND glutamic acid [accept aspartate in place of "aspartic acid"; accept glutamate in place of "glutamic acid"; accept answers in either order] [10e] The side chains of serine, threonine, asparagine, and glutamine have this property despite being uncharged. Water has this property, in which opposite ends of a molecule carry different charges. ANSWER: polarity <David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~25641~ <Editor: June Yin>

10. A church of this religion controversially reopened across from the University of Texas at Austin in 2024. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this religion based on dianetics that was founded by author L. Ron Hubbard. ANSWER: Church of Scientology [accept Scientologists] [10m] The Church of Scientology is reluctant to acknowledge this alien pivotal to the scriptures. Hubbard claimed that this alien dictator killed aliens with hydrogen bombs to curb overpopulation in the Galactic Confederacy. ANSWER: Xenu [accept Xemu] [10h] Members of Scientology undergo auditing to achieve this state of complete spiritual freedom. After a member has removed their reactive mind and achieved "Clear", they may attempt to go to this state. ANSWER: Operating Thetan [prompt on Thetan] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Other Religion> ~25327~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

11. This short story ends with a man observing that he "had never slept in a better bed." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this frequently-anthologized short story by Richard Connell. This story’s protagonist is tracked down on Ship-Trap Island by General Zaroff, who amuses himself by hunting humans as the title prey. ANSWER: "The Most Dangerous Game" [prompt on "The Hounds of Zaroff" by asking "what is the more common title?"] [10e] Margot shoots her husband while on safari in this author's story "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber." ANSWER: Ernest Hemingway [10h] People play a legal game of human-hunting in "Seventh Victim," a story by an author with this first name. An author with this first name wrote a poem ending "And the hunter home from the hill," and wrote about the abducted orphan David Balfour in Catriona ("Katrina"). ANSWER: Robert [accept Robert Sheckley or Robert Louis Stevenson] (David Balfour is the protagonist of Kidnapped.) <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Short Fiction> ~25542~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

12. Until 2010, the Easter Sonata by a composer with this surname was misattributed to her brother. For 10 points each: [10e] Give this maiden name of Fanny Hensel. Her brother with this surname wrote incidental music for A Midsummer's Night Dream. ANSWER: Mendelssohn [or Mendelssohn-Bartholdy; accept Fanny Mendelssohn or Felix Mendelssohn; accept Fanny Cäcilie Mendelssohn Bartholdy or Jakob Ludwig Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy] [10m] Felix Mendelssohn premiered his piece of this genre and number at a private concert for Fanny's 19th birthday. Johannes Brahms' piece of this genre and number channels Beethoven by starting in C minor and ending in C major. ANSWER: Symphony No. 1 [or First Symphony] [10h] Fanny made her performing debut with her brother's Piano Concerto No. 1 in this key. Albert Parlow's orchestration of Brahms' Hungarian Dance No. 5 transposes it into this key. ANSWER: G minor [reject "G"] (The piano version is in F-sharp minor.) <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~25207~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

13. Charlotte Rampling rejected a role in an unmade film adaptation of this book over a scene in which an army defecates in sync. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this 1965 sci-fi novel that Alejandro Jodorowsky ("ho-dor-OFF-skee") sought to adapt as a 10-hour film. Rampling would later star in a 2021 film of this Frank Herbert novel opposite Timothée Chalamet as Paul Atreides. ANSWER: Dune [accept Dune Chronicles or Dune World or Prophet of Dune or Jodorowsky's Dune] [10h] This artist demanded $100,000 an hour to play the Emperor in Jodorowsky's Dune, leading to plans to use a robotic double for most shots. ANSWER: Salvador Dalí [or Salvador Dalí, Marquess of Dalí of Púbol; or Salvador Domingo Felipe Jacinto Dalí i Domènech] [10m] Johnny Darrell's This Film Does Not Exist used AI to imagine a Jodorowsky version of this 1982 film. A character played by Jeff Bridges goes inside of a computer in this pioneering CGI film. ANSWER: Tron <Jamie Burchett, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~24708~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. The Nagarakretagama said this modern-day country was a constituent state of the Majapahit before becoming a Hashemite state. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this Asian nation governed from Kota Batu during the Castilian War with Spain. Since 1967, this small country has been ruled by Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah. ANSWER: Brunei [or Sultanate of Brunei; or Brunei Darussalam] [10e] During the Castilian War, Bruneians fought alongside Ottomans and soldiers from this present-day country, which composed most of the Straits Settlements, including Kuala Lumpur. ANSWER: Malaysia [or Federation of Malaya or Persekutuan Tanah Melayu] [10h] The royal house of Brunei developed trade partnerships with a sultanate of this name ruled by Sharif ul-Hāshim on a namesake Filipino archipelago between Sabah and Mindanao.
