ANSWER: Sultanate of Sulu [or Sulu Archipelago] <Noah Sheidlower, History - World - Asian> ~25757~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: superconductivity (The Ginzburg criterion shows that the mean-field approximation breaks down within only a small range of the superconducting critical temperature, so the latent heat produced is very small.)
Text: 15. The Ginzburg criterion shows why the onset of this phenomenon appears to be a second-order phase transition, despite it being first-order. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this phenomenon described by both Ginzburg and Landau's macroscopic mean field theory and BCS theory. ANSWER: superconductivity [or superconductors or superconducting; accept type I superconductivity] (The Ginzburg criterion shows that the mean-field approximation breaks down within only a small range of the superconducting critical temperature, so the latent heat produced is very small.) [10e] The mean-field Ising model correctly predicts these materials' second-order phase transition. Nickel, cobalt, and iron exemplify these materials. ANSWER: ferromagnets [or ferromagnetic materials; prompt on permanent magnets or magnets or magnetic materials; prompt on metals] [10h] The classification of phase transitions as first or second-order was introduced by this scientist. This scientist names a relativistic paradox and a theorem in quantum mechanics that states that expectation values behave as they do in classical physics. ANSWER: Paul Ehrenfest ("AIR-in-fest") <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~25593~ <Editor: David Bass>

16. This interventionist asserted a "responsibility to protect" while at the Harvard Kennedy School. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this person who wrote "A Problem from Hell." This diplomat represented the US in the United Nations from 2013 to 2017. ANSWER: Samantha Power [or Samantha Jane Power] [10e] Samantha Power is associated with this international relations theory, which emphasizes cooperation. The "neo-" form of this school, which is associated with Joseph Nye, is contrasted with the neoconservatism of Dick Cheney. ANSWER: liberalism [accept neoliberalism or liberal institutionalism or institutional liberalism] [10m] Joseph Nye defined this concept as "the ability to obtain preferred outcomes by attraction rather than coercion or payment." Hollywood movies are often cited as radiating this kind of power. ANSWER: soft power <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Other> ~25615~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

17. Due to a facial tumor affecting his vision, the second Portuguese king of this name fatally tripped down a staircase at a theater in 1885. For 10 points each: [10h] What regnal name did the king of Romania and tsar of Bulgaria share during World War I? ANSWER: Ferdinand [or Fernando II of Portugal; or Ferdinand August Franz Anton; or Ferdinand I of Romania; or Ferdinand Viktor Albert Meinrad; or Ferdinand I of Bulgaria; or Ferdinand Maximilian Karl Leopold Maria] [10e] Tsar Ferdinand's 1913 invasion of Serbia and Greece instigated the second war named for this European peninsula. Franz Ferdinand's assassination proved Bismarck's prediction that "some damned foolish thing" in this region would start World War I. ANSWER: Balkan peninsula [or Balkans; or Second Balkan War] [10m] This ruling house of Prussia's Sigmaringen branch included both Ferdinand of Romania and his father, Leopold, whom Bismarck had tried to place on the Spanish throne. ANSWER: House of Hohenzollern [or House of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen] <Cooper Roh, History - European - 1900+> ~24665~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

18. In the story "The Actor and the Alibi," an actress commits murder while acting in a play named for one of these places, since its staging has Lady Teazle hide behind a screen. For 10 points each: [10e] Lady Sneerwell plots to stop Charles Surface's marriage in a play named The [what place] for Scandal? As a child, Jane Eyre is punished by Mr. Brocklehurst at the cruel Lowood one of these places.  ANSWER: school [accept The School for Scandal; accept Lowood School; accept boarding school; prompt on Lowood Institution; prompt on campus or boarding school] [10m] This author of The Rivals did not finish writing The School for Scandal until its actors were already rehearsing. ANSWER: Richard Sheridan [or Richard Brinsley Sheridan] [10h] This actor wrote "every drop of blood - that's ink - is spilt for you" in his prologue to The School for Scandal, after Sheridan took over the Drury Lane Theater from him. Joshua Reynolds painted this Shakespearean actor between two women. ANSWER: David Garrick [accept David Garrick Between Tragedy and Comedy] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Drama> ~25440~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: naked mole-rats (The genus name alone is acceptable because the genus is monotypic.)
Text: 19. This species gains cancer resistance from a sugar that stops cells from clumping into tumors. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these earless mammals that do not feel pain from acid because they lack substance P. This East African species and a related "Damaraland" one are the only eusocial mammals. ANSWER: naked mole-rats [or Heterocephalus glaber or Heterocephalus glaber or sand puppy; prompt on mole-rat or Heterocephalus] (The genus name alone is acceptable because the genus is monotypic.) [10h] Naked mole-rats produce large amounts of the "high molecular weight" form of this polymer. This non-sulfated glycosaminoglycan is broken down by a namesake enzyme that sperm cells release during the acrosome reaction. ANSWER: hyaluronic acid [or hyaluronan; accept high molecular weight hyaluronic acid; prompt on "HA" instead of "hyaluronic acid"] [10e] Naked mole-rats respond to cancer malignancy by increasing metabolism of this monosaccharide that is named for its abundance in fruit. ANSWER: fructose [prompt on fruit sugar] <Rohan Kher, Science - Biology> ~25077~ <Editor: David Bass>

20. John Constable painted hundreds of studies of these objects at Hampstead. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these objects, cone-shaped examples of which were commonly depicted by Albert Bierstadt. These objects are rendered as rows of rectangles as viewed from above in a Georgia O'Keeffe painting in a stairwell at the Art Institute of Chicago. ANSWER: clouds [accept cloudscapes; accept Sky Above Clouds IV] [10e] Abraham Lincoln's head is traced by clouds in a Barry Faulkner mural next to this document at the National Archives. This object is signed in a John Trumbull painting on the $2 bill. ANSWER: Declaration of Independence [10m] George Catlin painted a green handprint on the face of White Cloud, a chief of the tribe that names this US state. A painting set in this state depicts a couple in front of the Dibble House. ANSWER: Iowa [or IA; accept the Iowa people or Iowa tribe] (The painting is American Gothic by Grant Wood.) <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - U.S. to 1945> ~25759~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

21. A Romanian folk tale about nine brothers who love hunting but are turned into stags inspired this composer's Cantata Profana. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this composer who depicted a group of tramps that murder a wealthy Chinese man in the ballet The Miraculous Mandarin. He wrote the piano collection Mikrokosmos. ANSWER: Béla Bartók [or Béla Viktor János Bartók] [10e] The Empress loses an amulet that lets her transform into a gazelle at the start of this composer's opera Die Frau ohne Schatten ("dee FROW oh-nuh SHA-ten"). This composer wrote Also Sprach Zarathustra. ANSWER: Richard Strauss [or Richard Georg Strauss; prompt on Strauss or R. Strauss] [10h] This composer's ballet Les biches ("lay BEESH"), or The Hinds, depicts three men and sixteen women attending a salon party. This gay member of Les Six ("lay SEESE") wrote Concert Champêtre ("con-SAIR sham-PET"). ANSWER: Francis Poulenc ("frahn-SEESE poo-LAHNK") [or Francis Jean Marcel Poulenc] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~24704~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

1. Henry Wise said, "There is no country," to urge an action taken at this place, which was followed by General Order No. 9 and a later meeting at Bennett Place. Ely Parker was told, "I'm glad to see one real American here," at a house in this place to which Wilmer McLean had moved four years prior. An army aiming to retreat to North Carolina after the Battle of Five Forks was eventually trapped at this place two weeks after the (*) Petersburg Campaign ended. A president asked the Marine band to play "Dixie" after an event at this place, where the Army of Northern Virginia was disbanded days after the capture of Richmond. For 10 points, in what Virginia town did Ulysses Grant accept Robert E. Lee's surrender? ANSWER: Appomattox [accept Appomattox County or Appomattox Court House or Battle of Appomattox Court House; prompt on McLean House until read; prompt on Virginia] <Rohan Kher, History - American - Pre-1865> ~30076~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

2. This scientist theorized that fluids behave similarly at similar reduced temperatures and pressures based on his finding that the critical compressibility factor was three-eighths. When studying an equation named for this scientist with PV diagrams, vertical or horizontal lines connect points on isotherms in the Maxwell construction. The distance of closest approach between two hard spheres is this scientist's (*) radius, which he used to derive a cubic equation of state with the constants a and b. London dispersion forces and dipole-dipole interactions are examples of intermolecular forces named after this scientist. For 10 points, a modification of the ideal gas law was developed by what Dutch physicist? ANSWER: Johannes Diderik van der Waals (The first clue refers to the principle of corresponding states.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~30794~ <Editor: June Yin>

3. An artist of ofu-ona patterns in this material, Olowe of Ise, inspired David Adjaye ("AD-jay") and Philip Freelon's design of upside-down trapezoids for the exterior of a Smithsonian museum. Medicine is built into "power figures" made of this material called nkondi. Symbols called ibol appear on Kuba ndop statues in this material. Strings are used to split this material and reveal a spirit's face in transformation artworks of the (*) Tlingit ("KLING-it") and Haida. Abstract faces on Fang artworks made of this material inspired the figures in Les Demoiselles d'Avignon ("lay duh-mwah-ZELL dah-veen-YON"). Artworks of this material portray spirits of animals like an eagle or orca stacked on top of each other. For 10 points, what common material for African masks is also used for totem poles? ANSWER: wood [accept trees or tree trunks; accept cedar] (The lead-in refers to the National Museum of African American History and Culture.) <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - World> ~30793~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

4. The Ramsey problem, which later yielded a second-best solution for monopoly pricing, was originally formulated to optimize these things. Peter Diamond and James Mirrlees found that these things need not alter production decisions. These things' economic incidence, which is independent from statutory incidence, depends on the elasticities of suppliers and consumers. One type of these things that can bring private marginal cost into equality with social marginal cost was described by (*) A. C. Pigou. They're not quotas, but infant industries benefit from a type of these things. The "wedge" caused by these things results in deadweight loss. For 10 points, name these government policies, exemplified by tariffs, that proportionally raise prices. ANSWER: taxes [or taxation; accept tax rates; accept commodity taxes; accept tariffs until read; prompt on rates] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~31168~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

5. A fan belt breaks in front of a general store owned by a man with this name, who breaks up a fight with a soda bottle. Contradictory lines about "Jay the only son of" this man and "twenty-one children, the last one Jake" support Susan Byrd's story about this man. Children in Shalimar sing a song replacing "Sugarman" with this name. A man thinks "if you surrendered to the air, you could (*) ride it" at a "Leap" with this name, where a "bag of gold" containing human bones is taken by Pilate. In a work titled for this name, Robert Smith jumps off a hospital roof, and the Seven Days group is joined by Guitar Bains. For 10 points, Milkman Dead is the protagonist of a Toni Morrison novel named for the Song of what king? ANSWER: Solomon [accept Song of Solomon; accept Solomon's Leap; accept Mr. Solomon] <Rohan Kher, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~30399~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

6. This quantity defines the threshold at which optimality is achieved by the Von Kármán ogive ("OH-gyve"), which is a special case of the Sears–Haack body. This quantity is calculated from the displacement of powder in a common classroom experiment involving the Kundt's tube. For an ideal gas, the square of this quantity equals the heat capacity ratio times R T. This quantity equals the negative-one-half power of the product of density (*) isentropic compressibility in the Newton–Laplace equation. The prefixes "hyper," "trans," and "super" describe flows in which this quantity is exceeded. This quantity is 343 meters per second in air. For 10 points, name this quantity that is matched by a projectile traveling at Mach one. ANSWER: speed of sound [accept Mach 1 before the end; prompt on speed or velocity; prompt on c or c-sub-s or a] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~30621~ <Editor: David Bass>

7. Either butterfly wings or a shell representing this location adorn the back of a son of Tlaloc ("TLAH-lohk") and Chalchiuhtlicue ("chal-CHEWT-lee-kway") in many depictions. An animal thrown to this location either hits Meztli or, due to his cowardice, Tecciztecatl ("teh-KEEZ-teh-COTT-ul"), who may embody a figure in this location. According to another story, this location was created when Coyolxauhqui ("coh-YOHL-shau-kee") was (*) decapitated and had her head thrown away by Huitzilopochtli ("weet-see-loh-poach-tlee"). Quetzalcoatl ("KET-sull-koh-AH-tull") imprints a rabbit's image on this location in one story due to the animal's willingness to serve as food for the god. For 10 points, the Aztecs tracked the phases of what celestial object? ANSWER: the Moon <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~30796~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

8. A giant one of these structures along the A93 Perth-Blairgowrie ("blair‑GOW‑ree") Road, dating to the Battle of Culloden, is named for the town of Meikleour. The Sherman Rhinoceros was developed to destroy these structures in the bocage of Normandy following D-Day. The Midland style of these structures slopes towards heavy bullocks. To enforce a salt tax in India, British officials built a 1,100-mile-long "Great" one of these structures. In the 1607 Newton Rebellion, commoners tore down these (*) living structures to protest enclosure. British formal gardens once routinely included mazes made from these structures. For 10 points, name these closely-placed shrubs that are widely used as fences and barriers in the UK. ANSWER: hedge [or hedgerows or hedgebank or Devon hedge or Cornish hedge; prompt on plants or shrubs or trees or bushes; before any of these terms are read, prompt on mazes or labyrinths or barriers or live fences or walls by asking "what were they made of?"] <Michael Bentley, Geography - Europe> ~30470~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. Note to players: Specific answer required. Imprecise answers will be rejected. The existence of this technology was accidentally revealed on an episode of Court of Current Issues by Senator Edwin Johnson. One country used an "alarm clock" design for this tech in the "Joe 4" demonstrated at Semipalatinsk. The MANIAC I computer was first used to help develop this tech. An early use of this technology caused a diplomatic incident involving the crew of Japan's (*) Lucky Dragon 5. A major milestone for this technology occurred with a device nicknamed the Sausage used in Ivy Mike. Sakharov's Third Idea was a Russian implementation of the Teller-Ulam design for this technology. For 10 points, the Castle Bravo test demonstrated what technology, thousands of times more deadly than the one used on Hiroshima? ANSWER: hydrogen bomb [or H-Bomb or neutron bomb or thermonuclear weapon or fusion weapon; prompt on nuclear bomb or super bomb; prompt on bomb; reject "atomic bomb" or "fission bomb", since those answers are not correct for any clue] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~29755~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

10. This author ended one novel by praising those who "lived faithfully a hidden life, and rest in unvisited tombs." In a novel by this author, a man returns a woman’s pawned necklace after he sees her losing at roulette. This author argued that overly perfect female protagonists reinforce prejudice against women's education in "Silly Novels by Lady Novelists." A man created by this author befriends Gwendolen Harleth and moves to "the East" upon learning his mother was (*) Jewish. A man who dies while writing The Key to All Mythologies puts a clause in his will forbidding his wife from marrying Will Ladislaw, in a novel by this author of Daniel Deronda. For 10 points, what author created Dorothea Brooke in Middlemarch? ANSWER: George Eliot [or Mary Ann Evans] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - British - Other> ~30263~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

11. A faction of these people who fought one conflict to its end was called the "bitter enders" and included Jopie Fourie. These people, who formed the Republic of Stellaland and the State of Goshen, won independence in the Sand River Convention. The term "commando" was first used to describe these people's infantry during land conflicts by the Great Fish River, which were led by men such as (*) Piet Retief ("PETE reh-TEEF"). Herbert Kitchener ordered infrastructure razed to defeat these people's guerrilla tactics. After their "Great Trek" north from the Cape Colony, these people formed the Transvaal and Orange Free State. For 10 points, what descendants of South Africa's Dutch settlers fought two wars against the British? ANSWER: Boers [accept Afrikaners; prompt on Voortrekkers; prompt on Dutch people or people from the Netherlands; prompt on South Africans] <Rohan Kher, History - World - African> ~30230~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

12. A piece by this composer repeats a different chord in each of the 11 sections that follow its opening "Pulses." In a piece by this composer, two performers repeat the rhythm "3 eighth notes, 2 eighth notes, eighth note, 2 eighth notes," with one of them delaying it by an extra eighth rest on each repetition. Terry Riley's In C and the preaching of Brother Walter inspired a tape composition by this composer. A string quartet by this composer of (*) Music for 18 Musicians ends with the movement "After the War," which intersperses interviews with Holocaust survivors. This composer pioneered phasing in pieces like It's Gonna Rain and Clapping Music. For 10 points, name this minimalist American composer of Different Trains. ANSWER: Steve Reich ("RYSHE") [or Stephen Michael Reich] <Benjamin Chapman, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~23669~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

Answer: bullfighting (Death in the Afternoon is by Ernest Hemingway.)
Text: 13. An "Old Lady" has questions about the ethics of this activity in a book that coined the term "moment of truth." This activity takes place each afternoon during a week-long July festival that also includes the waltzing Riau-Riau ritual. Participants in this activity often don a "suit of lights" and were celebrated by the original (*) "aficionados." This activity is the subject of the book Death in the Afternoon. Between 2022 and 2024, this activity was banned at the largest venue for it in the world in Mexico City. Volunteers help corral participants to "rings" for this activity after a "running" in Pamplona. For 10 points, lancing and sticks are used by matadors in what dangerous sport? ANSWER: bullfighting [accept corrida de toros] (Death in the Afternoon is by Ernest Hemingway.) <Sean Farrell, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29710~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. Borstein et al. 2024 rejects the hypothesis that evolution of this structure is a key innovation in cichlids. In certain fish, the first pair of branchial arches develops into this structure. VDJ recombination is a synapomorphy of the clade of vertebrates named for possessing this structure, which is analogous to rotifers' trophi. The morphology of this structure distinguishes teleosts from other fishes in Gnatho·stomata. (*) Moray eels have a second retractable instance of this structure, which is missing in hagfish and lampreys. This structure can feature the premaxilla and the mandible, which is the only independently movable part of the human skull. For 10 points, name this structure that enables chewing. ANSWER: jaws [or pharyngeal jaws; accept lower jaws or upper jaws] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30602~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. In a story, the deeds of a man with this title whisper, "Don't you remember?" while Death sits on his chest. A man with this title falls sick after a repetitive artificial bird replaces the singing of a story's title "Nightingale." In another story, two liars trick a man with this title by burning over six candles and using huge scissors to make the title objects for him, of which an official confusedly describes the "beautiful colors" and "exquisite (*) pattern." In a story, a man with this title shivers after a child says, "But he hasn't got anything on!", and an entire town thus ceases marveling at the title garments. For 10 points, Hans Christian Andersen described the invisible "New Clothes" of what kind of ruler? ANSWER: emperor [or emperors or kings or kejser or kejseren or kejsere; accept answers identifying the emperor of China or Chinese emperor or kejser af Kina or kinesisk kejser; accept "The Emperor's New Clothes" or "The King’s New Clothes" or "Kejserens nye klaeder"; prompt on rulers until "ruler" is read] <Kevin Wang, Literature - European - Short Fiction> ~29787~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

16. After a woman fell ill from a bottle of ginger beer containing one of these animals' remains, the case Donoghue v. Stevenson established modern negligence law. Lillian Randall suggested that these animals represent the Lombards, as they battle knights in the margins of medieval manuscripts. One type of these animals was boiled in lead vats at cities such as Mogador and Sidon to produce a good used to treat the (*) toga picta that names the system of porphyro·geniture. Roman pens known as cochlearia were used to raise these animals, whose Murex genus was harvested en masse by the Phoenicians. The city of Tyre names a valuable purple dye extracted from, for 10 points, what shelled gastropods that can be eaten as escargot? ANSWER: snails [accept rock snails; accept Murex until read; prompt on mollusks; prompt on gastropods until read; reject "slugs"] <Cooper Roh, History - European - Misc> ~29674~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

17. A C Major theme from this musical sings a "name on everybody's lips" with the notes "F, D." An eight-eight-quarter note rhythm is played on a snare drum in a song from this musical in which performers exchange a red scarf and identify with words like "Squish" and "Cicero." In a song from this musical, a woman sits on a man's lap and pretends to be a puppet as a chorus chants the phrases "Oh yes" and "The (*) gun." A 1979 film by Bob Fosse is titled for this musical's opening song, "All That Jazz." In this musical, the "murderess" Velma Kelly performs the "Cell Block Tango" and rivals the aspiring vaudeville star Roxie Hart. For 10 points, name this musical set in the 1920s in an Illinois city. ANSWER: Chicago <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~31267~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

18. A meter used in this non-Japanese language's poetry divides lines of seventeen syllables into sections of four long syllables, five short syllables and one long, and seven that alternate. In a poem in this language that uses "slow-stepped verse," a banished nature spirit tries to send a message to his wife in the mountains. A king is cursed to forget about his new queen until a (*) fisherman shows him a ring in a play in this language by the author of The Cloud Messenger. In an epic in this language attributed to Valmiki, a prince is exiled to the forest for fourteen years before his wife, Sita, is kidnapped by Ravana, the king of Lanka. For 10 points, name this classical language used to write the Ramayana. ANSWER: Sanskrit [or Saṃskṛtam] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~29586~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

Answer: springs (Robert Hooke introduced his namesake law with an anagram of "ut tensio, sic vis.")
Text: 19. An early result in the study of these devices was published in alphabetical order as "ceiiinossssttuu." These devices are used alongside masses and dashpots in the John Hancock Tower's tuned mass damper. The "leaf" variety of these devices contain layered arc-shaped plates. Mechanical analogies of circuits represent capacitors as these devices. The "hair" type of these devices are coupled with (*) balance wheels and regulators. Shock absorbers often feature these devices on their exterior. Compliance is the reciprocal of these devices' "constant," which is a linear scaling factor between their displacement and force. For 10 points, name these devices that can behave as harmonic oscillators governed by Hooke's law. ANSWER: springs [accept leaf springs or hairsprings] (Robert Hooke introduced his namesake law with an anagram of "ut tensio, sic vis.") <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Other Science> ~29686~ <Editor: David Bass>

20. Note to moderator: read the answerline carefully. In one region, a "sitting" form of this holiday is celebrated with a music festival until Dulhendi, and participants protect their Cheer from other villages. Men use shields to protect themselves against women beating them with lathis on this holiday. This is the later of two holidays whose practitioners drink bhang. On the night before this holiday, people build fires to celebrate the death of a (*) demoness and protection of Prahlada. This holiday that celebrates the love between Radha and Krishna begins at Phalguna Purnima, the first full moon in its month. Participants often make use of water guns and water balloons filled with powders like neem and kumkum on, for 10 points, what Hindu festival of spring and colors? ANSWER: Holi [accept Holika Dahan; prompt on Festival of Love or Festival of Spring or Festival of Colors or Festival of Equality; reject "Holika" alone] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Hinduism> ~30813~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: carbon dioxide (The second sentence describes carbaminohemoglobin.)
Text: 21. This molecule is mostly transported via a larger intermediate whose concentration increases via chloride shift. About one-fifth of the total amount of this molecule is transported via binding to one of four terminal amine groups. This molecule is the lightest product of PDC activity. This molecule is the smallest byproduct of the synthesis of alpha-ketoglutarate and succinyl-CoA, where two of this molecule is produced alongside (*) NADH. Increased concentrations of this molecule drive the right-shift in a dissociation curve in the Bohr effect because this neutral compound reduces the pH of blood. This linear molecule is produced by cellular respiration alongside water. For 10 points, name this three-atom gas dominant in exhaled breath. ANSWER: carbon dioxide [or CO2] (The second sentence describes carbaminohemoglobin.) <David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~30805~ <Editor: June Yin> NSC 2025 - Round 11 - Bonuses

1. A screechy violin repeats an ultra-high E-flat as others gradually enter on lower E-naturals and E-flats in a piece in this genre. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this genre of works by Erich Korngold that he quoted in his own violin concerto. Hans Zimmer, John Powell, and John Williams frequently compose in this genre. ANSWER: film score [or film music; accept music for movies or cinema] [10h] This American film composer restricted himself to a string orchestra when scoring Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho. ANSWER: Bernard Herrmann [or Maximillian Herrmann] [10m] The "F, E-flat, D" leitmotif that opens Herrmann's score to Psycho is derived from a piece for strings with this title. Leoš Janáček ("LAY-osh YA-na-check") included 25 brass parts in a militaristic piece with this diminutive Italian title. ANSWER: Sinfonietta [accept Sinfonietta for Strings] <Jamie Burchett, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~24814~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

2. A 2024 paper by Fedchin et al. found an acrostic of this philosopher's name in his The Elements of Law. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this English philosopher who wrote Leviathan. ANSWER: Thomas Hobbes [10h] In The Elements of Law, Hobbes defines a wise man as not one who knows this discipline or any other science, but as one who knows what is good for people. Another philosopher applied this discipline's methods to derive statements like "everything strives to preserve in its being." ANSWER: geometry [prompt on mathematics] (That other philosopher is Baruch Spinoza, who used a geometric method in his Ethics.) [10m] In that work, Hobbes claims that in this form of government, no covenant exists between the sovereign and any subject. Another philosopher’s book titled for this system warns that it may create a "soft despotism." ANSWER: democracy [accept word forms like democratic; accept Democracy in America] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Philosophy> ~24769~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

3. The fact that the Rayleigh quotient is bounded between the smallest and largest of these quantities is elaborated upon by the min-max theorem. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these quantities, the set of which is the spectrum. The trace equals the sum of these quantities, which are the roots of the characteristic polynomial. ANSWER: eigenvalues [prompt on lambda; prompt on characteristic value or characteristic root] [10e] Eigenvalues describe these rectangular grids of numbers that represent linear transformations. ANSWER: matrices [or matrix] [10h] This task, which factors a matrix into the product of a unitary matrix, a diagonal matrix denoted "Sigma," and the conjugate transpose of a unitary matrix, is named for the square roots of the non-negative eigenvalues that populate Sigma. ANSWER: singular value decomposition [or SVD; prompt on decomposition] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25515~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. The prologue of the epic Astronautilia ("astronaut-ILL-ee-uh") references this author's story "The Fall of House Voticky" ("voh-TIT-kee"). For 10 points each: [10m] Name this science-fiction author of War with the Newts, who wrote a 1920 play about a firm that creates the "universal" beings Primus and Helena. ANSWER: Karel Čapek ("CHAH-pek") (The play is R.U.R.) [10e] Jan Křesadlo's ("yan kres-AD-loh's") Astronautilia includes Homeric Greek text and a translation into this language. Čapek and Václav ("VAHT-slav") Havel wrote in this Central European language. ANSWER: Czech [or Čeština or Česky jazyk] [10h] In the Astronautilia, the universe can only exist while observed by one of these animals. In a novel titled for these animals, the killings of Garland, Polokov, and Luba allow a bounty hunter to buy his wife a Nubian goat. ANSWER: sheep [accept Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Literature - European - Other> ~24817~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

5. According to Cassius Dio, Hierocles drugged Aurelius Zoticus, a lover of this emperor, to cause erectile dysfunction. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this Roman emperor who married Julia Aquilia Severa. This emperor was a high priest of a sun god that Aurelian promoted as the chief god of Rome. ANSWER: Elagabalus [or Marcus Aurelius Antoninus; or Sextus Varius Avitus Bassianus; or Heliogabalus] [10e] According to Cassius Dio, Antinous, the male lover of Hadrian, was killed as a part of this practice. Carthage allegedly performed this action by killing children to appease their gods. ANSWER: human sacrifice [or ritual murder] [10m] This Julio-Claudian emperor ordered Sporus to be his lover after he kicked his pregnant wife Poppaea Sabina to death. This emperor earlier forced her to divorce Otho. ANSWER: Nero [or Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~24489~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. One character in this novel is assassinated after his criticism that the President wants to mint coins with his head is turned into a joke about him wanting to decapitate the President. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this novel about the political struggles and differences of the childhood friends Chris, Ikem, and Sam that is set in the fictional country of Kangan. ANSWER: Anthills of the Savannah [10e] Anthills of the Savannah is by this Nigerian author who wrote about Okonkwo hanging himself in shame in Things Fall Apart. ANSWER: Chinua Achebe [10m] The former mentor to the President, Raymond, befriends the shopkeeper Salim in this V.S. Naipaul novel set in an unnamed African country. ANSWER: A Bend in the River <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25736~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

7. According to a letter by a follower, this man mentally calculated the exact position of the sun on a given day while hunting on horseback. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this man whose madrasa in Registan Square attracted scholars such as Jamshid al-Kashi. This son of Shah Rukh was inspired by a visit to Maragheh to design a Fakhri sextant. ANSWER: Ulugh Beg [accept Mīrzā Muhammad Tarāghāy bin Shāhrukh] [10e] Ulugh Beg designed the sextant for a building for members of this profession such as al-Kashi, who compiled zij books containing star catalogs. ANSWER: astronomers [or astronomy; prompt on mathematicians or scientists] [10m] Ulugh Beg's observatory and madrasa were located in this Uzbek city. In this city, Ulugh Beg's grandfather founded a namesake empire that succeeded the Chagatai Khaganate. ANSWER: Samarkand (Ulugh Beg's grandfather was Timur.) <Steven Yuan, History - World - Asian> ~25758~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

8. A leader yells before this action is performed in three sets of three followed by a single instance of it in ippon-jime. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this action performed by challengers between points in Buddhist debate. This action is performed twice between bowing twice and bowing once at Shinto shrines. ANSWER: clapping [accept hakushu] [10m] Loud clapping during debates in monasteries of this Mahāyāna Buddhist sect is meant to awaken compassion and wisdom. This sect is split further into schools like the Kagyu and Gelug. ANSWER: Tibetan Buddhism [prompt on Vajrayāna or Tantric Buddhism or Esoteric Buddhism or Mantrayāna or Tantrayāna; anti-prompt on Red Hat Buddhism or Yellow Hat Buddhism] [10e] Toyo imitates geisha music and dripping water when Mokurai asks him about the sound of one hand clapping in one of this sect’s koans. This other sect of Mahāyāna Buddhism is mostly practiced in Japan. ANSWER: Zen Buddhism [or Chan Buddhism] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Buddhism> ~25763~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

9. Human gastrulation begins two to three weeks after this event. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this event in which sperm enters an egg, forming a zygote to begin gestation. ANSWER: fertilization [prompt on conception] [10m] Gastrulation organizes this set of three structures. Give the collective name for the endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm, which are stratified along the animal–vegetal axis in the amphibian blastocyst. ANSWER: germ layers [10h] An early step in amphibian gastrulation is the formation of this structure's dorsal lip from bottle cells. The endoderm and mesoderm internalize via involution through this structure, which forms opposite the site of sperm entry and is analogous to the primitive streak in amniotes. ANSWER: blastopore [prompt on mouth or anus or cloaca by asking "what structure in the gastrula develops into that structure?"; prompt on archenteron] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~24574~ <Editor: David Bass>

10. On the day Adolf Hitler died, Lee Miller was photographed in his bathtub while working as a correspondent for this magazine. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this New York fashion magazine currently edited by Anna Wintour. Its main competitors are Elle and Harper's Bazaar. ANSWER: Vogue [10h] Whoopi Goldberg laid in a bath full of milk for a Vanity Fair cover by this photographer. Another Vanity Fair cover by this celebrity photographer depicts a pregnant, nude Demi Moore. ANSWER: Annie Leibovitz [10m] Don Herron photographed this artist taking a bath in a room painted with his motif of a dog barking. Purple paint drips from an unfinished 1989 canvas by this graffiti artist who used his colorful dancing figures to raise awareness of AIDS. ANSWER: Keith Haring <Sean Farrell, Fine Arts - Photography> ~24660~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

Answer: 15 lines A 15-line poem evokes the "great wings" of one of these animals "beating still / above the staggering girl." Another poem by the same author described how "nine-and-fifty" of these animals "paddle in the cold" at Coole. ANSWER: swans "The Wild Swans at Coole" is by this Irish poet of "Leda and the Swan," who described how "The falcon cannot hear the falconer" in "The Second Coming." ANSWER: William Butler Yeats ("YATES")
Text: 11. A poem with this unusual number of lines lists "The broken wall, the burning roof and tower / And Agamemnon dead." For 10 points: [10h] Name the number of lines of that poem, which begins with the words "A sudden blow." Alfred, Lord Tennyson's poem "The Kraken" also has this many lines. ANSWER: 15 lines [accept 15 line sonnets; prompt on "a sonnet with one extra line" or equivalents] [10m] A 15-line poem evokes the "great wings" of one of these animals "beating still / above the staggering girl." Another poem by the same author described how "nine-and-fifty" of these animals "paddle in the cold" at Coole. ANSWER: swans [accept "Leda and the Swan" or "The Wild Swans at Coole"; prompt on birds] [10e] "The Wild Swans at Coole" is by this Irish poet of "Leda and the Swan," who described how "The falcon cannot hear the falconer" in "The Second Coming." ANSWER: William Butler Yeats ("YATES") <Kevin Wang, Literature - British - Poetry> ~24707~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

12. A study by Gutierrez-Aguirre et al. found that using a compound of potassium and this anion to oxidize ethylene increased the shelf life of bananas. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this anion, whose compound with potassium turns brown upon reacting with double or triple bonds in Baeyer's test. ANSWER: permanganate [accept potassium permanganate; accept MnO4-] [10e] Permanganate's central manganese atom has an oxidation state of plus this number, the number of electrons in the outermost shell of a halogen. ANSWER: seven [10m] Potassium permanganate is also widely used as a stain for this technique, during which a solvent is moved through a silica plate by capillary action. ANSWER: thin-layer chromatography [accept TLC; prompt on chromatography] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Chemistry> ~25760~ <Editor: June Yin>

13. Flooding often renders airports inoperable. For 10 points each: [10h] 8,000 people were stranded at this airport during Typhoon Jebi in 2018. This airport, built on an artificial island and designed by Renzo Piano, has sunk 38 feet since 1994. ANSWER: Kansai International Airport [10e] A portable flood wall was installed in this city's downtown airport due to frequent flooding of the Mississippi. Tim Walz resides at the Governor's Residence in this Minnesota capital city. ANSWER: Saint Paul [10m] A 2018 storm closed Nedumbassery Airport in this Indian state for two weeks. This Southern state has the highest literacy rate and life expectancy in India and is governed by the LDF, which includes the Communist Party of India (Marxist). ANSWER: Kerala <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~24682~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. It's not criminal justice, but Cheuksin, a goddess of this domain, attacks intruders with 150 centimeter long hair. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this domain that the Ainu believe is ruled by Rukar Kamuy. Christians claimed Crepitus was the Roman god of these locations that were adorned with images of Fortuna. ANSWER: toilets [or latrines; accept bathrooms; accept outhouses; accept equivalents] [10m] Koreans performed jesas ("jay-sahs") to Cheuksin when children or these objects fell into the toilet. In Greek myth, a man loses one of these objects while carrying a disguised goddess across the Anauros River. ANSWER: shoes [or sandals] (Jason loses his sandal while carrying the disguised Hera.) [10e] Those jesas involved Ttongtteok ("tohng-tuck"), whose name suggests it to be made of poop and this food. The kami Inari is depicted carrying a sack of this Asian staple food. ANSWER: rice [accept gohan or meshi or kome or bosatsu or ine; accept rice cake] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - World Mythology> ~24609~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

15. The U.S. sent Alcée Louis la Branche as chargé d'affaires to this country that they later annexed. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this country whose annexation was solidified via the Compromise of 1850. This country's second president, Mirabeau Lamar, moved its capital to Austin. ANSWER: Republic of Texas [10m] This monarch of another short-lived country was deposed outside the ʻIolani Palace by American-backed revolutionaries. This monarch opposed a king's signing of the Bayonet Constitution. ANSWER: Queen Liliʻuokalani [or Lydia Liliʻu Loloku Walania Kamakaʻeha] [10h] The U.S. did not recognize this republic, which James Madison thought was part of the Louisiana Purchase. Fulwar Skipwith was the only governor of this republic, which was officially ceded by the Adams-Onís Treaty. ANSWER: Republic of West Florida [reject "Florida"] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - American - 1865-1945> ~24537~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

16. In this play, a man says that his father told him to order his wife around, before concluding "I took the opposite of [his] advice and I've been happy ever since." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this play, whose second act features a couple getting cold feet on their wedding day. A man acting as a minister in this play says, "I've married over two hundred couples in my day. Do I believe in it? I don't know." ANSWER: Our Town [10m] This character in Our Town officiates the wedding of George and Emily in the second act. This man brings Emily back to relive her twelfth birthday after she dies in childbirth.  ANSWER: the Stage Manager [10e] Our Town was written by this author, whose play The Matchmaker inspired the musical Hello, Dolly! ANSWER: Thornton Wilder <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Drama> ~25550~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

17. A 2017 Alex Vitale book titled for the "end" of this practice argues for its abolition. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this practice, the subject of the Atlantic article "Broken Windows." Its "community-oriented" approach often involves "walking the beat." ANSWER: policing [or law enforcement; accept The End of Policing; accept "defund the police"; accept community-oriented policing or problem-oriented policing] [10e] Shortly after the murder of George Floyd, the "defund the police" campaign was popularized by this nationwide antiracist movement named for a three-word slogan. ANSWER: Black Lives Matter [or BLM] [10h] This activist argued for the abolition of police and prisons in the 2003 book Are Prisons Obsolete? This activist coined the term "prison-industrial complex" and wrote Women, Race, and Class. ANSWER: Angela Davis [or Angela Yvonne Davis] <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Sociology> ~25516~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

18. This doctoral mentee of Edward Teller received a Nobel Prize for proposing that the weak force violates parity. For 10 points each: [10h] Identify this physicist who is the alphabetically latter namesake of a class of non-abelian gauge theories that are the subject of an "existence and mass gap problem." ANSWER: Yang Chen-Ning [or Chen-Ning Yang or C. N. Yang or Frank Yang or Yáng Zhénnìng; accept Yang-Mills theory] [10m] This Chinese-American "First Lady of Physics" conducted the experiments that verified Lee and Yang's model of the weak interaction, but she was snubbed for their Nobel. ANSWER: Wu Chien-Shiung [or Chien-Shiung Wu or C. S. Wu or Wú Jiànxióng] [10e] Yang collaborated with Wu Tai-Tung to theorize an alternative to the "Dirac" type of these hypothetical particles that carry magnetic charge and contain north or south, but not both. ANSWER: magnetic monopoles [accept Dirac monopoles or Wu-Yang monopoles] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24656~ <Editor: David Bass>

19. This artist's daughter Julie appears in one self-portrait that led this painter to be attacked by critics for smiling. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this artist who drew compositional elements for a portrait of the noblewoman Yolande de Polastron from Self-Portrait in a Straw Hat. ANSWER: Élisabeth Louise Vigée Le Brun [or Louise Élisabeth Vigée Le Brun; accept Madame Le Brun; prompt on Le Brun] [10e] Vigée Le Brun's Self-Portrait in a Straw Hat was inspired by this artist's portrait of Susanna Lunden. This Flemish artist depicted many of his trademark fleshy nudes in Descent from the Cross. ANSWER: Peter Paul Rubens [10m] In Self-Portrait in a Straw Hat, Vigée Le Brun holds one of these objects with her left hand. These objects, which may be kidney-shaped, name diamond or oval-shaped knives used to mix or scrape paint. ANSWER: palettes [accept palette knives] <Aum Mundhe, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~24596~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

20. This monarch ordered a copy of Alfred Thayer Mahan's The Influence of Sea Power Upon History for every ship in his navy. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this monarch whose naval investments included completing the Kiel Canal in 1895 and building four Nassau-class battleships. ANSWER: Kaiser Wilhem II [or William II; or Friedrich Wilhelm Viktor Albert; prompt on Wilhelm] [10h] Germany's Alfred von Tirpitz, a Mahan acolyte, argued that the decisive battle against the Royal Navy would be won somewhere between this island and the Thames ("temz"). An 1890 treaty gave Germany control of this North Sea island in exchange for Zanzibar. ANSWER: Heligoland [or Helgoland] [10e] Mahan wrote a book on this naval battle, where the British fleet crossed the T against the French fleet. Admiral Nelson was killed at this 1805 British victory. ANSWER: Battle of Trafalgar <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25082~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

21. In histology, this task is often performed on tissue sections prepared with FFPE. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this task, types of which involve heavy metals for subsequent electron microscopy, immunohistochemistry for distinguishing antigens, and hema·to·xylin and eosin for distinguishing cellular features. ANSWER: staining [accept immunostaining] [10h] FFPE sections are typically prepared with these devices that slice samples into thin pieces. Femtosecond lasers can replace mechanical blades in these devices. ANSWER: microtomes [accept laser microtomes] [10e] FFPE tissue samples are fixed with formalin, which is a four-percent solution of this compound. This simplest aldehyde is used to preserve cadavers. ANSWER: formaldehyde [or CH2O or methanal] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~25563~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Rio de Janeiro (The first line refers to the Rio Pact.)
Text: 1. In 1947, the U.S. signed a non-NATO treaty in this city that maintained "hemispheric defense" and considered an attack against one as an attack against all. In this city, the Revolt of the Lash was a naval mutiny against corporal punishment. Veterans of the War of Canudos built a lower-income hilltop community in this city. Over one million slaves passed through this city's (*) Valongo ("vah-LOHN-goo") Wharf. The large slum of Rocinha was built on a hill in this city. John VI of Portugal was forced to move his court to this city during the Peninsular War. In 1888, a "Golden Law" signed in this city by a regent to Pedro II abolished slavery. For 10 points, Brasilia replaced what port city as the capital of Brazil? ANSWER: Rio de Janeiro (The first line refers to the Rio Pact.) <Geoffrey Wu, History - World - Latin American> ~30573~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

2. Sniffer probes detect this substance, the most common tracer of leaks in pressurized tanks. Gas chromatography capillary columns still mainly use this substance as a carrier despite the availability of cheaper replacements. Uranium deposits coincide with natural sources of this substance, which is detected spectroscopically by its yellow D3 emission line. NMR magnets are cooled by vaporizing this substance at the lowest (*) boiling point of any chemical. Since this substance is a byproduct of natural gas extraction, the war in Ukraine has contributed to its fourth recent global shortage. In a common demonstration, inhaling this element raises the pitch of one's voice. For 10 points, name this lightest noble gas. ANSWER: helium [or He; accept helium gas] <Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~25689~ <Editor: June Yin>

3. The target-undershoot hypothesis argues that physical constraints cause variation among these features. One gradation among these features is described as ablaut ("AH-blout"). William Labov identified an ongoing change among these features occurring in "northern cities." Daniel Jones introduced a trapezoidal representation of these features. These features have lower third formants when (*) rhotacized. The Western US displays a "merger" among two low-back examples of these features. Some English dialects display an "intrusive r" between these features, which may form diphthongs when pronounced consecutively. For 10 points, name these sounds, usually the nuclei of syllables, that are produced with an open vocal tract. ANSWER: vowels [prompt on sounds until read; prompt on phones; prompt on languages] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Linguistics> ~30590~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

4. A peacock appears on a balcony in a version of this scene with a UFO-like cloud by Carlo Crivelli. A figure in this scene holds a white lily representing Florence in the earliest known commissioned painting for Leonardo da Vinci. This scene is set in a cloister and broken up by Roman-style columns in a fresco for the San Marco Monastery by (*) Fra Angelico. This scene is flanked by two panels - one of donors at a door and the other of Joseph in his workshop - in Robert Campin's Mérode Altarpiece. This scene typically depicts an angel with rainbow-colored wings bowing towards a woman with a beam of light shining on her head or stomach. For 10 points, name this biblical scene of Gabriel speaking to Mary. ANSWER: the Annunciation [or L'Annunzo or L'Annunciazione] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~30595~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

5. This character depicts a fallen soldier surrounded by tulips in a Pieta-inspired painting she submits for her art school application. After missing a train to Graz, this character discovers that Markus is cheating on her on her eighteenth birthday. This character is told an exam will be on a Montesquieu essay about slavery by (*) God, who she talks to as a child and compares to Karl Marx. This character notes that "freedom has a price" after her grandmother's death, as she only saw her once after emigrating following her divorce from Reza. As a child, this character visits Uncle Anoosh in prison, who gives her swans made of bread before his execution. For 10 points, name this protagonist and author of Persepolis. ANSWER: Marjane Satrapi [or Marjane Satrapi; or Marji] <Jamie Burchett, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30757~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

6. In Britain, these institutions send samples to the Trial of the Pyx and included a Soho one founded by James Watt's business partner Matthew Boulton. The first Chinese versions of these institutions made objects that replaced earlier "knife" and "spade" objects. The first federal building erected under the Constitution was one of these institutions in Philadelphia headed by astronomer David Rittenhouse that was an early adopter of (*) decimalization. Raw material from Cerro Rico was brought to a prominent one of these institutions in Potosi. Medieval examples of these institutions produced the ducat. Electrum was used in the first-ever of these institutions in Lydia. For 10 points, name these institutions that make coins. ANSWER: mints [accept coin factories until "coins" is read; prompt on treasuries or banks or coin factories] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30585~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. Alexander Gorsky's 1900 revival of a ballet set in this country added a variation in which a fan is repeatedly snapped open and shut by Kitri. A trilled low E leads to a highly ornamented oboe solo in a ballet scene from this country in which Candela tries to banish the ghost of her husband. A novel from this country inspired the first collaboration between Ludwig Minkus and Marius Petipa. The "Song of the Will-o'-the-Wisp" and (*) "Ritual Fire Dance" appear in a ballet from this country. A composer from this country depicted the romance between a miller's wife and a magistrate in The Three-Cornered Hat, which includes a jota ("HO-ta") and a fandango. For 10 points, name this home country of Manuel de Falla and of flamenco. ANSWER: Spain [or España] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Ballet/Dance> ~30604~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

8. A character who acquires this object in the Ynglinga ("ING-ling-kah") Saga "smeared it in herbs" then "sang incantations over it." It doesn't belong to Heimdall, but the Prose Edda notes how this object is enhanced by using Gjallarhorn ("GYAH-lur-horn"). This object is sent away due to the Hoenir's behavior in front of the Thing. After constantly being told "let others decide," the Vanir return this object to the Aesir feeling that they were cheated. This object was kept under one of (*) Yggdrasil's ("IG-druh-sil's") roots at a location it belonged to and named. The Heimskringla ("HAMES-kring-lah") states that Odin carried this object with him as it could tell "him all the news of other countries." For 10 points, identify this disembodied object belonging to the owner of a wisdom-granting well. ANSWER: Mimir's head [accept any answer clearly indicating the decapitated head of Mimir; prompt on a head; prompt on Mimir] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~29595~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

9. Measurements of this value use the correction factor "one over one plus b over P a" where b is a constant with units of pascals times meters. In a commencement address, Richard Feynman criticized consistent underestimation of this value as "cargo cult science." The square of this value is used to define the von Klitzing constant, which describes the quantum Hall effect. An experiment co-designed by Harvey (*) Fletcher measured this value by observing the positions at which irradiated masses rested between two plates after falling from an atomizer. This value was measured to be on the order of 10-to-the-negative-19 coulombs by the Millikan oil drop experiment. For 10 points, give the name of the charge of a proton. ANSWER: elementary charge [accept just "elementary" after "charge" is read; prompt on answers describing the charge of an electron or the charge of a proton; prompt on charge until read; prompt on e or +1 e or -1 e; prompt on Faraday constant before “coulombs” is read by asking “what is the value for a single particle?”] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~30803~ <Editor: David Bass>

10. A policeman and fugitive in this modern-day country sit back-to-back on a barrel in a one-act play. That play’s author criticized an event in this country as "the old battle, between those who use a toothbrush and those who don't." In a play from this country, a man says "a daring fellow is the jewel of the world" while blessing a character who wins a mule race, impressing women like the (*) Widow Quin, and is saved from hanging at the last minute. Lady Gregory co-founded a theater in this modern-day country, where the word "shifts" sparked a riot at a play in which Christy Mahon brags about killing his father, The Playboy of the Western World. For 10 points, the Abbey Theater hosted John Millington Synge ("sing") and Sean O’Casey in what country? ANSWER: Ireland [or Eire or Republic of Ireland; reject "Northern Ireland" or "United Kingdom"] (The first two lines are about Lady Gregory, who criticized the Abbey Theater riots. The one-act play is The Rising of the Moon.) <Jamie Burchett, Literature - British - Drama> ~29796~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

11. This thinker was described as a "Jamesian Organic Intellectual" by Cornel West, who reads this thinker as a central member of the pragmatist canon. A field pioneered by historian David Roediger builds on this thinker's argument that a certain status functions as a "psychological wage." This thinker described "a sort of seventh son, born with a veil" whose gift of "second-sight" causes them to have the "sense of always looking at one's (*) self through the eyes of others." This author analyzed "sorrow songs" in a book that calls the "color-line" the "problem of the twentieth century," which the "talented tenth" may solve. For 10 points, name this thinker who wrote about "double consciousness" in The Souls of Black Folk. ANSWER: W. E. B. Du Bois [or William Edward Burghardt Du Bois] <Jordan Brownstein, RMP - Philosophy> ~25024~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

12. The opening of the overture to Porgy and Bess is a common audition excerpt for this instrument. The only instrument in a standard concert band to use a grand staff is a type of this instrument developed by enslaved Africans in Guatemala. The West African balafon is a type of this instrument that uses gourds as resonators. One of these instruments called the gambang kayu accompanies gongs in gamelan. Camille Saint-Saëns quoted his (*) Danse Macabre on this instrument in a movement depicting "Fossils." A grip originally developed for the vibraphone allows players of these instruments to play four notes at once. For 10 points, the marimba is a type of what instrument whose players strike wooden bars with mallets? ANSWER: xylophone [accept balafon or marimba until each is read; accept mallet percussion; accept metallophones; prompt on percussion] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~25715~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

13. In this novel, a character gambles all the money pooled by his fellow cadets for the purchase of a leaving present for the head of their academy. In this novel's epilogue, two old friends read from an album containing the phrase "To live life to the end is not a childish task." This novel begins with its protagonist attending his mother's funeral with his uncle Nikolai. This novel's protagonist's brother (*) Evgraf collects his poems, including "Hamlet." In this novel, Liberius commands a group of partisans called the Forest Brotherhood, who capture its title character after he has an affair with Lara during the Russian Civil War. For 10 points, name this novel about the physician Yuri, written by Boris Pasternak. ANSWER: Doctor Zhivago [or Doktor Zhivago] <Ridge Ren, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~21102~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

14. Estimates of this quantity can be expressed as being within the asymmetric Wilson score interval. Laplace smoothing contributes beta-distributed prior weight to estimates of this quantity. This quantity converges to, but still does not equal, a maximal value in the sunrise problem. The logit ("LOW-jit") function evaluates to the logarithm of this quantity over one minus this quantity. This quantity is the sole (*) parameter of the geometric distribution and the Bernoulli distribution. This quantity is estimated as the number of successes over the number of trials. This quantity and sample size parametrize the binomial distribution. For 10 points, name this quantity between zero and one that is used to calculate odds. ANSWER: success probability [or binomial probability or success proportion or binomial proportion; prompt on p or theta] <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~29620~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. In this event's aftermath, Attorney General Julius Grinnell declared, "Make the raids first and look up the law afterwards." Using a device hidden in a cigar, Louis Lingg killed himself before he could be executed for causing this event. Shortly before this event, the editor of the newspaper Arbeiter-Zeitung gave a speech from Crane's Alley. People convicted of carrying out this event were (*) pardoned by Governor John P. Altgeld. A day before this event, speaker August Spies ("SPEES") rallied with people locked out of the McCormick Harvesting Works. This 1886 event occurred during a workers' strike for an eight-hour workday. For 10 points, name this event in which a bomb was thrown at policemen in Chicago. ANSWER: Haymarket Square riot [or Haymarket affair or Haymarket massacre or Haymarket incident or Haymarket riot] <Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~30162~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

16. A 2024 report about these people highlighted poor record keeping at GIDS. The High Court's judgment concerning these people in the now-overturned case Bell v. Tavistock was opposed by organizations like Mermaids. A 2023 law benefiting these people was vetoed by the UK government's first-ever use of Section 35 of the Scotland Act. (*) WPATH ("W-PATH") has criticized a 2024 study concerning these people that was led by Hilary Cass. Keir Starmer opposes these people's right to self-ID. The NHS treats these people in segregated clinics with years-long waiting lists and in 2024 banned the puberty blockers some receive. For 10 points, J. K. Rowling opposes some rights of what people, whose gender differs from their sex assigned at birth? ANSWER: transgender people [accept transgender women or transgender men or nonbinary people; accept transgender children; accept transsexuals; prompt on LGBTQ or queer people; prompt on children or young people or teenagers; reject "gay people"] <Forrest Weintraub, Current Events - World> ~30197~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

17. A holiday whose name concatenates these beings and "Light" was deliberately established to be two days before Christmas. Thomas Huxley denounced a positivist religion named for these beings as "Catholicism minus Christianity." Years after discussing root races of these beings in Atlantis and Lemuria, Rudolf Steiner left the Theosophical Society to found a society named for these beings' wisdom. Paul Kurtz contributed to a manifesto for an anti-religious (*) "secular" movement centered on these beings. An "Oration on the Dignity of" these beings by Pico della Mirandola relates a Renaissance philosophical ideology centering on them. For 10 points, name these beings that include religious prophets like Moses. ANSWER: humans [or humanity or Homo sapiens; accept mankind; accept Oration on the Dignity of Man; accept secular humanism; accept Religion of Humanity; accept HumanLight; accept people or persons; prompt on anthroposophy] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Other Religion> ~31166~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

18. Taib et al. 2020 argues that the loss of a type of these structures evolved repeatedly in Terrabacteria. A cysteine in the N-terminal head of Lpp secures it to one of these structures. These structures can feature beta-barrel-shaped proteins like OmpF. Lipid A and O antigen appear in the lipopolysaccharides that jut out from one of these structures. Electroporation alters these structures, which are penetrated by (*) porins, in order to promote transformation. The presence of an "outer" one of these structures in addition to the "inner" one typically implies Gram-negativity. For 10 points, name these semipermeable lipid bilayers that compose the bacterial cell envelope alongside the cell wall. ANSWER: plasma membranes [or cell membranes or bacterial cytoplasmic membranes or outer membranes or inner membranes; prompt on lipid bilayers until read; prompt on OMs or or IMs] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30603~ <Editor: David Bass>

19. During this king's reign, a play modernizing a legend from a past war popularized the term chauvinism. This king's second son led a successful siege of Constantine instead of his heir, who had been hurt fighting Abdelkader's forces. The Communist Manifesto describes a "holy alliance" between Klemens von Metternich and this king's minister François Guizot ("fran-SWAH gee-ZOH"). This king's predecessor's attempted conquest of (*) Algeria was completed during this king's rule, which immediately preceded the Second Republic. This king established a limited monarchy after the "three glorious days" depicted in Eugène Delacroix's ("oo-ZHEN deh-lah-KWAHZ") Liberty Leading the People. For 10 points, the July Revolution installed what "Citizen King" from the House of Orléans? ANSWER: Louis-Philippe I [prompt on the Citizen King until read; reject "Louis" or "Philippe"] <Forrest Weintraub, History - European - 1500-1900> ~29959~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

20. One poem by this author states "as freedom is a breakfastfood / or truth can live with right and wrong." One poem by this author mocks women who "believe in Christ and Longfellow, both dead." One poem by this man ends "He spoke. And drank rapidly a glass of water" after a speech about "heroic happy dead" who "did not stop to think they died instead." This author of (*) "the Cambridge ladies who live in furnished souls" drove an ambulance in World War I, inspiring his novel The Enormous Room. One poem by this author of "next to of course god america i" asks "how do you like your blue-eyed boy / Mister Death." For 10 points, name this author of "Buffalo Bill's" and "anyone lived in a pretty how town," known for using lowercase.  ANSWER: e. e. cummings [or Edward Estlin Cummings] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~30389~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

21. Description acceptable. A law passed in response to this event created the NICS but was found to violate the Tenth Amendment in Printz v. US. The character of "Brass" Bancroft inspired Jerry Parr to join a group central to this event, after which Joan Quigley was hired. A two-word quip referencing this event triggered uproarious applause after a balloon popped during a speech in West Berlin. The Brady Bill was named for a man (*) wounded during this event, after which Alexander Haig claimed, "I am in control here." The target of this event joked, "Honey, I forgot to duck," to his wife Nancy. To impress Jodie Foster, John Hinckley Jr. perpetrated, for 10 points, what event that failed to kill the US president in 1981? ANSWER: attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan [or shooting of Ronald Wilson Reagan; or attempt on Ronald Reagan's life; prompt on partial answers; reject answers suggesting it was successful] (Reagan had played Secret Service agent "Brass" Bancroft as an actor. Reagan's two-word quip was "Missed me.") <Cooper Roh, History - American - 1945+> ~29722~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower> NSC 2025 - Round 12 - Bonuses

Answer: Tom Wolfe (The book that was mocked is From Bauhaus to Our House.)
Text: 1. Kurt Vonnegut lampooned this man as a “jangling journalist” in a review with the passage, "Oxymorons and serpentae carminael! ... Schlock!" For 10 points each: [10e] Name this New Journalist who wrote a book mocked as "What [This Author] doesn't know about modern architecture." This man wrote The Right Stuff and Bonfire of the Vanities. ANSWER: Tom Wolfe [or Thomas Kennerly Wolfe Jr.] (The book that was mocked is From Bauhaus to Our House.) [10h] That Vonnegut quote is from his review of a Wolfe collection lengthily titled for a “kandy kolored” “tangerine flake” one of these objects made by Ed Roth and George Barris. ANSWER: cars [accept equivalents like automobiles; accept specific models of cars; prompt on vehicles; prompt on The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby] (The collection was originally published under the title "There Goes (Varoom! Varoom!) That Kandy-Kolored (Thphhhhhh!) Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby (Rahghhh!) Around the Bend (Brummmmmmmmmmmmmmm)…".) [10m] Wolfe was criticized as “Peeping Tom” for his novel I Am Charlotte Simmons, mainly set at one of these places. Jack Gladney works in one of these places in White Noise, and Donna Tartt's The Secret History is set at one of these places. ANSWER: college campus [accept universities; prompt on schools or campuses] <Michael Bentley, Literature - American - Misc> ~24744~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

2. A score of Joseph Haydn's first concerto for this instrument is marked "written while asleep" to indicate where he mistakenly switched two instruments' parts. For 10 points each: [10h] Mozart's divertimento A Musical Joke is written for string quartet and two of what instrument? ANSWER: French horn [or natural horn; or corno da caccia; accept horn in F or horn in D] [10m] Only the best virtuosos of Haydn's time could play his first horn concerto because this technique, in which players fill in gaps in the harmonic series by moving their hand within the horn's bell, was not yet widespread. ANSWER: hand-stopping [or word forms like stopped horn; accept gestopft or bouché; reject "muting" or "mute"] [10e] Haydn's first horn concerto features many stopped notes in a movement with this slow tempo marking that also names a Samuel Barber piece "for strings." ANSWER: adagio [accept Adagio for Strings] <Aum Mundhe, Fine Arts - Music - Classical> ~25023~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

3. This person lent her name to a "moment" in which a politician denounces an extremist person who is linked to their own party. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this social activist and rapper whose remarks, responding to the Rodney King riots, were condemned by Bill Clinton during his 1992 presidential campaign. ANSWER: Sister Souljah [or Lisa Williamson; prompt on partial answers] [10e] Clinton rebuked Sister Souljah by comparing her words to those of David Duke, a former Grand Wizard of this hood-wearing white supremacist organization. ANSWER: the Ku Klux Klan [or KKK] [10m] Clinton's criticisms of Sister Souljah were decried by this Baptist minister and civil rights activist, who twice sought the Democratic presidential nomination in 1984 and 1988. ANSWER: Rev. Jesse Jackson <Jamie Burchett, History - American - 1945+> ~24645~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. This ratio of four phenotypes is skewed to 15-to-1 for duplicate genes and to 13-to-3 under dominant suppression. For 10 points each: [10h] Give the four-term ratio of phenotypes that, in Mendelian genetics, arises from a dihybrid cross of parents that are both heterozygous for two genes that cause independent phenotypes. ANSWER: 9-to-3-to-3-to-1 [accept numbers in any order] [10m] The 9-to-3-to-3-to-1 ratio is skewed by this most common exception to the law of independent assortment. This phenomenon is measured in centimorgans. ANSWER: genetic linkage [reject "linkage disequilibrium"] [10e] Linkage is a driver of linkage disequilibrium, which is measured with this quantity. In statistics, large values of this quantity are often misinterpreted as implying causation. ANSWER: correlation [or correlation coefficient; prompt on r; prompt on r-squared or coefficient of determination] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~25773~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. This prayer's second verse, "Baruch shem k'vod malchuto l'olam va'ed," ("bah-ROOKH SHEM keh-VOHD mahl-khoo-TOH leh-oh-LAHM vah-ED") does not appear in the Torah and is recited silently during normal services but read aloud on Yom Kippur. For 10 points each: [10h] Give the Hebrew name for this prayer written on scrolls that are placed in tefillin ("t'-FILL-in"). ANSWER: Shema [or "Shema Yisrael"; or "Shema Yisrael: Adonai eloheinu, Adonai echad"] [10e] The first full paragraph of the Shema commands doing this action to God "with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy might." Leviticus 19 requires doing this action to "thy neighbor as thyself." ANSWER: love [or word forms like loving; or ahav; accept "V'ahavta"] [10m] That paragraph, the V'ahavta ("vay ah-HAV-tah"), commands Jews to write the Shema on these locations, so it is written on a scroll placed inside a mezuzah. ANSWER: doorposts [or door frames; or doorjambs; accept doors] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Jewish Practice> ~25335~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

6. The speaker warns "Behold the time of the Assassins" in a poem about a "Morning" with this quality. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this quality that titles a different Arthur Rimbaud ("ar-TOOR ram-BOH") poem about a vehicle that goes down "impassive Rivers." ANSWER: drunkenness [or drunken or drunk or ivresse or ivre; accept "The Drunken Boat" or "Le Bateau ivre" or "Drunken Morning" or "Morning of Drunkenness" or "Matinée d'ivresse"] [10e] Rimbaud's "drunken boat" describes "small electric" examples of this thing. Rimbaud's partner Paul Verlaine ("vur-LEN") wrote a poem titled for the "light," or "clair," given off by this thing. ANSWER: Moon [or lune or moons or lunes; accept "Clair de lune" or "Moonlight"] [10h] A poem by a different French poet, from a collection partly titled for this concept, begins "You have to be always drunk." That poem's author popularized the name of this concept, which refers to a melancholy of uncertain origin. ANSWER: spleen [accept Paris Spleen or Le Spleen de Paris] (The poem is by Charles Baudelaire.) <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - European - Poetry> ~24497~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

7. The first one of these astronomical bodies to be discovered was initially dubbed "little green men 1." For 10 points each: [10m] Name these bodies, one of which is the central object of the Crab Nebula and has a 33-millisecond period. ANSWER: pulsars [prompt on neutron stars; accept optical pulsars] [10e] Scientists have speculated that energetic "fast bursts" of radiation from this region of the electromagnetic spectrum are emitted by ETs. LGM-1 was discovered by observing this lowest-energy form of EM radiation. ANSWER: radio waves [accept fast radio bursts or pulsating radio source] [10h] Jerry Ehman wrote this word next to a 1977 radio signal detected at OSU that was widely reported to be sent by extraterrestrial intelligence, causing the signal to be commonly named for this word. ANSWER: Wow! [accept Wow! signal] <Rohan Kher, Science - Other Science> ~24600~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. Ninety percent of this country's women went on strike on a 1975 "Women's Day Off." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this country whose first female president was referred to as Vigdís. ANSWER: Iceland [or Ísland] [10e] Vigdís presided over the 1985 Reykjavik Summit, during which Ronald Reagan and this reformist Soviet premier failed to reach an agreement regulating ICBMs. This leader introduced glasnost and perestroika. ANSWER: Mikhail Gorbachev [or Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev] [10m] Peace talks at the Reykjavik Summit fell apart primarily due to Reagan's insistence on continuing the development of this proposed protective system announced shortly after the "Evil Empire" speech. ANSWER: Strategic Defense Initiative [or the SDI, accept the Star Wars program] <Cole Hartung, History - European - 1900+> ~24774~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: ink Confederate soldiers made ink by boiling rusty nails in this substance. Many Chinese paintings depict Laozi, Buddha, and Confucius tasting this substance. ANSWER: vinegar J. S. Bach wrote his scores with a corrosive ink made from tree gall and salts of this metal. Prussian blue comes from a salt of this metal that undergoes oxidation, a process that causes this metal to rust. ANSWER: iron
Text: 9. Along with pen, paper, and a certain type of stone, this good was one of the "four precious things of study" in China. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this good, which could be made from a combination of ground soot and gelatin. The process of adding thick lines to comics is named for this good. ANSWER: ink [accept inking or inker or India ink or inkstone] [10h] Confederate soldiers made ink by boiling rusty nails in this substance. Many Chinese paintings depict Laozi, Buddha, and Confucius tasting this substance. ANSWER: vinegar [accept cù ("tsoo")] [10e] J. S. Bach wrote his scores with a corrosive ink made from tree gall and salts of this metal. Prussian blue comes from a salt of this metal that undergoes oxidation, a process that causes this metal to rust. ANSWER: iron [accept iron gall ink; prompt on Fe] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~26022~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

10. Transit systems sometimes open with isolated "starter lines" before the rest of the project completes. For 10 points each: [10e] 3,200 daily passengers travel on the starter line in this city, which mainly services the area around Pearl Harbor to its northwest. ANSWER: Honolulu [10m] After contractors messed up pouring concrete on a light rail line connecting this city to Mercer Island, the system started operating in its Eastside suburbs of Bellevue and Redmond in 2024. ANSWER: Seattle [10h] This city made its streetcar, called The Hop, more useful in 2024 by merging it onto a combined F-Line to serve Summerfest. You can take I-41 north from this city's Mitchell Interchange to the Fox Cities. ANSWER: Milwaukee <Michael Bentley, Geography - United States> ~24941~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

11. In an adaptation of this play, Governor Carter Ross tries to stop the title character's interracial marriage, which is halted by his arrival with a corpse. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this play reworked into an "African" adaptation by Femi Osofisan. Kamau Brathwaite's play Odale's Choice changes this play's setting to Africa. ANSWER: Antigone [accept Tegonni: An African Antigone; prompt on Tegonni] [10e] This other Sophocles title character is reimagined as Odewale in Ola Rotimi's The Gods Are Not to Blame, in which he unknowingly marries his mother Ojuola. ANSWER: Oedipus [accept Oedipus Rex, Oedipus Tyrannus, or Oedipus the King] [10m] Congolese author Sylvain Bemba wrote an adaptation of Antigone titled for wedding candles with this title characteristic. A pioneering Nigerian literary magazine named after Orpheus with this characteristic was named after a 1948 Sartre ("sart") essay. ANSWER: black [or noir; accept Black Orpheus or Orphée Noir; accept Black Wedding Candles for Blessed Antigone; prompt on posthumous or Noces Posthumes de Santigone] <Kevin Wang, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25438~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

12. Wolfgang von Kempelen created a fraudulent chess-playing automaton that required a mechanical person named for this ethnicity to function. For 10 points each: [10e] Eighteenth-century orientalists were fascinated with the carpet-making and fashion of what ethnicity's Ottoman Empire? ANSWER: Turkish [accept the Mechanical Turk] [10h] This Sultan of the South Indian kingdom of Mysore owned a near-life-size automaton of a tiger mauling a European man. This successor of Hyder Ali pioneered rocketry in the third Anglo-Mysore war.
