ANSWER: Tipu Sultan [10m] Xiao Xun ("sh'YOW SHOON") claimed that the Hongwu Emperor found automata in the shape of tigers and dragons when destroying the palaces in this Chinese dynasty's capital of Khanbaliq. ANSWER: Yuan dynasty [or the Yuan empire; or the Great Yuan; or Dà Yuán; or Yuáncháo; or Yeke Yuwan Ulus] <Forrest Weintraub, History - World - Asian> ~25280~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

13. When this reaction is incomplete, it can leave behind toxic intermediates like acetaldehyde and carbon monoxide. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this highly exothermic redox reaction that can occur between methane and oxygen. ANSWER: combustion [accept incomplete combustion or complete combustion] [10h] Combustion has a high activation energy because oxygen must first undergo a forbidden transition from one of these two states to the other. Atoms in these two states have a total spin of 1 and 0, respectively. ANSWER: triplet AND singlet [accept in either order] [10m] At very high temperatures, this element can react with oxygen during combustion, creating pollutants symbolized "[this element]-O-x." A common rocket fuel has two atoms of this element and four atoms of hydrogen. ANSWER: nitrogen [or N] (The rocket fuel is hydrazine.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Chemistry> ~25569~ <Editor: June Yin>

Answer: La fille du régiment ("lah fee doo ray-zhee-MAHN")
Text: 14. An unwritten ninth high C is often added to the eight high Cs sung in this opera's aria "Ah! mes amis!" ("ah may zah-MEE") For 10 points each: [10h] Name this opera in which the Tyrolean man Tonio falls in love with Marie, the title vivandière. ANSWER: La fille du régiment ("lah fee doo ray-zhee-MAHN") [or The Daughter of the Regiment] [10e] "Ah! mes amis!" is often called "the Mount Everest" for performers with this voice type. A noted performer of Tonio is Luciano Pavarotti, one of a famous group of "Three" singers with this voice type. ANSWER: tenor [accept the Three Tenors] [10m] La fille du régiment was the first French-language opera by this bel canto composer of the opera L’elisir d'amore. ANSWER: Gaetano Donizetti [or Domenico Gaetano Maria Donizetti] <Aum Mundhe, Fine Arts - Opera> ~24593~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

15. In an Inuit story, a giant wolf named Amarok uses his tail to knock "bad" examples of these objects out of a boy to make him stronger. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these objects, jade examples of which are sprinkled with blood by Quetzalcoatl to create humanity in Aztec myth. ANSWER: bones [accept skeletons; accept bad bones; accept human bones or dog bones] [10h] Rather than just having bones removed, this Inuit sea goddess has her fingers chopped off by her father while clinging to the side of his kayak. ANSWER: Sedna [or Arnakuagsak; or Satsuma Arnaa; or Nerrivik; or Nuliajuk; or Arnapkapfaaluk; or Takannaaluk; or Uinigumisuitung] [10e] Inuit legend ascribes these phenomena to spirits playing a soccer-like game with a walrus skull. These polar lights are named for the Roman equivalent of Eos. ANSWER: auroras [accept Aurora Borealis or Aurora Australis; accept Northern lights or Southern lights] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~25826~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

16. A riddle about a fish glued to a dish is told at one of these events that ends with the narrator waking up while shaking her cat Kitty. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this type of event where one character relates how he was accused of murdering Time after posing the riddle "Why is a raven like a writing desk?" ANSWER: party [accept the Mad Tea-Party; accept a dinner or a supper or a tea] [10e] This Lewis Carroll character attends a mad tea party in Wonderland and hosts a party for the Red Queen in Through the Looking-Glass. ANSWER: Alice [or Alice Liddell; accept Alice in Wonderland or Alice's Adventures in Wonderland or Through the Looking-Glass and What Alice Found There; prompt on Liddell] [10h] After Alice wakes up, Through the Looking Glass ends with an acrostic about one of these events. Wonderland was inspired by a "golden afternoon" when Lewis Carroll and the Liddell sisters did this type of activity, which is chronicled in Jerome K. Jerome’s most famous novel.  ANSWER: boating trip [or a rowing trip; accept descriptions of a trip on the Thames or a trip on a river; accept Three Men in a Boat; prompt on trip; prompt on picnic]  <Sean Farrell, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~24603~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

17. The negative ratio of two forms of this quantity gives Poisson's ratio, which is negative for auxetic metamaterials. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this quantity that, in mechanics, equals the ratio of the change in length to initial length. ANSWER: strain [accept characteristic strain or axial strain or transverse strain; prompt on epsilon] [10h] This scientist and Green name an object in infinitesimal strain theory that is calculated from the deformation gradient and its transpose. This scientist also names a "second-order" object that yields T when dotted with a normal vector. ANSWER: Augustin-Louis Cauchy ("koh-SHEE") (The objects are the Cauchy–Green deformation tensor and the Cauchy stress tensor.) [10e] Because strain equals a ratio of two lengths, it has this property in dimensional analysis that is also possessed by the Reynolds number. A description is acceptable. ANSWER: unitless [accept descriptions of no units or not having units; prompt on dimensionless or dimension one] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24811~ <Editor: David Bass>

18. This psychologist coined the term "cell-assembly" to refer to a group of neurons that form one processing unit. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this psychologist who developed a namesake theory of learning that is often summarized as "neurons that fire together, wire together." ANSWER: Donald Hebb [accept Hebbian theory or Hebbian learning] [10m] Donald Hebb introduced his theory of learning in a book titled The Organization of this word. A pioneer of a school of psychology named after this word, Edward Thorndike, placed cats in puzzle boxes to test the law of effect. ANSWER: behavior [accept behaviorism; accept behaviorist] [10e] Other behaviorist psychologists include John Watson and this man. This psychologist studied operant conditioning in pigeons using his namesake "box." ANSWER: B. F. Skinner [or Burrhus Frederic Skinner; accept Skinner box] <Geoffrey Wu, Social Science - Psychology> ~25781~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

19. Fiona Rae and Sarah Lucas were included in this movement's 1988 exhibit Freeze. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this art movement opposed by Billy Childish, a painter whose name appears appliquéd onto a blue tent in an artwork depicting everyone an artist from this movement had slept with. ANSWER: Young British Artists [or YBAs; or Britartists] [10m] Several YBA artists met at the Freeze exhibition curated by this artist, who began burning thousands of his polka dot paintings in 2022 in an NFT project. This artist preserved a shark in formaldehyde. ANSWER: Damien Hirst [or Damien Steven Hirst] [10e] The YBA Jenny Saville is known for her large depictions of obese women in this genre. The Guerilla Girls protested paintings at the Met in this genre, which overwhelmingly depict women without any clothes. ANSWER: nudes [accept nude paintings or nude portraits; prompt on paintings of naked people or paintings of unclothed people; prompt on portraits] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - 1945+> ~25558~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

20. In Ancient Mesopotamia, people in this job would carry around willow wood and a stool and included the high-ranking Gimil-Ninkarrak. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this job. Romans would start wearing a toga virilis following the first visit to a man in this job, who might use a novacila ("no-WAH-kee-lah"). ANSWER: barbers [accept hair cutter or hair stylist or barber surgeon; prompt on surgeon] [10m] The brother of this Roman emperor, Geta, unusually had a barber give him a daily shave. This son of Septimius Severus would later have the Praetorian Guard murder Geta. ANSWER: Caracalla [or Marcus Aurelius Antoninus or Lucius Septimius Bassianus] [10e] In the Middle Ages, barbers often doubled as surgeons, in which capacity they might apply these creatures to a patient to help balance their humors via bloodletting. ANSWER: leeches [or medicinal leeches; or Hirudinea; or Hirudo medicinalis] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25474~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

21. In a short story by this author, a woman gets a key-shaped scar on her forehead after she marries the Marquis, who plans to behead her. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this author of the Bluebeard-inspired story "The Bloody Chamber.” This author of Nights at the Circus wrote the Little-Red-Riding-Hood-inspired story "The Company of Wolves." ANSWER: Angela Carter [or Angela Olive Pearce; or Angela Olive Stalker] [10m] Another story in Carter's The Bloody Chamber is named for the "Bride" of this animal. A man is sentenced to look behind one of two doors in a Frank Stockton short story titled "The Lady, or [this animal]?" ANSWER: tiger [accept "The Tiger's Bride"; accept "The Lady, or the Tiger?"] [10e] In Carter's "The Lady of the House of Love," a bicyclist falls in love with a vampire before going to serve in this war, which is depicted in All Quiet on the Western Front. ANSWER: World War I [or WWI or the Great War or First World War] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~25480~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

1. A book in this language likens the collective pursuit of a concept meaning "happiness" to body parts working together; that book contrasts ignorant, dissolute, turncoat, and straying places with the title Virtuous City. A philosopher who used this language illustrated his occasionalism with the example of a fire burning cotton. This language was used by a philosopher who advocated the "unity of the intellect" and was called "The (*) Commentator" by Aquinas. The Aristotelian influence on thinkers who used this language was attacked by a member of the Ash'ari tradition in The Incoherence of the Philosophers, which inspired a similarly-titled rebuttal. For 10 points, name this language used by Averroes ("uh-VAIR-roh-eez") and al-Ghazali. ANSWER: Arabic [or al-'arabiyyah] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~30181~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

2. The depoliticization of the refugee crisis is argued for in a novel titled for this place that depicts migrants living in the "dark London" ghetto who clear land with the promise of "40 meters and a pipe." That novel titled for this place describes Nadia and Saeed going through doors to arrive at places like Mykonos and Marin County, California. A collection described by this place was defended by one critic against the (*) "School of Resentment." This place describes a canon defined in a book by Harold Bloom. For 10 points, a monk tasked with retrieving Buddhist scriptures is given a monkey companion as a bodyguard in a novel titled for a Journey to what place? ANSWER: the west [accept Exit West or Journey to the West or the western canon; prompt on exit or word forms] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30852~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

Answer: communication protocols (The ATmosphere Conference is dedicated to the AT Protocol.)
Text: 3. They're not databases, but "federated" examples of these systems include ActivityPub and the subject of the non-meteorological ATmosphere Conference. "Wars" over these systems were lost by X.25 and the OSI model following Van Jacobson's development of a congestion control algorithm for one of these systems. One of these systems has a "loopback" value for self-reference that begins (*) "127." To avoid "exhaustion" of four-number dot-decimal notation values, the "v4" of one of these systems has been partially supplanted by "v6". A "secure" extension to one of these systems adds "S" to a four-letter acronym that appears in web addresses. For 10 points, name these network communication systems denoted by the "P" in "HTTP." ANSWER: communication protocols [or transfer protocols or Internet protocols; accept Internet Protocol suite or Transmission Control Protocol or Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure; accept IPs or IPv4 or IPv6 or IP addresses; accept TCP/IP; accept HTTPS before read; prompt on computer networks or social networks before "network" is read by asking "what systems facilitate the formation of these networks?"; prompt on addresses before read by asking "what systems provide these addresses?"] (The ATmosphere Conference is dedicated to the AT Protocol.) <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~30841~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. Norwegian composer Ola Gjeilo ("YAY-lo") frequently collaborates with one of these ensembles from Royal Holloway, University of London. Adrian Willaert ("VILL-art") wrote antiphonal ("an-TIFF-uh-nal") music featuring multiple of these ensembles while living in Venice. Composition students learn four-part writing by studying J. S. Bach's short preludes written and named for these ensembles. The Duke of Norfolk apocryphally challenged Thomas Tallis to write (*) Spem in Alium for eight of these ensembles. "Jesu ("YAY-zoo"), Joy of Man's Desiring" is an excerpt from a Bach cantata featuring one of these ensembles. The most common type of these large ensembles that often tune to a pitch pipe is called SATB. For 10 points, name these large vocal ensembles. ANSWER: choirs [or choruses or chorales; or choral ensembles; accept church choirs; accept Choir of Royal Holloway; accept Venetian polychoral style; accept chorale preludes; accept vocal ensembles until mention; accept a cappella ensembles until mention] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~29515~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

5. In the 1870s, a member of this family consolidated control over and greatly expanded the Homestake Mine near Deadwood. A century later, another member of this family who worked with Wendy Yoshimura shouted "I'm Tania!" while caught on camera robbing the Hibernia Bank in San Francisco. Bill Clinton pardoned that member of this family for that crime and several others she committed with the (*) Symbionese Liberation Army. Members of this family included the kidnapping victim Patty and her grandfather, who engaged in a circulation war with Joseph Pulitzer and sensationalized atrocity reports in Cuba before the Spanish-American War. For 10 points, name this family that gained a fortune through newspaper magnate William Randolph. ANSWER: Hearst family [accept George Hearst or Patricia Campell "Patty" Hearst or William Randolph Hearst] <Lalit Maharjan, History - American - 1865-1945> ~29584~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. They’re not prostitutes, but an artist's comments calling these people "little rats" or "little monkeys" has led to a theory he was Jack the Ripper. These people stand in front of a forest in a painting titled for their pink and green layers of clothes. An artist, who confessed to Ambrose Vallard his joy in "rendering [these people's] movement," painted them in blue in a circle. In an 1874 painting, these people form a circle around an elderly (*) master with his hands atop a cane. A man behind a curtain watches one of these people lift her arms in L'Étoile ("lay-TWAHL"), a painting set at the Palais Garnier ("pah-LAY gar-NYAY"). A lace dress decorates a statue of one of these people "of Fourteen Years." For 10 points, name these performers often painted by Edgar Degas. ANSWER: ballerinas [accept ballet dancers; prompt on dancers or performers; prompt on girls or teenagers] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~30594~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

7. At the end of a novel's epilogue, a member of this family tells a prankster schoolboy about the religious custom of eating pancakes at funerals. Members of this family discuss a phrase rendered in Constance Garnett's translation as "everything is lawful." One member of this family explains a poem in which Jesus is told that free will has bad effects by a clergyman in (*) Seville. A novice monk from this family follows Father Zosima. The illegitimate son of this family's patriarch is the anti-religious servant Smerdyakov ("SMAIRD-yah-kov"). The story of the Grand Inquisitor is told by a member of this family called Ivan to his sibling Alyosha. For 10 points, a novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky is titled for brothers from what family? ANSWER: Karamazov family [accept The Brothers Karamazov or The Karamazov Brothers or Bratya Karamazovy or Alexei "Alyosha" Fyodorovich Karamazov or Ivan Fyodorovich Karamazov or Fyodor Pavlovich Karamazov] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~29776~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

8. A British cult celebrating this person was fueled by Harriet Martineau's novel The Hour and the Man. To keep up agricultural exports, this man's government issued the world's first national identification system. This man secured a namesake trade clause during the Quasi War a few years after he sent a letter mocking reforms announced by Commissioner Sonthonax ("sohn-toh-NAHKS"). Although this man ultimately died in the (*) French prison of Fort de Joux ("fohr de ZHOO"), he was victorious over André Rigaud ("ahn-DRAY ree-GO") in the War of the Knives. Two of this man's children were held as ransom by General Charles Leclerc ("SHARL le-CLAIR") in 1802 after Leclerc made peace with Henri Christophe ("ahn-REE cree-STOHF") and Jean-Jacques Dessalines ("deh-sah-LEEN"). For 10 points, name this leader of Haiti's slave insurrection. ANSWER: Toussaint Louverture [or Toussaint Louverture; or Toussaint L'Ouverture; or François Dominique Toussaint; or Toussaint Breda] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30472~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. This element is produced as a direct byproduct of serpentinization. This element is classified as "gray" or "blue" depending on whether carbon capture is used to produce it. This element reacts with CO2 under pressure in the Sabatier process. A compound’s degree of unsaturation equals its index of this element's "deficiency." This element and carbon monoxide make up a (*) synthetic fuel. By definition, this element’s reduction potential at a platinum electrode equals 0. This is the lighter input element of a process catalyzed by iron oxide that breaks a triple bond and is used to generate fertilizer. For 10 points, the Haber process reacts nitrogen with what element to produce ammonia? ANSWER: hydrogen [or H; accept H2 or hydrogen gas or dihydrogen] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~30572~ <Editor: June Yin>

10. Three young devils fail to trick a fool with this name into fighting his brothers, Tarras and Simeon. By either shooting arrows or chopping down trees, a man with this given name finds a frog bride that transforms into Vasilisa the Wise. A wolf shapeshifts into a princess and a horse to aid a man with this name who disobeys instructions not to touch a golden bridle and (*) cage. That man with this name attempts to catch a bird that stole golden apples and, in another story, obtains a magical horse from Baba Yaga. The title of tsarevich originated from a slayer of Koschei ("kuh-SHAY") the Immortal with this given name. A tsar who legendarily blinded the architect of St. Basil’s Cathedral had, for 10 points, what given name and the epithet “the Terrible?” ANSWER: Ivan [accept Ivan Tsarevich or Prince Ivan; accept Ivan the Terrible; accept Ivan the Fool or Ivan the Ninny] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~30812~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

11. According to Suetonius, the wealthy woman Cossutia was betrothed to this man before adulthood. Mamercus Aemilianus and Aurelius Cotta helped this man gain Sulla's forgiveness to undo his exile for refusing to divorce his wife, Cornelia. This man gave a funeral oration for both his aunt and his first wife, in which he asserted his family's descent from the goddess Venus. This man divorced his third wife, (*) Pompeia, because he suspected her of having had an affair with Clodius Pulcher ("POOL-care") during the Bona Dea festival. This man's last wife, Calpurnia, reportedly dreamt of his stabbing the night before he died. For 10 points, what Roman general had numerous affairs before the Ides of March? ANSWER: Julius Caesar [or Gaius Julius Caesar; prompt on Caesar] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~29585~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

12. The Brown–Peterson paradigm is used to test this faculty, which is reduced by displacement and trace decay. This faculty makes up the second of the three stages of the Atkinson–Shiffrin model. Baddeley and Hitch proposed a model of this faculty, whose central executive controls a visuospatial sketchpad, an episodic buffer, and a phonological loop. This faculty's capacity is increased by (*) chunking. Nelson Cowan found that this faculty has a capacity of four, in contrast with George Miller's finding of a capacity of seven plus or minus two. This faculty is consolidated by the hippocampus. For 10 points, name this faculty that temporarily holds information, which is contrasted with a long-term counterpart. ANSWER: short-term memory [accept short-term memory retention; accept working memory; prompt on memory; prompt on retention or storage] (The terms short-term memory and working memory are often used interchangeably but are generally considered distinct.) <Geoffrey Wu, Social Science - Psychology> ~31023~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

Answer: Robert Browning (The poem in the second sentence is “Soliloquy of the Spanish Cloister.”)
Text: 13. In one poem by this author, a man laconically notes "I found / a thing to do" about a woman "come through wind and rain" who "shut the cold out and the storm." In one poem by this author, a man plots to show his "heart's abhorrence" "twenty-nine distinct damnations" to "send him flying / Off to hell." One poem by this author ends "all night long we have not stirred / And yet (*) God has not said a word!" This author wrote about a woman strangled with her yellow hair in "Porphyria's Lover." In a poem by this author, Ferrara presents a Fra Pandolf painting showing the "spot of joy" of a woman executed for having a heart "too soon made glad." For 10 points, name this poet whose soliloquies include "My Last Duchess." ANSWER: Robert Browning [prompt on Browning; do not accept “Barrett Browning” or “Elizabeth Browning”] (The poem in the second sentence is “Soliloquy of the Spanish Cloister.”) <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Poetry> ~30499~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

14. The album Cookin' with the Miles Davis Quintet introduced the song "Blues by [this word]." Power chords are alternately named for this word due to their intervallic content. This word ends the title of a song whose accompaniment alternates between E-flat minor seven and B-flat minor seven in the rhythm "long-short, long-short, long long." A common jazz progression proceeds from two to this number. Paul (*) Desmond improvised the blues-scale melody of a song titled for this number to show off Joe Morello's ability to play in odd time signatures. A single from Dave Brubeck's album Time Out is titled "Take [this number]." For 10 points, what is one more than the number of beats in the most common time signature? ANSWER: five [accept "Blues by Five"; accept five chords or fifth chords; accept "Take Five"] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~29671~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

15. A 2019 claim that negative mass is carried by these particles complicates their status as Goldstone bosons. These are the typical particles emitted alongside photons when Brillouin ("bree-WANN") scattering contributes to Stokes shift. Beyond the regime in which these particles' energy increases linearly with momentum, maxons and rotons arise. A superconducting "isotope effect" evidences the role of these particles in the association of electrons into (*) Cooper pairs. The relative phase of neighboring lattice particles indicates whether these particles are "optical" or "acoustic." These particles are discrete units of vibration in crystals. For 10 points, identify these quasiparticles named for the Greek word for "sound." ANSWER: phonons [accept optical phonons or acoustic phonons; prompt on sound waves] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~30847~ <Editor: David Bass>

16. One of these people titles a story in which the narrator's head falls off after a green ribbon around her neck is untied, by Carmen Maria Machado. A character with this relationship to the narrator is "practical in the extreme" and has "an intense horror of superstition." The narrator has to "creep over" a character with this relationship to her, who faints after using a key under a plantain leaf. S. (*) Weir Mitchell inspired a physician with this relationship to the narrator, who forbids writing as a "rest cure" for the "nervous depression" that makes her hallucinate about a “flamboyant pattern.” For 10 points, what familial relationship does John have to the narrator of Charlotte Perkins Gilman's "The Yellow Wallpaper"? ANSWER: husband [accept "The Husband Stitch"; prompt on spouse or partner or married people; prompt on doctor or physician before mention by asking "what familial relationship does that character have to the narrator?"] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - American - Short Fiction> ~29709~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

17. Alanine scanning mutagenesis was introduced to inhibit this protein's binding to its namesake receptor. Deficiency in this protein is a childhood symptom of Prader–Willi syndrome, so injections of a version of this protein are a common treatment for it and for both SHOX deficiency and Turner syndrome. This protein is involved in a negative feedback loop in which it stimulates IGF-1 production in the liver. The most abundant cell type in the anterior (*) pituitary gland secretes this protein in short pulses that are regulated by somatostatin and somatocrinin. Until growth plate fusion, greater abundance of this protein increases height. For 10 points, name this hormone whose deficiency causes short stature. ANSWER: human growth hormone [or hGH or somatotropin or somatropin or recombinant human growth hormone or rhGH; accept answers without "hormone" or "H" after "hormone" is read] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30633~ <Editor: David Bass>

18. This religion is described as developing after "contemplative" and "purposive" counterparts in a paper by Herrlee Creel titled "What is [this religion]?"; that paper references a supernatural state sought by its priests by prepending its name with hsien ("shyen"). The three-day jiao ritual is performed in one of two sects in this religion to be led by a Celestial Master. This religion centers compassion, frugality, and modesty as its (*) Three Treasures, or sānbǎo. The Eight Immortals are revered in this religion. The Zhuangzi ("JWONG-dzih") describes a principle central to this religion, often translated as "effortless action." For 10 points, name this philosophically entrenched Chinese religion that espouses wu wei and the teachings of Laozi. ANSWER: Taoism [or Daoism; accept Zhengyi Taoism or Tianshi Taoism; accept "What is Taoism?" or Hsien Taoism or contemplative Taoism or purposive Taoism] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - East Asian Religion> ~30851~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

19. In 2024, this state's WLBZ radio station closed after an author stopped bankrolling it. This state's superlatives include having the highest rate of heat pump adoption in the country and the oldest population. A chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee from this state was one of only three Republicans to vote to confirm Ketanji Brown Jackson. Donald Trump has clashed with this state's "radical-left governor," (*) Janet Mills, a supporter of trans athletes. Vermont and this state are the only ones represented in the Senate by an Independent. In 2023, a mass shooter terrorized a bowling alley in this state's city of Lewiston. For 10 points, swing voter Susan Collins represents what New England state? ANSWER: Maine [or ME] (The author is Stephen King, and the independent senator is Angus King.) <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~30261~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. In this decade's final month, a special forces assault on Tajbeg Palace ended Khalqist ("CALL-keest") rule. In this decade, a banquet was held in the Tent City to commemorate 2,500 years of monarchy. During this decade, a leader who said he felt nothing upon his return from exile implemented the Guardianship by Jurist. The Barakzai dynasty was overthrown in this decade by the PDPA during the (*) Saur Revolution. During the last year of this decade, the SAVAK secret police were fully dissolved. The reforms of the White Revolution were reversed at the end of this decade, during which the Pahlavi dynasty was overthrown. For 10 points, name this decade, the last year of which saw the Iranian Revolution. ANSWER: 1970s [prompt on 70s] <Noah Chin, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~29988~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

21. The Special Drawing Right's value for this quantity is defined by a weighted, five-part basket. Along with the price level, this quantity's stability may be preserved through sterilization. The Mundell–Fleming model predicts that this quantity cannot stay constant if capital flows are unregulated and monetary policy is independent. This quantity's long-term level can be roughly predicted using (*) purchasing power parity, which relies on the law of one price. Crawling pegs prevent this quantity from fluctuating too quickly. Governments may intentionally lower this quantity to increase exports in a policy called devaluation. For 10 points, name this ratio, the relative value of one currency to another. ANSWER: foreign exchange rate [or currency exchange rate; prompt on rate; prompt on currency strength or currency value] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~30625~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers> NSC 2025 - Round 13 - Bonuses

1. The extinct non-dinosaur species Tyrannasorus rex is in this order's Hybosoridae family. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this order of insects that contains a quarter of all known animal species. Organisms in this order are distinguished by their hardened elytra. ANSWER: beetles [or Coleo·ptera] [10e] The Tyrannasorus rex beetle's set of these appendages had nine segments. These protrusions from an insect's head are typically used as sense organs. ANSWER: antennae [10h] The resin that trapped the Tyrannasorus rex holotype was produced by a tree in this family, Hymenaea protera. Members of this family secrete flavonoids that trigger the release of LCOs and activation of nod genes in their symbionts. ANSWER: legumes [or peas or beans or Faba·ce·ae or Legumi·nosae] <Steven Yuan, Science - Biology> ~24834~ <Editor: David Bass>

2. This architect's criticism of Postmodernism was titled "Private Jokes in Public Spaces." For 10 points each: [10h] Identify this architect of the National Gallery of Canada. In 2023, designers completed an Unreal Engine version of this architect's original plan for his landmark Habitat 67 project. ANSWER: Moshe Safdie [10m] A never-realized Safdie design for a national one of these buildings in Israel used glass to emphasize openness and transparency. Glass is also a key feature of Rem Koolhaas's design for one of these buildings in Seattle that features floating platforms. ANSWER: library [or libraries or central library] [10e] Safdie's Marina Bay Sands resort in this country contains the world's longest infinity pool. The Brutalist Golden Mile Complex exemplifies this city-state's approach to public housing under Lee Kuan Yew. ANSWER: Singapore <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Architecture> ~25037~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

3. During this war, the Army of the Three Guarantees was formed to defend the Plan of Iguala, in which Peninsulares and Americanos would get equal rights. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this war whose heroes included Vicente Guerrero ("gair-RAIR-oh") and Guadalupe Victoria. A rallying cry during this war was called the Grito de Dolores. ANSWER: Mexican War of Independence [or War of Mexican Independence or Guerra de Independencia de México; prompt on War of Independence or La Independencia; reject "Mexican Revolution"; reject "Mexican Civil War"] [10e] Miguel Hidalgo, who was a priest in this institution, gave the Cry of Dolores during the war. This religious institution sponsored Jesuit missions in the Americas. ANSWER: Roman Catholic Church [or Catholicism; accept The Vatican or The Papacy; prompt on the Church; prompt on Christianity] [10h] This independence leader, a rival of Vicente Guerrero and author of the Plan of Iguala, was the first emperor of Mexico and fought Antonio López de Santa Anna. ANSWER: Agustín de Iturbide [accept Augustine I or Agustín I] <Noah Sheidlower, History - World - Latin American> ~25788~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. In a novel by this author, Orvil Red Feather watches videos of pow-wows on the Internet. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this author who wrote Wandering Stars. Tony Loneman and other thieves attack the Big Oakland Powwow with 3D printed guns in this author's novel There There. ANSWER: Tommy Orange [10e] There There takes its title from this author's observation about Oakland. This American expatriate poet of Tender Buttons wrote "A rose is a rose is a rose is a rose" and an autobiography of her lover, Alice B. Toklas. ANSWER: Gertrude Stein [10m] This author's blurb was pulled from There There after sexual harassment charges. This author of Reservation Blues wrote about Junior in The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian. ANSWER: Sherman Alexie [or Sherman Joseph Alexie Jr.] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Misc> ~25472~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

5. The tale of Enmerkar and the Lord of Aratta is often compared with the story of this structure, which may have been inspired by Etemenanki. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this structure. The effect of the arrival of the Holy Spirit in Acts 2 is often described as a reversal of the confusion during the creation of this structure. ANSWER: Tower of Babel [or Migdal Bavel; prompt on tower or Migdal alone] [10h] This king of Shinar is typically cited as ordering the construction of the Tower of Babel. It's not Ashur, but Abraham once used gnats to destroy the entire army of this hunter who legendarily founded the cities of Nineveh and Uruk. ANSWER: Nimrod [10e] The story of the Tower of Babel is found in this first book of the Old Testament. ANSWER: Book of Genesis [or Bereshit ("buh-ray-SHEET"); or Liber Genesis] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Hebrew Bible> ~25372~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

6. The lemma is the chosen canonical form of these units. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these linguistic units of meaning that correspond to the set of forms taken by a root word, such as run, ran, and running. These units are often composed of morphemes. ANSWER: lexemes [10m] The forms of noun lexemes are related through this process, which is contrasted with verb conjugation. This process inflects nouns and adjectives to express different grammatical categories, such as gender and case. ANSWER: declension [or decline or declining] [10e] Conjugation can also be used to express this grammatical feature. In English, this feature comes in singular and plural forms. ANSWER: grammatical number [accept quantity or amount; accept descriptive answers such as how many; prompt on plurality or pluralization] <Geoffrey Wu, Social Science - Linguistics> ~26051~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

7. A technique with this name approximates propagation with short linear steps, often by solving the eikonal ("EYE-con-al") equation. For 10 points each: [10m] Give this name of an optical technique in computer graphics that performs a Monte Carlo simulation by sampling from point sources of light. ANSWER: ray tracing [or ray tracer] [10h] The eikonal equation restricts the norm of this function of travel time. Instead of writing it with the Laplacian, the wave equation can be written as "u-sub-t-t over c-squared equals the divergence of this function of u." ANSWER: gradient [prompt on del or nabla; prompt on partial derivative or derivative with respect to x or d-d-x] (The Laplacian is equivalent to the divergence of the gradient.) [10e] The eikonal equation approximates the wave equation well when this quantity is large. This quantity for a wave equals velocity over wavelength. ANSWER: frequency [prompt on f or nu] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~25823~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. Intense examples of these events common near Alice Springs are called haboobs. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these events, which have increased in frequency in Saudi Arabia due to wetland drainage. These events typically occur over 100 days per year in the Bodélé Depression in the southern Sahara. ANSWER: sandstorms [or dust storms; prompt on storms or winds] [10e] 4,000 people in this country were hospitalized following a spate of shamal-caused dust storms in 2022, which also grounded flights in its capital on the Tigris River. This country is home to Mosul. ANSWER: Iraq [or Republic of Iraq; or Jumhuriyat al-Iraq] [10h] These winds can blow dust from the Sahara into Southern Europe, causing "blood rain" in Italy. These winds are also known as marin in Spanish and Ḫamsīn in Arabic. ANSWER: Sirocco winds [or scirocco] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~25525~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. This animal partly nicknames the Kehlsteinhaus, a mountaintop home connected to the Berghof via elevator. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these birds, one of which clutches a swastika in the emblem of the Nazi Party in its nest. ANSWER: eagles [or Eagle's Nest; or Parteiadler; or Reichsadler] [10m] The RAF defeated the Luftwaffe on Eagle Day during this aerial "battle" fought over a namesake country, ending German hopes of launching Operation Sea Lion. ANSWER: Battle of Britain [reject "the Blitz"] [10h] Operated today by the US Coast Guard, the sailing ship Eagle was originally named for this SA officer who was killed in a 1929 street fight. This person wrote a namesake lied that became Nazi Germany's national anthem. ANSWER: Horst Wessel [or "Horst-Wessel-Lied"] <Cooper Roh, History - European - 1900+> ~24696~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. This character proposes marriage in Latin to an Oxford alumna by asking "Placetne ("plah-SET-nay"), magistra?" in Gaudy Night. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this detective who solves murders with, and eventually marries, the crime writer Harriet Vane. Dorothy Sayers wrote about this foolish-looking lord in works like Whose Body? and Murder Must Advertise. ANSWER: Lord Peter Wimsey [or Lord Peter Wimsey] [10m] Sayers wrote a chapter in the collaborative mystery The Floating Admiral, for which this man wrote a prologue. This Catholic creator of the detective Father Brown wrote The Napoleon of Notting Hill and The Man Who Was Thursday.  ANSWER: G. K. Chesterton [10e] Sayers did not consider her best work to be her mysteries, but instead her translation of Dante’s Divine Comedy, with this first section followed by Purgatorio and Paradiso.  ANSWER: Inferno [accept Dante’s Inferno] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~25342~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

11. This reaction was discovered and patented by Hans Goldschmidt. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this reaction that typically uses aluminum and iron oxide as inputs. It is primarily used to weld together railroad tracks without the need for complex equipment. ANSWER: thermite reaction [10e] The thermite reaction is an example of these processes, which consist of two half-reactions. These reactions involve the transfer of electrons. ANSWER: redox reactions [or reduction-oxidation reaction] [10m] These reactions occur when a compound undergoes a redox reaction with itself. In the human body, superoxide undergoes one of these reactions to form hydrogen peroxide and oxygen. ANSWER: disproportionation [accept dismutation; prompt on dismutase] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~25777~ <Editor: June Yin>

12. Merchant Oliver Pollock invented the dollar sign while tallying up his debts from financing this general's Gulf Coast Campaign. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this Spanish general whose service in the American Revolution earned him honorary US citizenship in 2014. He is the namesake of a coastal Texan city. ANSWER: Bernardo de Gálvez [or Bernardo Vicente de Gálvez y Madrid, 1st Count of Gálvez; prompt on Galveston] [10e] Gálvez ordered the construction of Chapultepec Castle in what is now this capital city, which US forces captured from Santa Anna in 1847. ANSWER: Mexico City [or Ciudad de México] [10m] Gálvez fielded the Regiment of Hibernia, composed of soldiers of this ethnicity. After capturing Chapultepec, Winfield Scott executed 30 soldiers of this ethnicity who had defected to Mexico from the US. ANSWER: Irish [or Irish American] (The 30 soldiers were members of the Saint Patrick's Battalion.) <Cooper Roh, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24756~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

13. This play's author played Orgon during the 1669 premiere of its final version. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this play that ends with a deus ex machina ("DAY-uss ex MACK-ih-nuh") as the King orders that the title religious hypocrite be arrested instead of Orgon. ANSWER: Tartuffe ("tar-TOOF") [or Tartuffe, or the Impostor or Tartuffe, or the Hypocrite or Le Tartuffe, ou l'Imposteur] [10e] Tartuffe is a play by this author, whose patrons included Louis XIV ("the fourteenth"). This author wrote The School for Wives and The Imaginary Invalid. ANSWER: Molière ("mohl-YAIR") [or Jean-Baptiste Poquelin] [10h] The last play in this trilogy, La Mère coupable ("lah mair koo-PAH-bluh"), is subtitled "The Other Tartuffe." The title character exclaims "Just because you are a great nobleman, you think you are a great genius" in the second entry in this Pierre Beaumarchais ("BOH-marsh-ay") trilogy, which was censored throughout Europe. ANSWER: Figaro trilogy [accept answers indicating a trilogy about Figaro or the Barber of Seville or le Barbier de Séville] (The second entry is The Marriage of Figaro.) <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - European - Drama> ~25230~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

Answer: bulls (The divine bull is named Kao, pronounced “cow.”)
Text: 14. Answer the following about figures in Meitei mythology. For 10 points each: [10m] A divine one of these animals terrorized fishermen of the Khuman kingdom until its capture by Khamba. For rejecting her, Ishtar sends one of these animals to attack Gilgamesh. ANSWER: bulls [accept Bull of Heaven; reject “cow” or “cows”] (The divine bull is named Kao, pronounced “cow.”) [10e] The legendary ancestor of the Khuman kingdom, Thongalen, was often syncretized with Yama as a god of this domain. Ammit dwells in this location ruled by Osiris. ANSWER: underworld [or death; or the dead; or hell; or afterlife; accept Duat or Tuat; or Tuaut; or Akert; or Amenthes; or Amenti; or Neter-khertet] [10h] In order to win the hand of Shangnu from mortals, the water god Wangpulen competed in three contests, the last of which involved these objects. Bhishma gave advice to both sides of a war while immobilized for over 50 days by these objects. ANSWER: arrows [accept bow and arrows; prompt on bows alone] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - World Mythology> ~25796~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

15. This painting was rejected by Les XX ("lay vahn") and features a man in a skull mask among a crowd of grotesque festival goers, many of whom represent real life or allegorical figures. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this painting in which the title figure rides on a donkey under a banner reading "Vive La Sociale." ANSWER: Christ's Entry into Brussels in 1889 [accept Entry of Christ into Brussels or L'Entrée du Christ à Bruxelles] [10e] The artist of Christ's Entry into Brussels, James Ensor, later split with Les XX over their adoption of this technique of using dots to create paintings pioneered by Georges Seurat ("zhorzh sir-AH") and Paul Signac ("see-NYAK"). ANSWER: Pointillism [or Pointillists] [10m] An odd Ensor still life depicts a series of bottles in front of a person with this relationship on a deathbed. A person with this relationship provides the common name to the painting Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1. ANSWER: mother [or mom; accept My Dead Mother or Whistler’s Mother; prompt on family member or parent] <Juliet Mayer, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~15072~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

16. 60 percent of all Pre-Columbian metal production in western Mexico went into making these objects, widely used by Mayan royalty. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these objects that include the Bonshō found in Buddhist temples in Japan. The Whitechapel Foundry cast the most famous American example of these objects. ANSWER: bells [accept the Liberty Bell or hand bells or church bells or temple bells; prompt on musical instruments] [10e] Bonsho are usually made from this metal, which names an "age" that falls between the Stone Age and Iron Age in a system popularized by Christian Jürgensen Thomsen. ANSWER: bronze [accept Bronze Age] [10h] Russia's enormous bronze Tsar Bell was commissioned by this ruler. Ernst Johann Biron helped convince this daughter of Ivan V to enter the War of the Polish Succession in 1733. ANSWER: Empress Anna [or Anna Ioannovna; or Anne; or Anna I; or Anne I] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25476~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

17. An Enrique Gonzalez Martinez poem titled for twisting this animal's neck contrasts this animal with the "knowing owl." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this animal that in a Ruben Dario poem titled for it is described as "Wagnerian" and brings in the "glorious rays and light" of "the new poetry." ANSWER: swan [prompt on bird] [10e] Ruben Dario and Enrique Gonzalez Martinez were both part of a movement named after this general art movement of the late 19th and 20th century, which was followed by a movement named for being "post" this movement. ANSWER: modernism [accept modernismo] [10m] Dario wrote a poem addressed to a member of this profession he calls an "Alejandro Nebuchadnezzar." One member of this profession wrote the memoir Dreams From My Father. ANSWER: President of the United States [accept "To Roosevelt"; prompt on politician] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~26121~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

18. Yolanda Kondonassis and the Rochester Philharmonic premiered this composer's harp concerto in 2018. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this composer of blue cathedral. The "Fly Forward" movement of this composer's violin concerto depicts its dedicatee racing in the Olympics. ANSWER: Jennifer Higdon [or Jennifer Elaine Higdon] [10e] In 2010, Higdon's Violin Concerto won this American award typically given to classical composers, which is part of a collection of awards for achievements in "journalism, arts, and letters." ANSWER: Pulitzer Prize for Music [10m] Higdon's pieces rapid♦fire and running the edgE are pieces for this solo instrument. Marcel Moyse ("moh-EEZ") taught many contemporary performers of this instrument, including James Galway. ANSWER: flute [or transverse flute] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Music - Recent> ~25193~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

19. Identify the following about some of the worst Nobel Prizes in medicine, for 10 points each. [10m] António Egas Moniz won for developing this procedure, which was performed on John F. Kennedy's sister Rosemary in 1941. ANSWER: lobotomy [or leucotomy] [10e] Santiago Ramón y Cajal had to share the 1906 prize with this scientist, who had wrong ideas about the nervous system and who names an "apparatus" that packs up proteins into vesicles in eukaryotic cells. ANSWER: Camillo Golgi [accept Golgi apparatus or Golgi body] [10h] Johannes Fibiger won in 1926 for "proving" that cancer was caused by these creatures. A different variety of these creatures that cause tiredness and weight loss was combated in the South by the Rockefeller Sanitary Commission. ANSWER: parasitic worms [or hookworms or roundworms or nematodes or Ancylostoma or Necator; prompt on parasites] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~25473~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. After these stars undergo the helium flash, they enter the horizontal branch and then travel along the asymptotic giant branch. For 10 points each: [10e] Give these post-main sequence stars named for their color and large size. The Sun will become one of these stars before becoming a white dwarf. ANSWER: red giants [or red giant stars or red giant branch stars; prompt on giant stars] [10h] AGB stars are named for following the red giant branch of the H–R diagram while undergoing this doubly eponymous process, which causes a star's core to shrink as it radiates energy. ANSWER: Kelvin–Helmholtz mechanism [or Kelvin–Helmholtz contraction; prompt on answers giving “KH” instead of “Kelvin–Helmholtz”; reject "Kelvin–Helmholtz instability"] [10m] AGB stars can become Wolf–Rayet stars via a strong form of this phenomenon. The heliopause separates the interstellar medium from a region distinguished by this phenomenon. ANSWER: stellar wind [or solar wind] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~25029~ <Editor: David Bass>

21. John Baeder's paintings of roadside diners exemplify an artistic style named after resembling this medium. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this artistic medium that is emulated by hyperrealistic artworks. Modern-day works in this medium are often produced by DSLRs from companies such as Nikon. ANSWER: photography [or word forms such as photographs or photos or taking photographs; accept Photorealism or word forms such as Photorealists; prompt on pictures; prompt on cameras] [10m] The Photorealist artists Robert Bechtle and Ralph Goings depicted scenes of everyday life in this state in the late 1960s. David Hockney's A Bigger Splash depicts a swimming pool in this state. ANSWER: California [or CA] [10h] This artist used a characteristic blur effect to create "photo-paintings" such as Ema. This German "capitalist realist" designed a pixelated stained glass window for the Cologne Cathedral. ANSWER: Gerhard Richter <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - 1945+> ~25539~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

1. Folk dances from this country are combined with pop music by "Electric-Techno Neon Gods." TV stations in this country widely cover a 200-kilometer annual pilgrimage of a litter containing flamethrowers and a statue of this country’s unofficial national goddess, Mazu. This country's nuclear waste-filled Orchid Island is known as the Island of Human Beings to its indigenous Tao people. A group called the Ben·sheng·ren arrived in this country prior to 1945, unlike (*) "mainlanders," and includes many Hakka people. This country north of the Luzon Strait controls the Penghu archipelago in the strait it shares a name with. For 10 points, name this country home to the Formosan black bear, with a capital at Taipei. ANSWER: Taiwan [accept Republic of China or ROC; prompt on China; prompt on Formosa before read; reject "People's Republic of China" or "PRC"] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~30579~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

2. They're not a type of bond, but these entities boost reaction rate at adjacent reaction centers in neighboring group participation. A theory named after polyhedral skeletal types of these entities is used to predict the structure of borane cluster compounds and is sometimes called Wade's rules. The fact that thallium is more stable in the +1 oxidation state is explained by an effect where these entities are (*) "inert." Replacing a bond with one of these entities decreases a bond angle by approximately 2.5 degrees. The presence of two of these entities explains the bent geometry of water, and these entities are typically drawn as two dots. For 10 points, name these groups of two negatively charged particles. ANSWER: electron pairs [or lone pairs; accept inert pairs or inert pair effect; accept polyhedral skeletal electron pair theory; prompt on electrons; prompt on pairs] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~30811~ <Editor: June Yin>

3. To become one of these people, initiates in one region perform a ritual to open up the "gates of speech," or malmun ("MAHL-moon"). Some of these people conduct performances of bon-puri "origin songs." That ritual is the naerim type of the gut ("goot") rituals performed by a group of these people, who are mostly women known as mu ("moo"). Examples of these people known as noaidi among the Sámi wield painted (*) drums and accompany the singing of yoiks. The word for these people comes from the language of the Siberian Evenki people, whose example of these figures may ride to the sky on reindeer and birds and enter namesake trances. For 10 points, name these pan-cultural people often conflated with medicine men who commune with spirits and ancestors. ANSWER: shamans [accept shamanism or shamanic trances; accept East Asian shamans or Korean shamans or Japanese shamans or Sámi shamans; accept yuta; accept mudang or musok or muism before "mu"; prompt on medicine men; prompt on Koreans or Ainu or Japanese people by asking "in what role?"; prompt on witch doctors, but inform players this is considered pejorative] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Other Religion> ~31265~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

4. Vittoria da Colonna ("vit-TOR-ee-ah dah koh-LON-nah") created 103 of these works as a 1540 present for Michelangelo. The strambotto ("stram-BOT-toh") may have inspired the first creation of these works by Giacomo da Lentini ("JACK-oh-moh dah len-TEE-nee"). In A. S. Kline's translation, "sighs on which I fed my heart" are described in the first of 317 of these works in a sequence that popularized them. 25 of these works, along with commentaries, form the bulk of the prosimetrum book The New Life, or La (*) Vita Nuova ("lah VEE-tah N'WOH-vah"). One of these poems addressed to "you who hear the sound, in scattered rhymes" provides an alternative title for Il Canzoniere ("eel cant-zon-YAIR-ay"), which includes many of them about Laura. For 10 points, an octave is followed by a sestet in the "Petrarchan" ("peh-TRAR-kun") form of what 14-line poems? ANSWER: sonnets [or sonetti or sonetto; accept Petrarchan sonnets; prompt on poems until read] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Poetry> ~29545~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

5. A house owned by this family lends its name to the Waddesdon Bequest made to the British Museum. A member of this family who co-founded the British Relief Association helped secure British control of the Suez Canal but was thrice denied a Parliament seat. A member of this family chose not to sail across the English Channel after a carrier pigeon legendarily delivered the outcome at Waterloo. This family built the first railway in (*) Austria and rose to prominence under Frankfurt native Mayer Amschel. Adolphe Thiers' government received two "liberty loans" from this family. Lionel, a member of this family, was the first member of his religion to serve in Parliament. For 10 points, name this prominent Jewish banking family. ANSWER: Rothschild [accept the Rothschilds] <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~30186~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. One man in this novel nicknames his dour supervisor "Dostioffski," while his coworker hangs an American flag upside down at a barracks. A man in this novel works as "the most fantastic parking-lot attendant in the world." The syllable "-orooni" is added to every word by the singer Slim Gaillard in this novel, whose protagonists watch the pianist George (*) Shearing. A man in this novel picks cotton with Terry, and works as a night watchman with Remi Boncoeur, who refuses to drive to a Duke Ellington concert with a friend of Carlo Marx. While suffering from dysentery, this novel's protagonist is left in Mexico City by Dean Moriarty. For 10 points, the travels of Sal Paradise are depicted in what Jack Kerouac novel? ANSWER: On the Road <Jamie Burchett, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~29699~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

7. This crop can bleach and harden from "ice-ice" disease and was once widely burned to harvest soda ash. Anna Atkins' first book of cyanotype photograms was of this crop. FutureFeed makes bromoform-heavy pellets from this crop that greatly reduce methane emissions from cows. Research on a form of this crop known as kombu led to the coinage of the term (*) umami. Ice cream is often thickened using carrageenans extracted from this crop. Other forms of this crop include the sheet-like nori. This crop is farmed vertically on longlines in the fastest-growing sector of aquaculture and can also be harvested from namesake forests. For 10 points, name these marine plants whose edible type can be dried to wrap sushi rolls. ANSWER: seaweed [or kelp; or macroalgae; or laver; or sea moss; or Irish moss; or brown algae; accept ognori until "nori" is read; prompt on algae or red algae or green algae or chlorophytes; reject "seagrass" or "moss"] <Cooper Roh, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29786~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

8. Maria João Pires ("Maria zh'WOW PEE-resh") prepared the wrong piece by this composer for a performance with the Concertgebouw ("con-SEHRT-huh-bau"), but played the correct one from memory. The first movement of a piano sonata by this composer is an A major siciliana ("see-cheel-YA-na") marked andante grazioso. A concerto this composer wrote for Victoire Jenamy ("veek-TWAHR zhe-nah-MEE") was once thought to be written for an unnamed "jeunehomme" ("zhun-UM"). Emperor Leopold II's coronation featured a performance of this composer's (*) 26th piano concerto. An ascending C major triad over an Alberti bass begins this composer's K. 545 piano sonata, which is nicknamed facile ("fah-CHEE-lay"). The A minor finale of an A major piano sonata by this composer imitates Janissary bands. For 10 points, name this composer of the "rondo alla turca." ANSWER: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart [or Joannes Chrysostomus Wolfgangus Theophilus Mozart] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Classical> ~29516~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

9. The "underwatergate" scandal in the aftermath of this weeks-long event was fueled by a secret diary kept by Narendra Sethia. One politician declared, "rejoice, rejoice" during this event. Alexander Haig failed to prevent this event in shuttle diplomacy with an OAS ally. A "factor" named for this event led to a huge electoral victory a year later over Michael Foot. This event was chronicled by tabloid headlines such as "Stick It Up Your Junta ("HOON-ta")!" and (*) "Gotcha!" An Exocet missile destroyed the Sheffield during this event, where the General Belgrano was also sunk. Leopoldo Galtieri was removed from power after Stanley was recaptured in this conflict. For 10 points, name this war between the UK and Argentina. ANSWER: Falklands War [or Guerra de las Malvinas; accept answers such as the conclusion of the Falklands War; accept anything related to the scandal around the sinking of the General Belgrano until "General Belgrano" is read] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~31079~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: permittivity (Index of refraction equals the square root of the product of relative permittivity and relative permeability, but relative permeability is near one in non-magnetic materials.)
Text: 10. Two prime symbols denote this quantity's imaginary part, which is divided by its real part to give the electric loss tangent. The index of refraction in non-magnetic materials is proportional to the square root of this quantity. After factoring out a value with units of newtons per ampere-squared, one side of Ampere's law can be written as "J plus [a value for this quantity] times d-E-d-t." A unitless "relative" form of this quantity equals this quantity divided by (*) 8.8 picofarads per meter and is synonymous with the dielectric constant. The Coulomb constant is the reciprocal of four-pi times this quantity for the vacuum. For 10 points, name this quantity denoted epsilon that is not to be confused with permeability. ANSWER: permittivity [or absolute permittivity or relative permittivity or vacuum permittivity or permittivity of free space or electric permittivity; prompt on dielectric constant before read by asking "the dielectric constant is a ratio of values for what quantity?"; prompt on epsilon or epsilon-naught before "epsilon" is read] (Index of refraction equals the square root of the product of relative permittivity and relative permeability, but relative permeability is near one in non-magnetic materials.) <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~29603~ <Editor: David Bass>

11. According to Dares ("DAH-rays") Phrygius, this figure refuted Amphimachus's warmongering speech attacking Antenor. A grandson of this figure accidentally shot Silvius and got exiled to Britain, becoming the mythical king Brutus. After this figure was wounded, Artemis and Leto healed him and Poseidon removed him from combat again to protect him. In the Bibliotheca, this figure is spared due to his filial piety. This figure leaves behind his wife (*) Creusa when fleeing a burning city with his father Anchises and his son Ascanius. Juno's wrath causes this figure to fall in love with Dido, who commits suicide after being abandoned by him. For 10 points, name this Trojan son of Venus, the protagonist of a namesake epic by Vergil. ANSWER: Aeneas [accept Jupiter Indiges or Pater Indiges] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~29627~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

12. This material contained the first-discovered piscivorous theropod, Baryonyx, at a "Smokejack" site in the Low Weald. It's not a metal, but this material is both abundant in the B horizon and leached, alongside organic matter, out of the E horizon. This material consists of hydrous aluminum phyllosilicates, which form when feldspars weather via hydrolysis. This non-sand material has a "quick" type and appears atop a (*) "texture triangle." Minerals that make up this material, like smectite and kaolinite, are the main components of shale. This material consists of two-micrometer grains, making it finer than silt. For 10 points, name this high-plasticity soil component that hardens at high temperatures. ANSWER: clay [accept quick clay or clay minerals] <Rohan Kher, Science - Other Science> ~29670~ <Editor: David Bass>

13. In the last work in this medium from one novel, the siblings Sister Fatima and Richard survive a 100-year fire only to die by falling through a trapdoor. One work in this medium ends with Sergeant Lituma holding a gun to a man's head trying to decide whether to shoot. After failing to obtain them from Cuba, one company hires a local writer to create works in this medium that form (*) alternating chapters of a novel in which the protagonist courts a 32-year-old divorcee. Pedro Camacho and Marito both write scripts for this medium for Panamericana in Mario Vargas Llosa's Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter. For 10 points, name this medium used for a 1938 reading of H. G. Wells' The War of the Worlds that purportedly caused a mass panic. ANSWER: radio [accept novelas or soap operas or radio plays; accept scripts until "Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter" is read; prompt on serials by asking "what type of serials?"] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30855~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

Answer: Judith (Judy Chicago created The Dinner Party, which itself has a spot dedicated to the biblical Judith.)
Text: 14. A "Victorious" person with this name wears steel gloves and court clothes in paintings by Lucas Cranach the Elder. An artist with this first name depicted herself painting a fiddler in blue and had paintings like The Procuress attributed to her from Frans Hals. An old woman with a grim expression holds a sack next to a woman with this name in a (*) Caravaggio painting. The Sackler Center hosts a triangular installation by an artist with this first name, which contains plates for famous women and is called The Dinner Party. A maid helps this person kill an Assyrian general modeled on a rapist in a painting by Artemisia Gentileschi. For 10 points, give this name of a Biblical woman depicted beheading Holofernes ("huh-LAW-fer-neez"). ANSWER: Judith [or Judy; accept Judith Leyster or Judy Chicago; accept Judith Beheading Holofernes or Judith Victorious] (Judy Chicago created The Dinner Party, which itself has a spot dedicated to the biblical Judith.) <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~30820~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

Answer: Maryland (The case is called McCulloch v. Maryland because the court clerk misspelled his name.)
Text: 15. Akhil Reed Amar called Martin v. Hunter's Lessee the "landmark precursor" of a case involving this state. A precedent established in a case originating from this state was circumvented by selective incorporation. The Supreme Court ruled that the Bill of Rights did not apply to the states when a city in this state was sued by the wharf owner James Barron. Ex parte Merryman challenged (*) Lincoln's suspension of habeas corpus in this state. The Supreme Court ruled that the "necessary and proper" clause gave the federal government implied powers, and that federal law supersedes state law, in a case started by this state's attempt to tax the Second National Bank. For 10 points, name this state sued by James McCulloh. ANSWER: Maryland [accept McCulloch v. Maryland] (The case is called McCulloch v. Maryland because the court clerk misspelled his name.) <Forrest Weintraub, History - American - Pre-1865> ~30387~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: genes (The second line quotes The Selfish Gene.)
Text: 16. Elisabeth Vrba co-defined the term "exaptation" to describe a form of change to these things. In one metaphor, these things are preserved by "survival machines—robot vehicles." Wilhelm Johannsen rejected the prefix "pan" when naming these things. A "[these things']-eye view" is exemplified by the underlying cause of the green-beard effect, in which these things are pleiotropic. These things, which are physically real, can be either (*) paralogous or orthologous if they are similar enough to be considered homologous. Richard Dawkins popularized the notion of these things being "selfish." Epistasis occurs among these things whose versions are called alleles. For 10 points, name these basic coding units of DNA. ANSWER: genes [accept selfish genes; accept alleles until read; prompt on answers describing portions of DNA before the end; reject "genomes"] (The second line quotes The Selfish Gene.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30632~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. Mrs. Reynolds compliments this character, leading a woman to think "how much of pleasure or pain it was in his power to bestow." A woman compares her art of music to this man's art of conversation, after his aunt Catherine insults her piano-playing. In a letter, this character reveals that a man tried to elope with his teenage sister, Georgiana. Calling a woman "tolerable: but not (*) handsome enough to tempt me," this man sits out dances at a ball. This character persuades Mr. Wickham to marry Lydia, after offending his love interest by encouraging Mr. Bingley not to marry Jane. For 10 points, name this "single man in possession of a good fortune" who marries Elizabeth Bennet in Pride and Prejudice. ANSWER: Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy [prompt on Fitzwilliam; reject "Colonel Fitzwilliam"] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Other> ~31212~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

18. Duke Bluebeard's Castle is sometimes performed on a double bill with a short opera by this composer about a woman finding her dead lover in the forest. This composer misspelled an opera's title for fear of it being thirteen letters long. The premiere of this composer's "monodrama" Erwartung was conducted by his teacher Alexander von Zemlinsky. This composer's opera Moses und Aron ("AH-ron") used a compositional technique he developed to build its source (*) row. This composer developed a half-singing, half-speaking technique called sprechstimme that his student employed in the operas Lulu and Wozzeck. For 10 points, name this teacher of Alban Berg, founder of the Second Viennese School, and developer of the twelve-tone technique. ANSWER: Arnold Schoenberg <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Opera> ~29543~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

19. American Green Berets helped to train this country's notorious kaibiles unit. Senator Sheldon Whitehouse's grandfather pressured Manuel Orellana ("or-ey-AH-nah") to resign as president of this country, and Orellana's daughters were part of CIA-sponsored "Voice of Liberation" radio recordings in a later coup masterminded by the Dulles brothers. The Guerrilla Army Of The Poor fought in a civil war in this country that began a few years after Operation (*) PBSUCCESS. The so-called "Silent Holocaust" in this country was documented by Nobel Peace Prize winner Rigoberta Menchú and targeted its Indigenous Maya people. For 10 points, name this Central American country once led by Jacobo Árbenz that shares a long border with Mexico. ANSWER: Guatemala [or Republic of Guatemala; or República de Guatemala] <Michael Bentley, History - World - Latin American> ~31201~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

20. The German-born Robert Michels co-founded a sociological school in this country that emphasized the "circulation" of elites in a theory of regime change. Robert Putnam studied twenty regional governments in this country, noting local levels of civic engagement, in Making Democracy Work. A thinker from this country contrasted the "war of maneuver" with the "war of position." The term "subaltern" was coined by a thinker from this country, who outlined the concept of (*) cultural hegemony in his Prison Notebooks. A thinker from this country names a principle that states 80 percent of consequences come from 20 percent of causes. For 10 points, name this country home to Antonio Gramsci and Vilfredo Pareto. ANSWER: Italy [or Italian Republic; or Repubblica Italiana; or Kingdom of Italy; accept Italian school of elitism] <Geoffrey Wu, Social Science - Sociology> ~30571~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

21. Regarding these people, a first lady said, "Let them burn and we shall clap our hands." A shooting killed nine protestors against Decree Number 10 after it banned these people from flying symbolic flags. A photo of one of these people protesting the persecution of these people by the ARVN was taken by Malcolm Browne a few months after the Huế Phật Đản ("hway fat dahn") shootings. The overthrow of (*) Ngô Đình Diệm ("goh deen diem") occurred amid his persecution of these people. Thích Quảng Đức, one of these people, self-immolated to express opposition to preferential policies in South Vietnam favoring Catholics. For 10 points, name these people whose religious sites were targeted by the Vietnamese government's pagoda raids. ANSWER: Buddhists [accept specific sects like Mahayana Buddhists; accept Buddhist monks; prompt on more general answers like Vietnamese people or Vietnamese civilians] <Rohan Kher, History - World - Asian> ~29715~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower> NSC 2025 - Round 14 - Bonuses

1. One poet from this modern-day country invoked a water goddess from this country that he offers "oilbean" to in his long poem "Heavensgate." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this birth country of another poet who wrote of a racist landlady asking over the phone if a potential tenant is "DARK? OR VERY LIGHT?" ANSWER: Nigeria [or Federal Republic of Nigeria] [10m] Christopher Okigbo wrote a poem titled for this poetic form "for Alto." Catullus 101 that ends with "Ave atque vale" is a poem in this poetic form’s couplets. ANSWER: elegy [accept “Elegy for Alto”; accept elegiac couplets] [10e] "Telephone Conversation" is a poem by this author who is best known for plays like Death and the King’s Horseman. ANSWER: Wole Soyinka <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25828~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

2. These beings' creation is prompted by Nusku's failure to placate a group of rebellious gods surrounding the palace in which he served as vizier. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these beings created by mixing clay, blood, and cosmic water in Mesopotamian myth, analogously to God breathing into dust to create them in the Bible. ANSWER: humans [accept obvious equivalents such as humanity or mankind] [10h] In the Atra-hasis, this water deity and consort of Mami or Ninhursag obtained blood for the creation of humanity by cutting up Geshtu-e ("GESH-too-AY"). ANSWER: Enki [or Ea] [10m] Mami directs the humans to fast in honor of this deity in celebration of their creation. This fertility goddess unclothes herself while traveling through the gates to the underworld. ANSWER: Ishtar [or Inanna; accept Astarte or Ashtart] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~25780~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

3. An article by Peter Temin claims that agricultural goods prices in this city moved in a random walk. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this city whose price data comes from cuneiform tablets written by employees of the Temple of Marduk. This city contained the Hanging Gardens. ANSWER: Babylon [10m] This crop was the first of six commodities listed on those cuneiform tablets. This cereal was used by Neolithic humans to make beer and in Babylon for bread. ANSWER: barley [or Hordeum vulgare; prompt on grain] [10h] Due to a possible shortage around 100 BCE, the price of this good uniquely spiked. One Pazyryk object made from this good was found in the grave of a Scythian depicting deer and horses. ANSWER: wool [or fleece; prompt on sheep or lambs; prompt on textiles or fiber or cloth or clothing] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~24873~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. This ethnic group's traditional triple-layered clothes must show the collar of each layer and include "deep garments" that inspired a 21st-century revival. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this ethnic group whose wide, loose sleeves were nicknamed for the shape of a lute-like instrument. This ethnic group's elite typically wore a flat, angled crown with tassels hanging down. ANSWER: Han [or Han Chinese; accept hanfu; prompt on Chinese; reject "Mandarin"] (The instrument is the pipa.) [10e] Han women placed dragonfly wings between these body parts to imitate a plum blossom in huadian ("hwa-dee-en") make-up. These facial features may be reshaped by tweezers or threading to prevent them from connecting. ANSWER: eyebrows [or brows] [10m] In 2022, Dior released a clothing line similar to hanfu’s mǎmiànqún ("ma mee-en chun"), a women’s fashion item for usage in this activity. A sport played while performing this physical action names Ralph Lauren’s first clothing line. ANSWER: horseback riding [accept word forms such as riding a horse; prompt on polo by asking "what physical action are players performing in that game?"] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~25535~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

5. The unsolvability of the Delian problem is equivalent to this function of two not being a constructible number. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this odd elementary function that is differentiable everywhere except the origin. It’s not the natural log, but Heron cryptically calculated that this function of 100 is about 4.6. ANSWER: cube root [or x to the power of one-third or one-third power of x or x to the one-third] [10e] Heron is best known for his formula for this quantity from side lengths. This quantity equals one-half times base times height. ANSWER: area of a triangle [prompt on area] [10h] The unsolvability of squaring the circle was proven via a result in the theory of these numbers. Liouville pioneered the study of these numbers that are described by the Gelfond–Schneider theorem. ANSWER: transcendental numbers [reject "transcendent"] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25822~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Woodward Woodward publicized the Chinagate scandal in this election year. In this election year, the losing candidate was married to a politician who became the first female senator from North Carolina and ran with a quarterback
Text: 6. While covering college football in 1933, a sportswriter with this surname, Stanley, coined the phrase "ivy colleges." For 10 points each: [10m] Give this surname of a journalist who co-wrote All the President's Men with his colleague Carl Bernstein. ANSWER: Woodward [or Rufus Stanley Woodward; or Robert "Bob" Upshur Woodward] [10h] Woodward publicized the Chinagate scandal in this election year. In this election year, the losing candidate was married to a politician who became the first female senator from North Carolina and ran with a quarterback. ANSWER: 1996 [prompt on '96] (The losing candidate was Bob Dole.) [10e] Woodward and Bernstein's exposé of Watergate was informed by Mark Felt, an associate director of this federal law enforcement agency. ANSWER: FBI [or Federal Bureau of Investigation] <Cooper Roh, History - American - 1945+> ~24750~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

7. In 2024, a letter describing how this poet "set his mind to evil" in his lost memoirs was discovered in a Cambridge library. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this poet, who dedicated the fourth canto of Childe Harold's Pilgrimage to John Hobhouse, who called for the burning of this man's memoirs after he died in the Greek War of Independence. ANSWER: Lord Byron [or George Gordon Byron] [10m] Hobhouse opposed the publication of this Byron epic that opens, "Bob Southey! You're a poet." This poem's title man falls in love with Haidee ("HAY-dee") and escapes a harem in Constantinople. ANSWER: Don Juan ("don JOO-an") [accept reasonable mispronunciations like "don yuan"] [10h] This lover of Byron called his memoirs "a mere-copy book." This author of Glenarvon called Byron "mad, bad, and dangerous to know." ANSWER: Caroline Lamb <Kevin Wang, Literature - British - Poetry> ~24946~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

8. FtsZ is a prokaryotic analog of these proteins. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these proteins whose polymerization is halted by colchicine. The catastrophe stage of dynamic instability is caused by the hydrolysis of GTP molecules bound to one type of these proteins. ANSWER: tubulins [accept alpha-tubulin or beta-tubulin; reject "microtubules"] [10e] Alpha-beta-tubulin dimers compose the microtubules that form axonemes to support these whip-like structures and the similar cilia. ANSWER: flagella [or flagellum] [10m] In Kirschner and Mitchison's "search and capture" model, dynamic instability drives the binding of microtubules in the mitotic spindle to these protein structures that surround centromeres. The KMN complex associates with these structures via the CCAN. ANSWER: kinetochores <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Biology> ~25517~ <Editor: David Bass>

9. A poem in Markings by Dag Hammarskjöld ("HAH-mer-shold") is titled for a sculpture given to him by this penpal of his. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this British artist of Single Form, a bronze sculpture pierced by a hole, which was installed outside the U.N. headquarters in honor of Hammarskjöld's death. ANSWER: Barbara Hepworth [or Jocelyn Barbara Hepworth] [10e] Like her other bronzes, Hepworth cast Single Form from a direct carving of this material. Copies of ancient sculptures were often made with a type of this wet material said to be "of Paris." ANSWER: plaster [accept plaster of Paris] [10m] Hepworth made her plaster prototypes at Trewyn Studio, which is now a museum run by this institution. This network of art museums' "Britain" gallery hosts the Turner Prize each year. ANSWER: Tate [accept Tate Britain] <Sean Farrell, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~24688~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>
