10. The Beveridge curve plots this economic indicator against the vacancy rate. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this indicator for which Bill Phillips found a negative correlation with the inflation rate. The "natural" level of this measure has structural and frictional components. ANSWER: unemployment rate [accept U or U-3] [10h] This curve plots the interest rate of a bond against the time remaining to maturity. The inversion of this curve for U.S. Treasury bonds is a key recession indicator. ANSWER: yield curve [10m] The aggregate supply curve of this type slopes upward, in contrast to a different, vertical aggregate supply curve. In this condition, some prices are sticky. ANSWER: short run [accept short term] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~25827~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

11. Levinthal's paradox arises from an apparent exponential growth in complexity with this quantity. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this quantity for which, as of Fallon et al. 2024's description of PKZILLAs ("P-K-zillas"), has been observed at values of up to 45,000. This quantity for titin ("TYE-tin") can exceed 35,000. ANSWER: protein length [or polypeptide length; accept answers describing the number of amino acids in a protein; prompt on protein size or polypeptide size; prompt on answers describing the number of monomers in a polymer by asking "what are the monomers in this context?"] [10h] PKZILLAs construct toxins called prymnesins ("pri-MEE-sins"), whose polycyclic "ladder-frames" feature repeats of this functional group. Polymers characterized by this group, like PEG ("P-E-G"), feature C and O atoms on opposite ends of their monomers. ANSWER: ethers [or polyethers] [10e] PKZILLAs are so large that they challenge current models of this process by which a protein gains three-dimensional tertiary structure. ANSWER: protein folding <David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~25769~ <Editor: June Yin>

12. This philosopher argued that laws should be enacted by the "general will," contrasted with the "will of all." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this Genevan philosopher who wrote, "Man is born free, and everywhere he is in chains" in The Social Contract. ANSWER: Jean-Jacques Rousseau [10m] Rousseau's Social Contract built on his earlier "discourse" on this concept, where he claimed that "the true founder of civil society" was the first man to enclose a piece of land and say, "This is mine." ANSWER: human inequality [or l'inégalité parmi les hommes; accept Discourse on Inequality or Discourse on the Origin and Basis of Inequality Among Men or Discours sur l'origine et les fondements de l'inégalité parmi les hommes] [10h] Discourse on Inequality claims that civil society developed from this type of self-love dependent on others' approval. According to Rousseau, humans in the state of nature lacked this emotion with a French name but felt pity and amour de soi. ANSWER: amour propre <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~24589~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

13. Samuel Gridley Howe developed the Boston Line Letter system for these people. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these people who were educated at the Perkins School. Charles Barbier's "night writing" system was adapted for use by these people. ANSWER: blind people [accept deaf-blind people; prompt on disabled people; reject "deaf people"] [10e] This Frenchman adapted Barbier's system for a namesake system of raised dots that is widely used in educating blind people. ANSWER: Louis Braille [10m] Helen Keller, a student of Perkins-trained Anne Sullivan, was a co-founder of this nonprofit, which financed the defense of teacher John T. Scopes in the Scopes Monkey Trial. ANSWER: ACLU [or American Civil Liberties Union]  <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25526~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. Historian Mark Lawrence Schrad points out that this novel mentions the peril of saloons and alcohol many more times than it condemns the meatpacking industry. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this novel about Lithuanian immigrant Jurgis Rudkus by Upton Sinclair. ANSWER: The Jungle [10h] Sinclair wrote eleven novels about this man, who helps a Jewish family escape Nazi Germany in Dragon’s Teeth. Sinclair named this son of an arms manufacturer after an actual arms manufacturing company.  ANSWER: Lanny Budd [or Lanny Budd; accept the Budd Company] [10m] An exclamation point was added to the title of this Sinclair novel to avoid a copyright dispute with Walter Gilkyson. Bunny Ross encounters many workers whose lives are ruined by the title industry in this novel. ANSWER: Oil! <Michael Bentley, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~22903~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

15. This man's construction projects include spending over half a billion dollars on a new, 1,100-room palace in Ankara. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this longtime president of Turkey. ANSWER: Recep Erdoğan ("EHR-doh-wahn") [or Recep Tayyip Erdoğan] [10m] Perhaps Erdoğan's most ambitious infrastructure project is a 45-kilometer one of these projects that won't be subject to the 1936 Montreux Convention. US pressure over rates for one of these projects has caused trouble for José Raúl Mulino. ANSWER: a canal [or artificial waterway; accept Istanbul Canal; prompt on transportation project] (José Raúl Mulino is president of Panama) [10h] The Erdoğan-affiliated "Gang of Five" firms have invested heavily in building roads in this country. In December 2024, this country's Supreme Court annulled an election because of a TikTok campaign backed by Russia. ANSWER: Romania <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~24679~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. Mastro Titta served in this role for the Papal States from 1796 to 1865 and almost certainly did not wear a mask while he worked. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this occupation that often passed from father to son. People in this job profited from royalties from hawkers selling ballads. ANSWER: public executioner [10e] During a royal execution in the mid-1600s, this Lord Protector and winner of the English Civil War was likely one of the few to know the identity of the hooded executioner. ANSWER: Oliver Cromwell [10m] The myth of the mask-wearing executioner spread as a result of William Harrison Ainsworth's 1840 novel about this person, who was executed in the Tower of London in 1553 shortly after Edward VI's death. ANSWER: Lady Jane Grey [prompt on partial answers] <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~25078~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

17. In British scores, this brass instrument reads in treble clef and transposes at the major ninth. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this band instrument commonly conflated with the baritone. In Holst's "Mars," this instrument typically plays a solo written for the similar tenor tuba. ANSWER: euphonium [10e] Like double horns, euphoniums use a fourth one of these devices to expand their range. These devices change the pitch of horns and trumpets. ANSWER: valves [accept trigger valves; accept piston valves; accept rotary valves] [10h] A special type of euphonium used in marching bands is held in the same manner as the trumpet and this instrument. Because it's easier to march with, horn players typically double on this instrument. ANSWER: mellophone <Abhinav Rachakonda, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~25027~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

18. In one play, Franz strangles himself with a golden cord from one of these objects to save himself from outlaws. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these objects, one of which in another play is stood on a pole in a marketplace to identify a king's "loyal subjects," who are obliged to bow to it. ANSWER: caps [or hats or Hüte or Hut; accept Hutschnuren or Hutschnüre] [10e] The tyrant Gessler makes peasants bow to a cap in William Tell, a play by this author of The Robbers and "Ode to Joy." ANSWER: Friedrich Schiller ("FREED-rick SHILL-ur") [or Johann Christoph Friedrich von Schiller] [10m] The high emotion of The Robbers, in which Franz commits suicide using his cap, makes the play a typical example of this late-18th-century proto-Romantic movement, whose three-word name comes from a Friedrich Maximilian von Klinger play. ANSWER: Sturm und Drang ("shturm oont drang") [accept Storm and Stress] <Sean Farrell, Literature - European - Drama> ~24606~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

19. Original language term required. Conditions such as 'ilm, yaqin, and qabul—or knowledge, certainty, and acceptance—must accompany the utterance of this statement. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this first pillar of Islam that asserts tawhid, the oneness of Allah. ANSWER: shahadah [10h] The "dual" and "triple" shahadas, which are used by Sunnis and Shi'is, respectively, differ in whether they mention this figure. The Alawite shahada claims that "there is no God but [this figure]," whom they revere as a human incarnation of God. ANSWER: Ali [or Ali ibn Abi Talib] [10e] The Sufi ritual of dhikr often makes use of the shahada as one of these often chanted phrases, which include the Gayatri one and the word "Om." ANSWER: mantras [accept Gayatri mantra] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Islam> ~25825~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

20. The "Pauli effect," by which Wolfgang Pauli and "a functioning device ... may not occupy the same room," is exemplified by a fire at the PPL around his visit to this town. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this New Jersey town home to an Ivy League university and the Institute for Advanced Study. ANSWER: Princeton [or Municipality of Princeton] [10m] The six-hour PPL fire consumed one of these devices designed by Henderson and White. These devices, which are no longer used in cutting-edge research, propel charged particles along a spiral path. ANSWER: cyclotrons [reject "synchrotrons"] [10h] Pauli wrote to Carl Jung about the numerology of this constant. This constant describes the splitting of spectral lines due to relativistic and spin interactions. ANSWER: fine structure constant [or Sommerfeld constant; prompt on 1/137; prompt on alpha] (Pauli was fascinated by its value of almost exactly 1/137.) <June Yin, Science - Physics> ~24755~ <Editor: David Bass>

21. In the 1830s, most stagings of Daniel Auber's ("oh-BARE's") La Muette de Portici ended with a staged recreation of this event. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this destructive event in 79 CE, which preserved the archaeological sites of Herculaneum and Pompeii. ANSWER: eruption of Mount Vesuvius [prompt on partial answers] [10m] In the 1820s, nightly "eruptions" of an 80-foot-high simulated Mount Vesuvius took place at one of these places in London called Vauxhall ("VOX-hall"). A royal one of these places was expanded by Joseph Banks and is named Kew. ANSWER: a garden [accept public garden or botanical garden; prompt on public park] [10h] A "volcano-mad" British diplomat with this surname created a "mechanical contrivance" that simulated lava erupting from Vesuvius. His wife Emma with this married surname was a mistress of Horatio Nelson. ANSWER: Hamilton [or William Hamilton or Emma Hamilton] <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~25093~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: Vienna (The first clue refers to the Ernst Mach Society, to which much of the Vienna Circle belonged.)
Text: 1. A physicist who worked in this city named a society whose "left wing" attempted to apply its "scientific world-conception" to all aspects of life. A philosopher who worked in this city wrote The Logical Structure of the World and argued for the "elimination of metaphysics" as part of the verificationist program. The logical positivist Rudolf Carnap was part of an empiricist (*) "circle" of philosophers from this city. A posthumously published book by a Cambridge professor born in this capital city developed the theory of "language games," contradicting the "picture theory of meaning" from his earlier Tractatus. For 10 points, name this capital city, the birthplace of the author of Philosophical Investigations, Ludwig Wittgenstein. ANSWER: Vienna [or Wien; accept Vienna Circle or Wiener Kreis] (The first clue refers to the Ernst Mach Society, to which much of the Vienna Circle belonged.) <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~29772~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

2. Edward Morse's excavation of a mound of these objects at Omori kick-started Japanese archaeology. They're not pebbles, but these objects were tied to wood to represent islands on Polynesian stick charts. The word "porcelain" comes from an Italian word for these objects. Imported examples of these objects devalued the nzimbu ones harvested from Luanda for use by the Kingdom of Kongo. These objects were thrown to the ground in a West African tradition for (*) divination. Native Americans made wampum beads from these objects. The Classical Chinese character for "money" was an image of these objects, which were harvested in the Indian Ocean from cowries. For 10 points, name these hard objects harvested from clams and conches. ANSWER: shells [accept seashells; accept cowrie shells; accept clamshells or channeled whelk shells; accept Omori Shell Mound] <Rohan Kher, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30105~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

3. Jean-Pierre Serre's epsilon conjecture connected work by this mathematician to a 1957 conjecture via an object named for Gerhard Frey. A non-conjectural statement named for Goldbach gives the coprimality of numbers named for this mathematician. A primality test that relies on a statement given by this mathematician fails on Carmichael numbers, which are this mathematician's "pseudoprimes." (*) Euler's totient theorem generalizes a statement by this mathematician, who stated a conjecture that motivated the proof of the Taniyama–Shimura conjecture. This mathematician stated that a-to-the-p equals p mod p and was vindicated in 1995 by Andrew Wiles. For 10 points, name this mathematician with "little" and "last" theorems. ANSWER: Pierre de Fermat (The epsilon conjecture gives that the Taniyama–Shimura conjecture implies Fermat's last theorem. Goldbach's theorem describes Fermat numbers.) <Steven Yuan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~30840~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. This modern-day country titles a highly geometric rendition of a Lancaster grain elevator by Charles Demuth. Edmonia Lewis depicted an ancient leader of this country dead on a throne. Some of the best surviving examples of Roman painting are funerary portraits on wooden boards in this country. Sculptures found in this country include a lifelike limestone of a seated (*) scribe and several of rulers stiffly walking with their fists clenched. Several artists painted landscapes with the Holy Family's "flight" into this country. Depictions of the ka decorate a tomb in this country where a gold and lapis lazuli death mask was discovered. For 10 points, name this home of the Mask of Tutankhamun. ANSWER: Egypt [or Arab Republic of Egypt; accept Ancient Egypt; accept My Egypt; accept the Flight from Egypt] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~30097~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

Answer: Yiddish (The first line refers to "Bontshe the Silent" by I. L. Peretz.)
Text: 5. One of this language's "three classics" authors wrote a story in which a heavenly court reviews the sufferings of a man dubbed "the Silent." An author whose pen name came from this language's phrase for "peace be upon you" created a protagonist who "blows a small fortune" after two women pay him to take them through a forest on his wagon. In a story in this language, a man learns from his dying wife that their children all resulted from affairs shortly before the Spirit of Evil tells him to (*) urinate into his dough. The Tevye ("TEV-yuh") the Dairyman stories and "Gimpel the Fool" were written in this language by Sholem Aleichem ("SHOH-lum ah-LAY-khum") and Isaac Bashevis Singer. For 10 points, what largely Germanic language is used by Ashkenazi Jews? ANSWER: Yiddish [or yidish or idish] (The first line refers to "Bontshe the Silent" by I. L. Peretz.) <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Other> ~30869~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

6. This politician chastised two ministers who refused to stand to honor the death of "black work" victim Satnam Singh. This politician, who once went by the IRC handle Kyr-ri, invited Rishi Sunak to the 2023 Atreju ("ah-TRAY-yoo") festival, named after the hero of The Neverending Story. As a youth, this politician participated in the Tolkien-inspired "Hobbit camps" of the MSI. This politician, the only EU leader invited to the 2025 (*) Trump inauguration, ended the "citizenship income" program initiated by the Five Star Movement. Northern League leader Matteo Salvini is a deputy minister for this politician, whose F·d·I party is sympathetic to fascists. For 10 points, name this first woman to hold the post of Prime Minister of Italy. ANSWER: Giorgia Meloni [prompt on Giorgia] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~30584~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. The rejection of less conventional examples of this action led Feeneyism to be declared heretical. One performance of this action inspired the use of the word yardna in Mandaeism. Dismas is often cited as an example of a Biblical figure undergoing one form of this action "of desire," while another form "of blood" was espoused by Cyprian of Carthage. The use of the (*) Trinitarian formula in this practice comes from Jesus ordering its performance in the Great Commission. A sect that stresses the importance of conscious belief before this sacrament and opposes its performance on infants is named for this practice prefixed with "Ana." For 10 points, name this sacrament performed on Jesus in the Jordan River. ANSWER: baptism [accept word forms such as baptize or baptist; accept christening; accept baptism by blood or baptism of blood or baptism by desire or baptism of desire; accept infant baptism; accept Anabaptists; accept believer's baptism] (The term yardna derives from the Jordan River.) <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Christian Practice> ~30940~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

8. Residents of this country conclude that a clock is a god because a man claims he seldom does anything without consulting it. People in this country are rewarded with red, green, or blue silks for skill in "leaping and creeping" around sticks. Rival factions in this country wear high or low heels to mark their affiliation and argue about whether (*) eggs should be broken at the big or little end. A man is charged with treason in this country for urinating to put out a fire. At the beginning of a novel, a man awakens after a shipwreck to find himself tied to the ground by the residents of this country, whose rival is Blefuscu. For 10 points, name this country of six-inch-tall people in Gulliver's Travels. ANSWER: Lilliput <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~30526~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

9. This person cared for the children of relatives William Smith and John Shaw because they were both alcoholics. In the 12 years as the sole head of the household, this person greatly expanded the Peacefield House. A stone monument named for this person marks the spot where she watched the Battle of Bunker Hill. This woman's (*) husband expressed fear of a "despotism of the petticoat" while participating in the First Continental Congress. In one of her many saved letters, this woman stated, "All men would be tyrants if they could," and urged, "Remember the ladies." This woman defended the Alien and Sedition Acts passed by her husband. For 10 points, name this second US First Lady. ANSWER: Abigail Adams [or Abigail Smith; prompt on Adams or Smith] <Lalit Maharjan, History - American - Pre-1865> ~30810~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. This is the third word of a method that uses character tables to identify equivalent atoms and stretching modes, where this word follows "symmetry adapted." This is the first word of a technique that uses the Hartree-Fock method to compute coefficients for the sum of a basis set of Gaussian or Slater-type orbitals. Molecular orbitals can be formed by a (*) combination of atomic orbitals described by this word. Molecules described by this six-letter word have 3N minus 5 vibrational degrees of freedom. Since it has three lone pairs and two bonds, tri·iodide has this molecular geometry. Carbon dioxide also has this geometry. For 10 points, name this geometry of molecules with a 180 degree bond angle. ANSWER: linear [accept symmetry adapted linear combinations or linear rotors or linear combination of atomic orbitals] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~30988~ <Editor: June Yin>

11. This author claims he would kiss the skin between the lower part of a woman's shoulder and the upper part of her arm if it were exposed. This author, who exclaims, "perhaps...my writings will not be given to the Lethe's waters," later invokes Phoebus and nine goddesses to grant that wish in the third book of one of his works. In that work, this author said that "as Chiron was to Achilles, I am to (*) Cupid". This author of Remedia Amoris structured one work as a long poem that progressed from the creation of the world to the deification of Julius Caesar. After a supposed "poem and an error" caused his exile to Tomis, this author wrote Tristia. For 10 points, name this Roman author of Ars Amatoria and Metamorphoses. ANSWER: Ovid [or Publius Ovidius Naso] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~29661~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

12. It's not chickens, but some Robert Fantz experiments on these subjects involved a "looking chamber." These subjects less frequently fail the Three Mountains task when three-dimensional models are used. To evaluate a semantogenic theory, Mary Tudor conducted the notorious Monster study of these subjects. These subjects are hesitant to move forward over a "visual (*) cliff." Researchers yelled "pow, boom" in front of these subjects to study their tendency to model aggression. Walter Mischel has lamented that one of his experiments on these people has been interpreted as implying that "your life is in a marshmallow." For 10 points, name these people whose progress through four stages, according to Jean Piaget. ANSWER: children [or infants or babies or toddlers; accept orphans; accept kids or youths; accept teenagers after "semantogenic" is read; prompt on young people or humans before "people" is read; prompt on minors or juveniles] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Psychology> ~30941~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

Answer: piano (The piece in the first clue is Isaac Albeniz's Iberia.)
Text: 13. Alicia de Larrocha made the first complete recording of a piece for this instrument that contrasts A-flat minor and A-flat major in its opening Evocación ("eh-vo-ca-see-OWN"). The song "Bésame Mucho" was inspired by "The Maiden and the Nightingale," a piece for this instrument from Enrique Granados' Goyescas. Ricardo Viñes premiered a piece for this instrument whose first movement depicts the Generalife ("he-ne-ra-LEE-feh"), Manuel de Falla's ("FA-ya's") (*) Nights in the Gardens of Spain. Basque folk music inspired a G major concerto for this instrument by Maurice Ravel that begins with a whip crack. Paul Wittgenstein premiered Ravel's concerto for the left hand on this instrument. For 10 points, the right pedal is used for sustain on what keyboard instrument? ANSWER: piano [or pianoforte] (The piece in the first clue is Isaac Albeniz's Iberia.) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~29531~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

14. In this modern-day country, a rebel leader was nicknamed "heavy thud" for his thunderous footfalls. To bolster his campaign, John F. Kennedy donated $100,000 to a Tom Mboya ("em-BOY-ah")-led program bringing students from this country to America. Rebels in this country were accused of leading blood-drinking rituals by Rawson Macharia during the 1952 trial of a group that included Kung'u Karumba and Bildad Kaggia, the (*) Kapenguria Six. Evelyn Baring authorized Operation Anvil during an anticolonial uprising in this country led by Dedan Kimathi. Jaramogi Oginga Odinga founded the KPU party in this country, which was rocked by the Mau Mau Rebellion. For 10 points, name this East African country led from Nairobi. ANSWER: Kenya [or the Republic of Kenya; or Jamhuri ya Kenya] <Cole Hartung, History - World - African> ~29682~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

15. Description acceptable. This action is performed three times in a "bi-elliptic" technique that can be optimal if a ratio of final to initial distance exceeds twelve. Performing this action quickly while potential energy is minimized exploits the Oberth effect. This action is performed twice, first for "raising" and then for "circularizing," in a Hohmann transfer. When performed with greater specific impulse, this action achieves greater (*) delta-v. By Newton's third law, propellant gas accelerated downward via this action produces an upward thrust force. This action is performed following the removal of each successive stage of a multistage rocket. For 10 points, name this action that powers rockets via combustion. ANSWER: fuel burning [or rocket burning or engine burning or propellant burning; accept rocket boosting or speed boosting or impulses or burn time or impulsive burning or finite burning; accept descriptions of rocket engines firing or combusting or igniting; accept fuel combustion until read; accept thrusting or rocket thrusters before "thrust” is read; accept propelling or rocket propulsion before "propellant” is read; prompt on descriptions of accelerating or speeding up by asking "what action causes the acceleration?"; prompt on orbital maneuvers or impulsive maneuvers by asking "what action is done to maneuver the orbit?"] <Rohan Kher, Science - Physics> ~29717~ <Editor: David Bass>

16. This king's ambassador to England was imprisoned in London after marrying the Jacobite Sara Wright, leading Daniel DeFoe to call him a "Stockfish Lunatic." This monarch, who was wounded by a bullet to the foot, was carried on a stretcher toward Turkey as his army surrendered at Perevolochna. Nine years earlier, this monarch's forces capitalized on the Peace of Travendal to win a battle in which 10 enemy generals and the personal physician of the tsar were captured, the first Battle of (*) Narva. Count Rehnskjold commanded a pre-dawn raid in which 7,000 of this monarch's troops were killed taking a Ukrainian fort at Poltava. For 10 points, name this rival of Peter the Great, a Swedish king who fought in the Great Northern War. ANSWER: Charles XII [or Carl XII; or Carolus XII; or Karl XII; prompt on Charles or Carl] <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~28653~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

17. This film's cinematographer F. A. Young created an illusion over a mudflat for a lengthy scene of a man in black riding towards a well. This film's protagonist mutters "Nothing is written" after rescuing a man with fatigue. A photographer captures this film's protagonist in white robes as he stands on an overturned train. Steven Spielberg has often recreated a (*) cut from this film in which a man blows out a match to reveal a sunrise. Omar Sharif plays a sheikh in this film, which was inspired by the book Seven Pillars of Wisdom and ends with its title character dying in a motorcycle accident. For 10 points, name this 1962 film in which Peter O'Toole plays a British officer in the Arab Revolt. ANSWER: Lawrence of Arabia <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Film> ~29517~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

18. In this play, a man says, "I give you my sweat and my blood," but that he's spent all his tears, in a speech where he describes trying to "blast a hole into forever." A woman in this play says, "I took all...my dreams...and I buried them inside you," leading a man to exclaim, "You say I take and don't give!" A man in this play sings, "Hear it ring!" in a song about the "good old dog" (*) Blue, and claims that "Death ain't nothing but a fastball on the outside corner." In this play, Gabriel blows a trumpet to "tell St. Peter to open the gates" after his brother's funeral. A patriarch in this play tries to discourage his son Cory from playing football. For 10 points, the Pittsburgh garbage truck driver Troy Maxson is the protagonist of what August Wilson play? ANSWER: Fences <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Drama> ~30504~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

19. While painted red and black, this god distracts the wives of seven seers in the Pine Forest. This god has been compared to Dionysus for causing a rampage leading to the beheading of Daksha after this god's first wife immolated herself. In a Purana named after him, this god was the judge of a contest between two other gods to locate the ends of a pillar of fire. This god received the epithet Nilakantha after (*) drinking the halāhala poison during the Churning of the Ocean, turning his throat blue. This god is sometimes depicted as the lord of dance in his Nataraja aspect. While protecting Parvati, Ganesha has his head cut off by, for 10 points, what Hindu destroyer god who makes up the Trimurti with Vishnu and Brahma? ANSWER: Shiva [or Siva; accept Shiva Purana] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - World Mythology> ~30815~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

20. One protein in this family localizes to the sides of stereocilia to support tip links and is the most common protein mutated in patients with type I ("one") Usher syndrome. One of these proteins cross-links antiparallel structures into stress fibers. Class VI ("six") of these proteins travel towards pointed ends, while their class II ("two") is "conventional." The presence of these proteins distinguishes the H zone and the A band, and these proteins are absent from (*) I ("eye") bands. The head domain of these proteins uses energy released by ATP hydrolysis for its "power stroke." These proteins form thick filaments in sarcomeres. For 10 points, name these motor proteins that drive muscle contraction by binding to actin. ANSWER: myosins [accept non-muscle myosin II or myosin II or myosin VI or myosin VIIa ("seven A"); prompt on motor proteins before "motor" is read; reject "tropomyosin"] (The lead-in describes myosin VIIa.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~30808~ <Editor: David Bass>

21. These animals are described as the "animal of fishing-gear" because of the double meaning of "taumr." Skinfaxi and Hrímfaxi are these animals, one of which dominates the top half of the Tjängvide ("shen-VEE-day") image stone. Two of these animals named for "shining" and "frost" are associated with Dagr and Nótt. Two of these animals named Árvakr ("AR-vak") and Alsviðr ("ULL-svin") are chased by the wolf Sköll while drawing the sun. To avoid losing a wager to the man building (*) Asgard’s walls, a deity transforms into one of these animals and distracts one named Svaðilfari ("SVAH-theel-FAH-ree"). According to Grímnismál, "the best” of these animals is one birthed with eight legs by Loki after that encounter. For 10 points, name these animals exemplified by Sleipnir ("SLAPE-neer"), Odin's steed. ANSWER: horses [accept mares; accept steed until read] <David Bass, RMP - World Mythology> ~31232~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales> NSC 2025 - Round 15 - Bonuses

1. 60 nobles drowned in liquid excrement in the Erfurt latrine disaster during an assembly called by a king of this name and regnal number. For 10 points each: [10h] Give both the name and regnal number of the king against whom Jack Cade revolted and who assumed power during the Great Bullion Famine. ANSWER: Henry VI [accept Henry VI, King of Germany; accept Henry VI, King of England; prompt on Henry] [10e] The former Henry VI married Constance of this kingdom, which he tried to invade. Based on a Mediterranean island, this kingdom was unified with Naples after Napoleon's defeat. ANSWER: Kingdom of Sicily [reject "Kingdom of the Two Sicilies"] [10m] That assembly in Erfurt was called to settle a feud after the defeat of another man named Henry with an epithet named for these animals. A king nicknamed for these animals was the victorious commander at the Battle of Jaffa. ANSWER: The Lion [accept Lion-Hearted or Lionheart or coeur-de-lion] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Middle Ages> ~24860~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings ("Sympathy" is by Paul Laurence Dunbar.)
Text: 2. This book was followed by six sequels including Singin' and Swingin' and Gettin' Merry Like Christmas and All God's Children Need Traveling Shoes. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this book whose title is taken from the poem "Sympathy." In this book, a girl moves from Stamps, Arkansas, to San Francisco and becomes a cable car conductor. ANSWER: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings ("Sympathy" is by Paul Laurence Dunbar.) [10e] The memoir I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings was written by this author. ANSWER: Maya Angelou [10h] Description acceptable. In I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings, Maya performs this action after being raped by Momma's boyfriend Mr. Freeman. She (emphasize:) stops this action after having tea with Mrs. Bertha Flowers, who teaches her "lessons in living." ANSWER: not speaking [accept equivalents like not talking or being mute or being silent or silence] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Nonfiction> ~25548~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

3. All that is known about Simeon I of Bulgaria's youngest son Bajan ("bah-YAN") is that he could turn himself into one of these beings, according to Liutprand of Cremona. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these beings who are vulnerable to silver bullets and who transform every full moon. ANSWER: werewolves [or lycanthropes] [10h] This author contrasted the Norman French word "garwalf" with the Breton name of a kindly werewolf in her poem "Bisclavret." She adapted part of the romance of Tristan and Iseult in her poem "Chevrefoil." ANSWER: Marie de France [prompt on de France] [10m] Spectral wolves that guide souls to the underworld called Cŵn Annwn ("COON AH-nun") feature in many tales from this four-branched collection of folklore whose characters include Rhiannon and Pwyll ("POOL"). ANSWER: Mabinogion <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - World Mythology> ~25330~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

4. These structures can be pigmented red-brown by protoporphyrin IX ("nine") or blue-green by biliverdin. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these structures that remain pigmented in some archosaurs. Pigmentation of these structures may provide camouflage and is often accompanied by speckled patterning. ANSWER: eggshells [prompt on eggs or shells] [10e] Egg color co-evolved with this task, whose "contact" type may have motivated the structured clutches of oviraptorosaurs. Premature infants are kept in warm, clear boxes that perform this task. ANSWER: incubation [accept word forms like incubators and incubate; accept contact incubation] [10h] Biliverdin caused the blue-green coloration of the eggs of this "terrible clawed" raptor. John Ostrom used this theropod to spark the warm-blooded "dinosaur renaissance." ANSWER: Deinonychus antirrhopus [or Deinonychus antirrhopus] <Kevin Thomas, Science - Biology> ~25913~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. In this piece's third movement, improvisatory piano arpeggios lead to a clarinet solo marked come in sogno ("COH-may in SOH-nyo"), or "as if in a dream." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this piece whose first movement's main theme is played by high cellos, bassoons, and English horn in 2/8 time. This piece's last movement requires six ancient trumpets called buccine ("boo-CHEE-nay"). ANSWER: Pines of Rome [or Pini di Roma] [10e] This conductor analyzed the unique orchestration of Pines of Rome in "The Anatomy of a Symphony Orchestra," one of his televised "Young People's Concerts." This conductor of the New York Philharmonic wrote the music to West Side Story. ANSWER: Leonard Bernstein [or Louis Bernstein or Lenny Bernstein] [10m] Pines of Rome is a piece by this composer of Ancient Airs and Dances. ANSWER: Ottorino Respighi <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~24480~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

6. In a story titled for one of these arrangements, the bourgeois Isabel runs to her room out of shame after reading a letter out loud to her Bohemian friends. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these arrangements. Ngugi wa Thiong'o ("GOO-gee wah thee-ON-go") and co-writer Ngugi wa Mirii ("GOO-gee wah MEER-ee-ay") were arrested for writing a play titled for entering one of these arrangements "When I want." ANSWER: marriage [accept "Marriage à la mode" or I Will Marry When I Want; accept equivalents like getting married or weddings or being wed or matrimony or nuptials] [10e] The aforementioned "Marriage à la mode" is by this New Zealand author who criticized class consciousness in her short story "The Garden Party." ANSWER: Katherine Mansfield [or Kathleen Mansfield Murry] [10h] Bertha Young is shaken in the belief in her perfect marriage after seeing her husband romantically embrace Pearl in this Mansfield short story. ANSWER: "Bliss" <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~26192~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

7. Simulation software based on this formalism, like Athena++ and Julia's PLUTO, use adaptive mesh refinement to improve efficiency. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this formalism used in most high-energy astrophysical simulations. This formalism is governed by both the Navier–Stokes equations and Maxwell's equations. ANSWER: magneto·hydro·dynamics [or MHD; or computational MHD; accept GRMHD or general relativistic MHD; prompt on hydro·dynamics or fluid dynamics or fluid mechanics] [10e] Magneto·hydro·dynamics models this state of matter as a conducting fluid. This "fourth state of matter" consists of an ionized gas. ANSWER: plasmas [10m] Numerical solutions to PDEs in MHD are often calculated using a class of methods named for "finite" instances of this quantity. Buoyant force equals the product of little g, density, and this quantity. ANSWER: volume [accept finite volume methods; accept displaced volume; prompt on V; reject "displacement"] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~25572~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. This term first described a college that trained Catholic missionaries. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this type of message that titles a 1928 book by Edward Bernays. Noam Chomsky and Edward S. Herman advance a model of mass media named for this type of message in Manufacturing Consent. ANSWER: propaganda [10h] The title of Manufacturing Consent comes from this media theorist, who called the public the "bewildered herd." He also introduced the modern meaning of "stereotype." ANSWER: Walter Lippmann [10e] Manufacturing Consent, which discusses anticommunist bias in the media, was written during this period of tension between the US and USSR. This period's two-word name was popularized by Lippmann. ANSWER: the Cold War <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Other> ~25889~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

9. After clearing this musician of a marijuana possession charge, Baroness Pannonica de Koenigswarter ("KURR-nigs-vahr-turr") wrote the liner notes for his album Criss-Cross. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this jazz pianist who honored the Baroness in the song "Pannonica" from the album Brilliant Corners. This "Genius of Modern Music" also wrote the standard "Straight, No Chaser." ANSWER: Thelonious Monk [or Thelonious Sphere Monk] [10h] In the 1950s, de Koenigswarter was a manager of this hard bop group founded by Horace Silver and Art Blakey, whose hits include "Blues March" and "Moanin'." ANSWER: The Jazz Messengers [accept Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers; prompt on the Messengers or Art Blakey’s Messengers] [10e] De Koenigswarter also patronized this musician, who died in her suite at the Stanhope Hotel. This bebop saxophonist was nicknamed "Bird." ANSWER: Charlie Parker [or Charlie Parker Jr.] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~25554~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

10. This leader was nicknamed the "Prince of Pacification" for leading the Lam Sơn uprising against China. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this leader of Vietnam who was the legendary owner of the Heaven's Will sword. This leader founded a dynasty that ruled Dai Viet before it was succeeded by the Tây Sơn dynasty. ANSWER: Lê Lợi [or Lê Thái Tổ; accept Bình Định vương; prompt on Lê or Lợi] [10e] Lê Lợi ("LAY loy") repelled this Chinese dynasty from Vietnam. This dynasty sponsored the voyages of Zheng He ("jung huh") and was succeeded by the Qing. ANSWER: Ming Dynasty [10m] Lê Lợi was supported during the Lam Sơn uprising by the Trịnh ("TRIN") and members of this prominent family, which later ruled a dynasty led by Tự Đức, who led for much of the mid-1800s. ANSWER: Nguyễn ("WIN") family [accept various pronunciations] <Noah Sheidlower, History - World - Asian> ~26103~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

11. A 2021 essay by critic Parul Sehgal made "The Case Against" now-ubiquitous plots focused on this condition. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this condition. A 2014 best-seller by Bessel van der Kolk about "Brain, Mind, and Body" helped popularize this condition and treatments for it such as EMDR. ANSWER: trauma [accept PTSD or trauma plot or psychological trauma or Post-traumatic stress disorder] (The book is The Body Keeps the Score.) [10e] Sehgal's essay opens with an anecdote about this author encountering a weeping woman on a train. This author wrote To The Lighthouse. ANSWER: Virginia Woolf [or Adeline Virginia Woolf] [10m] Jamie Hood's Trauma Plot: A Life examines Ovid's story of Tereus and Philomela, who are both turned into these creatures. The phrase "halcyon days" derives from Alcyone's transformation into one of these creatures. ANSWER: birds [accept kingfishers or nightingale or hoopoe] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~25039~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

12. It's not related to this tournament, but NASA's new PACE satellite is named for using optical spectroscopy to study the "phyto" type of these organisms. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this broad group of aquatic organisms that are a major food source for krill and baleen whales. ANSWER: plankton [or plankters; accept phytoplankton] [10m] The PACE satellite's HARP2 polarimeter observes these atmospheric suspensions. These substances scatter sunlight, increasing the Earth's albedo. ANSWER: aerosols [prompt on colloids or particulate matter or PM] [10h] The PACE satellite is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, which employs techniques from this field. Topographic maps made with LiDAR ("LIE-dar") exemplify this field's goal of studying the Earth via emitted and reflected radiation. ANSWER: remote sensing [accept active remote sensing] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~25537~ <Editor: David Bass>

13. Michael Hofmann's 2018 translation of Berlin Alexanderplatz from German to this language was the first since 1931. For 10 points each: [10e] Hofmann and Jenny Erpenbeck shared the 2024 International Booker for his translation of Kairos into what language? The Booker Prize is for novels in this language. ANSWER: English [10m] Hofmann's first translation was of a Kurt Tucholsky novel about one of these places. In an unfinished novel, the surveyor K. tries to enter one of these title places, whose bureaucrats include Klamm. ANSWER: castles [or Schloss or Schlösser; accept Castle Gripsholm or Schloss Gripsholm or The Castle or Das Schloss] [10h] Hofmann translated The Land of Green Plums, a novel inspired by this author's life in Communist-era Romania. This author wrote The Hunger Angel. ANSWER: Herta Müller <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~25884~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

14. A 1934 article argues that a couple's joined hands in this painting are a gesture of fides. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this painting whose background contains a convex mirror surrounded by medallions depicting the Passion. The small dog at the bottom of this painting may also represent fidelity. ANSWER: The Arnolfini Portrait [accept The Arnolfini Wedding; accept The Arnolfini Marriage] [10h] This German art critic advanced the hypothesis that The Arnolfini Portrait was a marriage contract in that 1934 article. This critic elaborated on the hypothesis in his book Early Netherlandish Painting. ANSWER: Erwin Panofsky [10e] The Arnolfini Portrait is by this Early Netherlandish painter who created the Ghent Altarpiece with his brother Hubert. ANSWER: Jan van Eyck [or Johannes de Eyck or Johannes van Eyck] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~24990~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

15. During the late 19th century, when silver was scarce, many American companies accepted these objects as currency, perhaps to the chagrin of philatelists. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these objects issued by a government agency led by John Wanamaker, which also ran a popular money order system. ANSWER: postage stamps [10e] The amount of silver in circulation increased after the 1890 Silver Purchase Act named for this Ohio senator, who also sponsored an Antitrust Act. ANSWER: John Sherman [10m] Another form of de facto currency was bearer notes issued by banks described by this word, which also identifies people who prospected for oil in unproven fields. This word names strikes that often occur without the support of union leaders. ANSWER: wildcat [accept word forms like wildcatter or wildcatting; accept wildcat strikes] <Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~25035~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

16. Answer the following about different religious protections against the evil eye. For 10 points each: [10e] Jewish boys in Central Europe sometimes wore halsgezeig neckbands adorned with coins to distract the evil eye during this practice of removing foreskin. ANSWER: circumcision [or word forms like circumcise; prompt on bris or brit milah] [10m] Original language term required. In Islam, certain protective phrases must be uttered as protection against the evil eye, such as this Arabic phrase meaning "God has willed it." ANSWER: mashallah [or Ma Sha Allah; or Masha Allah; or Ma Shaa Allah] [10h] Several religions across North Africa and the Middle East use this palm-shaped amulet to ward off the evil eye. Sephardic Jews were among the first to use this amulet against the evil eye. ANSWER: hamsa [or khamsa] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Other Religion> ~25338~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

17. In 2024, researchers at Cardiff University disputed the long-held belief that alkyl groups act as electron donors through this effect. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this effect, whose positive and negative types are respectively caused by electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups. ANSWER: inductive effect [accept induction; prompt on +I or -I] [10m] While electron-donating groups promote substitution at the ortho and para positions, electron-withdrawing groups direct substitution at this benzene position, which is separated from the group by one carbon in the ring. ANSWER: meta position [or 3-position; accept meta-directors] [10e] These elements are unusually ortho/para directors while also acting as electron-withdrawing groups. This group of elements includes chlorine. ANSWER: halogens [or Group 17] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~25893~ <Editor: June Yin>

18. A Chinese region often described by this English word is the setting of Shuang Xuetao's ("sh'WANG sh'WAY-tao's") novel Moses on the Plain, emblematic of the "Dongbei renaissance." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this word that also describes a "belt" of former industrial powerhouses such as Flint, Michigan and Gary, Indiana. ANSWER: rust [accept rust belt] [10m] Germany's rust belt is sometimes said to be in a coal and steel producing region that is named for this river that flows through Kettwig, Witten, and Arnsberg. ANSWER: Ruhr River [accept Ruhr Valley] [10h] This city's Rust Belt suburb of Elizabeth was once home to a factory making Holden cars. This city is north of the Fleurieu Peninsula and is named for the wife of Britain's King William IV. ANSWER: Adelaide, Australia <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~25324~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

19. Identify the following about the history of measuring years, for 10 points each. [10e] A calendar introduced by a pope of this name in 1582 better spaced out leap years to improve on the earlier Julian calendar. ANSWER: Gregory [or Gregorius; or Gregorio; or Gregory XIII; or Ugo Boncompagni; accept Gregorian calendar] [10m] Varro Reatinus is credited with formalizing the Roman system for counting years, which names the years for the holders of this office. The Praetor urbanus held power when the holders of this office were away. ANSWER: Roman consuls [10h] The minyan shəṭarot ("meen‑YAHN shuh‑tah‑ROHT") dating system used by Yemenite Jews is based on this ruler's reconquest of Babylon. In the contemporary dating system, this ruler was assassinated by Ptolemy Ceraunus in 281 BCE. ANSWER: Seleucus I Nicator [or Seleucus the Victorious; or Seleucus Nicator; or Séleukos Nikátōr; prompt on Seleucus] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25649~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. A 2023 play adapts this character as Alvita, who recalls her five marriages while telling stories at a pub. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this character who tears pages out of the book Valerie and Theofraste. This woman tells a story about King Midas' asses' ears, and goes deaf in one ear after her husband hits her. ANSWER: the Wife of Bath [or Alison; accept The Wife of Willesden] [10h] In Zadie Smith's The Wife of Willesden, Alvita was born in this country, and she sets the Wife of Bath’s tale there. Josey Wales fails to kill "the Singer" in this country in the 2015-Booker winning novel A Brief History of Seven Killings. ANSWER: Jamaica (Marlon James' A Brief History of Seven Killings is about the attempted assassination of Bob Marley.) [10e] Smith described turning "Alyson from Bath into Alvita from Willesden" while maintaining the "colloquial flow" of this author's The Canterbury Tales. ANSWER: Geoffrey Chaucer <Kevin Wang, Literature - British - Other> ~24776~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

21. The namesake of this process further adapted it to produce zirconium. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this process in which a certain element's tetrachloride is reduced by liquid magnesium to yield a pure metal. It supplanted the earlier Hunter process. ANSWER: Kroll process [10m] The Kroll process is used to produce this transition metal, whose dioxide is a white pigment commonly used in mineral sunscreens along with zinc oxide. ANSWER: titanium [or Ti; accept titanium dioxide] [10e] The Kroll process produced so pure titanium that it famously had a high value for this property, which corresponds to the ease of drawing it out into a wire. Metals can undergo either brittle fracture or a type of fracture named for this property. ANSWER: ductility [or being ductile; accept ductile fracture or failure] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Chemistry> ~25792~ <Editor: June Yin>

1. DTT reduces these bonds by forming a six-membered ring. A primary cellular use of selenium is by enzymes that break these bonds like GPx. These bonds form when the antioxidant glutathione is oxidized in the cytoplasm. Beta-mercaptoethanol breaks these bonds before SDS-PAGE ("S-D-S page") and was used to break them in Anfinsen's experiment. The enzyme (*) PDI in the endoplasmic reticulum rearranges these bonds, which hold together the light and heavy chains of antibodies. Irreversible denaturation occurs when these covalent bonds are broken. These covalent bonds, which are formed by the thiol groups of two cysteines ("SIS-teenz"), stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins. For 10 points, name these covalent bonds that join two S atoms. ANSWER: disulfide bonds [or disulfide bridges; accept sulfur-sulfur covalent bonds or any answer describing two sulfur atoms being linked; accept S-S bonds or answers describing two S atoms being linked until "S" is read; prompt on answers only mentioning one sulfur or S; prompt on covalent bonds until read] <Rohan Kher, Science - Chemistry> ~30063~ <Editor: June Yin>

2. In a musical, one of this author's characters belts, "Oh my god, why am I standing here?" at the end of the climactic number "Edges of the World." One of this author's characters describes "your swagger and your bearing and the just right clothes you're wearing" in the musical number "Ring of Keys," by Jeanine Tesori and Lisa Kron. In one work, this Oberlin-educated author depicted the suicide of her closeted father, who owned a (*) funeral parlor. A graphic novel by this author was adapted into the 2013 musical Fun Home, in which she comes out as a lesbian to her parents. A film must include a conversation between two named female characters about something other than a man in order to pass, for 10 points, what author's namesake "test?” ANSWER: Alison Bechdel [accept Bechdel test] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~29751~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

3. One of these beings is swept away by a "Wave" near the harbour of Glandore after being put to sleep by Manannan's music in Colloquy of the Ancients. One object became able to give deceptive power when Clíodhna ("CLEE-nuh"), a queen of these beings, instructed Cormac Laidir MacCarthy to kiss it. Les Lavandières ("lah-vah-dee-AIRS") of Breton legend are analogues of these mythical beings that can be seen washing bloody clothes of dying people. These creatures, which are associated with namesake mounds and the (*) Morrigan, may summon a death coach via the traditional funerary practice of keening. These fae are said to shatter glass in parts of Leinster. For 10 points, name these female beings from Irish myth known for their wailing. ANSWER: banshees [or bean sidhe or ban sith; accept bean-nighe; prompt on fairy women or fairies or fae until "fae" is read] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~29696~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

4. In this novel, a squirrel hangs on an unfinished house before one man shows another a picture of his dead wife. After a professor sings, two women in this novel remain in emotional "cocoons" for a fortnight. One of those women claims, "I like mysteries but I rather dislike muddles," after attending a bridge party in this novel. This novel ends with two men riding horses as the earth and the sky say, (*) "No, not yet." In this novel, Mrs. Moore repeatedly hears the echo "boum" and is sent home by her son, Ronny Heaslop. Cyril Fielding defends a man in this novel in a trial where a woman’s broken field-glasses are used as evidence. For 10 points, Adela Quested accuses Dr. Aziz of attempting to rape her in the Marabar Caves in what E. M. Forster novel? ANSWER: A Passage to India <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~30536~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

5. A member of this family boasts of her friendship with Saddam Hussein in Lauren Greenfield's documentary The Kingmaker. In 1994, a ruling that cited the 1789 Alien Tort Claims Act ordered this family to pay $1.2 billion in damages. Adnan Khashoggi helped a member of this family buy Manhattan's Crown Building. A member of this family grabbed diamonds for her exile in Hawaii after being overthrown. This family's patriarch was (*) forced out of the country after nuns stopped his troops from firing on demonstrators in the People Power Revolution. A museum in Marikina contains thousands of shoes owned by a member of this family nicknamed the "Iron Butterfly." For 10 points, name this family whose patriarch, Ferdinand, ruled the Philippines. ANSWER: Marcos [or Ferdinand Marcos; or Imelda Marcos; or Imelda Remedios Visitación Trinidad Romuáldez] <Michael Bentley, History - World - Asian> ~27129~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: cello (The first clue refers to Boccherini's Ninth Concerto.)
Text: 6. A Classical-period concerto for this instrument in B-flat major only barely resembles its arrangement in a late-Romantic style by Friedrich Grützmacher. In 1961, Oldřich Pulkert rediscovered Haydn's early C major concerto for this instrument. This is the higher instrument that plays recitative-like passages between quotations of prior movements in the finale of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. The string quintet (*) Night Music of the Streets of Madrid and a "Celebrated Minuet" were written by this instrument's virtuoso Luigi Boccherini ("boh-keh-REE-nee"). A prelude in G major begins the first of J. S. Bach's six suites for this instrument, which were popularized by Pablo Casals. For 10 points, name this instrument played by Yo-Yo Ma. ANSWER: cello [or violoncello] (The first clue refers to Boccherini's Ninth Concerto.) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Classical> ~29771~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

7. Jack Wisdom's 1982 doctoral thesis hypothesized that a pattern in the distribution of these objects was caused by Arnol'd diffusion. A Russian-Polish railroad engineer pioneered work on a thermal force exerted on these objects that was added to models in CNEOS's Sentry-II software. OSIRIS-REx measured aspects of the Yarkovsky effect on one of these objects, which comprise the Hilda group. MMRs of (*) 3-to-1 and 5-to-2 correspond, respectively, to the semi-major axes 2.5 and 2.82 AU of the largest Kirkwood gaps in the distribution of these objects, which are exemplified by the dwarf planet Ceres. For 10 points, name these astronomical objects that appear between Mars and Jupiter in a namesake "belt." ANSWER: asteroids [accept meteoroids or near-Earth asteroids; accept answers describing objects in the main asteroid belt; prompt on NEAs] <David Bass, Science - Other Science> ~30848~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. One of these things found in Rabivere, Estonia, in 1936 was disposed of before it could be properly studied. Alfred Dieck fabricated evidence of these things, which provide evidence of the Suebian knot. A 1969 book by P.V. Glob summarized research on these specimens, including ones found in Elling and Tollund. These specimens are (*) preserved by the antibacterial properties of sphagnum. These usually Iron-Age specimens frequently exhibit signs of violent deaths, which has fueled speculation about ritual sacrifice among Germanic peoples. These specimens' bones are usually dissolved, leaving behind darkened soft tissue. For 10 points, name these human remains found buried beneath layers of peat. ANSWER: bog bodies [accept bog skeletons or bog mummies or bog people; accept singular forms such as bog body; accept natural mummies; prompt on mummies; prompt on dead bodies or preserved bodies or skeletons or mummies or people or remains by asking "in what locations were they found?"] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Anthropology> ~30857~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

9. A postwar housing crisis in this city was partly caused by the 1944 Abercrombie Plan proscribing an outer Green Belt. Property prices in this most populous city in its country increased following a scheme introduced in the 1980s called Right to Buy. This city's Brutalist Trellick Tower was built as part of a broader council house project advocated for by Aneurin (*) Bevan ("uh-NYE-rin BEV-in"). In 2017, a building in this city with an aluminum cladding manufactured by Arconic caught fire, killing 70 people in the Grenfell Tower disaster. Two suffragette attacks in this city targeted its St. Martin-in-the-Fields Church, as well as St. Paul's Cathedral. For 10 points, name this capital city where many houses were destroyed during The Blitz. ANSWER: London <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1900+> ~29702~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: State of Palestine (The poem from the first line is "Mawtini" by Ibrahim Tuqan and was adopted as the National Anthem of Iraq.)
Text: 10. In a poem adopted as the national anthem of a different country, the "Poet of" this country declared both "the sword and the pen" as "our symbols." A woman from this country describes how she misses "the smell of coffee" in her late poem "Longing Inspired by the Law of Gravity." The speaker declares, "You killed me…and I forgot, like you, to die" while within the "ancient walls" of a city in this country. It's not Lebanon, but a poet from this country reflected on the siege of Beirut in the prose poem (*) Memory for Forgetfulness. A poet from this country declares to "beware, beware of my hunger" in the poem "Identity Card." For 10 points, name this country home to the literary Tuqan family and Mahmoud Darwish. ANSWER: State of Palestine [or Dawlat Filastin; prompt on Israel] (The poem from the first line is "Mawtini" by Ibrahim Tuqan and was adopted as the National Anthem of Iraq.) <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30790~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

11. A text named for this figure is the earlier of two with sections preserved in the Birmingham manuscript. It’s not Moses, but this child of Imran may have originated the practice of ruku after being told to "bow down in prayer with those who bow down." This figure receives nourishment after a long journey when God creates a river and (*) dates fall from a shaken palm tree. A surah named for this figure features an opening verse containing five "mysterious letters" and describes Abraham leaving behind his family's idolatry. Jibreel announced the pregnancy of this “greatest woman,” the only woman referred to by name in the Quran. For 10 points, name this mother of the prophet Isa, the Arabic equivalent of Jesus. ANSWER: Maryam [or Mary; accept the Virgin Mary; accept Surah Maryam] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Islam> ~31049~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: Mona Lisa (Peruggia stole the Mona Lisa.)
Text: 12. The titles of this painting and Manet's Olympia are written on a black background in Jean-Michel Basquiat's painting Crown Hotel. An artist wrote an analysis of "attacks" of this painting after being photographed as its subject by Philippe Halsman. Prior to a 1963 tour of this painting in the US, Fernando Botero created a parody of its subject at (*) "Age Twelve." Nationalist beliefs about this painting motivated Vincenzo Peruggia. A "desecration" of this painting with a goatee and mustache is adorned with the letters "LHOOQ" and is by Marcel Duchamp. As of January 2025, this painting will be moved out of the Salle des Etáts due to its popularity. For 10 points, name this Leonardo da Vinci portrait of a smiling woman. ANSWER: Mona Lisa [or La Gioconda; or La Joconde; accept Mona Lisa, Age Twelve or Self Portrait Mona Lisa or Crown Hotel (Mona Lisa Black Background)] (Peruggia stole the Mona Lisa.) <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - 1945+> ~30593~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

13. Description acceptable. A glass device to aid in providing this service was popularized by HMS Beagle captain Robert FitzRoy. It's not astronomy, but a federal agency for this service led by Adolphus Greely and once part of the Army Signal Corps used human computers to crunch data. James Stagg is often credited for "saving D-Day" by providing this service. Eugenicist Francis Galton developed the first synoptic maps for this service. Vanguard 2 was the first (*) satellite to provide data for this service. A scale that provided data for this service was developed by Francis Beaufort. In 2017, a federal agency offering this service provided warnings to Texans about Harvey. For 10 points, name this service provided via NEXRAD Doppler radar systems. ANSWER: weather prediction [or weather forecasting; or meteorology; or weather reports; or weather warnings; accept clear knowledge equivalents for predicting the weather; prompt on wind prediction or hurricane prediction or precipitation prediction by asking "what is the more general service?"] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30124~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. Estimates obtained by observing these particles are reported with distinct values for their "inverted" and "normal" orderings. Stars can cool via the creation of these particles by direct Urca processes. A vector written in these particles' mass eigenbasis is left-multiplied by the PMNS matrix. A right-handed class of these particles that only interacts via gravity is a dark matter candidate. These particles have been observed by (*) Super-Kamiokande observatory and an underground tank containing cadmium chloride. These particles are emitted alongside positrons in beta-plus decay. These particles oscillate between electron, muon, and tau flavors. For 10 points, name these particles whose name means "little neutron." ANSWER: neutrinos [accept sterile neutrinos] (Normal ordering and inverted ordering are the two ways of representing the neutrino mass hierarchy.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~30014~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. In a work by this author, a woman imagines a friend saying, "What pretensions, Madame!" after noting that a "part of her life" need not "possess her, body and soul." That woman in a work by this author hears a dog barking, the spurs of a cavalry officer, and bees humming while standing "naked under the sky." In a story by this author, a woman whispers "Body and soul free!" before dying of "the (*) joy that kills" after learning her husband is alive. A work by this author of "The Story of an Hour" ends with a woman reminiscing about Mademoiselle Reisz and her lover Robert's farewell letter. Edna Pontellier drowns herself in the Gulf of Mexico in a novella by this author. For 10 points, name this author of The Awakening. ANSWER: Kate Chopin [or Katherine O'Flaherty] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Misc> ~31139~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

16. Nancy Naumburg photographed the construction of one of these projects, the largest single cause of silicosis in US history. The Raker Act approved one of these projects first proposed by James D. Phelan. In 1947, Congress restored Ray Lyman Wilbur's original name for one of these projects, which was the Bureau of Reclamation's first major project. To criticize a rival, Harold (*) Ickes protested the name of one of these projects. Michael O'Shaughnessy oversaw one of these projects in the Hetch Hetchy valley that was opposed by the Sierra Club. Boulder City was founded while building a Depression-era one of these projects named for Herbert Hoover. For 10 points, name these barriers built on rivers to generate electricity. ANSWER: dams [accept Hoover Dam; accept O'Shaughnessy Dam; prompt on hydroelectric plants or power plants or power stations; prompt on water project or artificial lakes; prompt on tunnels by asking "for what larger project?"] <Sean Farrell, History - American - 1865-1945> ~29706~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

17. In a 2022 historical novel in this language, a tubercular ("t'yoo-BURK-yoo-lur") engineering student drinks hallucinogenic alcohol while talking with people at a health resort. The Empusium ("em-POO-zee-um") is in this language, as is a novel in which a lieutenant is separated from his love Helena during an uprising. In a novel in this modern language, the author Petronius helps the protagonist look for a Christian princess. A historical (*) "Trilogy" in this language includes With Fire and Sword. Though its title is a Latin reference to St. Peter, this language was used for a novel about Lygia's ("lih-JEE-uh's") love for the Roman officer Marcus Vinicius ("vih-NISS-ee-uss"), Quo Vadis. For 10 points, name this language used by Olga Tokarczuk ("toh-CAR-chuck") and Henryk Sienkiewicz ("shen-K'YAY-vitch"). ANSWER: Polish [or Polski] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~30989~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

18. This quantity is increased by the synthetic peptide Giapreza. SARS-CoV-2 enters cells by binding its spike protein to an enzyme whose main function is to decrease this quantity. A system named for aldosterone production increases this quantity with renin. A water-regulating molecule named for its arginine residue and its control over this quantity is also known as the (*) antidiuretic hormone. This quantity is decreased by nitric oxide and increased by angiotensin. High measurements of this quantity with a sphygmomanometer ("s'fig-moh-muh-NOM-eh-ter") can motivate the prescription of vasodilators. This quantity is reported as a ratio of its "systolic" and "diastolic" values. For 10 points, name this quantity that is increased in hypertension. ANSWER: blood pressure [accept mean arterial pressure or systemic arterial pressure or systolic pressure or diastolic pressure; prompt on pressure] (SARS-CoV-2 binds to ACE2.) <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Biology> ~30232~ <Editor: David Bass>

19. The Ai-Petri mountains border this region's Grand Canyon as well as a resort city home to the Massandra Palace. A port on the southwestern Heracles Peninsula in this region contains a monument to the storming of its Mount Sapun. This land region is separated from the mainland to its north by the hypersaline Syvash Sea. This region's town of Livadiya has a "Great Three" monument depicting FDR. Greeks established the colony of (*) Chersonesos Taurica in this region. Since 2022, a new bridge to this region spanning the Kerch Strait has been repeatedly attacked. This region is home to the resort city of Yalta and the Black Sea port of Sevastopol. For 10 points, name this Ukrainian peninsula now controlled by Russia. ANSWER: Crimean Peninsula [or Crimea; or Autonomous Republic of Crimea; accept Crimean Mountains or Yayla Mountains; accept Tauric Peninsula or Tauris before "Taurica" is read; prompt on Southern Ukraine or Russia; anti-prompt on Kerch Peninsula by asking "can you be less specific?"] <Michael Bentley, Geography - Europe> ~30380~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. Pope Paul VI's love of this author is supposedly why England is permitted to use the Tridentine Mass. This author met archaeologist and future husband Max Mallowan on a dig with Leonard Woolley. An earlier husband may have caused this author to enter a fugue state and disappear for 11 days in 1926. Tony Marston chokes to death early in a novel by this author whose original (*) racist title came from a minstrel song. This author's radio play Three Blind Mice was adapted for the West End and ran continuously from 1952 to 2020. This author of The Mousetrap provided the source material for Kenneth Branagh ("brah-naw") films such as Death on the Nile. For 10 points, name this mystery author of Murder on the Orient Express. ANSWER: Agatha Christie [or Dame Agatha Mary Clarissa Christie; or Mary Westmacott; or Agatha Miller; accept Lady Mallowan until "Mallowan" is mentioned] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29975~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

21. In opposition to this man's policies, Eduard Lasker led a faction simply known as the Secession that later merged with the radical Free-Minded Party. This leader invoked a monarch's power to fill a legal "gap" per the so-called Lücken theory. After dropping his Anti-Socialist Laws to ally with the Centre Party, this leader enacted so-called State Socialism, which created the first modern (*) welfare state. Rudolf Virchow coined the name of one of this man's campaigns, which expelled Jesuits under the May Laws. This man justified greater military spending by arguing that "blood and iron" would decide history. For 10 points, what Prussian statesman became the first chancellor of a unified Germany? ANSWER: Otto von Bismarck [or Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck; or Otto, Prince of Bismarck, Count of Bismarck-Schönhausen, Duke of Lauenburg] <Cooper Roh, History - European - 1500-1900> ~29714~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower> NSC 2025 - Round 16 - Bonuses

1. Workers are hoisted via chairs to dust and clean a massive bronze statue of one of these figures during the annual ominugui ceremony at Tōdai-ji. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these religious figures whose statues often perform hand symbols called mudra. In China, one of these figures is often depicted laughing with a round belly. ANSWER: buddhas [or the Buddha; or Amitabha Buddha; or Amida Buddha; or Amita Buddha; or Amitāyus; accept Siddhartha or Siddhartha Gautama; accept the Maitreya Buddha or Laughing Buddha or Fat Buddha or Budai or Qieci] [10m] This valley housed two Buddhas, the "Eastern" and Western" ones, carved into sandstone cliffs. Those two Buddhas in this valley were blown up by the Taliban in 2001. ANSWER: Bamiyan [or Bamyan; or Bamian] [10h] Those Bamiyan Buddhas were stylistically inspired by this art style, which depicted bodhisattvas with mustaches and topknots. Buddhas from this style had large circular halos and robes inspired by statues of Apollo. ANSWER: Gandhara art [accept word forms such as Gandharan; prompt on Greco-Buddhist art; reject “Greek” or “Buddhist” alone] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~25246~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. Johnnie Cochran was criticized for comparing this person to Adolf Hitler in a speech in which he called him a "lying, perjuring, genocidal racist." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this LAPD detective whose exposed racism led his testimony to be heavily scrutinised in a 1995 trial. ANSWER: Mark Fuhrman [10e] The revelations of Fuhrman's racism contributed to the controversial acquittal of this former NFL star of the murder of his ex-wife Nicole Brown and her friend Ron Goldman. ANSWER: O.J. Simpson [or O.J. Simpson or Orenthal James Simpson] [10m] The evidence Fuhrman was alleged to have planted included a blood-spattered one of these objects. During the trial, Simpson's defense made a claim about one of these objects that ends, "you must acquit." ANSWER: gloves [accept mittens or mitts] <Jamie Burchett, History - American - 1945+> ~25952~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

3. In a novel in this genre, Abendsen uses the I Ching to write a subversive novel, The Grasshopper Lies Heavy. For 10 points each: [10h] Name the genre of that aforementioned novel, in which Frank Frink sells antiques. Characters theorize about the kidnapping of Charles Lindbergh's son in another novel in this genre.  ANSWER: alternate history [or alternative history; accept althist; accept answers indicating works set in an alternate reality or alternative reality; accept uchronia; prompt on counterfactual; prompt on speculative fiction; prompt on historical fiction; prompt on science fiction or sci-fi or SF or speculative fiction; prompt on dystopia; prompt on fiction about a parallel universe or world or reality] [10m] The Man in the High Castle and The Plot Against America are alternate history novels by authors with this first name, the latter of whom created the recurring character Nathan Zuckerman. ANSWER: Philip [accept Philip K. Dick or Philip Roth; accept Phil] [10e] Possibly the first English alternate history is a story by this author about a man who claims to know Napoleon, “P’s Correspondence.” Characters watch a meteor from a scaffold in this author’s The Scarlet Letter. ANSWER: Nathaniel Hawthorne <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~24684~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

4. This book argues that human freedom is rooted in natality, or the fact that we appear in the world by birth, which thus creates new possibilities. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this Hannah Arendt book that defines work, labor, and activity as parts of the vita activa, which is contrasted with the vita contemplativa. ANSWER: The Human Condition [10m] A 2012 paper by Jennifer Shaw argues that studies of pregnancy were central to the development of the "medical gaze" described in this author's book The Birth of the Clinic. ANSWER: Michel Foucault [or Paul-Michel Foucault] [10e] This existentialist philosopher and lover of Jean-Paul Sartre claimed "one is not born, but rather becomes, a woman" in the second volume of her book The Second Sex. ANSWER: Simone de Beauvoir [or Simone Lucie Ernestine Marie Bertrand de Beauvoir] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~24626~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

5. Count data output by this technique is normalized as TPM or FPKM. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this technique whose "single-cell" form yields data that can be processed via UMAP followed by clustering. This central technique of transcriptomics can identify differential expression. ANSWER: RNA sequencing [accept single-cell RNA sequencing or scRNA-seq; prompt on sequencing; reject "DNA sequencing"] [10e] RNA-seq is performed at this more coarse level of biological organization by the GTEx project. This broad category of structures, which compose organs, includes "muscle" and "epithelial." ANSWER: tissues [accept tissue-specific] [10h] Tissue-specific GTEx data can be used to call these genomic regions, which are distinct from GWAS hits. These regions are linearly correlated with continuous traits like gene expression. ANSWER: quantitative trait loci [or QTLs or expression quantitative trait loci or eQTLs; or quantitative trait locus; prompt on quantitative characters] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~25994~ <Editor: David Bass>

6. A poll tax prompted a thousand people of this ethnicity to flee to the Bud Dajo crater, where they subsisted on sweet potatoes. For 10 points each: [10h] Identify these predominantly Muslim people who were massacred by forces under Leonard Wood. ANSWER: Moros [or Bangsamoro; prompt on Filipinos] [10e] The Moro massacre was criticized by the American Anti-Imperialist League, whose vice presidents included this peace-loving industrialist. This man sold his namesake steel company to J. P. Morgan in 1901. ANSWER: Andrew Carnegie [10m] American troops bought improved weapons from this company because they needed more "stopping power" against "Juramentado" ("hoo‑rah‑men‑TAH‑doh") Moros. In 1847, the Texas Rangers bought revolvers from this pioneer of interchangeable parts. ANSWER: Colt [or Colt's Manufacturing Company; or Colt's Patent Firearms Manufacturing Company; or Patent Arms Manufacturing Company of Paterson, New Jersey, Colt's Patent; accept Samuel Colt] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25090~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. Mass marriages in this religion are known as "Blessing ceremonies." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this new religious movement whose practitioners are sometimes called "Moonies" after its founder, Sun Myung Moon. ANSWER: Unification Church [or Unificationism or Unificationists; accept Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity or HSA-UWC; accept Family Federation for World Peace and Unification or FFWPU] [10e] The Unification Church believes in Apokatastasis ("app-oh-kuh-TASS-tuh-sis"), the principle that everyone will eventually undergo this process. This process is sometimes defined as "being rescued by God from the consequences of our wrongdoing" and names an "army" founded by Catherine and William Booth. ANSWER: salvation [accept Salvation Army] [10h] Chung Hwa Pak's exposé of sexual abuse in the Unification Church was titled for this number of Marys. This is the lesser of two numbers of Ages of the World defined by Augustine of Hippo. ANSWER: six [accept Six Ages of the World or the Tragedy of the Six Marys] <Michael Bentley, RMP - Christian Practice> ~25061~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

8. These objects, which are the typical target of applications of Wick's theorem, are depicted as a gray cat in Griffiths' Introduction to Quantum Mechanics. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these paired objects that can be written as L-sub-x plus-or-minus i-L-sub-y for angular momentum. These objects can be denoted a and a-dagger. ANSWER: ladder operators [accept raising AND lowering operators; or creation AND annihilation operators] [10m] Ladder operators are used to find the energy eigenstates of this system, whose nth energy level equals h-bar omega times n plus one-half. ANSWER: quantum harmonic oscillator [or QHO; prompt on harmonic oscillator or HO] [10e] Wick's theorem describes contraction, which is a variation of an operation that shares its name with this property.
