This mathematical property holds for operators a and b when ab equals ba. ANSWER: commutativity [or commutes; accept commutator] <Steven Yuan, Science - Physics> ~25984~ <Editor: David Bass>

9. Siri von Essen was the director of the Scandinavian Experimental Theater, which she co-founded with this author. For 10 points each: [10e] Von Essen originated the title role of what Swedish author's play Miss Julie? ANSWER: August ("OH-goost") Strindberg [or Johan August Strindberg] [10m] With August Falck, Strindberg created the Intima Theater, which used this type of raised stage with a name from the Greek for "before the stage." The audience looks towards this type of stage's namesake "arch." ANSWER: proscenium ("pro-SEE-nee-um") stage [accept proscenium arch] [10h] Falck and Strindberg fell out when the Intima Theater staged its only non-Strindberg play, which was this author's The Intruder. This Belgian symbolist wrote the marionette play Interior and The Blue Bird. ANSWER: Maurice Maeterlinck ("moh-REES MAY-tuh-link") [or Maurice Polydore Marie Bernard Maeterlinck] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Drama> ~25981~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

10. A 2021 paper by Ahmad et al found that climate-related outages in this industry have increased by a factor of eight since the 1990s. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this industry reliant on coolants such as borated water. New entrants into this industry are often designed to be dry cooled or adhere to "island mode." ANSWER: nuclear power [or nuclear energy; or fission industry; or atomic energy industry; prompt on power industry or energy industry or electrical industry] [10e] In 2024, this company rebooted a Three Mile Island nuclear power plant to meet the energy demands for its AI offerings such as Copilot for Excel. ANSWER: Microsoft [10h] Bill Gates is an investor in TerraPower, a maker of these types of nuclear power plants, which are under 300 megawatt in capacity and have some parts that are factory assembled. ANSWER: small modular nuclear reactors [prompt on SMRs or small reactors] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~24926~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

11. A bird is described as a "[this word]-dawn-drawn Falcon" in "The Windhover." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this word. The poem "Pied Beauty" lists "skies of couple-colour as a brinded cow" and "all things counter, original, spare, strange" after stating, "Glory be to God for" things described by this word. ANSWER: dapple [or dappled] [10m] This poet of "The Windhover" and "Pied Beauty" wrote "I kiss my hand...to the dappled-with-damson west" in "The Wreck of the Deutschland." ANSWER: Gerard Manley Hopkins [10e] Hopkins' phrase "dapple-dawn-drawn Falcon" exemplifies his "sprung rhythm," where this property is placed on a foot's first syllable. The second syllable of an iamb, but not the first, has this property. ANSWER: stressed [accept emphasized; accept lengthened or descriptions of making the syllable longer; accept accented] <Rohan Kher, Literature - British - Poetry> ~24935~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

12. Finite groups with this property compose the 26 sporadic groups, the largest of which is the monster group. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this property of groups that contain no non-trivial normal subgroups. The smallest non-Abelian group with this property is A5. ANSWER: simple [10m] McKay observed monstrous moonshine by connecting the monster group to this mathematician's j-invariant. This namesake of a "four-group" also names a non-orientable surface that is self-intersecting when embedded in 3D space. ANSWER: Felix Klein [accept Klein bottle] [10e] The fundamental polygon of the Klein bottle is this shape, whose symmetries compose the group D2. Matrices with equal numbers of rows and columns have this shape. ANSWER: square (D2 is isomorphic to the Klein four-group.) <Steven Yuan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25805~ <Editor: David Bass>

13. Original language term required. Glámr, a prominent antagonist in Grettis saga, is often stated to be one of these beings. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these undead beings from Norse mythology who are portrayed as zombies in modern depictions. ANSWER: draugrs [or aptrganga; or aptrgangr; or haugbui] [10e] Draugrs appear throughout the sagas written in what is now this country. The Prose Edda was compiled by Snorri Sturluson, a scholar from this modern-day country. ANSWER: Iceland [or Ísland or Icelandic Commonwealth or Icelandic Free State] [10m] Thrainn is a draugr from Hrómundar saga Gripssonar, who is identified by this term "of Valland." This term refers to warriors who entered a furious, trance-like state in battle, often by wearing wolf or bear skins. ANSWER: berserker [accept Berserker of Valland; accept going berserk] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~25821~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

14. The US "Marines' Hymn" is based on the "Gendarmes' ("zhan-DARMS") Duet" from this composer's operetta Geneviève ("zhan-v'YEV") de Brabant. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this French composer of Orpheus in the Underworld, whose "Infernal Galop" is a popular can-can tune. ANSWER: Jacques Offenbach [or Jacob Offenbach] [10m] In Offenbach's operetta The Grand Duchess of Gérolstein, the title character gives Fritz one of these objects near the end of Act I. Trombone glissandi punctuate a xylophone solo in a dance from the Armenian ballet Gayane ("ga-ya-NEH") titled for these objects. ANSWER: sabres [accept "Voici le sabre de mon père"; accept "Sabre Dance"; prompt on swords] [10h] This Austrian composer modeled his operettas, like Die schöne Galathée ("dee SHUR-nuh GAH-lah-tay"), on those of Offenbach. He is best known for the overture to his operetta Light Cavalry. ANSWER: Franz von Suppé [or Francesco Ezechiele Ermenegildo de Suppé] <Cooper Roh, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~24767~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

15. Leymah Gbowee founded a women-led Mass Action for Peace in this country that united Christians and Muslims to end a 2003 civil war. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this country where Charles Taylor overthrew Samuel Doe. Indigenous groups overthrew the American-descended True Whig Party in this country. ANSWER: Liberia [or Republic of Liberia] [10h] The Amujae Initiative for female leadership was founded by this Liberian president, who put Taylor on trial in the Hague. This person was the first democratically elected female head of state in Africa. ANSWER: Ellen Johnson Sirleaf [10e] Sirleaf's leadership earned her this nickname shared by Eugenia Charles in Dominica. This two-word nickname referred to Margaret Thatcher's stalwart nature. ANSWER: Iron Lady [accept the Iron Lady of Africa or Iron Lady of the Caribbean] <Ganon Evans, History - World - African> ~25785~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

16. In the 1940s, Billboard magazine began using this phrase in place of "race music." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this phrase that the recording industry used as a catch-all label for secular music made by and marketed toward Black Americans. ANSWER: Rhythm and Blues [or R&B] [10e] The ASCAP composers' boycott and musicians' strike during World War II helped R&B supplant this genre as the dominant style of popular music. Benny Goodman was known as the "King" of this style. ANSWER: swing [accept "King of Swing"; prompt on jazz] [10m] Big Mama Thornton created a hit 1952 recording of this R&B song, though three years later, a white artist would record it as a rock-and-roll song with Freddie Bell’s lyrics like “You ain’t never caught a rabbit” and “Cryin’ all the time.”  ANSWER: “Hound Dog” (The artist was Elvis Presley.) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~26005~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

17. Yves Chauvin won one-third of the 2005 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work on these reactions. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these reactions that commonly use transition metal carbene catalysts. In these reactions, two olefins break and regenerate their double bonds, thus exchanging substituents. ANSWER: olefin metathesis ("muh-TAH-thuh-sis") [accept alkene metathesis] [10e] Most catalysts for olefin metathesis have this property. Unlike homogeneous catalysts, catalysts with this property are in a different phase than their reagents. ANSWER: heterogeneous [or heterogeneous catalysts] [10m] Catalysts for olefin metathesis are typically supported by this oxide. It doesn't contain silicon, but this oxide is often used as an abrasive or as a stationary phase in column chromatography. ANSWER: aluminum oxide [or aluminium oxide or Al2O3 or aluminum(III) oxide or alumina or aloxide or aloxite or alundum; prompt on "corundum" by asking "what is the compound?"] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~25894~ <Editor: June Yin>

Answer: imperial examinations "Kong Yiji" is by this Chinese author, who also criticized imperial China in The True Story of Ah-Q. ANSWER: Lu Xun Lu Xun satirizes traditional values by having Ah-Q fail to recite lines from a Chinese work in this genre. David Henry Hwang titled M. Butterfly after a work in this genre. ANSWER: opera
Text: 18. The tradition of composing poetry at these events was revived by the Qing dynasty in 1756 after it was abolished by the Yuan and Ming dynasties. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these events that were criticized in one short story as causing the title "Kong Yiji" to become a beggar and a thief. ANSWER: imperial examinations [or civil service examinations or kējǔ; prompt on exams or tests] [10m] "Kong Yiji" is by this Chinese author, who also criticized imperial China in The True Story of Ah-Q. ANSWER: Lu Xun [or Zhou Shuren] [10e] Lu Xun satirizes traditional values by having Ah-Q fail to recite lines from a Chinese work in this genre. David Henry Hwang titled M. Butterfly after a work in this genre. ANSWER: opera [accept Peking opera] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~26191~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

19. David Neumark and William Wascher have criticized a 1994 study of these policies, whose results they have failed to replicate. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these policies that Alan Krueger and David Card analyzed with a difference-in-differences approach comparing New Jersey and Pennsylvania unemployment rates. ANSWER: minimum wage laws [prompt on wage laws; prompt on living wage] [10e] Difference-in-differences estimation compares a treatment group with one of these groups. These groups may still experience a placebo effect. ANSWER: control group [10h] These variables, which satisfy the exclusion restriction, are often used in natural experiments. Krueger and Joshua Angrist used one of these exogenous variables to study the draft. ANSWER: instrumental variables [or IVs; accept instruments] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~25561~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

20. Dr. Maria Liston studied the skeletons of the Sacred Band of Thebes, who died in this battle. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this 338 BC battle in which Demosthenes led forces against Philip II of Macedon. Philip's victory in this battle against Athens and Thebes led to Macedonian hegemony over Greece. ANSWER: Battle of Chaeronea ("KYE-ruh-NEE-uh") [or Battle of Mount Haemus] [10h] This Greek historian from Chaeronea provides the most substantial account of the Sacred Band of Thebes. This man featured the sayings of Spartan women in his Moralia. ANSWER: Plutarch [or Ploútarchos; or Lucius Mestrius Plutarchus] [10e] An essay in Moralia criticizes this historian for prejudice. This author of The Histories is considered the "father of history." ANSWER: Herodotus <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~25152~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

21. While walking in one of these places, a group suddenly becomes unable to talk in the novel The Castle of Crossed Destinies. For 10 points each: [10h] In a novel from the Our Ancestors trilogy, the 12-year-old baron Carlo elects to live his life in what sort of place? ANSWER: forests [or trees or woods; accept The Baron in the Trees] [10e] Those novels are by this Italian author, who imagined you, the Reader, reading about leaves falling from a gingko tree in a section of If on a winter's night a traveler. ANSWER: Italo Calvino [10m] After seeing a chessboard owned by Kublai Khan in this Calvino book, Marco Polo explains how a knot developed in one of the trees used to make it. This book describes journeying through trees to a place called Tamara. ANSWER: Invisible Cities [or Le città invisibili] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~25985~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

1. Description acceptable. The Council of Five Elders immediately ended one of these conflicts after taking power. Wagons called hwachas, which launched hundreds of rocket arrows, were mass-deployed during one of these conflicts. A side in one of these conflicts employed a semicircular formation dubbed the "crane wing." The first truce in one of these conflicts was negotiated by the (*) Ming dynasty and was ended by the continuing Chongyu War. Iron spikes covered the roofs of boats called "turtle ships" that were deployed in one of these conflicts. In one of these conflicts, Admiral Yi repelled forces sent by Toyotomi Hideyoshi. For 10 points, identify these two late 16th-century conflicts between an East Asian archipelago and a nearby peninsula. ANSWER: Japanese invasions of Korea [accept answers that describe a war between Korea and Japan; accept Imjin War; accept Chongyu War until read; prompt on Japanese invasions or invasions of Korea] <Lalit Maharjan, History - World - Asian> ~29650~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

2. Three joined upright cylinders perform this technique in a device invented by Hofmann. When run in reverse, regenerative fuel cells act as devices that perform this technique. Chlorine bubbles are produced as a byproduct of this technique in the Castner–Kellner process. This technique is performed on the output of the Bayer process in molten (*) cryolite ("CRY-oh-light") in the major industrial process to produce aluminum. Two laws named for Michael Faraday govern this technique and explain the mass deposited when plating metals. Performing this technique on water at an electrode produces hydrogen and oxygen gas. For 10 points, name this technique that splits molecules using an electrical current. ANSWER: electrolysis [accept electrolyzers; accept electrolysis of water; prompt on electrochemical reaction; prompt on water splitting until "water" is read] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~31022~ <Editor: June Yin>

3. A woman in this story complains about women being turned out of choirs for "whipper-snappers of boys" before a Black Gaiety tenor is praised. A man in this story asks why Trappist monks sleep in coffins. During a toast in this story, a man confuses women by calling them "the Three Graces," and watches his wife on the stairs. A man in this story is called a "West Briton" and criticized by (*) Miss Ivors for going abroad, and gives a speech at a party hosted by his aunts Kate and Julia. This story ends with a man looking out into the snow after his wife Gretta says "The Lass of Aughrim" reminds her of Michael Furey, a boy who died for her. For 10 points, what story about Gabriel Conroy is the last in James Joyce's Dubliners? ANSWER: "The Dead" <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~31137~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

4. In one essay, this thinker described adopting the "religion" but discarding the "morals" of G. E. Moore while studying at Cambridge. E. F. Schumacher's "Multilateral Clearing" paper influenced this thinker's "bancor" proposal at a 1944 conference. A chapter by this Bloomsbury Group member uses the Cartesian phrase "animal spirits" to describe irrational behavior and imagines rational judges who try to predict the winners of a (*) beauty contest. This thinker, who quipped that "in the long run, we are all dead," criticized the harshness of the Treaty of Versailles. For 10 points, name this economist who advocated deficit spending to combat recessions in The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money. ANSWER: John Maynard Keynes <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Economics> ~30577~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

Answer: television (The party was called Party to Protect the People from the NHK. Shari Redstone runs Paramount Global.)
Text: 5. A party "to protect people" from an organization that provides this service was founded by Japanese populist Takashi Tachibana. US companies offering this service have faced declining revenue pledged in "upfronts." A conglomerate run by Shari Redstone has been hurt by a decline in "linear" consumption of this service. In 2022, the UK froze increases in the mandatory (*) license fee required to receive this service. In 2025, an agency run by Brendan Carr received a petition to deregulate ownership rules for this service from conservative-leaning Sinclair. In 2021, AT&T wrote down 15 billion dollars after buying a company that provided this service via satellite. For 10 points, name this service whose "public" form in the US includes PBS. ANSWER: television [accept TV or cable television or satellite television or broadcast television; prompt on broadcasting or entertainment; prompt on local news by asking "in what medium?"; reject "internet" or "streaming"] (The party was called Party to Protect the People from the NHK. Shari Redstone runs Paramount Global.) <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~27546~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

6. A 1958 essay draws on an ancient philosopher's classification of these concepts by asking if their intellectual type has a "moral aspect." These concepts title a book that compares today’s "dark age" with a world where science is destroyed, by Alasdair MacIntyre. G. E. M. Anscombe's "Modern Moral Philosophy" helped spark the aretaic turn, which repopularized an ethical theory based on these concepts often contrasted with both (*) deontology and consequentialism. Pursuing these concepts results in a flourishing called eudaimonia, according to a book that views them as the "golden mean" between two negative extremes. For 10 points, Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics argues for the pursuit of what opposites of vices? ANSWER: virtues [accept arete until "aretaic" is read; accept After Virtue] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~30191~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

7. Widespread smuggling of this good in Britain was reduced via the 1784 Commutation Act. A company that made its fortune selling this good built Art Deco Corner Houses and is called J. Lyons and Co. Queen Catherine of Braganza popularized the non-medicinal use of this good in England. Smuggler Robert Fortune broke an Asian monopoly on this good, which became a major industry in the (*) Assam region of India. A 1773 law granting the British East India Company a monopoly to sell this good in North America led to the Coercive Acts. The Duchess of Belford popularized an afternoon ritual named for this good. For 10 points, the Sons of Liberty threw thousands of chests full of what good into Boston Harbor in 1773? ANSWER: tea [accept black tea or green tea or tea leaves] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30518~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

8. A print of a photograph of this location by Charles Leander Weed was used to advertise a hotel owned by James Mason Hutchings. Carleton Watkins created "photographic views" of this location with a "mammoth plate" camera. It's not in New Mexico, but a photograph taken in this location, subtitled "Winter, Sunrise," was created by an artist who also photographed a different (*) landmark in this location beside a waxing gibbous moon. The Zone System was partly inspired by a photograph of a granite monolith in this location that was used to promote conservation efforts by the Sierra Club. For 10 points, name this national park where Ansel Adams took many photographs of Half Dome. ANSWER: Yosemite National Park [accept Yosemite Valley or Yosemite Falls; prompt on Sierra Nevada; prompt on California or CA; prompt on Half Dome or El Capitan by asking "what national park is that located in?"] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Photography> ~30617~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

9. A murderer, a priest, and an archaeologist search for ancient American artifacts in this author's collaborative novel Caverns, written by his creative writing class. A speech in a novel by this author divides people into "rabbits" and "wolves" and is given by Harding. In a novel by this author, the motto "never give an inch!" is used by the patriarch Henry Stamper as he breaks a strike to supply a (*) mill with logs. A man organizes an unauthorized fishing trip attended by Billy Bibbit and Chief Bromden in a novel by this author of Sometimes a Great Notion. For 10 points, name this author who wrote about Randle McMurphy rebelling against Nurse Ratched in a mental hospital in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. ANSWER: Ken Kesey [or Ken Elton Kesey] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Misc> ~30535~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

10. The memory required by these data structures can be reduced by storing only the bitwise XOR of two opposite values. Hitotumata and Noshita introduced a technique to manipulate these structures that Donald Knuth ("kuh-NOOTH") popularized as "dancing." In hash tables, separate chaining typically uses these structures to store colliding keys. The roots of a (*) Fibonacci heap are placed into a "circular" one of these structures. These structures feature constant-time insertion without shifting and can be reversed by iterating over "current," "previous," and "next" values for the pointers that connect their nodes either "singly" or "doubly." For 10 points, name these linear data structures that are often conflated with arrays. ANSWER: linked lists [accept singly linked lists or doubly linked lists; prompt on lists; prompt on dancing links] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~30619~ <Editor: David Bass>

11. A novella by this author describes a flawed entanglement with the married Beatriz and a 72-year-old Polish concert pianist. That novella by this author was published alongside short stories centered on a character who wrote a reimagining of Ulysses titled The House on Eccles Street. A novel by this author ends with its main character giving a stray dog to Bev Shaw to (*) euthanize. A lecturer in this author's The Lives of Animals titles a later novel in which that character travels around giving lectures as a celebrated 66-year-old writer. An affair with the student Melanie Isaacs causes David Lurie to be fired in a novel by this author. For 10 points, name this South African novelist who wrote Elizabeth Costello and Disgrace. ANSWER: J. M. Coetzee [or James Maxwell Coetzee] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~31048~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

12. A work named for these objects is the topic of essays in a "kaleidoscope" by Gene Reeves, who wrote a modern translation of it. Tara rose out of one of these objects created from Avalokiteshvara's tears. A mantra and common metaphor refers to a "jewel in [one of these objects]." Toy cars that lure children out of a burning house illustrate (*) skillful means in a text named for these objects. Seven of these objects appeared after the first steps of a religious leader, ten months after Maya dreamt of an elephant holding one of these objects entering her side. Mahakashyapa was immediately enlightened after a sermon in which the Buddha smiled and held up, for 10 points, what flower that names a central Mahayana sutra? ANSWER: lotuses [or lotus flowers; accept white lotus or pundarika; accept jewel in the lotus; accept padma or Om Mani Padme Hum; accept Lotus Sutra or A Buddhist Kaleidoscope: Essays on the Lotus Sutra; prompt on flowers or plants until "flower" is read] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Buddhism> ~31047~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

13. Cupid sits astride a dolphin in one of many works in this medium in Fishbourne, England. A work in this medium in Huqoq ("hoo-COKE") unusually depicts Samson tying torches to foxes' tails. Scantily clad figures play sports in a work in this medium nicknamed for its "bikini girls." A military leader wears a breastplate emblazoned with Medusa's head in a depiction of the Battle of (*) Issus in this medium in the House of the Faun. A halo surrounds Justinian I in one of many works in this medium that decorate Ravenna's Basilica of San Vitale. Gold leaf embellishes an image of Mary and Jesus in this medium in the Hagia Sophia's apse, created using glass tesserae. For 10 points, works in what medium are created by combining tiles? ANSWER: mosaics [prompt on glass or tesserae or tiles until each are respectively read] <Jamie Burchett, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~30804~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

14. The MAN2A1 gene encodes an enzyme that acts on these molecules, after which they become Endo H-resistant. The antibiotic tunicamycin inhibits the transfer of one of these molecules. Tree-like diagrams use colored polygons to represent examples of these molecules like the acid NANA and the amide derivative GlcNAc ("GLIK-NAK"), which composes (*) chitin. Different alleles of the ABO gene cause erythrocytes to present different types of these molecules, giving rise to ABO blood types. A post-translational modification that adds these molecules to proteins has "N-linked" and "O-linked" types that respectively occur in the ER and the Golgi. For 10 points, name these molecules named with the suffix "ose," like glucose. ANSWER: sugars [accept carbohydrates or carbs or monosaccharides or disaccharides or oligosaccharides or polysaccharides or glycans; prompt on glycoproteins or glycopeptides or proteoglycans by asking "what  constituent molecules?"; prompt on antigens] <Rohan Kher, Science - Biology> ~29645~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. A failed scheme to provide 32,000 mirrors to these people spurred a young Johannes Gutenberg to focus his efforts on the printing press. A "great" event named for German examples of these people was led by Gunther of Bamberg in 1064. In the Middle Ages, these people donned fertility badges and scallop shells. Book V of the Codex Calixtinus instructed these people on what to do in Galicia. The artist Cimabue ("chee-MAH-boo-ay") became one of these people to (*) participate in the 1299 Jubilee. These people might follow the Way of Saint James. Protecting these people from harassment in the Levant was a frequent justification for new crusades. For 10 points, name these people who travel to places like Rome or Jerusalem for religious purposes. ANSWER: religious pilgrims [prompt on Christians or Catholics] <Michael Bentley, History - European - Middle Ages> ~27435~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: length (The lead-in describes the Debye length.)
Text: 16. Assuming equal ion temperature, the square of a form of this quantity is proportional to T over n-q-squared. TIRF·M exploits the low value of this quantity achieved by the evanescent wave. Fritz and Heinz London name a form of this quantity that describes magnetic fields in superconductors. A small value for this quantity, denoted delta, describes an exponential decay in alternating current density due to eddies in the (*) skin effect. The decrease in electric field strength with this quantity due to screening is described by two forms of this quantity named for Thomas and Fermi and for Debye. This quantity is squared in the denominator of Coulomb's law. For 10 points, name this quantity measured in microns or meters. ANSWER: length [accept distance or depth or penetration depth or radius; accept Debye length or Debye radius or Debye–Hückel screening length or London penetration depth or skin depth or Thomas–Fermi length; prompt on r or lambda-sub-D] (The lead-in describes the Debye length.) <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~31034~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. Before Akhenaten's own attempt, a long-lived Hyksos ruler named for this figure may have practiced a form of monotheism centered around Set. In Hour 10 of the Book of Gates, this figure is held down with nets. The Book of Overthrowing [this figure] includes spells that spit on and trample on this figure with the left foot. In some traditions, this figure sprang from the (*) spit of the goddess Neith. A painting in Deir el-Medina depicts this figure being attacked by his rival in the form of a cat. This figure’s magical gaze alone threatened an entourage of deities on a solar barge that possibly included its rival's “Eye.” For 10 points, name this serpent that Ra battled in the underworld every night. ANSWER: Apep [or Apophis; accept Apepi; accept Book of Apophis or Book of Apep or Book of Overcoming Apep or Book of Overthrowing Apep or Book of Overcoming Apophis or Book of Overthrowing Apophis] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~29629~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

18. This composer claimed that the only pianist who played his transcriptions of peasant dances called slåtter ("SLOH-ter”) with the right feeling was his ardent champion Percy Grainger. This composer used a melody beginning "4 Gs, then G, E, F" in a collection's first and last pieces: a waltz called "Remembrances" and an "Arietta." An A minor concerto by Robert Schumann inspired another by this composer that ends with a (*) Halling dance and begins with a timpani roll before the pianist enters. This composer of Lyric Pieces wrote incidental music to a scene in which trolls try to kill and eat a character who later wakes up while “Morning Mood” plays. For 10 points, name this Norwegian composer of “In the Hall of the Mountain King”. ANSWER: Edvard Grieg [or Edvard Hagerup Grieg] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~29644~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

19. This movement included a baroness who coined portmanteaus like "kissambushed" and wrote Body Sweats, Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven ("FRY-tahk-LOH-ring-hof-un"). A poet who largely founded this movement used the phrase "jolifanto bambla" in "Karawane" ("kah-ruh-VAN-uh"), one of his "sound poems." Instructions for making a poem from this movement, which predated the Beats, begin with cutting up a newspaper. Hugo Ball read a manifesto for this movement at Zurich's (*) Cabaret Voltaire ("kah-bah-RAY vohl-TAIR") two years before Tristan Tzara ("ZAH-ruh") wrote a competing one in 1918. This movement's name was supposedly chosen when a knife landed on a dictionary entry meaning "hobby horse." For 10 points, name this "anti-art" movement whose writers included Marcel Duchamp ("mar-SELL doo-SHOMP"). ANSWER: Dada [or Dadaism or Dadaist movement; accept "To Make a Dadaist Poem" or "Pour faire un poème dadaïste"] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Poetry> ~31011~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

20. James Lee testified that this state ordered ChoicePoint to populate a database with anyone who matched 80 percent of a felon's last name. In this state, John Sweeney's cry to "shut it down" ignited well-dressed protestors in the Brooks Brothers riot. Antonin Scalia cited potential "irreparable harm" from a process in this state involving Katherine Harris, partly necessitated by so-called (*) hanging chads. Pat Buchanan was suspected of benefiting from a misaligned "butterfly" design used in this state. A margin of 537 votes was declared in this state in favor of a candidate whose brother Jeb was its governor. For 10 points, name this state where, in the 2000 presidential election, Al Gore requested a recount in Miami-Dade county. ANSWER: Florida [or FL] <Lalit Maharjan, History - American - 1945+> ~29713~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

21. A form of this quantity that is proportional to power over bandwidth measures the noise produced by a radio antenna. In the Saha equation, this quantity and a constant divide a difference of energies by appearing in the denominator of the exponential term. The "excitation" form of this quantity is negative in lasers because this quantity equals the constant-volume entropy derivative of internal energy. One over (*) beta equals Boltzmann's constant times this quantity. Internal energy minus the product of entropy and this quantity equals Helmholtz free energy. The change in this quantity over the change in energy gives a material's heat capacity. For 10 points, name this quantity whose "standard" value equals 273 kelvin. ANSWER: temperature [accept antenna noise temperature or excitation temperature; prompt on T] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~30618~ <Editor: David Bass> NSC 2025 - Round 17 - Bonuses

1. This author's book Last Witnesses collects testimonies of World War II from people who were children at the time. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this Belarusian Nobel laureate whose oral histories include War's Unwomanly Face, the first book in her series Voices of Utopia. ANSWER: Svetlana Alexievich [or Svetlana Alexandrovna Alexievich] [10e] Alexievich helped inspire an HBO series with a book about this 1986 event, subtitled "The Oral History of a Nuclear Disaster." ANSWER: Chernobyl disaster [accept answers indicating an incident at Chernobyl or Chornobyl; accept Voices from Chernobyl: The Oral History of a Nuclear Disaster or Chernobyl Prayer or Chernobylskaya molitva] [10m] Hundreds of prisoners' recollections helped inform this 1973 book by another Nobel laureate about the Soviet penal system, whose subtitle calls it an "Experiment in Literary Investigation." ANSWER: The Gulag Archipelago: An Experiment in Literary Investigation [or Arkhipelag GULAG] (by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn) <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Other> ~24808~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

Answer: A People's History of the United States (by Howard Zinn)
Text: 2. This book's chapter "Tyranny is Tyranny" claims that the economic elite who led the Revolutionary War created "the most effective system of national control devised in modern times." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this anti-nationalist book that opens by depicting Columbus's arrival in Hispaniola from the Arawaks' perspective. ANSWER: A People's History of the United States [prompt on A People's History] (by Howard Zinn) [10e] The book's second chapter argues that the "color line" was created to pacify these people by distinguishing them from slaves. These servants worked without pay for a set amount of time. ANSWER: indentured servants [or indentured laborers; accept indentured servitude] [10m] Zinn traced the discontent of poor white settlers to this 1676 uprising, in which Governor William Berkeley was targeted before a city was burned. ANSWER: Bacon's Rebellion <Forrest Weintraub, History - American - Pre-1865> ~25990~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

3. Rose Yu led the development of a 2023 generative adversarial network, or GAN, for the discovery of these properties. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these properties that correspond to elements of certain groups, like the Lorentz group. Noether's ("NURR-tuh's") theorem relates conservation laws to these properties. ANSWER: symmetries [or symmetry; accept continuous symmetries of the action] [10h] The GAN is named for this mathematician's "theory." The exponential map connects this mathematician's namesake algebra to groups that behave as differentiable manifolds. ANSWER: Sophus Lie ("LEE") [or Marius Sophus Lie; accept Lie algebra] [10e] By studying N-body simulations, LieGAN rediscovered the restricted Lorentz group and the group of these transformations. In this transformation, an object moves around its own axis. ANSWER: rotations [accept rotate or rotating] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~26002~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. A subgenre of this genre called toebakje ("toe-BAHK-yeh") depicted smoking instruments and was popular in the Netherlands. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this genre of art depicting inanimate objects such as flowers, fruit, and coins. ANSWER: still-lifes [10m] Willem Claesz Heda made many works in the vanitas genre, paintings that remind the viewer of their mortality through elements known by this two-word term, such as skulls, rotting food, and extinguished candles. ANSWER: memento mori [10h] This 18th-century French artist found great success with still-life paintings such as Basket of Plums and The Ray. This artist also delighted the Salon with idealized domestic scenes like Saying Grace. ANSWER: Jean-Baptiste-Simeon Chardin <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~22554~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

5. Hindus are taught not to step on books out of reverence for this goddess. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this Hindu goddess often seen holding a book in one of her four hands. Children are taught to write for the first time during a celebration for this Hindu goddess of wisdom. ANSWER: Saraswati [or Sarasvati] [10e] Saraswati is often depicted with clothes and a swan of this color that represents purity. "Sky-clad" Digambara ("dig-GUM-buh-ruh") Jains are contrasted with Śvetāmbara ("shvay-TAHM-buh-ruh") Jains clad in this color. ANSWER: white [accept white-clad Jains] [10h] Saraswati is also depicted holding a pot of water that sometimes symbolizes this drink. This drink is extracted from a plant of the same name, which is discussed in the ninth Mandala of the Rigveda. ANSWER: soma <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Hinduism> ~26006~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

6. People were buried with boat-shaped axes in the Battle Axe culture that likely brought the Indo-European language to this region. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this multinational region where many ship burials were conducted by the Norse. ANSWER: Scandinavia [accept Scandinavian Peninsula; prompt on Nordic countries; prompt on Northern Europe; prompt on Denmark or Norway or Sweden by asking "what region is that country a part of?"] [10h] The pre-Indo-European culture, supplanted by the Battle Axe culture, made collective graves called dolmens out of these objects. The name for a kind of these objects called menhirs comes from the Breton language. ANSWER: stones [or rocks; or liths; accept megaliths; accept standing stones] [10m] The Battle Axe culture was an offshoot of a culture named for producing "corded" examples of this product. Pieces of this product are called ostraka, which is the root word of "ostracism." ANSWER: pottery [or pots; or wares; or ceramics; accept jars or vases or amphorae; accept Corded Ware culture] <Forrest Weintraub, History - European - Misc> ~25157~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: Joaquim Maria Machado de Assis ("ma-SHA-doo JEE uh-SEES")
Text: 7. At the end of a story by this author, a young man who escaped to Rita's house reluctantly hands Rita a stick to beat a slave. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this author who, in one story, wrote about the madness of the title psychiatrist, who confines both healthy and sick people to the "green house." ANSWER: Joaquim Maria Machado de Assis ("ma-SHA-doo JEE uh-SEES") [10m] Machado de Assis is best known for a novel written as the fictional memoir of Bras Cubas after one of these events. A collection of sonnets by a different author is titled for one of these events that occurred to Romelio Ureta. ANSWER: death [accept word forms like dying; accept funerals; accept muerte or morte; accept suicide; accept The Posthumous Memoirs of Bras Cubas or Sonnets of Death] [10e] Esteban Trueba builds the title house of this Isabel Allende novel after the tragic death of his fiancée Rosa the Beautiful. ANSWER: The House of the Spirits [or La casa de los espíritus] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25779~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

8. Carina Heller and Laura Pritschet performed dense sampling studies of their own brains while on and off this type of medication. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this type of medication with 150 million global users. "POP" is a class of these medications, contrasted with "combined" ones that can include ethinyl·estra·diol. ANSWER: birth control pills [or oral hormonal contraceptives or contraception or combined oral contraceptive pills or COCP or progestogen-only pills; prompt on the pill or mini pills] [10e] Heller and Pritschet used this brain-scanning technique with a three-letter name, whose "functional" type targets specific regions. ANSWER: MRI [or magnetic resonance imaging or fMRI or functional magnetic resonance imaging; prompt on NMR or nuclear magnetic resonance] [10h] Heller found that birth control decreased brain volume and a property named for this word that is measured with fMRI BOLD data. With the suffix "-ome," this word names whole-brain maps of neural pathways. ANSWER: connect [accept word forms like connected; accept connectivity or functional connectivity or connectome] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~26011~ <Editor: David Bass>

9. A Nobel-winning physicist from this country showed how the unique harmonics of one of its drums were generated by combining two inhomogeneous circular membranes. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this largest country home to a fretted instrument with over a dozen sympathetic strings, called the sitar. ANSWER: India [or Republic of India; or Bhārat Gaṇarājya] (The physicist is C.V. Raman.) [10m] India's two main classical traditions are the northern Hindustani tradition, whose performers improvise around modes called ragas, and this southern tradition whose musicians perform existing compositions. ANSWER: Carnatic music [or Karnāṭaka saṃgīta; or Karnāṭaka saṅgītam] [10h] Carnatic music is accompanied by this two-sided drum made from the jackfruit tree. Shiva legendarily invented the tabla by cutting this drum in half. ANSWER: mridangam ("mri-DUN-gum") <Abhinav Rachakonda, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~25211~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

10. Note to moderator: read the first answerline carefully. Note to players: description acceptable. Leto granted this boon to Leucippus to protect him from the ire of his father Lamprus. For 10 points each: [10h] Name or describe this boon that Isis granted to Iphis, a youth betrothed to Ianthe ("eye-ANN-thee"). In addition to being invulnerable to weapons, Caeneus received this other boon from Neptune. ANSWER: changing sex [accept changing genders; accept answers describing transitioning from female to male; reject answers that mention changing from "male" to "female"] [10e] Leucippus, Iphis, and Siproites, who was turned into a woman by Artemis, were all natives of this Greek island. Daedalus built the Labyrinth for Minos, the king of this island. ANSWER: Crete [or Kríti or Krētē] [10m] Hera punishes this figure for hitting a pair of mating snakes by turning him into a woman for seven years. In the underworld, this figure tells Odysseus how to get past Scylla and Charybdis. ANSWER: Tiresias <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~24517~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

11. During this dynasty, Hasan al-Rammah proposed a "combustible egg," the world's first rocket-propelled torpedo. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this dynasty that stopped Mongol expansion at Ain Jalut after divisions of Burjī murdered al-Ṣāliḥ Ayyūb’s heir in the 1250s. ANSWER: Mamluk Sultanate [or Mamluks or Mamluk Empire or Mamluk Egypt; accept Salṭanat al-Mamālīk; prompt on State of the Turks or State of the Circassians] [10h] In a manuscript for Al-Nasir Muhammad, al-Jazari illustrated one of these devices built into the structure of an elephant. Ibn al-Haytham built one of these devices that dipped a cylinder in a tank. ANSWER: clocks [accept water clock or elephant clock or clepsydra] [10e] Ibn al-Nafis documented metabolism during the Mamluk Sultanate while at a hospital begun by this first Ayyubid sultan, who led Muslim forces against an English king in the Third Crusade. ANSWER: Saladin [or Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub] <Ganon Evans, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~25790~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

12. Element 117, tennessine, was discovered by bombarding berkelium with this element. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this element, whose bombardment was used to synthesize four other superheavy elements. This element's isotope 48 is the lightest nuclide to undergo double beta decay. ANSWER: calcium [or Ca] [10m] Two of the six naturally occurring isotopes of calcium are stable because their numbers of protons and neutrons are [emphasize] both this type of number. Because flerovium-298 and un·bi·hexium-310 are doubly this type of number, they are thought to land in an "island of stability." ANSWER: magic numbers [accept doubly magic] [10e] The bombardment used to create tennessine is a form of this nuclear process, which turns hydrogen into helium. ANSWER: nuclear fusion [prompt on nucleosynthesis; prompt on transmutation] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Chemistry> ~25775~ <Editor: June Yin>

13. Scholarly interest in this concept spiked in response to a 2015 paper examining "all-cause mortality of middle-aged white non-Hispanic men and women." For 10 points each: [10h] Give this alliterative term that Anne Case and Angus Deaton used to denote deaths caused by economic and social insecurity, like suicides and overdoses. ANSWER: deaths of despair [10e] Addiction to this class of drugs causes many deaths of despair. These drugs are exemplified by oxycodone and fentanyl. ANSWER: opioids [accept opiates; prompt on narcotics; prompt on painkillers or pain relievers or pain medications or pain drugs] [10m] Deaths of despair are more common among people with low values of this variable. Thomas Piketty coined the term "brahmin left" to describe a political faction with high levels of this variable. ANSWER: education [or educational attainment or schooling] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Sociology> ~25560~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

Answer: crucifixion This playwright wrote The Cocktail Party. This playwright wrote about an “Unreal City” where “Saint Mary Woolnoth kept the hours” in a poem that ends “Shantih Shantih Shantih.” ANSWER: T. S. Eliot (The poem is "The Waste Land.") In this T. S. Eliot verse drama, four "tempters" appear to the main character, St. Thomas Becket, who responds that the "greatest treason" is to "do the right thing for the wrong reason." ANSWER: Murder in the Cathedral
Text: 14. In The Cocktail Party, Celia meets death in this specific manner after joining a nursing order in Kinkanja. For 10 points each: [10e] Medieval passion plays depict Jesus’s death in what manner? ANSWER: crucifixion [accept word forms; accept dying on the cross] [10m] This playwright wrote The Cocktail Party. This playwright wrote about an “Unreal City” where “Saint Mary Woolnoth kept the hours” in a poem that ends “Shantih Shantih Shantih.” ANSWER: T. S. Eliot [or Thomas Stearns Eliot] (The poem is "The Waste Land.") [10h] In this T. S. Eliot verse drama, four "tempters" appear to the main character, St. Thomas Becket, who responds that the "greatest treason" is to "do the right thing for the wrong reason." ANSWER: Murder in the Cathedral <Joseph Chambers, Literature - British - Drama> ~25236~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

15. 48 percent of Italy's electricity is generated from the 900 or so hydroelectric plants on this river. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this rapidly deteriorating river that flows through Cremona. ANSWER: Po River [10h] One consequence of the Po Valley drying up is less reliance on water-hungry crops such as this one. Cultivars such as Soreli and Dori make Italy the leading producer of this fruit, most famously grown in a country that markets this fruit under the brand "Zespri." ANSWER: kiwi [or kiwifruit; or Chinese gooseberry; prompt on gooseberry] (Zespri is from New Zealand) [10e] Postwar automation of rice farms in the Po Valley sent many farmers to work in the factories of this city, the capital of Piedmont. This host city of the 2006 Winter Olympics is home to a chapel housing its namesake burial shroud of Jesus. ANSWER: Turin [or Torino] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~25977~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. Identify the following about policies of public forgetting, for 10 points each. [10h] Spain's Pact of Forgetting was complicated by the existence of this monument near Madrid, effectively a shrine to Francisco Franco built with convict labor. Franco's body was exhumed from this monument in 2019. ANSWER: Valley of the Fallen [or Valle de Cuelgamuros or Valley of Cuelgamuros or Valle de los Caídos] [10m] In his book In Praise of Forgetting, David Rieff argued that this agreement that spared Slobodan Milošević ("mih-LAW-shuh-vitch") was better than a punitive prosecution. This agreement, named for an American city, ended the Bosnian War. ANSWER: Dayton Accords [or Dayton Agreement or the Dayton; or Dejtonski mirovni sporazum; accept Dayton Peace Accord; accept General Framework Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina] [10e] In 1996, King Norodom Sihanouk ("SEE-hah-nook") granted mass amnesty to both political prisoners and many perpetrators of the genocide committed in this Southeast Asian country by the Khmer Rouge. ANSWER: Cambodia [or Kingdom of Cambodia] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25478~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

17. Ekman transport causes these structures to bulge as much as one meter in their centers. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these largest persistent oceanic flow structures. These rotating structures are driven by constant-sign wind-stress curls and dominate flow within ocean basins. ANSWER: ocean gyres [prompt on ocean currents] [10h] This scientist's "balance" is exemplified by the stationarity of ocean gyres despite constant-sign wind-stress curl. This scientist names a unit for oceanic volumetric flow rate that equals one million cubic meters per second. ANSWER: Haral Sverdrup [or Harald Ulrik Sverdrup] [10e] Gyres feature flows driven by geostrophic balance, in which the pressure gradient force is opposed by this hemisphere-specific "fictitious force." ANSWER: Coriolis force [or Coriolis effect] <David Bass, Science - Other Science> ~26010~ <Editor: David Bass>

18. A person from this place says "time is tied to the wrist" and "rain is when the earth is television" in a poem by Craig Raine. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this place where Ylla ("ILL-uh") dreams of the poem "Drink to Me Only with Thine Eyes." A story collection named for this place's Chronicles includes "Usher II" and "There Will Come Soft Rains." ANSWER: Mars [accept The Martian Chronicles; accept "A Martian Sends a Postcard Home"] [10e] The Martian Chronicles were written by this author. A man recites "Consider the lilies of the field" to drown out subway advertising in this author's novel Fahrenheit 451. ANSWER: Ray Bradbury [or Ray Douglas Bradbury] [10h] This U. S. poet laureate from 2017 to 2019 wrote the collection Life on Mars. This author of Ordinary Light wrote "A pair of eyes. The most remarkable lies" in "My God, It's Full of Stars." ANSWER: Tracy K. Smith <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~25446~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

19. Identify the following about Jára Cimrman ("YAH-ruh TSIM-er-mahn"), a fictional Czech equivalent of Forrest Gump who appears at important moments in history, for 10 points each. [10e] Cimrman is said to have carried 45 tubs of radioactive pitchblende to this scientist, who shared a 1903 Nobel Prize with her husband, Pierre. ANSWER: Marie Curie [or Maria Salomea Skłodowska-Curie or Maria Skłodowska] [10m] Cimrman supposedly titled this Anton Chekhov play, which opens with Irina celebrating her name day. "Lovesick Major" Aleksandr Vershinin is another character in this play. ANSWER: Three Sisters [or Tri sestry; accept Two Sisters] (According to legend, Two Sisters was Chekhov's original title before Cimrman asked him, "Shouldn't there be more?") [10h] In a complicated story involving watchmaking, Cimrman introduced this discipline to Switzerland. A device used in this medical field was a secret tool of the trade in the Chamberlen family and was used by Dr. Slop in Tristram Shandy. ANSWER: obstetrics [accept OB; prompt on OB/GYN or gynecology or childbirth] (The device was forceps.) <Abhinav Rachakonda, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~25534~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. In an opera by this composer, Claggart sings in F minor while Billy Budd sings in E major. For 10 points each: [10e] What English composer used the same key relationship to represent the "maladjustment" of Peter Grimes? This composer wrote The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra. ANSWER: Benjamin Britten [10h] The similar polychord "E-flat major over E minor" appears in Golaud's ("go-LO's") theme from this 1902 opera, which depicts a love triangle in the fictional medieval kingdom of Allemonde. ANSWER: Pelléas et Mélisande [or Pelleas and Melisande] (by Claude Debussy) [10m] This opera's climactic polychord "F-sharp major over A dominant seventh" has been called "the most sickening chord in all opera." This 1905 opera contains the "Dance of the Seven Veils." ANSWER: Salome (by Richard Strauss) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Opera> ~25557~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

Answer: Friedrich Nietzsche (That book is The Birth of Tragedy.)
Text: 21. This philosopher's "On Music and Words" is a study for a book which describes its title art form as "Out of the Spirit of Music." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this philosopher who attributes elements of both the Apollonian and Dionysian to the title art form in that book. ANSWER: Friedrich Nietzsche (That book is The Birth of Tragedy.) [10h] This book placed music atop a hierarchy of the arts, influencing Nietzsche's "On Music and Words." Readers of this book are instructed to first read its author's dissertation titled On the Fourfold Root of the Principle of Sufficient Reason. ANSWER: The World as Will and Representation [or The World as Will and Idea or Die Welt als Wille und Vorstellung] (The book is by Arthur Schopenhauer.) [10e] The World as Will and Representation's artistic hierarchy is in a section titled for this philosophical field that studies beauty in art. ANSWER: aesthetics [or aesthetic philosophy] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~25155~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

1. For over 700 years, Jerusalem's Razzouk family has sold these things to Armenian pilgrims. The future King George V started a trend for these things after buying one from Tokyo's Karakusa Gonta. Nora Hildebrandt was one of the first "ladies" nicknamed for having many of these things who performed at circuses. Sailor Jerry's "Old-School" designs for these things often featured (*) anchors. The English word for these things is a Samoan loanword. In Japan, Samurai-themed examples of these things are linked with being in the Yakuza. Triangles and numbers were often used in examples of these things forcibly given to Jews who entered concentration camps. For 10 points, name these body markings applied with special ink. ANSWER: tattoos [accept sailor's tattoos or old school tattoos or Irezumi; prompt on body art; prompt on ink until read] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~30085~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: combustion (The first line refers to ICP-MS.)
Text: 2. Samples are nebulized, undergo this process, and are then filtered through a skimmer cone in a technique that can detect metals at part-per-trillion concentrations. This process is performed on samples in atomic emission spectroscopy using an ICP. In a common setup for gas chromatography, eluted analytes undergo this process before being detected by an ionization detector. The D lines of (*) sodium are filtered out using cobalt blue glass in a technique that relies on this process, which first dips the sample in nichrome wire and produces a red color when performed on lithium. For 10 points, samples can be identified by performing what process in a device named for Robert Bunsen? ANSWER: combustion [or burning or becoming a fire or becoming a plasma or becoming a flame; accept flame ionization detector or flame test; accept ionization until read; prompt on oxidation] (The first line refers to ICP-MS.) <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~30934~ <Editor: June Yin>

3. This painting's erotic symbolism may have been inspired by a Jacques de Gheyn print whose subject helps a crossbowman. X-ray scans of this painting reveal that it was decluttered by removing a plank with knobs or a tub for holding clothes. A basket and copper pail in this painting hang next to a window on its left side, a frequent light source for its artist. In this painting, blue and white wall tiles depicting (*) Cupid and a man with a pole appear behind a foot warmer. This 1658 painting's title figure wears a white bonnet, yellow shirt, and blue apron as she stands next to a table with fresh bread and a large bowl. For 10 points, name this Jan Vermeer painting of a servant pouring liquid from a pitcher. ANSWER: The Milkmaid [or The Kitchen Maid; or De melkmeid or Het melkmeisje or De keukenmeid] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~30821~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

Answer: the island from Lord of the Flies
Text: 4. Description required. In this place, one character recounts a dream about "Twisty things" among trees. A "creature that bulged" like "a great ape…sitting asleep with its head between its knees" is seen in a patch of ashes in this place. A character who is seen "expanding like a balloon" declares "I'm the reason why it's no go" and says "We are going to have fun" [in this place] before (*) Simon faints. The "littluns" are afraid of a "beast" in this location, which turns out to be a dead parachutist. A pig's head is mounted on a stick in this place, where meetings are conducted with a conch shell. For 10 points, describe this location where boys like Ralph, Jack, and Piggy are stranded in a William Golding novel. ANSWER: the island from Lord of the Flies [prompt on descriptions of the setting of Lord of the Flies] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~30576~  <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

5. An embellished account by this historian claims that when a noblewoman's enemies threatened to kill her children, she raised her skirt and said, "I have the tools to make more." This historian claimed that Agathocles of Syracuse's excessive brutality kept him from achieving glory. After the republic he worked for was overthrown, this historian was placed under house arrest and wrote a treatise dedicated to his new ruler. This author's commentary on (*) Ab Urbe Condita defends republican government, contrary to a work of his that compares fortune to a woman who must be beaten and praises Cesare Borgia ("CHAY-za-ray BORE-ja"). For 10 points, name this Florentine historian who wrote "it is much safer to be feared than loved" in The Prince. ANSWER: Niccolò Machiavelli (The first clue refers to a story about Caterina Sforza included in the Discourses on Livy and Florentine Histories.) <Forrest Weintraub, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30760~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

6. Both "suns" and these objects are described as being "lured" or "coaxed" out by Joy in the fourth stanza of "Ode to Joy." After one of these objects appeared in a dream sequence in the novel Heinrich von Ofterdingen ("HINE-rick von OFF-tur-DING-un"), Romantic poets adopted it as a symbol of longing. The title of a Penelope Fitzgerald novel refers to a "blue" one of these objects described by the poet (*) Novalis ("noh-VAH-liss"). "Folly," "error," "sin," and "avarice" are listed near the start of a book titled for these objects, which includes "The Litanies of Satan." These objects title an 1868 collection whose address to a "hypocrite reader" precedes poems like "The Albatross." For 10 points, a Charles Baudelaire ("sharl BOH-duh-lair") collection is titled for what objects "of evil"? ANSWER: flowers [accept fleurs or Blumen or Les Fleurs du mal or The Flowers of Evil or blue flower or blaue Blume or lichtblaue Blume] <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Poetry> ~31030~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

7. Henry of Champagne claimed he saw a leader of this group order two of its members to prove their loyalty by jumping off a cliff. This group left a cake at the bedside of a rival to intimidate him into withdrawing his forces. The Mongols held a leader of this group hostage before Hulegu Khan sacked their fortress of Alamut in his conquest of Nizari. Marco Polo described how a leader of this group, known as the (*) "Old Man of the Mountain," built a "garden of paradise" to which recruits were taken after being drugged. Hassan-i Sabbah founded this group, whose name derives from their supposed cannabis use. For 10 points, name this Islamic sect whose mythologized covert killings originated a term for politicized murders. ANSWER: Assassins [or Ḥashshāshīyīn or al-Hashishiin; prompt on Ismaili or batiniyya; prompt on Nizari until read] <Jamie Burchett, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~31163~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

8. A knot garden is featured in a larger period-appropriate garden named for this man designed by Jens Jensen at Northwestern University. A John Quincy Adams Ward sculpture of this man in New York draws from the Chandos portrait. A building named for Angus Bowmer was constructed to meet demand for a summer festival named for this man in Ashland, Oregon. A nonprofit named for this man got around opposition from Robert Moses to construct the (*) Delacorte in Central Park, used for free performances. The Huntington Library in San Marino, California, owns four copies of this man's First Folio. For 10 points, New York's free "In the Park" performances stage what playwright’s plays, such as The Tempest? ANSWER: William Shakespeare [accept Shakespeare Gardens or Shakespeare in the Park] <Michael Bentley, Geography - United States> ~30818~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. Description acceptable. According to Plutarch's Life of this object's owner, Scirus of Salamis was chosen to control this object due to Athenians lacking the skills at the time. Executions were banned during an annual tradition of taking this particular object to Delos, which delayed Socrates's death according to Phaedo. Plutarch recounts how this object was preserved for that tradition by having (*) "decaying" parts of it replaced. The Aegean Sea is named for a king who killed himself after he saw parts of this object colored black. This object was diverted during a storm to Naxos, where its owner abandoned Ariadne. For 10 points, a philosophical thought experiment concerns what object used by a minotaur-slayer to reach Crete? ANSWER: ship of Theseus [accept any answer indicating the boat that Theseus sailed to Crete; accept answers like Theseus's sails that reference part of a boat; prompt on ship or boat alone] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~29524~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

10. This scientist is the alphabetically latter namesake of a theory in which a particle's motion depends on the positions of all other particles, as expressed in the guiding equation. This scientist developed the first deterministic hidden-variable theory. In this scientist's generalization of the Planck relation, momentum is proportional to the vector k. This scientist's pilot-wave theory was revived by David Bohm. This scientist was validated by observations of electron diffraction in the (*) Davisson–Germer experiment. A quantity named for this scientist equals Planck's constant over momentum. For 10 points, matter was hypothesized to exhibit wave-particle duality by what Frenchman who names an associated wavelength? ANSWER: Louis de Broglie ("duh BROY") <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~31075~ <Editor: David Bass>

11. Description acceptable. They're not clergy, but Marsh v. Chambers upheld a practice regarding these groups. A theory regarding these groups, which was based on William Rehnquist's opinion in Bush v. Gore and rejected in Moore v. Harper, claims that they are "independent." Chiafalo v. Washington expanded these groups' rights, some of which stem from Article I, Section 4. Before the ruling in Shelby County v. Holder, these groups' powers were limited by (*) preclearance. These bodies choose the "Times, Places, and Manner" of Congressional elections. The 17th Amendment ended these bodies' selection of US Senators. Exactly one of these bodies is unicameral. For 10 points, name these bodies that meet in places like Richmond and Sacramento. ANSWER: state legislatures [accept independent state legislature theory; accept any answer that describes the legislative branch of states; accept state senates; prompt on legislatures or senates; prompt on states or state governments by asking "which branch?"] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Other> ~31040~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

12. This author drew on the modernist style of Finnegans Wake in a novel centered around the construction of El Escorial. The narrator of one of this author's novels refuses to testify to Congress and argues that they must learn to "live with" the central setting rather than to "save" it. This author copied the structure of Tristram Shandy for a novel in which the title character's parents scheme to have him born on the 500 year anniversary of (*) Columbus's arrival in the Americas. One of this author's characters, who carries a copy of Don Quixote, falls in love with Harriet Winslow and is killed by General Arroyo. For 10 points, name this author who fictionalized Ambrose Bierce's life in Mexico in The Old Gringo. ANSWER: Carlos Fuentes <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30511~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

13. These systems are the typical holders of high values of Gaia's RUWE ("ROO-wee") statistic. Blue stragglers may form from these systems following the development of a common envelope. X-ray emissions result from the asymmetry of a compact object in these systems whose mass is typically measured up to a factor of the sine of the inclination angle. The "contact" type of these systems fill both of their (*) Roche lobes, facilitating mass transfer through the L1 Lagrange point. These non-planetary systems are "spectroscopic" when detected by changes in radial velocity, and are "visual" if the mutual orbit of their members can be observed directly. For 10 points, name these systems containing two stars. ANSWER: stellar binaries [or binary stars or binary star systems or binary stellar systems; accept contact binaries or X-ray binaries or spectroscopic binaries or visual binaries; prompt on multiple stellar systems or multiple star systems or two-body systems; reject "double stars"] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~29599~ <Editor: David Bass>

14. These people's attire included symbolic red and white ribbons accompanying a veil called a suffibulum. These people were tasked with mixing salt and emmer to make the bread mola salsa. Plutarch described how these people were punished for incestum by being buried alive in a chamber near the Colline Gate. These people oversaw rites during the Bona Dea festival. These people only answered to the (*) pontifex maximus, who chose candidates between the ages of six and ten to become these people. These people who made oaths not to marry for 30 years were tasked with guarding the Palladium and ensuring that a sacred flame never extinguished. For 10 points, name these ancient priestesses to the Roman goddess of the hearth. ANSWER: Vestal Virgins [or Vestales; accept answers that describe priestesses of Vesta; prompt on priestesses alone until read; prompt on Roman women; prompt on virgins] <Rohan Kher, History - European - Classical> ~29654~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: trains (The first line is about "Choo Choo Ch'Boogie.")
Text: 15. These things inspired a "hillbilly" jump blues song written by Milt Gabler and recorded by Louis Jordan in 1946. A riff from "Happy-Go-Lucky Local" inspired a song about these things by Jimmy Forrest. One band's live performances of a song named for these things featured scat-singing by Ray Nance, who played an oft-imitated trumpet solo on its original recording. The film Sun Valley Serenade popularised a (*) Glenn Miller recording of a song named for these things in which the singer talks to a shoeshine boy. A song that describes using one of these things "to go to Sugar Hill way up in Harlem" was written by Billy Strayhorn for Duke Ellington. For 10 points, what vehicles are exemplified by the "Chattanooga Choo-Choo?" ANSWER: trains [accept "Night Train" or "Take the A Train"] (The first line is about "Choo Choo Ch'Boogie.") <Jamie Burchett, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~30816~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

Answer: "The Tell-Tale Heart" (The Wilbur essay connects the "vulture eye" to the vulture in "Sonnet - To Science.")
Text: 16. A Richard Wilbur essay connects this story to its author's sonnet about a bird "whose wings are dull realities." A man in this story thinks one event is "wind in the chimney," "a mouse crossing the floor," or "a cricket which has made a single chirp." This story's narrator says "Object there was none. Passion there was none" and says "how cunningly" he slowly (*) opens a door and peeks his head through. After three police officers arrive at his house, this story's narrator hears the sound of a watch "enveloped in cotton." A man in this story fears a pale blue "vulture eye." For 10 points, name this short story by Edgar Allan Poe, whose narrator kills an old man and buries the title body part under the floor. ANSWER: "The Tell-Tale Heart" (The Wilbur essay connects the "vulture eye" to the vulture in "Sonnet - To Science.") <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Short Fiction> ~30528~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

17. Cornell's DiTommaso lab has pioneered the study of "neutral communities" of these organisms. These organisms are antagonized by substances classified into 27 modes of action by the IHRWD. These are the largest organisms removed via solarization with polyethylene covers. These organisms, which are contrasted with volunteers, are targeted by 2,4-D and atrazine. "Secondary" species evolved via the winnowing of species with this role, like Avena sterilis and Secale montanum, in instances of (*) Vavilovian mimicry. These organisms are excluded from being made "Ready" for Roundup, whose glyphosate content kills these organisms in a procedure developed by Monsanto. For 10 points, herbicides target what undesirable plants? ANSWER: weeds [prompt on plants or crops or grains or pests or invasive species] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~31110~ <Editor: David Bass>

18. A symphony by this composer opens with a short brass fanfare before a choir outlines the striking chord change "B-flat minor to D major." This composer adapted a song whose Phrygian ("FRIDGE-ian") melody begins "E, G, G, long G" in a piece for double string orchestra with string quartet. This composer's seventh symphony, which uses a wind machine and wordless SSA chorus, adapts a score he wrote for a film about an (*) Antarctic voyage. A piece for strings by this composer adapts the 16th-century song "Why fum'th in fight." The lyric "behold, the sea itself" begins this composer's first symphony, which sets Whitman's Leaves of Grass. For 10 points, name this English composer of A Sea Symphony and Fantasia on a Theme of Thomas Tallis. ANSWER: Ralph ("RAFE") Vaughan Williams <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~31218~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

19. Note to moderator: read the answerline carefully. On December 11, 2024, a group in Bhopal broke the world record for doing this activity with the Karma Yoga. This activity is both facilitated by, and in itself the best way to understand, the contents of the Samaveda. In a practice called japa that is aided by objects like the japamala, Hindus perform this action (*) 108 times. Millions of Hindus do this action daily with the Hanuman Chalisa. This activity may be done when an aarti flame is being offered with Om Jai Jagdish Hare. Forms of this activity include bhajan, mantra, and kirtan, the last of which uniquely features a call and response. For 10 points, along with playing instruments and dancing, groups of Hindus perform what vocal activity? ANSWER: singing [or song; or chanting; or reciting; accept bhajan, mantra, and kirtan until read; accept chanting or reciting shloka or any god's name; accept hymning; accept sama until "Samaveda" is read; accept gāyana or gā́yati; accept japa until read; prompt on vocalizing or ululating; prompt on music or dancing or playing instruments or meditating with "alongside what other action?"; prompt on speaking or uttering or equivalents or praying or reading the Bhagavad Gita or reading the Vedas with "in what manner?"] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Hinduism> ~31094~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

20. By 1830, two-thirds of all slaves in Northern states lived in this state, whose extremely gradual abolition law was not fixed until 1846. In 1807, this state removed voting rights granted to some of its women. This state’s Liberty Hall was once the home of a governor who succeeded its Tory colonial governor, an illegitimate son of Ben Franklin. This state's city of (*) Morristown was where the Continental Army spent the second of two harsh winters. A unicameral legislature was part of a "small state" counter to James Madison's Virginia Plan, proposed by this state's William Paterson at the Constitutional Convention. For 10 points, name this state where the Battles of Monmouth and Trenton were fought. ANSWER: New Jersey [or NJ] <Michael Bentley, History - American - Pre-1865> ~31089~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

21. It's not The Book Thief, but a character in this novel runs away from a party after being gifted a biography of Hitler before receiving a notebook to write stories in. A character in this novel is taught his father's religious interpretation that all sins are variations of the one sin of theft, and becomes afraid that his birth stole his mother's life. A character in this novel hides money under a (*) pillow to frame his friend so he doesn't have to admit that he saw his friend being raped. That event happens when his friend performs this novel’s title action after a local competition in which the central objects have glass glued to them. For 10 points, name this novel that fictionalizes Amir's experience growing up with the rise of the Taliban, by Khaled Hosseini. ANSWER: The Kite Runner <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~31226~ <Editor: Jim Fan> NSC 2025 - Round 18 - Bonuses

1. The minimax algorithm is often impractical for types of these data structures with large branching factors. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these structures often used to represent all possible states of sequential games. These acyclic graphs contain root and leaf nodes. ANSWER: trees [accept binary trees or game trees or decision trees] [10m] The minimax algorithm performs this type of search on game trees, which involves backtracking while traversing every branch as far as possible, unlike an alphabetically earlier type of search. ANSWER: depth-first search [or DFS] (The alternative is breadth-first search.) [10h] Implementation of minimax is improved by an algorithm named for both this technique and two adjacent Greek letters. This technique removes undesirable subtrees from consideration. ANSWER: pruning [accept alpha–beta pruning; accept word forms like prunes] <Steven Yuan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25568~ <Editor: David Bass>

2. In The Signifying Monkey, Henry Louis Gates Jr. analyzes a scene in which this man holds a book up next to his ear, expecting it to talk. For 10 points each:  [10h] Name this author whose "Interesting Narrative" describes hardships he experienced on the Middle Passage, as well as his subsequent travels to Turkey and the North Pole.  ANSWER: Olaudah Equiano [or Gustavus Vassa] [10e] In the collection The Classic Slave Narratives, Gates collected Equiano's "Interesting Narrative" along with this man's story of his escape from slavery in Baltimore. This author of "What to the Slave is the Fourth of July?" published The North Star. ANSWER: Frederick Douglass [10m] That collection also includes Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl, written by an author with this first name and last name Jacobs. Gates rediscovered the first African American novel published in the U. S., by an author with this first name. ANSWER: Harriet [accept Harriet Jacobs or Harriet Wilson] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Nonfiction> ~25468~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

3. Wolfram Eberhard described the Cold Food Festival as a remnant of a prehistoric version of this holiday. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this holiday which, in China, is often celebrated with longevity noodles and the gifting of red cash-filled envelopes. ANSWER: Lunar New Year [accept Chinese New Year or Spring Festival or chūnjié] [10m] In one of these celebrations for Shitala, families avoid lighting their stoves and eat cold food to prepare for summer as a form of prasāda, which is a type of offering made in front of a murti during these observances. ANSWER: pujas [or poojas; accept Sheetala Puja; anti-prompt on arti or aarati] [10h] Some Buddhists adhere to a prohibition on cold drinks that may have originated in this South Asian medicine system, which postulates three doshas and five elements. ANSWER: Āyurveda [or Āyurvedic medicine] <Michael Bentley, RMP - Other Religion> ~25979~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

4. In 2024, Kaido Peremees found the wreck of the airplane Kaleva after it was shot down over a Gulf named for this country. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this country. Before the Soviets shot it down, the Kaleva was headed to this country's capital, Helsinki. ANSWER: Finland [or Republic of Finland or Suomi or Suomen tasavalta] [10h] Part of this region was ceded to the Soviets at the end of the Winter War so the Soviets could have greater access to the fishing waters of Lake Ladoga. ANSWER: Karelia [or Karjala; or Karélija; or Korjela; or Karelen] [10m] The Winter War was partly instigated due to a non-aggression pact partly named for this Soviet politician. This Soviet, who was banished to Mongolia, was denounced as part of the "Anti-Party Group." ANSWER: Vyacheslav Molotov [prompt on Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - 1900+> ~25885~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

5. A model with this first name and the surname Sims was the first Black woman on the cover of Ladies' Home Journal. For 10 points each: [10h] Give this first name shared by a Black-British supermodel who was Gianni Versace's first bridal dress model and tripped at a 1993 Vivienne Westwood show. ANSWER: Naomi [accept Naomi Sims or Naomi Campbell] [10m] This designer threatened to pull all funding from the French edition of Vogue if they refused to put Naomi Campbell on its cover. This student of Christian Dior designed the Le Smoking tuxedo for women. ANSWER: Yves Saint Laurent [or YSL; or Yves Henri Donat Mathieu-Saint-Laurent] [10e] Naomi Sims developed Kanekalon Presselle fiber for her namesake brand of these accessories, which may be made out of synthetic or real hair, like a toupée. ANSWER: wigs [accept weaves; prompt on hairpieces] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~26016~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

6. In rare cases, the "keloid" type of these structures arises from intradermal inoculation. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these permanent accumulations of tissue left after a wound heals. ANSWER: scars [accept keloid scars] [10m] A bacterial clade and two French scientists give the acronymic name of an intradermal vaccine against this disease, which can cause false positives in the Mantoux ("mahn-TOO") test for this disease. ANSWER: tuberculosis [or TB] [10h] The clade IIb strain of this disease prompted the FDA to grant emergency approval to transdermal inoculation with the JYNNEOS vaccine in 2022. This disease presents with fever, myalgia, and a characteristic rash that evolves over two to four weeks.
