ANSWER: mpox [prompt on monkeypox by asking "what is the accepted name today?"] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~26036~ <Editor: David Bass>

7. In a variant in this genre, the main shite ("SHEE-tay") actor begins as a warrior ghost who has fallen into the underworld and must plead his case for release. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this genre, which features comedic kyōgen performances during planned intermissions between acts. ANSWER: Noh [10e] The main shite actor in Noh typically wears these objects traditionally carved from hinoki cypress. These objects are often swapped to emphasize degrees of the emotion they express. ANSWER: masks [10h] In a core Noh play, a gardener is tricked into believing that one of these objects will signal a rendezvous with an imperial consort, but commits suicide and haunts the consort after realizing he was tricked. ANSWER: drums [accept The Damask Drum] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~26059~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

8. This process’s namesake matrix includes source, message, and channel variables. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this process. Robert Cialdini tested the "door-in-the-face" strategy and included social proof as one of six principles of this process. ANSWER: persuasion [or word forms such as persuading; accept persuasion matrix; accept attitude influence or attitude change; prompt on influence or word forms] [10e] Social proof exemplifies this phenomenon in which people choose to "fit in." A Solomon Asch experiment involving three lines found that this phenomenon can override individual judgment. ANSWER: conformity [accept word forms like conforming] [10m] Muzafer Sherif studied conformity in this experiment that helped develop realistic conflict theory. This experiment divided 22 boys into two groups in a namesake Oklahoma park. ANSWER: Robbers Cave experiment [or Robbers Cave study] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Psychology> ~26056~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

9. In this piece's F minor first movement, the two soloists enter with a melodic sequence in stretto, resulting in a chain of suspensions. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this sacred piece that Neapolitan composer Giovanni Battista Pergolesi wrote for soprano, alto, strings, and continuo while dying of tuberculosis. ANSWER: Stabat Mater [10e] Pergolesi's Stabat Mater ends with a long fugue on this two-syllable word, which often names plagal cadences and ends Gregorian chants. ANSWER: amen [10m] Pergolesi's Stabat Mater overshadowed a prior setting by a composer from this family who founded the Neapolitan school and helped develop the da capo aria. A member of this family wrote 555 keyboard sonatas. ANSWER: Scarlatti [accept Alessandro Scarlatti or Domenico Scarlatti] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~25094~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

10. This man turned down a 3 million dollar contract extension with the Arizona Cardinals to join the Army following 9/11. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this soldier whose death in Afghanistan in April 2004 led the military to spread false narratives of a Taliban ambush. ANSWER: Pat Tillman [or Patrick Daniel Tillman, Jr.] [10e] Tillman was posthumously awarded this medal, given to soldiers wounded or killed in combat and named after the physical form of its predecessor, the Badge of Military Merit. ANSWER: Purple Heart [10m] This senator accused the army of an "inexcusable cover-up" regarding Tillman's death. This man received a Purple Heart for his service in Vietnam, where his time as a POW left him unable to raise his arms above his head. ANSWER: John McCain [or John Sidney McCain III] <Jamie Burchett, History - American - 1945+> ~25976~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

11. Elizabeth McGrath analyzed how an artist with this first name whitewashed Andromeda as she stands amongst Black attendants in a 1510 painting of Perseus on a sea monster. For 10 points each: [10h] Give this first name shared by a Renaissance artist who depicted Jesus carrying a banner and stepping over a sarcophagus and sleeping guards in The Resurrection. ANSWER: Piero [or Peter; accept Piero di Cosimo or Piero della Francesca] [10m] A whitewashed Queen of Sheba appears in a Claude Lorrain landscape titled for this type of event. Aristocrats travel to Venus's birthplace in an Antoine Watteau painting titled for one of these events. ANSWER: embarkation [accept The Embarkation of the Queen of Sheba or The Embarkation for Cythera; prompt on voyage or pilgrimage; prompt on departure or return] [10e] This artist's "poesie" paintings whitewashed Andromeda but featured various Black attendants in scenes like Diana and Acteon. This artist painted Venus of Urbino. ANSWER: Titian ("TIH-shun") <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~25766~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

Answer: Zambia Kenneth Kaunda changed Zambia's name from a "Northern" region with this other name. A leader of the ZANU-PF fought in a Bush War in a region with this name. ANSWER: Rhodesia The 1974 Lusaka Accord granted independence to this formerly Portuguese nation on Africa's southeast coast. FRELIMO forces fought in this country's capital of Maputo. ANSWER: Mozambique
Text: 12. Edward Makuka Nkoloso ("IN-koh-LOH-soh") recruited the so-called "Afronauts" from this modern-day country to convert Martians to Christianity. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this country that was ruled by Frederick Chiluba, who was raised in its economically important Copperbelt District. ANSWER: Zambia [or Republic of Zambia] [10m] Kenneth Kaunda changed Zambia's name from a "Northern" region with this other name. A leader of the ZANU-PF fought in a Bush War in a region with this name. ANSWER: Rhodesia [or Northern Rhodesia or Southern Rhodesia] [10e] The 1974 Lusaka Accord granted independence to this formerly Portuguese nation on Africa's southeast coast. FRELIMO forces fought in this country's capital of Maputo. ANSWER: Mozambique [or Republic of Mozambique or Republica de Moçambique] <Noah Sheidlower, History - World - African> ~25787~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

13. A boy stands on this kind of deck "whence all but he had fled" in Felicia Hemans' poem "Casabianca." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this event, which titles a poem whose narrator is woken by "thund'ring noise"? A villanelle states that "old age should [do this action] and rave at close of day." ANSWER: burning [accept "the boy stood on the burning deck" or "Verses upon the Burning of our House, July 10th, 1666" or "old age should burn and rave at close of day"; prompt on synonyms like fire or flame; prompt on destruction] [10e] This Welsh poet of "A Refusal to Mourn the Death, by Fire, of a Child in London" wrote "old age should burn and rave at close of day" in "Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night." ANSWER: Dylan Thomas [or Dylan Marlais Thomas] [10m] This poet wrote "My pleasant things in ashes lie" in "Verses upon the Burning of Our House." This poet addressed her work as a “rambling brat” and "ill-form'd offspring of my feeble brain.” ANSWER: Anne Bradstreet [accept Anne Dudley] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Poetry> ~25547~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

14. Isaiah Berlin's characterization of a hedgehog knowing one big thing inspired the title of this philosopher's essay "Do Values Conflict? A Hedgehog's Approach." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this legal philosopher who advocated for a theory of law as integrity in his book Law's Empire. ANSWER: Ronald Dworkin [or Ronald Myles Dworkin] [10e] Dworkin argued that moral values' interdependence forms one big thing in a book titled [this concept] for Hedgehogs. John Rawls wrote A Theory of [this concept]. ANSWER: justice [accept Justice for Hedgehogs; accept A Theory of Justice] [10m] Dworkin's analysis of what underlies this concept in Justice for Hedgehogs discusses Berlin's distinction between its positive and negative types. A book titled for this concept coined the harm principle. ANSWER: liberty [accept positive liberty; accept negative liberty; accept On Liberty; prompt on freedom] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~25106~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

15. Topological insulators conduct in these regions via a "correspondence" co-named for them. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these regions whose namesake "conditions" are exemplified by the no-slip condition and the requirement that the wavefunction outside of a material equals zero. ANSWER: boundaries [accept surfaces or edges or borders] [10h] This technique uses "tapping" and "contact" modes to map the surface of a material by running a piezoelectric tip at the end of a cantilever over the surface and measuring the tip's deflection. ANSWER: atomic force microscopy [or AFM; prompt on microscopy] [10e] Band bending occurs at the edges of p-type and n-type semiconductors when they are joined in the "bipolar junction" type of these small switches found on microchips. ANSWER: transistors [accept bipolar junction transistors; prompt on BJTs] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24991~ <Editor: David Bass>

16. While at the Cape of Good Hope, John MacDonald allegedly spotted one of these objects that was lost due to a vision obstruction by storms. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these vehicles whose "ghost" examples include the Mary Celeste and the Flying Dutchman. ANSWER: ships [accept boats; ghost ships] [10h] A legendary challenge atop Table Mountain involved Jan van Hunks and the Devil producing this substance. The Rainbow Crow in Lenape ("leh-NAH-pay") myth has his voice and feathers changed by this substance. ANSWER: smoke [accept soot or ash; prompt on fire; prompt on clouds with "what are the clouds believed to be made of?"] [10m] The legendary grootslang is believed to live in a cave in the Northern Cape filled with these objects. In another myth, a character sees a valley full of these objects after tying his turban to a roc's leg. ANSWER: diamonds [prompt on jewels or gems or gemstones] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - World Mythology> ~26160~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

17. This company's 1904 "Circular 57" helped popularize the "C-Q-D" distress signal. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this British telecommunications firm where John Ambrose Fleming developed the vacuum tube. George Bernard Shaw's The Music Cure references a scandal named for this company during the Asquith government. ANSWER: Marconi Company [accept English Marconi or American Marconi or Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company or Wireless Telegraph and Signal Company or Marconi International Marine Communication Company] [10e] Passengers on this ship could send "marconigrams," at least until it hit an iceberg on its maiden voyage on April 15, 1912. ANSWER: RMS Titanic [10m] Marconi Research Lab employee Tony Sale led the construction of the Mark 2 Colossus computer at this center of British codebreaking during World War II in Milton Keynes. ANSWER: Bletchley Park [prompt on Bletchley or Government Code and Cypher School or GC&CS] <Rohan Kher, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25791~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

18. This term derives from a period in Greek mythology during which humans and gods lived together. For 10 points each: [10e] Give this term for periods considered high points in a country's literary history, such as a "Spanish" period during which Miguel de Cervantes ("mee-GHEL day sair-VAN-tayz") wrote. ANSWER: golden age [accept Spanish Golden Age or Siglo de Oro] [10m] Dutch Golden Age author Johan van Heemskerk ("YOH-han van HAYMZ-kerk") wrote a book about a "Batavian" version of this place. The mythical Golden Age was said to have occurred in this place, which early modern writers depicted as a utopia inhabited by shepherds. ANSWER: Arcadia [accept Batavian Arcadia or Batavische Arcadia] [10h] In this book, often considered the first major prose novel of the Russian Golden Age, an archetypal "superfluous man" duels with Grushnitsky on a cliff. ANSWER: A Hero of Our Time [or Geroj našego vremeni] (Pechorin is the superfluous man; A Hero of Our Time is by Mikhail Lermontov.) <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~26007~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

19. A South African dog named Killer won the Dickin Medal for helping to catch 115 people engaging in this crime. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this crime militantly combated in a "fortress" strategy practiced in Botswana. Richard Leakey staged the first ceremonial fire to burn objects commonly targeted in this crime. ANSWER: illegal wildlife poaching [accept ivory poaching or elephant poaching; accept ivory trafficking or wildlife trafficking] [10e] This actor produced the documentary Virunga about poaching in the DRC. This actor was interviewed by the FBI for links to the 1MDB scandal after starring in The Wolf of Wall Street. ANSWER: Leonardo DiCaprio [or Leo DiCaprio; or Leonardo Wilhelm DiCaprio] [10h] This group led by Ahmad Umar gets some of its funding from conflict ivory. This al-Qaeda affiliate once ran a Covid treatment facility in Jilib in Middle Juba. ANSWER: al-Shabaab [or Harakat al-Shabaab al-Mujahideen; or Ḥarakat ash-Shabāb al-Mujāhidīn; or Hizb al-Shabaab; or Islamic Emirate of Somalia; or Ḥarakat ash-Shabāb al-Mujāhidīn; or Xarakada Mujaahidiinta al-Shabaab; prompt on The Youth] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~25047~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. A formula for this quantity is carved on the gravestone of Ludwig Boltzmann. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this quantity, which in the aforementioned formula, is proportional to the log of the number of microstates. This quantity measures the amount of disorder in a system. ANSWER: entropy [prompt on S] [10m] This statement states that the entropy of a closed system approaches a constant value as temperature approaches absolute zero. ANSWER: third law of thermodynamics [prompt on third law] [10h] This scientist was the first to formulate the third law of thermodynamics using his namesake heat theorem. This scientist names an equation that can be derived from the Butler–Volmer equation by setting the reaction rate to zero. ANSWER: Walther Nernst [or Walther Hermann Nernst; accept Nernst heat theorem or Nernst equation] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~25986~ <Editor: June Yin>

21. A hotel named for this word burned down after James Bentley was cleared of wrongdoing in James Scobie's death. For 10 points each: [10m] Give this word that names a fortification constructed by gold miners following an oath sworn on Bakery Hill in the suburb of Ballarat. ANSWER: Eureka [accept Eureka Stockade or Eureka Hotel or Eureka Rebellion] [10h] The Eureka Stockade took place in Ballarat in this state, whose "Marvellous" alliterative capital developed as a result of the 1850s gold rush. ANSWER: Victoria [10e] During the Eureka Rebellion, gold miners hoisted a flag displaying the "Southern" type of this religious symbol, which features on the flags of Australia and New Zealand. ANSWER: Southern Cross [or Crux] <Noah Chin, History - World - Miscellaneous> ~24957~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: conductor (The first sentence refers to the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra.)
Text: 1. A New York-based organization named after Orpheus is famous for not employing anyone in this profession. Neville Marriner joined this profession a decade after founding the Academy of St.-Martin-in-the-Fields. The third member of this profession to have an exclusive contract with Decca is Riccardo Muti's designated successor, Klaus Mäkelä. Marin Alsop was the first woman to win this profession's (*) Koussevitzky Prize, whose namesake founded summer programs at Tanglewood while leading Boston's member of the American "Big Five." A Venezuelan youth organization named after Simón Bolívar was directed by this profession's member Gustavo Dudamel. For 10 points, what profession's members use a baton to lead an orchestra? ANSWER: conductor [or word forms like conducting; or music director; or director of music; prompt on artistic director] (The first sentence refers to the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra.) <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Music - Recent> ~26113~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

2. In one novel by an author born in this country, an anarchist becomes a Jesuit after the burning of an all-female hostel. A nun from this country authored the psychological treatise "The Transfiguration of the Commonplace" after ending an affair with a one-armed artist. This is the birth country of the novelist of The Girls of Slender Means, who created a set of schoolgirls dubbed the crème-de-la-crème by the (*) fascist-sympathizing teacher Miss Jean ("jeen") Brodie. In a novel from this birth country of Muriel Spark, the title character saves the Jewish nurse Rebecca from burning at the stake and is helped by the disguised Black Knight to marry Lady Rowena - that novel is Ivanhoe. For 10 points, name this home country of Robert Burns and Walter Scott.  ANSWER: Scotland [or Alba; prompt on United Kingdom or Great Britain; reject "England" or "Wales"] <Noah Chin, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~30265~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

3. Applying this technique to Crypto·meria japonica reveals at least five SEP events named for Fusa Miyake. This technique uses standards in the IntCal series and is complemented by a calculation involving the standard PDB ratio obtained from the Pee Dee Belemnite. Measurements in this technique are depressed by the emissions-driven Suess effect and are inflated by the marine reservoir effect. Willard Libby won a Nobel for this technique that accounts for a (*) "bomb pulse" from when nuclear tests altered atmospheric concentrations. Calibration curves for this technique are produced by applying it to tree rings. For 10 points, name this technique that uses the 5,730-year half life of a 14-dalton isotope to measure age. ANSWER: radiocarbon dating [or carbon-14 dating or C14 dating or 14C dating; prompt on radioactive dating or radiocarbon analysis; reject "relative dating"] ("SEP" stands for "solar energetic proton.") <Rohan Kher, Science - Other Science> ~29741~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. Maureen Murdock identified an "identification with" and "shift" towards the "masculine" in her adaptation of this concept for women. While the original name of this concept was taken from Finnegan's Wake, its popular name emerged in the 1980s from two documentaries, a biography of its creator and an interview with Bill Moyers. This concept was divided into 17 stages with names like "Freedom to Live" and (*) "Belly of the Whale." This concept was introduced in a book titled for a figure "with a Thousand Faces," where the first of this concept's three acts begins with "The Call to Adventure." For 10 points, name this concept proposed by Joseph Campbell about a path shared by legendary figures across cultures. ANSWER: Hero's Journey [or monomyth; accept Heroine's Journey; prompt on hero or heroine; prompt on The Hero with a Thousand Faces] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~30614~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

5. Flight attendant Gabriele von Lutzau is called the "Angel of" this city for supporting hijacking victims. West German counterterrorism organizations rescued passengers in this city after the hijacking of Lufthansa Flight 181. During a 1992 famine, UNITAF dropped leaflets over this city. Operation Gothic Serpent aimed to capture Mohamed Farrah Aidid in this city. A Mark Bowden book describes a battle in this city during a civil war initiated by rebels against (*) Siad Barre. Three American Sikorskys were shot down during a battle in this city, as detailed in Black Hawk Down. Though active in the Gulf of Aden, piracy spiked off the coast of this capital in the 1990s. For 10 points, name this capital of Somalia. ANSWER: Mogadishu <Rohan Kher, History - World - African> ~29698~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. An anonymous 9th-century Buddhist poet who left many of their poems in these places is referred to as the "Cold" one of these places. In one novel, a Taoist monk at one of these places explains that a character's "tragedy" is returning to "a normal life among normal people." This is the first title place in an ancient classic that describes 550 of these places alongside a list of mythological (*) beasts. In a novel titled for one of these places, the narrator "I" starts an ephemeral relationship with "She" and begins searching for one of these places after learning that his cancer diagnosis was misdiagnosed. The "sound" of one of these title places disturbs Shingo Ogata in a Kawabata novel. For 10 points, Gao Xingjian wrote a novel titled for a "Soul" one of what type of geographical features? ANSWER: mountains [accept Hanshan or Cold Mountain; accept Soul Mountain; accept Classic of Mountains and Seas or Shanhai jing; prompt on monastery by asking "what kind of place is that monastery located in?"] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~31169~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

7. Philippe Van Parijs ("pah-REE") asked, "what (if anything) can justify capitalism?" in a 1995 book advocating this policy that theorized the concept of "real freedom." Finland became the first country to implement this policy during a trial from 2017 to 2018. The results of this policy can be replicated by a kind of "negative tax" championed by Milton Friedman. An example of this policy, which definitionally does not use means testing, is enacted by a (*) Permanent Fund supported by Alaska's oil revenue. To counter the effects of automation, a program of this type called the Freedom Dividend was proposed by Andrew Yang. For 10 points, name this type of welfare program that transfers money to all citizens, regardless of need. ANSWER: universal basic income [or UBI; or guaranteed income; or unconditional basic income; or citizen's income; or basic income guarantee; or universal demogrant; accept the Freedom Dividend or Permanent Fund Dividend or dividend until "dividend" is read; prompt on social security; prompt on welfare until read; prompt on government payment] <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Other> ~30508~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

8. An effect named for this word increases the lability of certain ligands in square planar complexes, such as one that contains platinum. Upon absorbing a photon, the pigment retinal enters a state of being entirely described by this word. When the two groups with the highest priority according to CIP ("C-I-P") rules are described by this word, a (*) double bond has an E configuration. Substituents added by an "anti" addition are described by this word. Partial hydrogenation produces a type of unsaturated fat known by this word that is banned in many countries due to its health effects. For 10 points, give this word that describes a conformation in which groups are on opposite sides of a bond, contrasted with cis. ANSWER: trans [accept trans configuration or trans isomer; accept trans effect; accept all-trans retinal; accept trans fat] <June Yin, Science - Chemistry> ~29745~ <Editor: June Yin>

9. Edward R. Murrow visited this city's Japanese Modern Sinatra House, designed by Black architect Paul R. Williams. One of the first steel frame houses in the world was built in this city in the late 1920s by modernist architect Richard Neutra and is called the Lovell Health House. Floor-to-ceiling glass characterizes Pierre Koenig's Stahl House in this city. The (*) Eames House is one of the Case Study Houses in this city being preserved by researchers at its Getty Conservation Institute. The Maya-influenced Ennis House built by Frank Lloyd Wright in this city can be seen in a film set here, Blade Runner. For 10 points, name this city where homes were once advertised with a sign reading, "HOLLYWOODLAND." ANSWER: Los Angeles [or LA; accept Beverly Hills; accept Hollywood until "HOLLYWOODLAND" is read] <Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Architecture> ~29753~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

10. To obtain a navigational quadrant that had been stolen by this island's people, a man followed their custom of drawing a circle on the ground, sitting in it, and negotiating. The first king of this island's Pōmare Dynasty acquired firearms from a band of mutineers who were later captured by the HMS Pandora. An observatory was built on this island by James Cook to track the 1769 transit of Venus. Before settling (*) Pitcairn Island, Fletcher Christian abducted women from this island, where he had earlier gathered breadfruit for the HMS Bounty. The most famous resident of this island's town of Pape'ete was Paul Gauguin ("go-GAN"). For 10 points, name this island which contains the capital of modern-day French Polynesia. ANSWER: Tahiti [or Otaheite] <Yingzhi Nyang, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~29523~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

11. Women performing this activity like Texas Guinan and Gertrude Lythgoe benefited from laws limiting the activity of male police. For engaging in this activity in Cincinnati, George Remus was prosecuted by Mabel Walker Willebrandt. To do this activity, Bill McCoy made voyages from Bimini in the Bahamas. Long lines of (*) ships near ports such as Galveston and off the coast of New Jersey were "rows" for "runners" who did this activity. Businesses performing this crime were raided by the Untouchables, led by Eliot Ness. Al Capone made most of his wealth from this crime, which supplied illegal speakeasies. For 10 points, name this crime in which products banned under Prohibition were smuggled. ANSWER: bootlegging [accept rum-running; accept any answer describing illegally smuggling or selling or providing alcohol; accept moonshine running or smuggling moonshine or other specific types of alcohol; prompt on smuggling alone; prompt on running a speakeasy or a store; prompt on being a criminal] <Rohan Kher, History - American - 1865-1945> ~29678~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: thymine (The analog in the lead-in is BrdU. dT oligomers hybridize with mRNAs' poly(A) tails. The HIV drug is AZT. The promoter motif is the TATA box.)
Text: 12. Substituting a methyl in this molecule with a bromine yields an analog that is tagged in to monitor the cell cycle. Beads coated in oligomers of this molecule are used to isolate mRNA. An azide-containing mimic of this molecule was the earliest HIV drug. This common nucleobase is distinguished by two carbonyl groups and one methyl group. This is the first nucleobase in the name of a promoter motif that appears (*) 30 bases upstream of the transcription start site. This nucleobase creates kinks in DNA when it dimerizes due to UV radiation. This is the second DNA nucleobase in the start codon and the first one in stop codons. For 10 points, name this pyrimidine that is mimicked by uracil and pairs with adenine. ANSWER: thymine [or thymidine or deoxythymidine or thymidine monophosphate or azidothymidine or Thy; prompt on T or or TMP or dT or dTMP or AZT or TATA box] (The analog in the lead-in is BrdU. dT oligomers hybridize with mRNAs' poly(A) tails. The HIV drug is AZT. The promoter motif is the TATA box.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~29611~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: William Carlos Williams (Williams' wife Flossie wrote the "Reply" to "This Is Just To Say" in the first line; the unnamed poem in the second and third lines is Williams' "Asphodel, That Greeny Flower.")
Text: 13. This author is asked to "Please shut off the telephone" in a "Reply" crumpled on a desk. This man wrote, "I come, my sweet, to sing to you" in a poem to his wife that uses this author's triadic line style. This poet claimed that all women "have Helen in their hearts" in that poem, whose title "green and wooden" object can be found in hell. In a poem set when his wife and baby are asleep, this author asked, "Who shall say I am not / the happy genius of my household?". This poet of (*) "Danse Russe" wrote, "Forgive me" in a 28-word note to his wife describing some "sweet" and "cold" objects. For 10 points, name this Imagist poet who confessed to eating "the plums / that were in / the icebox" in his poem "This Is Just To Say." ANSWER: William Carlos Williams (Williams' wife Flossie wrote the "Reply" to "This Is Just To Say" in the first line; the unnamed poem in the second and third lines is Williams' "Asphodel, That Greeny Flower.") <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Poetry> ~30047~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

14. Moses and the seventy elders of Israel see some of these objects made of sapphire under God's feet after they ascend Mount Sinai. Following the Ashkar-Gilson manuscript, the song "Mi Chamocha" is written in a layout that represents these objects. Either the material used to make these objects or to bind them together is represented by a mixture of chopped fruits and nuts in which a Hillel sandwich is dipped called (*) charoset. After Moses and Aaron say "let my people go," Pharaoh retaliates by forcing the Israelites to make these objects without straw. Many visitors to the Kotel slip prayer notes into the spaces between these objects. For 10 points, name these often baked objects that include limestone ones used to build Western Wall. ANSWER: bricks [or mud bricks; or l'venah; accept sapphire brickwork or l'venah ha-sapir; accept limestone bricks or limestone blocks; prompt on limestone] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Jewish Practice> ~29559~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

15. This modern-day country is home to millennia-old stone shelters called bunja ("BOO-nya"). The sport of Picigin ("peets-EE-geen") originated at the beaches of a city in this country that used to be called Spalato. A military unit composed of the majority ethnic group of this country helped popularize the necktie. The only Roman amphitheater that still has its four side towers fully preserved is in this country's city of (*) Pula. Knin ("ke-NEEN") was the capital of this modern country's breakaway Serbian state of Krajina ("kra-YEE-na"). The former Venetian colony of Rovinj ("roh-veen-nya") is a highlight of this country's Istrian region. This country's coastal city of Split is the largest city in its region of Dalmatia on the Adriatic. For 10 points, name this country whose capital is Zagreb. ANSWER: Croatia [or Republic of Croatia; or Hrvatska; or Republika Hrvatska] <Michael Bentley, Geography - Europe> ~30379~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. This family's member Susan wrote an essay in opposition to women's suffrage and impressed Charles Darwin with her nature diary Rural Hours. Samuel Morse helped decorate Otsego Hall for this family's patriarch, William. A member of this family wrote a "descriptive tale" of his hometown featuring Oliver Effingham and Judge Marmaduke Temple called The (*) Pioneers. In a town named after this family, a variant of rounders was legendarily invented by the future Civil War general Abner Doubleday. Mark Twain critiqued the "literary offenses" of an author from this family whose father names the town home to the Baseball Hall of Fame. For 10 points, an author from what family wrote about Natty Bumppo in The Last of the Mohicans? ANSWER: the Cooper family [or Fenimore Cooper family; accept Susan Fenimore Cooper; accept William Cooper; accept James Fenimore Cooper; accept Cooperstown or the Coopers; prompt on Fenimore as it was used as a compound last name by some members of the family] <Forrest Weintraub, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29719~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

17. In a novel by this author, a woman lifts her head to see a "great map" on a street sign, which she follows back to a supermarket where she had earlier looked for food. In another novel by this author, cross-border travel arranged by the Maphia, spelled with a "p-h," eventually allows people to die. This author of Death with Interruptions described how a man is stabbed with a stiletto heel when he tries to sexually assault a girl with dark (*) glasses in a novel whose main characters are initially quarantined in a mental health hospital. In that novel by this author, only the doctor's wife does not get the titular "white sickness." For 10 points, name this Portuguese Nobel Laureate, the author of Blindness. ANSWER: José Saramago ("zhoo-ZAY suh-ruh-MAH-goo") [or José de Sousa Saramago] <Halle Friedman, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~14345~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

18. Straight trajectories within these devices were first demonstrated via Maltese cross-shaped shadows. Ferdinand Braun pioneered these devices by using a "cold" component to supplement thermionic emission. In these devices, two pairs of deflection coils determine position on a phosphor screen. Evacuation of these devices was improved by William (*) Crookes, who demonstrated deflection by pressing magnets against them. These devices were central to the earliest oscilloscopes. J. J. Thomson used these devices to discover the electron. Liquid crystals and OLEDs have supplanted the inclusion of these devices in electronic displays. For 10 points, name these devices found in analog television screens. ANSWER: cathode ray tubes [or CRTs or vacuum tubes; accept Crookes tubes or Crookes–Hittorf tubes until "Crookes" is read; prompt on Crookes tubes or Crookes–Hittorf tubes after “Crookes” is read; prompt on evacuated tubes or discharge tubes or gas-filled tubes or Plücker tubes or CRTs] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~29596~ <Editor: David Bass>

19. This artistic style was criticized as "decorative" by Amédée Ozenfant ("ah-meh-DEE oh-zen-FANT"), who founded the Purist movement in response to this style. Statues of harlequins with instruments in this style were created by Jacques Lipchitz. "To understand Cézanne is to foresee [this style]," according to a treatise co-written by the artist of the painting Tea Time. Jean Metzinger was primarily associated with this style, whose name was derived from a critique of (*) Houses at L'Estaque by Louis Vauxcelles ("voh-SELL"). Juan Gris ("gree") coined the terms "analytic" and "synthetic" for this style's periods, the former of which includes Georges Braque ("brock"). For 10 points, name this style which deconstructs subjects into geometric shapes, like in paintings by Pablo Picasso. ANSWER: Cubism [or Cubist; accept analytic Cubism or synthetic Cubism or Crystal Cubism or proto-Cubism or Orphic Cubism; prompt on Orphism] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~29856~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

20. These objects replace the mention of the British in the chorus of Portugal's national anthem, written during the Pink Map ultimatum. Exhibitions of these objects at Alfred Krupp's estate inspired his nickname. A rule named for these objects historically defined a country's international waters. Apocryphally, the first Victoria Crosses were made from these objects. Alfred Dreyfus was accused of selling secrets about these (*) weapons, handheld types of which were first used during the Hussite Wars. In 1866, Queen Victoria was gifted one of these weapons modeled after the Ottoman Basilisc, which the Hungarian engineer Orban designed to break Constantinople's walls in 1453. For 10 points, name these heavy artillery weapons. ANSWER: cannons [accept artillery until mentioned; accept mortars; accept cannon-shot rule; accept bombards; prompt on guns; prompt on weapons until read] <Sean Farrell, History - European - Misc> ~29660~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

21. In 1875, suffragist Frances Power Cobbe founded a society to advance this cause. Clay objects were introduced into one activity by a New York advocate of this cause named Henry Bergh. A militant group advocating this cause emerged from the Band of Mercy and inspired "gag" laws protecting an industry they oppose. An 1809 oration by Thomas Erskine in the House of Lords on this cause sought to outlaw certain "baiting" activities. A (*) "liberation front" shares part of its name with a 1975 book advocating this cause by Australian philosopher Peter Singer. This cause was advocated for by the National Anti-Vivisection Society. For 10 points, name this cause advocated for by groups such as the ASPCA and PETA. ANSWER: animal rights [or animal welfare; or animal liberation; accept answers like preventing animal cruelty or ending animal testing; accept banning vivisection or banning live animal dissections or being part of the National Anti-Vivisection Society before "vivisection" is read; prompt on vegetarianism or veganism or not eating animals or ending factory farming] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30615~ <Editor: Michael Bentley> NSC 2025 - Round 19 - Bonuses

1. Muslims and Islamic scholars debate the contested historical accounts of these lines. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these lines from the 53rd surah of the Qur'an. Their validity is challenged since they seem to permit the worship of the goddesses al-Lāt, al-ˊUzzā, and Manāt. ANSWER: Satanic Verses [or al-Gharāniq Verses] [10e] The Satanic Verses are said to be "not…from God" by this archangel who revealed verses of the Qur'an in the cave of Hira. ANSWER: Gabriel [or Jibril or Jibreel or Jibra'il] [10h] Description acceptable. In editing one of these works partly titled "Rasūl Allāh," Al-Tabari decided to include the Satanic Verses omitted by Ibn Hisham. A subset of these sources known as maghāzī documented military campaigns. ANSWER: biographies of Muhammad [or prophetic biography; or sīra or sīrat; or As-Seerat al-Nabawiyyah or Sīrat Rasul Allāh; prompt on biography or biographies] <Alyssa Jorgensen, RMP - Islam> ~16921~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

2. Julie Wheelwright claimed this woman's performances of supposed Javanese religious rituals led her to be viewed as a "nude of art." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this exotic dancer who, after being identified by French intelligence as "H-21," was executed in 1917 for espionage. ANSWER: Mata Hari [or Margaretha Geertruida Zelle; or Margaretha Geertruida MacLeod] [10e] Hari was executed for spying for this country, whose defeat in World War I led to the overthrow of Kaiser Wilhelm II. ANSWER: Germany [or Deutschland or Allemagne] [10h] Allied propaganda contrasted Hari with Edith Cavell, a British woman with this profession executed by Germany in 1915 for helping soldiers escape occupied Belgium. This was the profession of the first Black British woman to write an autobiography, Mary Seacole. ANSWER: nurse [or nursing; prompt on medicine or medical care or healthcare; reject "doctor"] <Jamie Burchett, History - European - 1900+> ~25737~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

3. Sofie Zamchick played this person in Eve Sussman's short film 89 Seconds at Alcázar, which fictionalizes the moments before and after a 1656 painting. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this person, who in a painting in the Prado, is seen from the point of view of her parents, who themselves are depicted in a mirror next to a lit doorway. ANSWER: Infanta Margarita Theresa [or Margarita Theresa of Spain or Margaret Theresa; prompt on Theresa or Infanta] [10e] The Infanta Margarita and her court appear in this Diego Velázquez painting. ANSWER: Las Meninas [10h] The composition of the Infanta Margarita and her servants in Las Meninas inspired John Singer Sargent’s painting of this man’s daughters, one of whom plays with a doll while two others in white dresses stand next to a large blue-and-white porcelain vase.  ANSWER: Edward Darley Boit [accept The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~24788~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

4. In the Old East Slavic poem The Tale of Igor's Campaign, Vseslav ("vuh-seh-slahv") of Polotsk turns into one of these creatures in order to travel long distances at night. For 10 points each: [10e] Many Slavic tales describe people who share characteristics with what creatures, who are sometimes called lycanthropes? ANSWER: wolves [or wolf or werewolves or werewolf] [10m] In response to claims that The Tale of Igor's Campaign was a forgery, this author of the 1820 poem Ruslan and Ludmila said no-one was good enough to fake it. ANSWER: Alexander Pushkin [or Alexander Sergeyevich Pushkin] [10h] Vseslav of Polotsk is sometimes identified with Volkh ("volc") - or "wolf" - Vseslavevich ("vuh-seh-slahv-uh-vitch"), one of these knights ubiquitous in Old East Slavic poems. A group of three of these warriors included Ilya Muromets. ANSWER: bogatyrs ("boh-guh-TIERS") <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Poetry> ~24515~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

5. These orbitals and p orbitals have the smallest shifts from spin–orbit coupling because they have the least values of orbital angular momentum. For 10 points each: [10e] Name these spherical atomic orbitals with angular momentum quantum number l-equals-zero. ANSWER: s orbitals [10m] The Lamb shift in the energy gap between 2s and 2p orbitals is due to fluctuations in this thing. Pair production causes "polarization" of this thing. ANSWER: vacuum [accept QED vacuum] [10h] In degenerate perturbation theory, this effect causes the separation of "mixed" states that are linear combinations of 2s and 2p orbitals. This effect is the splitting of spectral lines due to an external electric field. ANSWER: Stark effect <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~24778~ <Editor: David Bass>

6. Populations from the Nov. 2024 BC and Dec. 2024 Louisiana human HPAI cases featured the E186D mutation in this protein. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this antigen that, alongside neuraminidase, is used to name IAV subtypes. An assay for antibodies against a given virus measures inhibition to this protein's binding to sialic acid. ANSWER: hem·agglutinin [or HA; prompt on H] [10e] The LA sample unexpectedly lacked the PB2 M631L mutation, which occurs in most bird flu infections of this ruminant livestock species with scientific name Bos taurus. ANSWER: cows [or cattle; prompt on bulls or steers or heifers or bullocks] [10m] Viral zoonosis also caused the evolution of HIV from SIV, which is named for this infraorder that contains the namesake species of SIVcpz and SIVsmm. ANSWER: simians [or Simiiformes or anthropoids or Anthropoidea; prompt on apes or monkeys or primates by asking "what infraorder is that in?"] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~25524~ <Editor: David Bass>

7. In the 1830s, Connecticut experienced a so-called "mania" for growing this crop. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this fruit that names a "row" of slave quarters at Monticello. Bandits' Roost was a tenement alley off a New York street named for this fruit, photographed by Jacob Riis. ANSWER: mulberries [or Mulberry Mania; or Mulberry Row; or Mulberry Street; or Morus alba] [10m] In a failed attempt to start a silk industry, hundreds of mulberry trees were planted in this city's Trustees' Garden. James Oglethorpe created two dozen squares in this city, founded as the capital of a debtors' colony. ANSWER: Savannah [10e] As owner of Savannah's Mulberry Grove Plantation, Nathanael Greene's widow Catharine helped Eli Whitney design a gin for processing this other crop. ANSWER: cotton [or cotton gin] <Cooper Roh, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24672~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

8. Yuja Wang played this excerpt as an encore at her 2023 Rachmaninoff marathon with the Philadelphia Orchestra. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this four-movement ballet sequence with a prominent flute solo from the Paris version of Christoph Gluck's opera Orfeo ed Euridice. This excerpt plays after the Furies let Orpheus into Elysium. ANSWER: "Dance of the Blessed Spirits" [or "Danse des esprits bienheureux"; or "Dance of the Happy Shades"] [10m] In the Paris version of Orfeo ed Euridice, Orpheus is sung by a haute-contre, or French countertenor, instead of this type of singer. These male singers could sing soprano parts. ANSWER: castrato [or castrati; accept evirato or evirati] [10e] Gluck originally wrote "Dance of the Blessed Spirits" for a ballet about this womanizer who is dragged to Hell at the end of a Mozart opera. ANSWER: Don Juan [or Don Giovanni; prompt on Juan or Giovanni] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Opera> ~24627~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

9. In this story, a man who stands "like Saint Sebastian" fantasizes about only being able to find a Black doctor for his mother, and awkwardly asks a Black man for matches although he has no cigarettes. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this story, in which Julian's mother dies of a stroke after trying to give a penny to a Black boy whose mother wears the same ugly hat as her. ANSWER: "Everything That Rises Must Converge" [10e] Everything That Rises Must Converge" was written by this Southern Gothic author of stories like "A Good Man Is Hard to Find." ANSWER: Flannery O'Connor [or Mary Flannery O’Connor] [10h] In this O'Connor short story, Mary Grace yells "Go back to hell where you came from, you old wart hog" and throws a book at Ruby Turpin in a waiting room after hearing her racist tirade. ANSWER: "Revelation" <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Short Fiction> ~25518~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

10. A work written during this event called for women to be able to identify their children's fathers. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this 1789 uprising during which Olympe de Gouges ("oh-LIMP de GOOZH") wrote a feminist critique of the Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen. ANSWER: French Revolution [or Révolution Française; prompt on the Revolution] [10m] Edmund Burke's reactionary Reflections on the Revolution in France were critiqued in a Mary Wollstonecraft book titled for this word, which also titles her book on "the rights of woman." ANSWER: vindication [accept A Vindication of the Rights of Man; accept A Vindication of the Rights of Woman] [10h] Joseph de Maistre ("zho-SEFF de MESS-truh") argued that God punished Enlightenment philosophers for abandoning this view by causing the French Revolution. Plato's Euthyphro ("YOO-thi-fro") examines this ethical theory that claims we should do what God wants. ANSWER: divine command theory [or DCT; or theological voluntarism; prompt on command theory; prompt on voluntarism] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~24768~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

11. George Henry Lewes ("Lewis") claimed that one character's death in this manner was "giving currency to a vulgar error," though a novel’s preface argues it had been observed "beyond all rational doubt." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this manner of death that Mr. Guppy and Mr. Jobling find has killed the alcoholic rag and bone man Krook in an 1853 novel. ANSWER: spontaneous combustion [or spontaneous human combustion; or SHC; prompt on combustion; prompt on fire or burning or bursting into flames or immolation or alcoholism or drinking] [10m] After Krook spontaneously combusts in this novel, a will found among his papers complicates the Chancery court case Jarndyce and Jarndyce. Esther Summerson narrates this novel.  ANSWER: Bleak House [10e] Bleak House is the only novel with a female narrator by this author. This author depicted Miss Havisham dying from her burns after her dress catches fire in Great Expectations. ANSWER: Charles Dickens [or Charles John Huffam Dickens] <Jamie Burchett, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~24662~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

12. For 10 points each, name the following figures from Greek mythology depicted by statues in London's Hyde Park. [10m] Jacob Epstein's The Rush of Green depicts this god next to a family playing with their dog. King Midas is given donkey ears after he chooses this god over Apollo in a musical contest. ANSWER: Pan [10h] Hyde Park is separated from Green Park by the Wellington Arch, which contains a bronze statue of this deity riding a quadriga chariot. Zelus, Bia, Kratos, and this deity are the children of Styx and Pallas. ANSWER: Nike [prompt on Victory] [10e] Another Hyde Park statue dedicated to Wellington depicts this Greek hero. Paris kills this hero of the Trojan War by shooting an arrow at his heel. ANSWER: Achilles [or Achilleus] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~24490~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

13. This instrument is traditionally created from eucalyptus trees that have been attacked by termites. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this long wind instrument developed by Aboriginal Australians that produces a low drone. ANSWER: didgeridoo [10m] Didgeridoo players like Mark Atkins can hold notes for extended periods of time by employing this technique. A performer uses this technique by inhaling through the nose while simultaneously exhaling into their instrument. ANSWER: circular breathing [10h] Didgeridoos are traditionally accompanied by percussion instruments that are named for this action. Indian classical music uses rhythmic patterns called talas, whose name derives from the word for this action. ANSWER: clapping [accept clapsticks] <Aum Mundhe, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~24530~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

Answer: merge conflicts Linus Torvalds developed this predominant version control system, which has a three-letter name. "-Hub" is a code-sharing website represented by Octocat. ANSWER: Git
Text: 14. Drawing on Darcs, the version control system Jujutsu treats these issues as first-class objects. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these issues that result from ambiguous requests to merge diverged branches. Index files surround the text that causes these issues with repeated inequality symbols. ANSWER: merge conflicts [or edit conflicts] [10e] Linus Torvalds developed this predominant version control system, which has a three-letter name. "[this system]-Hub" is a code-sharing website represented by Octocat. ANSWER: Git [or GitHub.com] [10m] Resolving merge conflicts can involve this command, which typically follows "git add" and precedes "git push." Like "git branch," this command uses the "dash-m" flag to supplement a message. ANSWER: commit [or git commit or commits] <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25527~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. Zhuge Liang anecdotally left his fort unguarded to feign an ambush, causing an army of this state led by Sima Yi to retreat. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this state founded by Cao ("tsao") Pi, the son of Cao Cao, with its capital at Xuchang before being moved to Luoyang. ANSWER: Cao Wei [10m] Wen Ping, a general for the Wei, also used the Empty Fort Strategy to defeat the troops of this state. This state warred with the Wei and the Shu during the Three Kingdoms period. ANSWER: Eastern Wu [or Dong Wu; or Sun Wu] [10e] The founder of this dynasty, Li Yuan, later Emperor Gaozu, employed a similar strategy against the Göktürks. The An Lushan rebellion caused the decline of this dynasty, which preceded the Song. ANSWER: Tang dynasty <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - World - Asian> ~25739~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

16. This author wrote "Do not remember me / as disaster / nor as the keeper of secrets" in the poem Movement Song. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this author of Sister Outsider who advocated for intersectional feminism that centers Black women's concerns in "The Master's Tools Will Never Dismantle the Master's House." ANSWER: Audre Lorde [10h] Lorde depicted the intersection between Blackness and lesbianism in this "biomythography" titled for "a Carriacou ("carry-ah-koo") name for women who work together as friends and lovers." ANSWER: Zami: A New Spelling of My Name [10e] This earlier author included black feminist themes in works such as Sweat. This author wrote about Janie Crawford in the novel Their Eyes Were Watching God. ANSWER: Zora Neale Hurston <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24597~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

17. A 2021 book by Kathryn Paige Harden on why this field "Matters for Social Equality" makes heavy use of GWAS ("JEE-WASS") studies. For 10 points each: [10e] Identify this field that has spawned direct-to-consumer businesses such as 23andMe, which offers saliva-based testing and mapping. ANSWER: genetics [accept answers like genes or DNA or gene testing or genomics; prompt on biology or medicine or ancestry] [10h] This oncologist explored efforts such as the Human Genome Project in his book The Gene, a follow-up to his best-selling The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer. ANSWER: Siddhartha Mukherjee [10m] Several critics have compared Harden's book to this pseudo-scientific 1994 book by Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray with a mathematical title. This book argues that much of human intelligence is inherited. ANSWER: The Bell Curve [or The Bell Curve: Intelligence and Class Structure in American Life] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~25057~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

18. Many animals move their bodies repetitively in response to this stimulus in the process of entrainment. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this stimulus. Although it's a myth that exposing children to this stimulus increases their IQ, it does increase the likelihood that they develop perfect pitch. ANSWER: music [accept classical music; prompt on sound or auditory stimulus] [10m] Douglas Hofstadter explored self-reference and repetition in math, art, and music in this book titled after a mathematician, an artist, and a composer. ANSWER: Gödel, Escher, Bach [or Gödel, Escher, Bach: an Eternal Golden Braid; accept GEB] [10h] Robert Gjerdingen applied the theory of these concepts to repetitive musical forms from the 18th century in his book Music in the Galant Style. In genetic epistemology, these patterns of thought organize information into categories. ANSWER: schemata [or schemas; accept galant schemata] <Forrest Weintraub, Social Science - Psychology> ~25007~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

19. Identify the following about Leon Trotsky's career in exile, for 10 points each. [10m] Trotsky wrote articles for Der Forverts while briefly living in this American borough. Unscrupulous landlords hired arsonists to burn apartments for insurance money during a period in the 1970s when this borough was "burning." ANSWER: The Bronx [10h] Despite opposition from Vidkun Quisling, in 1935 Trotsky secured a Norwegian entry visa from this Justice Minister. This Norwegian served as the first General Secretary of the UN. ANSWER: Trygve Lie [or Trygve Halvdan Lie] [10e] Trotsky was ultimately assassinated by Ramón Mercader while living in this country, where he had an affair with Frida Kahlo. ANSWER: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25067~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

20. Since they have near-zero enthalpy of mixing, heptane and hexane are a commonly cited example that this law applies to. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this higher concentration analogue of Henry's law. Positive and negative azeotropes deviate from this law in opposing directions. ANSWER: Raoult's law [10e] Zero enthalpy of mixing characterizes the ideal type of these systems, which Raoult's law applies to. The concentration of these mixtures can be given as molarity or molality. ANSWER: solutions [10h] The effect of interactions on enthalpy of mixing is reflected by the parameter chi ("kye") in this theory of polymer solutions. Chi appears in an equation for Gibbs free energy in this doubly eponymous theory. ANSWER: Flory–Huggins solution theory <Sean Farrell, Science - Chemistry> ~24732~ <Editor: June Yin>

21. This author's relatives in the banking industry informed her character Leo, a bank teller who is pressured to steal railroad bonds. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this author, whose childhood inspired Toys in the Attic. This author of Watch on the Rhine wrote about teachers accused of a lesbian affair in The Children’s Hour. ANSWER: Lillian Hellman [10m] Hellman’s family inspired the Hubbard family in this play and its prequel. In this play, Regina Giddens allows her husband Horace to die of a heart attack after he threatens to change his will, and blackmails her brothers to wrest control of a cotton mill.  ANSWER: The Little Foxes (The prequel is Another Part of the Forest.) [10h] Hellman's relationship with Dashiell Hammett led him to fictionalize her as a character with this name in The Thin Man. James Joyce's play Exiles was inspired by his time in Trieste with his lover with this name. ANSWER: Nora [accept Nora Barnacle; accept Nora Charles] <Sean Farrell, Literature - American - Drama> ~24631~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: Germany (The lead-in is August Sander. The second line is Joseph Beuys.)
Text: 1. A photographer from this modern-day country captured a pastry chef and bricklayer as part of his People of the 20th Century. A performance artist from this country who frequently worked with felt was photographed holding a staff as he shared a room with a coyote. An artist from this country created characteristically horizontal, flat photos, including two series depicting a river and (*) 99-cent stores. In a picture from this country's capital, watches were edited off the wrist of a man raising a flag over its Parliament building. A soldier jumps over a barbed wire fence in a city in this modern-day country where graffiti depicted a leader kissing Leonid Brezhnev. For 10 points, name this home country of Andreas Gursky where Peter Leibing photographed the Berlin Wall. ANSWER: Germany [or Deutschland; accept East Germany or West Germany] (The lead-in is August Sander. The second line is Joseph Beuys.) <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Photography> ~30548~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. Public promises about "labor, fare, and board" in these places were made by Edmund Du Cane. An 1823 act named for these places was championed by Quaker Elizabeth Fry, whose advocacy for them built on the work of John Howard. It's not a street, but "fleet marriages" were named after one of these places. Anti-Catholic protesters painted the phrase "His Majesty, King Mob" on the walls of one of these places during the (*) Gordon Riots. Ships on the Thames called "hulks" often doubled as these places in Britain. Historic examples of these places included Marshalsea and one next to the River Fleet. Charles Dickens was a critic of types of these places meant specifically for debtors. For 10 points, name these places that housed English convicts. ANSWER: British prisons [accept jails; accept gaols or Gaol Act; accept local prisons or convict prisons or debtors prisons; accept penitentaries or penal facilities; accept borstals] <Rohan Kher, History - European - 1500-1900> ~30195~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

3. A "clash" of this property was a common issue on 8-bit computers such as the Commodore 64. German Romantic Philipp Otto Runge ("RUN-ghee") wrote a book on a "sphere" of this property. A viral 2025 paper by Fong et al announced a new form of this property called olo. Cylindrical coordinates are used to represent this property in the HSL and (*) HSV systems. A book on how humans perceive this property influenced Thomas Johann Seebeck and was written by Goethe ("GUR-tuh"). A matching system for this property widely used in fashion design is offered by Pantone. Software "pickers" of this property often give 256-cubed distinct values for this property as hex codes. For 10 points, name this property described by printers' "CMY" values and RGB codes. ANSWER: colors [prompt on hues or shades] <David Bass, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~31065~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

4. This phenomenon and ram pressure are the two main drivers of the destruction of dwarf satellite galaxies via "stripping." Quiescent supermassive black holes can become transiently observable when a star’s orbit is "disrupted" by this phenomenon. This phenomenon, whose magnitude is proportional to the negative-third power of (*) distance, causes Io's volcanism and the spaghetti·fication of objects near black holes. The same half of a satellite always faces the body it orbits due to this phenomenon's namesake "locking." "Spring" and "neap" periods named for this force occur when the Sun's gravitational pull reinforces or opposes the Moon's. For 10 points, name this force that drives oscillations in sea level. ANSWER: tidal force [or tides; accept tidal stripping or tidal disruption events or tidal locking; prompt on gravitational force or gravity until "gravitational" is read] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Other Science> ~29600~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. A subgenre named for this place titles a 1950 Jack Vance short story collection that includes the story "Mazirian the Magician." Golan Trevize and Janov Pelorat set out with Bliss on a journey to find this place in a novel that followed Foundation's Edge. A trilogy named for this place takes place on a supercontinent named the "stillness" and opens with the novel (*) The Fifth Season. The "Spacer" culture and overcrowding on this planet is depicted in a novel where Elijah Bailey meets and teams up with the robot Daneel Olivaw. After entering the interior of this planet through a dormant volcano, Professor Otto Lidenbrock discovers a vast underground ocean and dinosaurs. For 10 points, a journey to the center of what planet titles a Jules Verne novel? ANSWER: the Earth [accept The Dying Earth; accept Foundation and Earth; accept The Broken Earth trilogy; accept Journey to the Center of the Earth] <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~31114~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

6. Cylindrical components called "stitching vias" interface with a pair of components that are named for "power" and this process. This process names a copper foil "plane" in PCBs. This process names the bus on a breadboard denoted with a blue or black line. Three slanted lines distinguish a "chassis" component for this process from the typical component depicted with three stacked (*) horizontal lines of decreasing length. Zero voltage is typically defined relative to the site of this process, and this process dissipates a build-up of static electricity. This process is performed by the third terminal on AC outlets. For 10 points, name this process in which excess charge is safely directed into the Earth. ANSWER: grounding [accept word forms, like grounded; accept ground plane or signal ground of chassis ground or Earth ground or earthing] <Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~29592~ <Editor: David Bass>

7. Isata Kanneh-Mason recorded pieces by this composer, such as a scherzo ("SCARE-tso") in C minor, on her debut album Romance. Brahms, Joachim, and this composer were the most prominent supporters of "absolute music" in the "War of the Romantics." This composer popularized performing piano sonatas and other "serious music" alongside virtuosic works and, like Liszt, popularized performing from memory. This composer likely inspired another's "year of (*) lieder," whose products include Dichterliebe ("DEEK-ter-lee-beh"). A nickname for this composer titles the short piano piece "Chiarina" ("kee-ah-REE-nah"). After another composer entered an asylum, his works were promoted by this daughter of Friedrich Wieck. For 10 points, name this composer whose husband wrote Carnaval. ANSWER: Clara Schumann [or Clara Josephine Wieck; accept just Wieck until it is read and prompt thereafter; prompt on Schumann or C. Schumann] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~30802~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

8. The speaker of a poem by this author says "I want to trade my horse for her house, my saddle for her mirror, my knife for her blanket" after describing a girl held "up above the water" by an "icicle of moon." One of this author's poems repeatedly uses the same color to describe "flesh," "hair," "wind," and "branches." "Body Laid Out" and "The Spilled Blood" are sections of an elegy by this poet, whose line (*) "Green, how I want you green" opens "Sleepwalking Ballad." A poem by this author repeats the line "at five in the afternoon." Leonardo and the Bridegroom duel in a play by this poet of "Lament for the Death of a Bullfighter." For 10 points, what Spanish author's "Rural Trilogy" includes Blood Wedding? ANSWER: Federico García Lorca [or Federico del Sagrado Corazón de Jesús García Lorca] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - European - Poetry> ~29587~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

9. While visiting a king, a ruler of this empire reveals goat legs after mistaking a glass floor for a pool of water. The question "Of what doth the Glory of Kings consist?" appears in the opening of this empire's national epic. Makeda was the mother of this empire's legendary founder, who requests only a tassel but is instead given the entire Ark of the Covenant by his father. The (*) Kebra Nagast is the national epic of this empire, whose 14th century contact with the Portuguese led this empire to be labeled the new home of the mythical king Prester John. Yekuno Amlak claimed to be a direct descendant of the Queen of Sheba when founding the Solomonic Dynasty of, for 10 points, what East African Christian empire? ANSWER: Ethiopia [or Ethiopian empire; accept Abyssinia; accept Kingdom of Aksum; prompt on Sheba with "what other kingdom did that ruler lead?"; prompt on the South] <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~30612~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

10. One of the first instances of this specific practice was accompanied by a poem that compares the writer's life to "a fossil tree, from which we gather no flowers." Before this practice, people bathed in cold water, wore white clothing, and ate their favorite foods. The leader of the Shield Society performed this practice at the end of an event at the JSDF in which he gave a quiet speech from a (*) balcony after a coup d'etat attempt. The kaishakunin stood behind those performing this practice, which included an object like a tanto wrapped in cloth. 46 of the 47 Ronin were ordered to commit this action after a successful revenge killing. For 10 points, name this gruesome practice where samurai would disembowel themselves. ANSWER: seppuku [or harakiri; prompt on less specific answers like suicide by sword or stabbing] <Lalit Maharjan, History - World - Asian> ~29684~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

11. Bid'ah may be defined as changes made after this number of generations following Muhammad; the Salafi movement is named for that number of generations. The Hadith of Gabriel is commonly interpreted as enumerating this many levels of faith. Excluding Zoroastrians, the Quran explicitly lists this many People of the Book. One must wait this many months to remarry after ending an Islamic marriage, which can be done by saying (*) talaq this number of times. This many jamarat can be struck during the Stoning of the Devil. Zakat, or almsgiving, is the Islamic pillar of this number. This many caliphs [emphasize] precede Ali in Sunni belief. For 10 points, most of Islam rejects the notion of a God with how many persons that form the Trinity? ANSWER: three [accept triple talaq] <Sean Farrell, RMP - Islam> ~29688~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

12. This equation is expanded to account for inner and outer sphere electron transfers when used in Marcus theory. This equation supports the rule of thumb that the Q10 coefficient for biological systems is typically between 2 and 3. In a modification of this equation from transition state theory, "the transmission coefficient times Boltzmann's constant times temperature, all over Planck's constant" replaces a quantity equal to (*) steric factor times collision frequency. In this equation, e is raised to the power of negative activation energy over RT and multiplied by the pre-exponential factor. For 10 points, identify this equation that relates temperature to the reaction rate constant, named for a Swedish chemist. ANSWER: Arrhenius equation [prompt on Eyring equation] <Clark Smith, Science - Chemistry> ~18940~ <Editor: June Yin>

13. Artists at a postcard workshop in this city who designed Brussels' Stoclet Palace included Koloman Moser. The "Glasgow Four" were Arts and Crafts designers who influenced artists in this city who sought to "show the modern man his true face." In a wall painting in this city, daughters surround a figure with a monkey's body and snake's tail, Typhon. An art gallery in this city was designed by Joseph Maria (*) Olbrich for artists published in the newspaper Ver Sacrum. A dress covered in eyes is worn in a portrait of a socialite from this city, Adele Bloch-Bauer. An artist from this city created the Beethoven Frieze and a gold leaf painting of a couple embracing. For 10 points, what city's "Secession" movement included The Kiss by Gustav Klimt? ANSWER: Vienna [or Wien; accept the Vienna Secession] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~31153~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

14. This text claims that the word "wait" "rings in the ear" with "piercing familiarity." This text notes that everything Hitler did in Germany was "legal" after its author likens himself to people "willing to face hungry lions." One of the "two honest confessions" in this text decries "a negative peace which is the absence of tension." This text quotes (*) St. Augustine by saying that "an unjust law is no law at all." The author explains his disappointment in the "white moderate" and describes how he is "compelled to carry the gospel of freedom" in this text to his "fellow clergymen." The author of this text wrote "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere" on a smuggled-in newspaper. For 10 points, name this text by Martin Luther King Jr. written while imprisoned in Alabama. ANSWER: "Letter from Birmingham Jail" [or "Letter from a Birmingham Jail" or "Letter from Birmingham City Jail" or "The Negro is Your Brother"] <Lalit Maharjan, Literature - American - Misc> ~29779~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

15. The Carter administration pulled millions in aid to this country after US Ambassador Adolph Dubs was killed during a hostage rescue attempt. A conflict in this country was the origin of the term "Cargo 200" for flights in which soldiers were returned in zinc coffins. In 2004, this country adopted a new constitution at a loya jirga. A young refugee born in this country named Sharbat Gula gained global fame in a 1985 Steve McCurry cover photo for (*) National Geographic. Texas's Charlie Wilson helped get Stinger missiles delivered to this country's mujahideen in a conflict often dubbed the "Vietnam" of the Soviet Union. For 10 points, name this country invaded in 2001 by the US following the September 11 attacks. ANSWER: Afghanistan [or Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan or Kingdom of Afghanistan or Republic of Afghanistan or People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30471~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

16. A love triangle involving characters from this city was likely inspired by one in Jorge de Montemayor's Seven Books of the Diana. A chorus says that what their summary of events in this city "shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend." The dog Crab belongs to Launce, a servant from this city, whose master attempts to force himself on Silvia and is named Proteus. "We lay our scene" in this (*) "fair" city in a prologue that describes "Two households, both alike in dignity" before a scene in which a servant bites his thumb. The author of a play about "Two Gentlemen of" this city used it as the setting for a play that coined the phrase "star-cross'd lovers." For 10 points, name this setting of Romeo and Juliet. ANSWER: Verona [accept The Two Gentlemen of Verona] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - British - Drama> ~29525~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

17. Motorized wooden canoes called pinasses work ports on this river such as Korioumé ("koh‑RYOO‑may"). This river flows due north at its origin in the Fouta Djallon highlands. In the 19th century, Hamdullahi in this river's internal delta served as the capital of the Massina Empire. A Scottish explorer who both mapped this river and died on it was named (*) Mungo Park. This river is called the Joliba in the language of the Mandinka people. The upper portion of this river terminates at the Sotuba Dam near Bamako in Mali. Over thirty million people live in the "Oil Rivers" of this river's delta on the Gulf of Guinea. For 10 points, name this river that shares its name with an African country with capital at Niamey. ANSWER: Niger River [accept Joliba until read] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~30582~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

18. A book titled Among [this city's workers] was written by Lucy Larcom, whose autobiography recounts her move here from Beverly Farms. The LFLRA, a labor union in this city, included activist Sarah Bagley, who published the Offering. This city was founded by and named for an industrialist partly named Francis Cabot, who patented a power loom. The Rhode Island system was succeeded by a system named for (*) Waltham and this city, which hired young people between 15 and 35 to work in centralized, strictly supervised factories. This city's system improved upon Samuel Slater's model by hiring young women known as its "mill girls." For 10 points, the "cradle of the American Industrial Revolution" was what Massachusetts town? ANSWER: Lowell [accept Lowell mill girls or Lowell system or Waltham-Lowell system or Lowell Female Labor Reform Association or Lowell Offering; accept Francis Cabot Lowell] <Rohan Kher, History - American - Pre-1865> ~30196~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

19. Description acceptable. Robert Darnton offered a "thick description" of this phenomenon in Bourbon France, the British Raj, and East Germany. The History of Sexuality argues that this practice operated as "a regulated and polymorphous incitement to discourse." An "invisible" form of this practice occurs in television, according to a Pierre Bourdieu essay. The Supreme Court established a three-pronged test for this practice in Miller v. California. One version of this practice, (*) prior restraint, is restricted by the First Amendment. Lord Chamberlain could exercise this practice over any British play until 1968. For 10 points, name this practice by which political actors prevent the dissemination of art or information. ANSWER: censorship [accept word forms; accept banning books; accept any description indicating the prohibition or suppression or restriction or banning of writing or reading or speaking or publishing; prompt on deeming works obscene by asking "what is the result of that?"] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Other> ~30856~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

20. The NAM population of this species was created by crossing with its B73 inbred line in order to pioneer nested association mapping. Rollins A. Emerson’s work on an "unstable mutation" in this species was later elucidated as the Ac/Ds system. It's not N. crassa, but a retired George Beadle made 50,000 crosses of an ancestor of this species with it. Delta endotoxins from B. thuringiensis are produced by this species’ (*) "Bt" type. Coloration in this species is controlled by "jumping" genes, or transposons, which were discovered in this species by Barbara McClintock. This teosinte-derived crop is in the genus Zea. For 10 points, name the major ingredient in U.S. production of ethanol and high-fructose syrup. ANSWER: corn [or maize or Zea mays or Glass Gem corn] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~29610~ <Editor: David Bass>

21. In the chapter "Beyond Sandy Hook," this poet described throwing his textbooks into the ocean. This poet declared "I'm the man who sailed those early seas" in a poem that asks "Who said the free? … Surely not me?" This author of the autobiography The Big Sea wrote "the stars went out and so did the moon" before a man "slept like a rock or a man that's dead." This poet wrote "I've seen its (*) muddy bosom turn all golden in the sunset" and "I bathed in the Euphrates when dawns were young." This poet wrote "my soul has grown deep like the rivers," and in another poem, asks whether one concept will "dry up / like a raisin in the sun?" For 10 points, name this Harlem Renaissance poet of Montage of a Dream Deferred. ANSWER: Langston Hughes [or James Mercer Langston Hughes] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~30601~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson> NSC 2025 - Round 20 (TB B) - Bonuses

1. Richard Thaler compiled evidence of a "curse" common to these markets. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these markets, which may be first-price or second-price, in which participants act based on private valuations. These markets and matching markets are the main subjects of market design. ANSWER: auctions [or auction markets] [10h] This economist developed a sealed-bid auction in which the winner's cost depends on the size of losing bids. This economist also pioneered congestion pricing. ANSWER: William Spencer Vickrey [10e] Rights to produce this output, which causes climate change, are auctioned off under California's cap-and-trade program. A Canadian tax on this greenhouse gas is assessed at 20 cents per liter of gasoline. ANSWER: carbon dioxide emissions [or CO2 emissions; accept carbon tax; prompt on emissions] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Economics> ~25532~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

2. This is the alternate title of a painting in which a girl in a red dress and a black hat rests her hands on a black picture frame. For 10 points each: [10h] Give this title of a late 1660s painting in the Rijksmuseum ("reeks-museum") by the same artist in which a man in gold rests his hands on a woman in red, whose religious affiliation has been debated.  ANSWER: The Jewish Bride [or Het Joodse bruidje; prompt on Portrait of a Couple as Isaac and Rebecca or Isaak en Rebekka by asking "what other title is given to the painting?"] (The other Jewish Bride is more commonly called The Girl in a Picture Frame.) [10e] This Dutch painter of The Jewish Bride and The Night Watch depicted himself leaning out over a ledge in one of his dozens of self-portraits. ANSWER: Rembrandt [or Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn] [10m] Rembrandt depicted his wife Saskia holding out a flower to the viewer in a painting of her as Flora, a goddess who stares at the viewer in this other painting. A blue spirit lunges out of a tree in this painting, which depicts the Three Graces dancing in an orange grove. ANSWER: Primavera [or Spring] (by Sandro Botticelli) <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~24983~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

3. Early forms of this process, such as the Burton process, are described as "thermal." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this process commonly employed during oil refining in the petroleum industry. In this process, kerogens or long-chain hydrocarbons are broken down into simpler molecules. ANSWER: cracking [accept thermal cracking; accept fluid catalytic cracking; prompt on FCC] [10h] This process, which was discovered by two German scientists, produces hydrocarbons from a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide. ANSWER: Fischer-Tropsch process [or FT process] [10e] This hydrocarbon is a common product of cracking. This simplest alkene with formula C2H4 forms a polymer that is commonly used in plastic bags. ANSWER: ethylene [or ethene; accept polyethylene] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~25778~ <Editor: June Yin>

4. The book America Is in the Heart describes an author farming with water buffalo during his boyhood in this country. For 10 points each: [10h] Name the birthplace of that author of an essay accompanying Rockwell's Freedom from Want. Another author from this country wrote a "farewell" poem ending "to die is to rest" before his execution by firing squad. ANSWER: the Philippines [or Republic of the Philippines; or Republika ng Pilipinas] (The second unnamed author is José Rizal.) [10e] Carlos Bulosan recalled his life as a migrant during this time period in his America Is in the Heart. Steinbeck's Of Mice and Men is set during this period in American history. ANSWER: the Great Depression [accept the 1930s; prompt on the Dust Bowl] [10m] The book alludes to how this author described a "Philippine temptation" in a 1901 satire. This author of Roughing It condemned the Philippine-American War in "The War Prayer."
