ANSWER: Mark Twain [or Samuel Langhorne Clemens] (The unnamed satire is "To the Person Sitting in Darkness.") <Kevin Wang, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~24749~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

5. In Istanbul, people in this job who deviated from a 110 dirhem standard had their ears nailed to a door. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this job. A New York law regulating the working hours of people in this job was overturned in the Lochner decision. ANSWER: bakers [accept answers such as breadmakers or bread seller or pastry chef; prompt on retailer or shop owner or cook or chef or retail worker or restaurant worker] [10e] In most of Europe in the Middle Ages, bakers began in this role, where they would get on-the-job training from the master bakers they lived with before becoming journeymen in the guild system. ANSWER: apprentices [prompt on trainees] [10h] This country's Socialist Party pioneered the use of Borbeck ovens to provide pastries for its working classes. It's not the UK, but Karl Marx was expelled from this country after publishing The Communist Manifesto. ANSWER: Belgium [or Kingdom of Belgium] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25475~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

6. Maria Dahvana Headley translated this poem's opening word as "Bro!" For 10 points each: [10e] Name this work, which inspired Headley's novel The Mere Wife. J. R. R. Tolkien's lecture "The Monsters and the Critics" contrasts Grendel and the dragon in this Old English epic poem. ANSWER: Beowulf [or "Beowulf: The Monsters and the Critics"] [10m] This poet compared translating Beowulf to bringing down a megalith with a toy hammer. This Irish poet wrote "the squat pen rests" in "Digging." ANSWER: Seamus Heaney [or Seamus Justin Heaney] [10h] In "Hasped and Hooped and Hirpling," Terry Eagleton reviewed Heaneywulf in a London magazine of this title. Irina Dumitrescu reviewed Headley's Beowulf in a New York magazine of this title, known for its line of underappreciated "classics." ANSWER: The London Review of Books [or LRB; or The New York Review of Books; or NYRB; or NYRB Classics] <Michael Bentley, Literature - British - Other> ~23755~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

7. Certain beaked whales perform this behavior during deep dives, but not during successive shallow dives. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this behavior in which animals search for food. ANSWER: foraging [accept forage; prompt on hunting or predation or predatory behavior by asking "what is the more general ecological term?"] [10m] Schreer and Kovacs 1997 relates this quantity with maximum diving depth in air-breathing mammals. Allometry is the study of this quantity, which is described by Foster's rule and related to cancer rate by Peto's paradox. ANSWER: body size [or body mass or body volume; prompt on answers given without "body"] [10h] A scientist with this surname pioneered decompression tables. His son with this surname wrote "On Being the Right Size," pioneered primordial soup theory alongside Oparin, and names a "rule" for inferring heterogametic sex from hybrid sterility. ANSWER: Haldane (John Scott Haldane is the father of J. B. S. Haldane.) <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~26089~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. One of these people is central to the religion of Ravidassia, which split from another faith after the 2009 assassination of Niranjan Dass, who held this title, in Vienna. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this title that followers ascribe to Ravidas instead of the lesser bhagat. The last person with this title performed the first Amrit Sanchar on the Panj Pyare. ANSWER: gurus [accept Sikh gurus or gurus of Sikhism; accept Guru Ravidas; accept Guru Gobind Singh] [10e] Ravidas contributed 41 poems to this holy text and current guru of Sikhism. ANSWER: Guru Granth Sahib [or Adi Granth] [10h] An engraved one of these things belonging to Ravidas is located in front of Meera's temple in Chittorgarh. The word paduka sometimes refers to examples of these things that are often venerated. ANSWER: footprints [accept footsteps; accept foot marks; accept pada; prompt on prints or steps or foot or feet or toes; prompt on footwear or shoes or sandals with "what other things does that term refer to?"] <Jeremy Cummings, RMP - Other Religion> ~25793~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

9. Pennies are mockingly placed on this family's gravesite in Green Mount Cemetery. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this family that included John Wilkes, who shot and killed the 16th president at Ford's Theatre. ANSWER: Booth [10h] John Wilkes Booth's brother Edwin had earlier saved this politician from an accident on a train platform. This man served as Secretary of War under James Garfield and Chester A. Arthur. ANSWER: Robert Todd Lincoln [prompt on Lincoln or R. Lincoln] [10m] John Wilkes Booth, perhaps inspired by his father's name, Junius Brutus Booth, uttered this phrase when he shot President Lincoln. This three-word Latin phrase is the state motto of Virginia. ANSWER: sic semper tyrannis <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - American - 1865-1945> ~25270~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. A recent book on "When [This Company] Comes to Town" documents how its cost-cutting proposals led to a death on Disney's Big Thunder Mountain. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this consulting firm, which makes up the "Big Three" with Boston Consulting Group and Bain. ANSWER: McKinsey & Company [10e] This politician's time working for the Boston Consulting Group was used in attack ads during his failed 2012 bid for President. In 2023, this Utah senator announced his retirement. ANSWER: Mitt Romney [or Willard Mitt Romney] [10h] In 2023, the Court of Auditors ruled that this man's government had an "inappropriate" reliance on McKinsey. In 2024, this politician refused to appoint Lucie Castets as Prime Minister. ANSWER: Emmanuel Macron [or Emmanuel Jean-Michel Frédéric Macron] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~25049~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

11. The number of these structures distinguishes MLPs from SLPs. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these substructures of neural networks that come in "convolution" and "pooling" types in CNNs. The "deep" in "deep learning" refers to large numbers of these structures. ANSWER: hidden layers [10h] The number of hidden layers is an example of these quantities that determine how a machine learning model trains. Nested cross validation "optimizes" or "tunes" these quantities that can include regularization terms and learning rates. ANSWER: hyperparameters [accept HPs or HPO or hyperparameter optimization; prompt on parameters] [10e] HPO can be performed naively via a "search" over one of these structures in hyperparameter space. Graph paper features these lattices of squares. ANSWER: grids [or grid search] <David Bass, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25562~ <Editor: David Bass>

12. Despite being instrumental in its creation, this politician was forced to resign after the election of the First Duma. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this first Prime Minister of Russia who drafted the October Manifesto after the 1905 Revolution. This politician advocated for a closer alliance with China. ANSWER: Sergei Witte [10m] Witte negotiated this treaty ending the Russo-Japanese War. Theodore Roosevelt became the first American Nobel Peace Prize winner for negotiating this treaty. ANSWER: Treaty of Portsmouth [10e] Witte rose in government by overseeing the construction of a railroad project named for being "Trans" this cold, vast region of eastern Russia. ANSWER: Siberia [or Trans-Siberian Railroad] <Jamie Burchett, History - European - 1500-1900> ~24628~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

13. The Suda claims that this author's husband was Kerkylas of Andros, which roughly translates to "Little Penis from Man Island." For 10 points each: [10e] Name this author who was portrayed as a promiscuous heterosexual woman in Athenian comedy. Anne Carson's If Not, Winter translates the works of this poet from Lesbos. ANSWER: Sappho of Lesbos [10m] Ambroise ("ahm-BWAHZ") Phillips originated the practice of translators heterosexualizing this Sappho poem that refers to the speaker's ex-lover as a woman. This poem describes its title figure as "deathless" and "of the spangled mind." ANSWER: "Ode to Aphrodite" [or Sappho 1; or fragment 1] [10h] Authors like Pontano and Martial compared Sappho's poetry to Sulpicia's extremely heterosexual erotic poems in this genre. This genre has a "Menippean" form. ANSWER: satire [accept Menippean satire] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~24511~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

14. Contests between members of this occupation were judged according to a rulebook called the Tabulatur. For 10 points each: [10m] Hans Sachs ("zahks") led Nuremberg's guild for what occupation, as depicted in a Richard Wagner ("REE-card VAHG-ner") opera? ANSWER: meistersingers [or master-singers; accept Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg or The Master-Singers of Nuremberg; prompt on singers; prompt on musicians; prompt on poets] [10e] Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg's ("dee MY-ster-zing-er fon NOORN-berg's") scene "Wacht auf" ("vakt owf") quotes a poem by Sachs that calls this composer a "Wittenbergish Nightingale." This man wrote "A Mighty Fortress Is Our God" and the Ninety-Five Theses. ANSWER: Martin Luther [10h] According to legend, the first meistersingers were twelve singers from this tradition that included Wolfram von Eschenbach and Tannhäuser ("TAHN-hoy-zuh"). This tradition exalted, and was named for, a Middle High German word for courtly love. ANSWER: minnesang ("MIN-uh-zahng") [accept minnesingers or minnesänger ("MIN-uh-zeng-uh"); accept minne ("MIN-uh")] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~24492~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

15. After fleeing from Arcadia to an island in this city, Arethusa was transformed into a spring in an attempt to escape Alpheus's pursuits. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this city home to the island of Ortygia. A monarch of this city apocryphally invited Damocles to take his place on the throne beneath a sword suspended from string. ANSWER: Syracuse [or Siracusa or Sarausa or Seragusa or Syrakousai or Syracusae] [10e] Ortygia was the reputed birthplace of this Greek goddess, whom Leto gave birth to a day earlier than her twin brother Apollo. ANSWER: Artemis [reject "Diana"] [10m] Ortygia was legendarily created when this deity's mother Asteria fled from Zeus as a quail. According to Hesiod, Artemis saved Iphigenia ("if-uh-juh-NAI-uh") by transforming her into this torch-carrying triple goddess. ANSWER: Hecate <Sean Farrell, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~24599~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

16. James Clerk ("CLARK") Maxwell created a parody of Robert Burns' poem "Comin' Thro the Rye" about how one these objects "Sings." For 10 points each: [10m] Name these objects whose rotation is described by Euler's ("OILER’s") equations. In these objects, the distance between each pair of points remains constant at all times. ANSWER: rigid bodies [or rigid objects] [10e] Euler's equations describe the change of the angular velocity vector when this quantity is applied. This quantity is the rotational analogue of force. ANSWER: torque [prompt on tau or M or N] [10h] Euler's equations can be broken into three components when these objects define the reference frame. These objects are the eigenvectors of the inertia tensor. ANSWER: principal axes [or principal axes of inertia; accept principal axis; prompt on axes or axis] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~25026~ <Editor: David Bass>

17. The empress Kassi was the wife of a holder of this position named Sulayman who maintained relations with the Marinids. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this position held by leaders named Maghan, whose powers were regulated by the Kouroukan Fouga ("koo-ROO-can FOO-guh"). The architect and poet al-Sahili accompanied a holder of this position. ANSWER: mansa [or emperor of the Mali Empire; or king of the Mali Empire; or leader of the Mali Empire; or emperor of the Mandinka ;or king of the Mandinka; prompt on leader or king or emperor] [10e] Before being divorced by Mansa Suleyman, Kassi gained the favor of many in the royal court, including those who earlier followed this mansa who made an extremely expensive pilgrimage to Mecca. ANSWER: Mansa Musa [or Musa Keita I] [10m] Kassi was said to have ruled jointly with her husband according to this author, who recounted his travels across Africa in his travelogue The Rihla. ANSWER: Ibn Battuta <Noah Sheidlower, History - World - African> ~25783~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

18. This opera's libretto includes passages from the Bhagavad Gita and Charles Baudelaire. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this opera in which Pasqualita sings a Tewa lullaby about a "cloud flower" that blossoms in the north. This opera’s opening chorus proclaims that "energy may become matter." ANSWER: Doctor Atomic [10e] This composer wrote Doctor Atomic. This composer also wrote Short Ride in a Fast Machine and Nixon in China. ANSWER: John Adams [or John Coolidge Adams; reject "John Luther Adams"] [10h] To close out Act I, J. Robert Oppenheimer performs this aria in which he repeats "knock, breathe" and "break, blow." The aria’s common title or the poem it was drawn from is acceptable. ANSWER: "Batter my Heart" [accept "Batter my heart, three person'd God" or Holy Sonnet XIV] <Joseph Chambers, Fine Arts - Opera> ~25257~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

19. In The Book of the City of Ladies, Lady Rectitude commends this woman for returning to plan a marquis's wedding. For 10 points each: [10h] Many European folktales describe what woman obediently enduring cruel tests by her husband? In a version of her story, Gualtieri ("g'wal-T'YAIR-ee") pretends to put her children to death. ANSWER: Griselda [accept Patient Griselda] [10e] The latter version of the Griselda story appears in this Boccaccio ("bo-KAH-cho") work, in which ten Florentines tell each other stories during a plague outbreak. ANSWER: The Decameron [or Il Decamerone] [10m] This author wrote a 1695 novella adapting the Griselda story. The stories "Diamonds and Toads" and "Bluebeard" appear in this French author's collection of fairy tales attributed to Mother Goose. ANSWER: Charles Perrault ("sharl peh-ROH") <Joseph Chambers, Literature - European - Short Fiction> ~25237~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

20. This philosopher's paper "On Denoting" argues that all propositions involving the non-existent present king of France are false. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this philosopher who argued that theists had the burden to prove God's existence in his essay "Why I Am Not A Christian." ANSWER: Bertrand Russell [or Bertrand Arthur William Russell, 3rd Earl Russell] [10h] In "On Denoting," Russell attacks this philosopher for granting a form of being to non-existent objects like round squares; such objects are said to inhabit this philosopher's "jungle." ANSWER: Alexius Meinong ("MY-nong") [accept Meinong's jungle] [10e] Russell argues that Meinong's non-existent objects violate a principle forbidding these statements. A claim is assumed false in the first step of a "proof by [these statements]." ANSWER: contradictions [accept the law of contradiction or the law of non-contradiction; prompt on paradoxes] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~25088~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

21. Theodor Fontane wrote a poem about the Tay Disaster, one of these events in Scotland. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these disasters. Barney Elliott filmed an unsuccessful attempt to rescue a dog during one of these events in Washington in 1940. ANSWER: bridge collapse [or bridge failure; accept anything involving the destruction of a bridge; prompt on collapse or failure] [10e] An 1807 bridge collapse killed 2,000 people during a festival in this city when the Eitai Bridge failed. Over 100,000 people were killed in American firebombing of this capital city in 1945. ANSWER: Tokyo [or Edo] [10h] In Switzerland's worst rail disaster, a bridge in Münchenstein designed by this engineer failed in 1891. A company named for this man changed its name after he resigned in disgrace during the Panama Scandal. ANSWER: Gustave Eiffel [or Alexandre Gustave Eiffel; or Alexandre Gustave Bonickhausen dit Eiffel] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25477~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

1. Aristotle defined this phenomenon's "violent" type as contrary to something's nature. John Philoponus rejected Aristotle’s theory of this phenomenon by developing a concept that Jean Buridan reintroduced to the West. A book preceding one titled for "first philosophy" defines this phenomenon as a reduction from potentiality to actuality. A being who does not exhibit this phenomenon but imparts it unto others is the subject of cosmological arguments and often called the (*) "first cause." The theory of impetus concerns this phenomenon, which a thinker argued was impossible with a paradox involving an arrow. Zeno's paradoxes argue for the impossibility of, for 10 points, what phenomenon exhibited by non-stationary things? ANSWER: motion [or movement or change or kinesis or motus; accept impetus until read; accept unmoved mover or prime mover; accept violent motion; accept natural motion; accept speed or velocity or momentum] <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~29602~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

2. An unnamed book in this novel describes a burial on a snowy day and sparks a conversation that leads to the second request for a one-tenth payment. The business of a crystal merchant in this novel is boosted by cleaning the crystal and putting up a display case. The prologue of this novel recounts a version of the myth of (*) Narcissus where the lake mourns because it can no longer see its beauty reflected. A quote from this novel is "If you want something, all the universe conspires in helping you achieve it." The protagonist of this novel crosses a sea after having a recurring dream of a boy leading him to the pyramids. For 10 points, the shepherd Santiago goes on a journey in search of treasure in what novel by Paulo Coelho ("coe-EL-yo")? ANSWER: The Alchemist <Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30824~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

3. Thomas McEvilly ("mack-uh-vill-ee") criticized this museum for omitting dates on indigenous artwork in a "Primitivism" exhibition organized by William Rubin. This museum's 1970 Information exhibition included Hans Haacke polling visitors about its former president's support for the Vietnam War. This museum, whose minimalist architecture was designed by Yoshio Taniguchi, hired Frank (*) O'Hara as a curator. This museum has analyzed the cobalt paint in one of its paintings that depicts cypress trees breaking up a swirling sky. A 1958 fire at this museum caused paintings like Christina's World to be evacuated to the Whitney Museum. For 10 points, Starry Night and The Persistence of Memory are in what New York City contemporary art museum? ANSWER: Museum of Modern Art [or MoMa; reject the "Metropolitan Museum of Art" or "the Met"] <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - 1945+> ~31154~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

4. This politician claimed that his government's fundamental task was to promote the development of "productive forces." The First Great Debate pitted the dogmatic Whateverist faction against this politician, who promoted the motto "seek truth from facts." This politician used the pragmatist "cat theory" to justify "Socialism with [his country's] characteristics." This politician toured the South of his country in 1992 to promote the establishment of (*) Special Economic Zones oriented towards foreign trade, such as Shenzhen. The "one country, two systems" principle was developed by this predecessor of Jiāng Zémín. For 10 points, name this "architect of modern China" who presided over the Tiananmen Square Massacre. ANSWER: Dèng Xiǎopíng [accept Dengism or Deng Xiaoping Theory] <Forrest Weintraub, History - World - Asian> ~31021~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: polynomials (Bernstein polynomials are used to construct Bézier curves.)
Text: 5. One of these objects provides the weight in Gauss–Jacobi quadrature. Sergei Bernstein names a type of these objects that are used to construct a more general class of objects around control points. Before it was generalized by Stone, these objects were doing the "approximation" in the Weierstrass ("VYE-er-stross") approximation theorem. Namesake simple "nodes" characterize examples of these objects named for (*) Chebyshev, which can mitigate Runge's ("ROON-guh's") phenomenon. Barycentric weights define a type of these objects that were used by Lagrange for interpolation. These objects are partial sums of Taylor series. The fundamental theorem of algebra describes the roots of these expressions. For 10 points, name these sums of monomials. ANSWER: polynomials [accept cyclotomic polynomials or Bernstein polynomials or Chebyshev polynomials or Chebyshev polynomials of the first kind or Chebyshev polynomials of the second kind] (Bernstein polynomials are used to construct Bézier curves.) <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~30284~ <Editor: David Bass>

6. A poem by this author criticizes "fools" who "roar aloud, 'Subscribe, subscribe'" and are "ten times worse when they repent." In that poem, this author asked, "Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?" This poet wrote "drop into thyself, and be a fool" in a poem asserting "the proper study of Mankind is Man." This poet of (*) "Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot" wrote "Fools rush in where angels fear to tread" and "to err is human; to forgive, divine." This author of "An Essay on Criticism" wrote an epic about the goddess Dulness. One work by this poet of The Dunciad details a crime committed by the Baron with a pair of scissors. For 10 points, name this author of a mock-epic about the theft of Belinda's hair, The Rape of the Lock. ANSWER: Alexander Pope <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Poetry> ~30600~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

7. A storm god from this modern-day country is perpetually angry because his brother used his strong legs to push apart their parents, the sky and the Earth. A cannibal goddess from this country was blinded by her mortal husband, whose name means "man-eater." The explorer Kupe was legendarily guided to this country by a "long white cloud" referenced in its indigenous endonym. It's not the US, but a culture hero from this modern-day country stole a (*) goddess's fingernails to bring fire to humanity and lassoed the sun using a rope of hair or a jawbone. This country's northern half was legendarily fished up by Maui. For 10 points, name this island country whose forests are legendarily protected by the flightless kiwi. ANSWER: New Zealand [or Aotearoa] (The storm god and his brother are Tawhirimatea and Tane, the cannibal goddess and her husband are Whaitiri and Kaitangata.) <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - World Mythology> ~30332~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

8. This element is the most common nodulizing element used to form graphite-rich cast iron. This element can be produced via a silicothermic reaction in the Bolzano process or the more cost-effective Pidgeon process. This non-bromine element is extracted by the Dow process and is the third most common ion in seawater. Since this element is a cofactor of Taq ("tack") polymerase, this element's chloride is found in (*) PCR master mixes. This element and calcium can be extracted from dolomite. This element is often used in flares since it gives off an intense white light when burned. The hepta·hydrate of this element's sulfate is Epsom salt. For 10 points, name this second-lightest alkaline earth metal, with atomic number 12. ANSWER: magnesium [or Mg] <Geoffrey Wu, Science - Chemistry> ~31027~ <Editor: June Yin>

9. This man sank in the polls when the AP printed the full French menu of a dinner he had with Andrew Carnegie and Jay Gould at Delmonico's. This politician shielded his future campaign manager Richard Kerens from prosecution in the Star Route scandal. Evidence that this man benefited from Union Pacific payoffs was unearthed in a document that ended, "Kindly burn this letter," known as the (*) Mulligan Letter. While campaigning for this man, Samuel D. Burchard called the Democrats a party of "Rum, Romanism, and Rebellion." This man, who led the Half-Breeds, was called "the continental liar from the state of Maine." For 10 points, name this politician who lost to Grover Cleveland in the 1884 election. ANSWER: James G. Blaine [or James Gillespie Blaine] <Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~31087~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

10. This piece's third movement contains many quiet "flat 7, 1" cadences played in parallel fifths by brass and two pianos. Tenors in this piece sing "equi-ta-vit, ta-vit, ta-vit" to imitate retreating horses. This piece hails "Venus generosa" at the end of "ave formosissima," which segues ("segways") into the reprise of its 3/1 melody "rest, long E, F, D, D." This piece's sections "Cour d'amours" ("COOR dah-MOOR") and "Blanziflor et Helena" follow "In (*) Taberna," where a high bassoon represents a soon-to-be-roasted swan. In this piece's first and last movements, the lyric "semper crescis, aut decrescis" describes an "inconstant" Roman goddess exalted by medieval goliard poets. For 10 points, "O Fortuna" is from what secular cantata by Carl Orff? ANSWER: Carmina Burana <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~29849~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

11. The "pulse" of these events is examined in a book that heavily focuses on Myanmar by James C. Scott titled "In Praise of [These Events]." A medieval structure for monitoring these events was built under caliph Sulayman ibn Abd al-Malik at Roda. Other structures for monitoring these events included flights of stairs and walls marked out in cubits. During Li Zicheng's campaign against the Ming Dynasty, one of these events destroyed (*) Kaifeng. A season called akhet was named for coinciding with one of these events. A regular cycle of these events ended in the 1970s with the completion of a project championed by Gamal Abdel Nasser. For 10 points, name these events, which regularly irrigated the fields in Ancient Egypt. ANSWER: river floods [or inundations; or flood high points; accept Nile floods or intentional floods or seasonal floods or flooding; prompt on rising water levels or falling water levels] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30842~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

12. This man ordered the stoning of Achan for stealing gold and silver meant to be consecrated. God tells this man, "No one will be able to stand against you all the days of your life" as he embarks on a campaign involving a mass circumcision at Gibeath Haaraloth, or the "hill of foreskins." This man's namesake book claims God has only ever heeded a man when, at Gibeon, this man asked God to stop both the (*) sun and moon. A prostitute named Rahab and her family are spared for hiding this man's spies during a battle in which his army is led by seven priests with trumpets while marching with the Ark of the Covenant around a city. For 10 points, name this successor of Moses who conquered Canaan and won the Battle of Jericho. ANSWER: Joshua [or Yehoshua or Jehoshua or Josue or Hoshea] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Hebrew Bible> ~13573~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

13. One of these companies that once worked with Fusion GPS was the subject of Executive Order 14320, which was struck down in May 2025 by Beryl Howell. A month earlier, one of these companies that has Mark Pomerantz on its payroll agreed to allocate forty million dollars over four years to fund "areas of shared interest" such as preventing antisemitism. Paul Weiss was the first (*) white-shoe one of these companies to sign a controversial deal with the Trump administration. A 2023 Florida law hurt these companies by setting a statute of limitations for negligence claims as part of broader tort reforms. For 10 points, name these firms whose employees sometimes provide pro bono representation in court. ANSWER: law firms [accept Big Law or white-shoe law firms or corporate law firms or legal companies; prompt on firms until read] <Michael Bentley, Current Events - U.S.> ~30817~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

14. A 1976 Peter Nowell paper pioneered the evolutionary analysis of these structures. Regions surrounding these structures undergo stromagenesis, which involves the differentiation of fibroblasts into CAFs. Sustained proliferative signaling via autocrine receptors in these structures was identified by Hanahan and Weinberg as one of six "hallmarks." Excessive VEGF in these structures facilitates (*) sustained angiogenesis. Cells adapt to these structures' hypoxic micro·environments by fermenting glucose for energy in the Warburg effect. Impairment of p53 allows these structures to ignore signals to halt growth. For 10 points, name these structures that are either benign or malignant based on whether they metastasize. ANSWER: tumors [or cancer tumors; accept tumor microenvironment or tumor cell populations; prompt on neoplasms or cancers; prompt on cancer cells by asking "what structures do they compose?"] <Rohan Kher, Science - Biology> ~29666~ <Editor: David Bass>

Answer: Six Characters in Search of an Author
Text: 15. During plans to rehearse this play over Zoom, Anna Lundberg and Michael Sheen discuss whether its author was a fascist in the 2020 show Staged. In this play, the heavily-accented proprietor of a so-called "atelier" ("ah-TEL-ee-ay") arrives shortly after a Property Man is told to find a pale blue envelope to place on a table. In this play, the recreation of a (*) hat rack summons Madame Pace ("PAH-chay"), at whose brothel a character encountered his stepdaughter. The Boy commits suicide and the Child drowns in a fountain near the end of this play, after which a man comments that he has "lost a whole day" of rehearsals. For 10 points, the Stage Manager is visited by the title people in what absurdist play by Luigi Pirandello ("pih-ran-DEL-loh")? ANSWER: Six Characters in Search of an Author [or Sei personaggi in cerca d'autore] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Drama> ~27542~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

Answer: Ireland (The second line is about Sean nós.)
Text: 16. This is the westernmost of two regions whose dance is often performed in a "1-2-3 Shuffle," like in a 9/8 dance often done to "strip the willow" at group events. A dance style from this region focuses on the "batter" to eight-count music. Dancers from this region practiced with stones in their hands to keep their arms (*) straight while brushing their feet with crossed legs. This region's Ballet Up and Flat Down dance styles appear in Michael Flatley's show "Lord of the Dance." This region's folk style of ceili ("kay-lee") dancing includes quadrilles, reels, and jigs. This is the westernmost region where shoes called ghillies ("gill-eez") are worn to perform many genres of step dancing. For 10 points, the musical Riverdance is based on the Celtic dance of what island? ANSWER: Ireland [or Éire ("ay-ur"); accept Republic of Ireland; accept Northern Ireland] (The second line is about Sean nós.) <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Ballet/Dance> ~31046~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

17. In Jakob Murer's account of this conflict, pen and ink drawings illustrate a battle cry of "We're eating goose!" In the Three Leagues of Grisons, the Haufens in this conflict secured the local election of the clergy. Monasteries were ransacked early in this conflict while one side fought the Battle of Pavia. During this conflict, Sebastian Lotzer drafted resolutions calling for economic and religious liberty, called the (*) Twelve Articles. Participants in this conflict were called a "murderous horde" by a theologian who opposed a more radical preacher named Thomas Müntzer. Martin Luther opposed the instigators of, for 10 points, what 16th-century rebellion among the lower classes in Germany? ANSWER: German Peasants' War [or Great Peasants' Revolt; or Deutscher Bauernkrieg; or Aufruhr] <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~31059~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

18. In George Vaillant's hierarchy, defense mechanisms associated with this trait are better than immature but worse than mature ones. The mental noise hypothesis is based on this trait's correlation with cognitive failure. Karen Horney ("HORN-eye") described ten needs associated with this trait. Adam Perkins' research into self-generated thought revived claims that this trait is positively correlated with (*) creativity. Increases in this personality trait may indicate dementia. This trait is alternatively called negative affect and is associated with mood disorders like anxiety and depression. This Big Five trait describes sensitivity to stress. For 10 points,  name this trait associated with negative emotions, represented by the N in OCEAN. ANSWER: neuroticism [accept negative affectivity or negative affect until "negative affect" is read; prompt on N until read; prompt on NA; prompt on neurosis or neuroses] <Joseph Chambers, Social Science - Psychology> ~31041~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

19. The Lorenz gauge condition can be written as an equation featuring the term "one over c-squared times this operation applied to the scalar potential." The E-field equals minus-del-phi minus this operation applied to the vector potential. This operation applied to charge density equals the negative divergence of current density by the continuity equation. This operation applied to the displacement field gives displacement current. This operation gives the negative curl of the (*) E-field when applied to the B-field. This operation is applied to magnetic flux to calculate the e·m·f with Faraday's law. This operation applied to charge equals current. For 10 points, name this calculus operation written "d-d-t." ANSWER: partial time derivative [or partial derivative with respect to time; prompt on partial derivative; prompt on d-d-t before the end; prompt on answers describing division by time, like x over time, by asking "what calculus operation is equivalent to dividing by time at an instant?"] <Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~29775~ <Editor: David Bass>

20. In a story by this author, a woman notes that she can kill a calf with a sledgehammer while imagining reuniting with her daughter on Johnny Carson. Dee, who adopts the name Wangero, complains to her mother that her sister Maggie "can't appreciate these quilts" in a story by this author. This author of "Everyday Use" wrote the sequel Possessing the Secret of Joy, which follows Adam and (*) Tashi, after she undergoes genital mutilation. This author looked for Zora Neale Hurston's grave in In Search of Our Mothers' Gardens. A woman is abused by Mister, writes letters to her sister Nettie, and falls in love with Shug Avery in a novel by this author. For 10 points, name this author who created Celie in The Color Purple. ANSWER: Alice Walker [or Alice Malsenior Tallulah-Kate Walker] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~30525~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

21. A priest founded a group called Libera to help female members of these organizations. Three Spanish knights supposedly founded three of these organizations after being shipwrecked near Favignana. One of these organizations initiates members by dropping blood onto a prayer card which is then burnt. Pentiti who betrayed these organizations were key to a 1980s (*) "maxi trial" focusing on them. One of these organizations gets its name from a dialect term likely deriving from the Greek for manly virtue and is called the 'Ndrangheta (in-DRAHN-gay-tah). These organizations often enforce a code of silence called omertà that discourages squealing. For 10 points, the Cosa Nostra is an example of what type of criminal enterprise active in Sicily? ANSWER: Italian mafia [or Sicilian mafia; or the mob; prompt on organized crime or gangs or organized crime families; accept 'Ndrangheta until read] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~28616~ <Editor: Michael Bentley> NSC 2025 - Round 21 (TB C) - Bonuses

1. One poem about this man describes him as "A stray ghost-walker with a ghostly gun." For 10 points each: [10m] Name this historical figure, the subject of an epic poem by Stephen Vincent Benet. A song set to the tune of "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" describes how this man's "soul is marching on." ANSWER: John Brown [10h] In this author's novel The Good Lord Bird, Henry Shackleford follows John Brown and disguises himself as the girl "Little Onion" to escape slavery. This author wrote The Heaven and Earth Grocery Store. ANSWER: James McBride [10e] This author praised Brown in his essay "The Last Days of John Brown." This sometimes-resident of Walden described being jailed for refusing to pay taxes supporting slavery in "Civil Disobedience." ANSWER: Henry David Thoreau <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Misc> ~25465~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

2. Answer the following about drag artist Taylor Mac's 2019 performance of a 24-hour-long show themed around musical history, for 10 points each. [10e] In one section, audience members scrambled for space in a representation of this state's settlement. This state is where "the wind comes sweeping down the plain" in a musical titled for it by Rodgers and Hammerstein. ANSWER: Oklahoma [or OK; accept the Oklahoma Land Rush] [10m] An hour-long sketch set parts of this Savoy opera on Mars. A "little maid" in this opera named Yum-Yum is betrothed to a Lord High Executioner who sings about his "little list." ANSWER: The Mikado [or The Mikado; or, The Town of Titipu] [10h] Mac interspersed several Walt Whitman poems with the compositions by this artist inspired by Black laborers and minstrel shows. This prolific songwriter of the early 1800s wrote "Camptown Races," "My Old Kentucky Home," and "Oh, Susanna!" ANSWER: Stephen Foster <Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~26018~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

3. A five-month dhamma recitation occurred during a fifth Buddhist one of these events in Burma. For 10 points each: [10e] Give this term for meetings of sangha for correcting canon. Many Christian principles were outlined in "ecumenical" examples of these meetings, such as in Chalcedon and Nicaea. ANSWER: councils [accept ecumenical councils or Council of Chalcedon or Council of Nicaea; accept Buddhist councils or Fifth Buddhist Council or Mandalay Council] [10h] The first two Buddhist councils appear in all six of these texts. This collection, which makes up the Tripiṭaka with the Sutta Piṭaka and Abhidamma Piṭaka, contains rules for the sangha. ANSWER: Vinaya Piṭaka [or Vinayas; accept Basket of Discipline] [10m] The sixth Buddhist council lasted two years from one instance of this holiday to another. This holiday commemorates the birth, nirvana, and parinirvana of Siddhartha Gautama. ANSWER: Vesākha [or Vaiśākha or Visak Bochea; accept Buddha Jayanti or Buddha Purnima or Buddha Day] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Buddhism> ~26127~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

Answer: vesicles (The lead-in describes vesicular stomatitis virus.)
Text: 4. Mouths and these structures name the virus whose G protein was used for pioneering experiments by Jennifer Lippincott-Schwartz and James Rothman. For 10 points each: [10m] Name these structures that form within clathrin lattices. The direction of these structures' transport is regulated by COPII ("COP TWO") and COPI ("COP ONE"). ANSWER: vesicles (The lead-in describes vesicular stomatitis virus.) [10e] Vesicles perform exocytosis as the final step in this process. Hormones exit cells via this process that is contrasted with excretion. ANSWER: secretion [accept secretes or secretory pathway] [10h] COPII and COPI are named for composing these vesicle-associated structures that can also consist of clathrin triskelia. Viral capsid proteins are alternatively named in analogy to these structures. ANSWER: vesicle coats [accept coated vesicles or coatamers or coat proteins or clathrin-coated pits or coat protein complex] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~26058~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. According to Strabo, in 166 BC, the Romans made Delos into a free port to wreck the trade of this island. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this island whose residents sold military equipment to build a structure dedicated to Helios after a failed siege. Chares of Lindos built that structure on this island. ANSWER: Rhodes [or Ródos; accept Rhodians; accept Colossus of Rhodes or Kolossós tes Rhódou or ho Kolossòs Rhódios] [10e] Rhodes' maritime economy was very similar to this civilization they traded with, which founded the cities of Tyre and Carthage. ANSWER: Phoenicia [or Phoenicians] [10h] These people founded three cities on Rhodes, including Lindos, which made up half of their namesake Hexapolis. Most of these people, whom Thucydides calls the ancestors of the Syracusans, settled the Peloponnese. ANSWER: Dorians [or Doric; or Doris; or Dorieis; or Doriewes; accept Doric Greek or Dorismos] <Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~25160~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

6. Once completed, this city's REM light metro system will connect its eastern suburbs to its international airport in Dorval. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this city, whose metro connects Longueuil ("long-OY") with McGill University. This city is the most populous in Quebec. ANSWER: Montréal, Canada [10m] The Brutalist architecture in Montréal Metro stations partly inspired the architecture of this other city's Metro system. An infill station serving this city's Gallaudet ("gal-uh-DET") University opened in 2004. ANSWER: Washington, D.C. [or Washington, D.C.; accept the District of Columbia] [10h] Although the Montréal metro was the first to use rubber tires, the use of rubber tires in automated metros was pioneered in this city. This third-busiest port in Japan is the capital of Hyōgo Prefecture. ANSWER: Kobe [or Kobe City] <Cole Hartung, Geography - World> ~24629~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

7. Well into the 1960s, most public schools sang "God Save the Queen" rather than this song, whose lyric "in all thy sons command" was changed to "in all of us command." For 10 points each: [10e] Identify this national anthem that is typically sung in both English and French at sporting events. ANSWER: "O Canada" [or "Ô Canada"; prompt on the national anthem of Canada or Canadian national anthem] [10m] "God Save the King" was first sung to this monarch during a performance of The Alchemist. This Hanoverian commanded troops at the 1743 Battle of Dettingen in the War of the Austrian Succession. ANSWER: George II [prompt on George or George Augustus] [10h] Australia first replaced "God Save the Queen" during the government of this man, who was controversially dismissed by Governor-General John Kerr in 1975. ANSWER: Gough Whitlam ("goff WIT-lum") [or Edward Gough Whitlam] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25980~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

8. Larry E. Smith argued that English often operates as one of these languages. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these languages, one of which was created by L.L. Zamenhof. These languages, many of which develop as lingua francas, are mainly used as second languages. ANSWER: auxiliary languages [or international auxiliary language; accept IAL or auxlang; prompt on constructed languages; prompt on interlanguages] [10m] Creoles, which may be used as auxiliary languages, are exemplified by this language with a portmanteau name. The Malay-origin word "lah" is often used at the end of sentences in this language with substantial Hokkien influence. ANSWER: Singlish [accept Singapore English or Colloquial Singaporean English or Singapore Colloquial English] [10e] Singlish allows for the omission of this verb, also called the copula, from sentences. This English linking verb can translate to either "ser" or "estar" in Spanish. ANSWER: to be [accept conjugations like is] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Social Science - Linguistics> ~24754~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

9. Answer the following about the literary influence of Madame de Maintenon ("muh-DAHM duh MAN-tuh-non"), for 10 points each. [10e] She hosted one of these regular informal meetings of authors, thinkers and artists popular in Enlightenment France, whose name comes from a French word for a living room. ANSWER: salons [or intellectual salons] [10h] For a school she founded in Saint-Cyr ("san-seer"), Madame de Maintenon commissioned this author to write Esther and Athalie ("ah-tah-lee"), which include some of this author's noted alexandrines. ANSWER: Jean Racine ("zhon rah-SEEN") [or Jean-Baptiste Racine] [10m] Madame de Maintenon's upbringing on Martinique ("mar-tin-EEK") is referenced during her appearance in Twenty Years After, a sequel to this novel. A spy in this novel had a fleur-de-lis ("flur duh lee") branded onto her shoulder. ANSWER: The Three Musketeers [or Les Trois Mousquetaires] (The spy is Milady de Winter.) <Joseph Krol, Literature - European - Other> ~24819~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

10. A 2023 paper by Google Quantum AI gives a protocol for creating qubits by "braiding" non-Abelian instances of these particles, which arise as D3Vs in a grid of plaquettes. For 10 points each: [10h] Give these exotic particles, named for having statistics with properties of both fermions and bosons, that may be useful for quantum error correction. ANSWER: anyons ("EN-ee-ons") [accept non-Abelian anyons; reject "anions" ("AN-eye-ons")] (D3Vs are degree-three vertices.) [10e] Anyon braiding induces this shared property that is central to the utility of qubits. This property manifests as "spooky action at a distance" in which particles convey information about each other. ANSWER: quantum entanglement [accept word forms, like entangled; accept entangled states] [10m] Anyons arise in systems with this property. The prototypical system with this geometric property is graphene. ANSWER: two-dimensional [or 2D or two dimensions; prompt on flat or planar or monolayer or single-layered] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~26037~ <Editor: David Bass>

11. In this novel, a girl draws caricatures of people, while her friend Rick writes thought bubbles for them. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this novel in which the title "AF" uses P-E-G Nine to destroy a Cootings Machine while caring for the sick "lifted" girl Josie. ANSWER: Klara and the Sun [10m] The author of Klara and the Sun wrote this novel, in which Kathy, Tommy, and Ruth are raised at Hailsham. Madame collects the art of children intended to be organ donors in this novel. ANSWER: Never Let Me Go [10e] Klara and the Sun and Never Let Me Go are written by this British-Japanese author of The Remains of the Day. ANSWER: Kazuo Ishiguro [or Ishiguro Kazuo] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~25448~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: monsoon (Trenberth et al. 2000 is "The Global Monsoon as Seen through the Divergent Atmospheric Circulation.")
Text: 12. Trenberth et al. 2000 introduces a "global" framing of this phenomenon that occurs over six sectors, including "Australia–Asia." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this phenomenon whose low-pressure "trough" can be denoted with parallel red lines. In this phenomenon, seasonal reversals in the temperature gradient between regions of land and adjacent oceans drive large ranges of precipitation levels. ANSWER: monsoon [accept global monsoon] (Trenberth et al. 2000 is "The Global Monsoon as Seen through the Divergent Atmospheric Circulation.") [10m] The monsoon trough is part of this region in which trade winds converge. This "zone" appears as a band of clouds near the Equator. ANSWER: Intertropical Convergence Zone [or ITCZ ("itch") or ICZ or doldrums; prompt on calms or near-equatorial trough by asking "what is the more generally used name?"] [10e] Climate change-driven variability in the monsoon has disrupted India's production of this renewable energy source from dams. ANSWER: hydroelectric power [or hydropower or hydroelectricity] <David Bass, Science - Other Science> ~25774~ <Editor: David Bass>

13. During the reign of a holder of this position, the PFLO was put down in the final years of the Dhofar War. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this position held by Qaboos, who oversaw the abolition of slavery and the signing of his country's modern constitution during his 1970-2020 reign. ANSWER: Sultan of Oman [prompt on leader of Oman; prompt on leader or Sultan] [10e] The Dhofar War was partly sparked by the British withdrawal from Aden in this present-day neighboring country, which until 1990 was divided into North and South portions, the former governed from Sana'a. ANSWER: Yemen [or Republic of Yemen; or al-Yaman] [10m] As part of Oman's modernization efforts, Qaboos installed the rial as currency instead of this currency, used in a country whose leader at the time was targeted in Operation Blue Star. ANSWER: Indian rupee <Noah Sheidlower, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~25800~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

14. After this man arrogantly discounted Poseidon's help, Poseidon struck the rock he was clinging to with either his trident or a thunderbolt. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this man from Locris who was said to be the fastest runner among the Greeks at Troy after Achilles; he incurred divine wrath after he raped Cassandra in a temple. ANSWER: Ajax the Lesser [accept Little Ajax or Small Ajax; accept Oilean Ajax or Ajax Oilei; prompt on Locrian Ajax; reject "Ajax the Greater" or "Telamonian Ajax"] [10h] In that story, this deity convinced Zeus to send a storm after Ajax's ships. This deity caused Ajax to stumble during a footrace at Patroclus's funeral games. ANSWER: Athena [or Minerva] [10e] Ajax saved himself from being killed by his Greek allies by clinging to one of these objects sacred to Athena, a real example of which was the Athena Parthenos. ANSWER: statues [or monuments; or sculptures accept reasonable equivalents; prompt on artworks] <Abhinav Rachakonda, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~24619~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

15. This 3/4 movement opens with the eighth-note melody "C-flat, down to E-flat, D, up to C-flat, B-flat, down to D, long G-flat" played sempre vivo and fortissimo, then meno vivo and piano. For 10 points each: [10h] Vladmir Stasov claimed that what movement depicts a creature "clumsily running with crooked legs?" This E-flat minor movement follows its piece's first promenade. ANSWER: "Gnomus" [or "The Gnome"; prompt on, BUT DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL, descriptions like the first movement of Pictures at an Exhibition] [10e] Movements like "Gnomus" and "the Old Castle" depict Viktor Hartmann's artworks in this suite by Modest Mussorgsky. ANSWER: Pictures at an Exhibition [or Tableaux d'une Exposition; or Kartinki s vïstavski] [10m] Pictures at an Exhibition returns to an E-flat tonic for this last movement of the piece, which begins with a slow brass fanfare in Maurice Ravel's orchestration. ANSWER: "The Great Gate of Kyiv" [or "Bogatyrskiye vorota (V stolnom gorode vo Kiyeve)" or "The Bogatyr Gates (In the Capital in Kyiv)"; or "The Heroes' Gate at Kyiv"] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~24479~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

16. This was the first theory to classify transition metal complexes as "high-spin" or "low-spin." For 10 points each: [10h] Name this theory that models the breaking of orbital degeneracy in transition metals due to the static electric field of surrounding anions. ANSWER: crystal field theory [or CFT] (The other theory is ligand field theory.) [10e] Crystal field theory is most commonly applied to these orbitals, whose "z-squared" example is the only one without four lobes. Transition metals can store up to 10 electrons in these atomic orbitals. ANSWER: d orbitals [10m] Ligands higher on the spectrochemical series form lower-spin complexes; one of the highest ligands is this ion, equivalent to a nitrile group, that complexes with iron to form Prussian blue. ANSWER: cyanide [or CN-] <June Yin, Science - Chemistry> ~26052~ <Editor: June Yin>

17. This term originally referred to a fire safety device in theaters. For 10 points each: [10m] Give this term, whose first use in a political sense may have been in Vernon Lee’s 1915 book The Ballet of Nations. This term was popularized at a speech in Fulton, Missouri in 1946. ANSWER: iron curtain [10e] This politician gave the Iron Curtain speech at Fulton. This Prime Minister's other greatest hits include the "we shall fight on the beaches" speech during World War II. ANSWER: Winston Churchill [or Sir Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill] [10h] A sculptor from this family named Gabriela designed a monument of a literal Iron Curtain for Fertőrákos ("FEHR-tuh-rah-kohsh"), Hungary. A much earlier member of this family adopted the motto A.E.I.O.U. ANSWER: Habsburgs [or Hapsburgs] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~26020~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

18. In a story by this author, a wounded criminal is carried into town by his father, who asks him to listen for dogs barking. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this author of the story collection El llano en llamas who wrote a novel about Juan Preciado seeking his father, whose name contains the Spanish word for "wasteland." ANSWER: Juan Rulfo [or Juan Nepomuceno Carlos Pérez Rulfo Vizcaíno] [10e] Rulfo is an author from this country. Native author Octavio Paz wrote about this country in The Labyrinth of Solitude. ANSWER: Mexico [10h] The public-domain website Ciudad Seva that hosts many of Rulfo's stories is named for a fictional town in this region. An author born in this region wrote the cross-genre Spanglish novel Yo-Yo Boing. ANSWER: Puerto Rico [or PR; prompt on the United States or America or USA] <David Bass, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~25991~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

19. The Isaac Potts House is often named for providing this service to George Washington at Valley Forge. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this service that Nathanael Greene oversaw while leading a corps of its namesake "masters." Providing this service for soldiers during peacetime is banned by the Third Amendment. ANSWER: quartering soldiers [accept Washington's Headquarters; or Quartermaster Corps; prompt on housing soldiers or synonymous answers by asking "what is the historical term for this practice?"] [10m] The Second Quartering Act was part of this set of laws that Thomas Gage oversaw, which also included the Port Act. ANSWER: Intolerable Acts [or Coercive Acts] [10h] Continental soldiers scornfully coined the phrase "[this man's] quarter" after his dragoons massacred surrendering Americans at the Battle of Waxhaws. He commanded and sometimes names the British Legion. ANSWER: Banastre Tarleton [or Sir Banastre Tarleton, 1st Baronet] <Cooper Roh, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24701~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

20. Guido Reni's homoerotic painting of Saint Sebastian in this position partially inspired Oscar Wilde's pseudonym of Sebastian Melmoth. For 10 points each: [10m] Name this position of figures who stand with most of their weight on one foot. ANSWER: contrapposto [10e] This artist, who chased an apprentice and lover to Ferrara when the latter left his studio, placed David in an exaggerated contrapposto for a bronze sculpture in which he stands on the head of Goliath. ANSWER: Donatello [or Donato di Niccolò di Betto Bardi] [10h] Vasari wrote of how a painter from this city, who wrote many songs about his love of boys, acquired the nickname Il Sodoma. The Allegory of Good and Bad Government is a fresco series depicting this city's council. ANSWER: Siena <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~25253~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

21. Infinite descent involves contradicting this theorem by showing that a falsehood would have to apply to arbitrarily many smaller numbers. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this theorem that is often conflated with the less general statement that every nonempty subset of N contains a least element. ANSWER: well-ordering theorem [accept well-ordering principle] [10e] N denotes this set, which can be defined as either the set of non-negative integers or of positive integers. ANSWER: natural numbers [or whole numbers; prompt on counting numbers by asking “what is the more formal name?”] [10m] Work on the well-ordering theorem caused Ernst Zermelo to introduce this equivalent statement. This statement, which is the "C" in "ZFC," enables the creation of a set consisting of one element from each of infinitely many collections. ANSWER: axiom of choice [prompt on AC] <Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~25970~ <Editor: David Bass>

1. A painting by this artist inspired a 2022 Hugh Hayden sculpture that was included in a Met exhibition titled after this artist's "crosscurrents." A man prepares for a Junkanoo festival by donning a multicolored costume in this artist's Dressing for the Carnival. This artist's painting of four Confederate soldiers surrendering for Harper's Weekly was mimicked in A Visit from the Old Mistress. Several landscapes of rocky cliffs by this artist were created near his studio in (*) Prout's Neck, Maine. This artist's numerous trips to the Bahamas inspired a painting in which a group of sharks surrounds a stranded Black man. For 10 points, name this American artist whose seascapes include The Gulf Stream. ANSWER: Winslow Homer [accept Winslow Homer: Crosscurrents] <Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Painting - U.S. to 1945> ~30801~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

2. Ernst Cassirer cited a type of this concept as the "common opponent" of the Enlightenment. Catholicism and Pelagianism are on alternate sides of a debate in hamartiology ("ha-MAR-tee-ology") concerning whether Romans 5 supports the existence of a form of this concept. Jansenists claim free will cannot exist due to a condition named for this concept. This concept’s transmission via "concupiscence" as described in (*) Augustine’s Confessions inspired later thinkers like John Calvin to refer to a human inclination toward it. Scholars debate whether the fall of Adam and Eve imparted the "original" form of this concept on human nature. Pride is included among "seven deadly" examples of, for 10 points, what transgressions against God? ANSWER: sin [accept seven deadly sins; accept original sin; accept hereditary sin or ancestral sin; accept Adam and Eve's sin] <Sinecio Morales, RMP - Christian Practice> ~31260~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

3. A mother of 10 living in this city named Jean McConville disappeared in 1972. A convergence point in this city called Clonard ("CLAW-nard") was a frequent site of violence. In 1969, a child in this city was killed in Divis Flats by a stray bullet fired by the RUC. Short Strand is home to one of this city's many "peace walls." Nationalists who lived along this city's Falls Road were bitter rivals of those living on Shankill Road. A successor to the (*) Sunningdale Agreement named for this city was opposed by the Democratic Unionist Party at Stormont. Violence in this capital decreased following the signing of the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. For 10 points, name this capital city ravaged by The Troubles in Northern Ireland. ANSWER: Belfast <Michael Bentley, History - European - 1900+> ~31017~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

4. One of these enzymes called "terminal transferase," or "TdT," is central to the TUNEL assay. Some functionality of one of these enzymes is maintained in the cleaved "large" Klenow fragment. These enzymes produce concatemers in a repetitive "rolling circle" process. A homotrimer that serves as a processivity factor for one of these enzymes is the "sliding clamp" PCNA. These enzymes, whose activity follows strand invasion, catalyze (*) synthesis that occurs alongside the activity of both topoisomerases and helicases. Ligation is needed to combine the Okazaki fragments synthesized by the "delta" one of these enzymes on the lagging strand during replication. For 10 points, name these proteins that make new DNA. ANSWER: DNA polymerases [accept DNA Polymerase I or DNA Polymerase III or DNA Polymerase kappa or DNA Polymerase delta; prompt on polymerases; accept answers without "DNA" at the end; reject "RNA polymerases"] <David Bass, Science - Biology> ~31145~ <Editor: David Bass>

5. A professor of this language who is slowly going blind teaches it to a mute woman in a 2011 Han Kang novel that was translated into English in 2023. A book in this language is the only possession of László de Almásy that survives a plane crash in Michael Ondaatje's The English Patient. A city drinks its dead king's blood in the title "Communion Rite" of Wole Soyinka's adaptation of a play in this language. The blind man (*) Seven Seas represents an author who used this language in a poem that reimagines his characters as St. Lucian fishermen. A gay romance novel inspired by a work in this language was the debut novel of Madeline Miller. For 10 points, a work in what language inspired Margaret Atwood's Penelopiad? ANSWER: Ancient Greek [or Classical Greek; or Hellēnikḗ; accept Greek Lessons; reject "modern Greek"] <Forrest Weintraub, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~30226~ <Editor: Jim Fan>

6. The gagara boats used to cross this body of water were replaced by Idris Alooma, according to a history by ibn Furtu. The Duguwa dynasty established the city of Njimi near this body of water, which was governed by rulers called mais ("MY-ees"). Heinrich Barth publicized a history of a Kanuri-speaking empire based on this body of water, the Girgam. Usman dan Fodio's (*) Sokoto Caliphate conquered states near this body of water as part of his Fulani Jihad. The empires of Kanem and Bornu surrounded this body of water. Though a "mega" version of this body of water formed during the African Humid Period, climate change has reduced its surface area. For 10 points, name this lake that is the namesake of a Central African country. ANSWER: Lake Chad [or Buhayrat ta-Shad; accept Lake Mega-Chad] <Cole Hartung, History - World - African> ~31176~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

7. This property is implied by the absence of non-trivial points from the largest invariant set via LaSalle's invariance principle. A numerical analog of this property is difficult to achieve while solving stiff O·D·Es. This property's "i.s.L.," "asymptotic," and "exponential" forms are defined via a Lyapunov function. The [emphasize] absence of this property names a fluid phenomenon that is co-named for (*) Rayleigh and Taylor. Local energy minima house states with the "meta" form of this property. This property arises when the second derivative is positive at an equilibrium. This property is notably lacked by the inverted pendulum. For 10 points, name this property of systems that return to their resting states when perturbed. ANSWER: stability [or stable; accept asymptotic stability or exponential stability or stability in the sense of Lyapunov or stability i.s.L. or Lyapunov stability or numerical stability or metastability] <David Bass, Science - Physics> ~31167~ <Editor: David Bass>

8. Visitors who kill one of these animals at the Karni Mata Temple must provide a solid gold replacement. Working in Maryland, John B. Calhoun developed the concept of behavioral sinks while studying a colony of the Norway species of these animals. A nocturnal North American variety of these animals noted for their hopping abilities are the (*) "kangaroo" type. They're not human children, but as per the Brothers Grimm, these animals were led away from Hamelin by the Pied Piper. New Zealand's Breaksea Island was a pioneer in using Brodifacoum ("broh-DIF-uh-koom") to eradicate these animals. For 10 points, the New York subway system was home to a pizza-loving example of what rodents, whose fleas are commonly blamed for spreading the Black Death? ANSWER: rats [accept Norway rats or black rats or brown rats; prompt on rodents until read; reject "mice"] <Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~30581~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

9. The first of this novel's chapter epigraphs, which reads "put thousands together less bad, but the cage less gay," is wrongly attributed to Thomas Hobbes. In this novel, a man misses the forests of Vergy ("vair-ZHEE") while imprisoned after firing two shots in a church. A Voltaire-reading woman uses a marble tomb to hold a human head in this novel, which is subtitled (*) "Chronicle of the Nineteenth Century." After his affair is exposed by Valenod ("vah-luh-noh"), this novel's protagonist works at a seminary with Abbé Pirard ("ah-BAY pih-RAR"). At the end of this novel, Mathilde de la Mole ("mah-TEELD duh lah MOHL") and Madame de Rênal ("mah-DAHM duh reh-NAL") both fail to stop the execution of Julien Sorel ("zhoo-lee-ahn soh-REL"). For 10 points, the clergy and the army are represented by what Stendhal ("stond-ahl") novel's two title colors? ANSWER: The Red and the Black [or Red and Black or Scarlet and Black or Le Rouge et le Noir: Chronique du XIXe Siècle] <Kevin Wang, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~29757~ <Editor: Joseph Krol>

Answer: video games (The third line is Cuphead.)
Text: 10. A 2011 work in this medium by Pippin Barr recreates performance artist Marina Abramovic's The Artist is Present. Clouds scroll through one of the many modifications to works in this medium by Cory Arcangel. A work in this medium inspired by the Fleischer Brothers' cartoons depicts a character dressed like Cab Calloway in a purple suit. A 2007 work in this medium directed by Ken Levine responds to Ayn Rand with the character (*) Andrew Ryan. “Inside the Castle Walls” and “Great Fairy Fountain” are songs conducted for this medium by Koji Kondo. Directors in this medium include Hideo Kojima and Shigeru Miyamoto. For 10 points, a debate about the "art" of what medium includes works like BioShock and The Legend of Zelda? ANSWER: video games [accept computer games or Nintendo games or Flash games or NES games; prompt on games] (The third line is Cuphead.) <Jamie Burchett, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~30298~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

11. Art cannot function without this concept but can function without a market, according to a Lewis Hyde book featuring a section claiming it "Must Always Move." The relationship between this concept and domination is used to analyze its "Gender" in a book by Marilyn Strathern that builds on an earlier work's discussion of these things' "spirit" that creates a bond called hau among the Maori. A work titled for this concept describes it as (*) "total prestation" and argues that reciprocity is expected. That book by Marcel Mauss contrasts commodity exchange with the exchange of these things in systems like kula and potlatch. A namesake "economy" describes providing, for 10 points, what goods that lack an agreement for reward? ANSWER: gifts [accept gift exchange or gift economy; accept The Gift or Essay on the Gift; accept don or Essai sur le don; accept The Gender of the Gift; accept "The Gift Must Always Move"; prompt on exchange until read] <Sinecio Morales, Social Science - Anthropology> ~31161~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

12. In 1987, two earthquakes struck on the same day in this country's Coca Valley, now home to the sinkhole-plagued Coca Codo Sinclair Dam. The ancient Cañari city of Tumebamba in this modern-day country sat at the confluence of four rivers and is mostly buried under its city of Cuenca. This country's most populous city is on the west bank of the largest Pacific-discharging river in South America. Tourists can head to the Teleférico district in this country's capital to take a gondola up the (*) Pichincha Volcano. Another volcano in this country is home to the farthest point from the Earth's center and can be seen from Guayaquil. For 10 points, name this country home to Cotopaxi and Chimborazo, whose capital is Quito. ANSWER: Ecuador [or Republic of Ecuador] <Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~31055~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

13. One man in this play "sucks on a cigar all day because he can’t suck a teat," according to staging notes by Elia Kazan. This play’s author described pouring chocolate on a steak before writing this play in "The Catastrophe of Success." A woman in this play picks up a scarf, tells a man he looks like a prince from the Arabian Nights, and covers a light with a (*) paper lantern, after a "blue piano" plays. The Varsouviana polka in this play reminds a woman of her husband Allen Grey, who kills himself after a gay affair. A woman in this play says "I have always depended on the kindness of strangers" after she is raped by a man who yells "STELLA!", Stanley Kowalski. For 10 points, name this Tennessee Williams play about Blanche DuBois ("doo-BWAH"). ANSWER: A Streetcar Named Desire [prompt on The Poker Game by asking "what was its later title?"] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Drama> ~31325~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

Answer: bridges (Aeroelastic flutter caused the collapse of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge nicknamed “Galloping Gertie.”)
Text: 14. Simple examples of these structures can be incrementally launched. Joseph B. Strauss pioneered the “bascule” type of these structures and assisted in the construction of one of these non-vehicular structures that provides a textbook example of aero·elastic flutter. Scour holes are dug around these structures’ (*) abutments. Little falsework is used when building these structures with the cantilever method. In one type of these structures, fan-shaped "stays" distribute compression throughout the deck and girders. The distance between these structures' supporting piers is their span, which is maximized by their “suspension” type. For 10 points, name these structures used to drive across rivers. ANSWER: bridges [accept suspension bridges or bascule bridges; prompt on piers or abutments or arches or girders until they are respectively read by asking "what larger structures do they support?"] (Aeroelastic flutter caused the collapse of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge nicknamed “Galloping Gertie.”) <Sean Farrell, Science - Other Science> ~29672~ <Editor: David Bass>

15. This man outlined his views about the Doctrine of Accommodation in a text written to Grand Duchess Christina. A military device that this man first demonstrated alongside Paolo Sarpi was preceded by one by Hans Lipperhey and was key to his writing Sidereus nuncius. Views advocated for by Urban VIII are related by the character of Simplicio in a book by this man that led to a trial where he supposedly muttered, "And (*) yet it moves." This lecturer at the University of Padua had his Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems placed on the Index of Forbidden Books for its sympathetic treatment of Copernicus's heliocentric system. For 10 points, name this scientist who used a telescope to discover the moons of Jupiter. ANSWER: Galileo [or Galileo di Vincenzo Bonaiuti de' Galilei] <Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~31056~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

Answer: Gustav Mahler's Symphony no. 5 in C-sharp minor
Text: 16. This symphony's second movement begins "stormily" in A minor but climaxes with a D major brass chorale that reappears near the end of its rondo finale. This symphony's scherzo ("SKAIRT-so") opens with four horns playing "D - F-sharp - long low A," then running up to a high B as the obbligato horn enters. The fourth of this symphony's five movements is in F major and scored for strings and solo harp. A solo trumpet plays a (*) "short-short-short-long" rhythm on C-sharp to open this symphony's first movement Trauermarsch, or funeral march. This symphony's adagietto is often said to be a love song to its composer's wife Alma. For 10 points, the "Tragic" symphony was written after what symphony that began Gustav Mahler's middle period? ANSWER: Gustav Mahler's Symphony no. 5 in C-sharp minor [or Gustav Mahler's 5th Symphony; prompt on Symphony no. 5 until "Mahler" is read and accept after] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~31152~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

17. Gerry Danilatos pioneered an "environmental" form of this technique in which water vapor is admitted into the sample chamber. In this technique, capturing "backscatter" instead of "secondary" particles emphasizes differences in atomic number rather than surface topology. Prior to this technique, samples can be coated in palladium or carbon to avoid charging. Dubochet, Frank, and Henderson won a 2017 Nobel Prize for pioneering the use of (*) vitreous ice in the "cryogenic" form of this technique, which has partially supplanted X-ray crystallography for determining protein structure. For 10 points, name this technique with "scanning" and "transmission" types that images samples with negatively charged particles. ANSWER: electron microscopy [or EM or scanning electron microscopy or SEM or transmission electron microscopy or TEM or cryogenic electron microscopy or cryo-EM or environmental scanning electron microscopy or ESEM; prompt on microscopy] <David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~31258~ <Editor: June Yin>

18. In a story by this author, Laura torments her friend Amanda after being reincarnated as an otter. A boy created by this author decides that a Houdan hen is an Anabaptist, which he thinks is "dashing and not very respectable," and says another animal has "red thoughts and his teeth were white." A party decides to kill a cat who knows their secrets after it learns to talk in this author's story (*) "Tobermory." In a story by this man, Vera tells her family that Mr. Nuttel was hunted in the Ganges by a "pack of pariah dogs" to create "Romance at short notice." The sickly boy Conradin prays for a ferret to kill Mrs. de Ropp in a story by this author. For 10 points, name this author of "The Open Window" and "Sredni Vashtar." ANSWER: Saki [or Hector Hugh Munro] <Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~30527~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

19. A member of this group described having flaming paper dropped on her in a bathroom stall in the memoir Warriors Don't Cry. Will Counts took the "scream image" of a member of this group, Elizabeth Eckford. Virgil Blossom's "Blossom Plan" led to an event involving members of this group including Melba Beals and Ernest Green, whose consequences included the suit that led to Cooper v. Aaron six months later. (*) Paratroopers in the 101st Airborne Division were sent to protect this group by Dwight Eisenhower after Orval Faubus called in the National Guard, violating the ruling in Brown v. Board. For 10 points, what group of African-American students were initially blocked from entry to their Arkansas high school? ANSWER: Little Rock Nine [prompt on descriptions of the students who integrated Little Rock Central High School] <Rohan Kher, History - American - 1945+> ~30040~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

Answer: coffins (The Jan Assmann book is Death and Salvation in Ancient Egypt.)
Text: 20. Inscriptions on these objects are used to describe a concept "as Mystery" and "as Return" in a book partially titled for "salvation" by Jan Assmann. A collection of compositions named for these objects includes elaborate depictions of the Paths of Rostau and Field of Offerings in its Book of Two Ways. Spells protecting transmigration of the akh appear in those texts named for these objects. In Plutarch's retelling, one of these objects (*) secretly designed for Isis' husband is displayed at a banquet for the guests to try. Osiris floats along the Nile after Set tricks him into getting sealed inside one of these objects. For 10 points, name this general type of object Howard Carter found King Tut stored inside. ANSWER: coffins [accept sarcophagus or sarcophagi; accept Coffin Texts; prompt on less specific answers like boxes or containers] (The Jan Assmann book is Death and Salvation in Ancient Egypt.) <Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~30038~ <Editor: Sinecio Morales>

21. This concept is preferred to alternatives based on tenacity, a priori, and authority in C. S. Peirce's ("purse's") essay "The Fixation of Belief." This concept titles a 1975 book in which the slogan "anything goes" is used to advocate for "epistemological anarchism." Paul Feyerabend titled a book Against this concept, which was first developed in a book describing four fallacies called "idols" of locations like "the (*) marketplace" and "the cave." Verifiability is rejected as a standard for this process by Karl Popper, a proponent of falsifiability. An inductivist form of this process was formalized in the book Novum Organum by Francis Bacon. For 10 points, name this process of developing and experimentally testing hypotheses. ANSWER: scientific method [or method of science; accept scientific discovery; accept The Logic of Scientific Discovery; accept the Baconian method until "Bacon" is read; prompt on science; prompt on method; prompt on Against Method] <Aum Mundhe, RMP - Philosophy> ~29532~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe> NSC 2025 - Round 22 (Finals 1) - Bonuses

1. Ivan Illich argued that industrial society's over-reliance on people in this profession causes harm through the process of iatrogenesis. For 10 points each: [10e] Name this profession whose ethical standards are upheld through the Hippocratic oath. ANSWER: medical doctors [or physicians] [10h] Illich's views disagree with those of this sociologist, whose concept of the "sick role" includes an obligation to visit doctors. This sociologist developed the AGIL paradigm in his book The Structure of Social Action. ANSWER: Talcott Parsons [10m] According to Parsons, people in the "sick role" oxymoronically exhibit a "sanctioned" example of this type of behavior, which is categorized as the violation of social norms. ANSWER: deviance [accept word forms like deviant behavior; accept sanctioned deviance] <Aum Mundhe, Social Science - Sociology> ~26114~ <Editor: Joseph Chambers>

2. In this tone poem, second violins and violas lead a metric modulation to a section in 2/4 time depicting a farmer's wedding. For 10 points each: [10h] Name this tone poem that begins in 6/8 time with the second flute playing a fragment of an E minor scale. One of its themes is based on the 17th-century madrigal "La Mantovana." ANSWER: Die Moldau [or The Moldau; or Vltava] [10m] Die Moldau is part of this cycle of six tone poems by Bedřich Smetana depicting locations and events in modern-day Czechia. ANSWER: Má vlast [or My Fatherland or My Country or My Homeland] [10e] The first tone poem in Má vlast, Vyšehrad ("vee-SHEH-rahd"), begins with a duet in which one of these instruments plays block chords while another plays arpeggios. This instrument's 47 strings are plucked with both hands. ANSWER: harp [or pedal harp; or concert harp; or double-action harp] <Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~26038~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

3. These diagrams are used to minimize the number of logic gates on hardware systems. For 10 points each: [10h] Name these diagrams consisting of Gray-coded truth tables that are used for manual implementation of the Quine–McCluskey algorithm. Grouping cells of these diagrams into implicants assists with Boolean minimization. ANSWER: Karnaugh maps [accept K-maps or Karnaugh–Veitch maps; prompt on Marquand diagrams or Marquand–Veitch diagrams or Svoboda charts by asking "what is the more common name?"; prompt on KM] [10m] The number of terms in a minterm group of a Karnaugh map is one of these numbers. In binary, these numbers are represented with precisely one digit set to one. ANSWER: powers of two [accept two to the n] [10e] The Karnaugh map representing this function is a two-by-two grid with only one zero cell, since this Boolean function asserts true when one or both of its inputs are true.
